HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Real Change or Empty Promises?

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, June 18

 BODY:
As currency trading resumed this morning in Asia, the central question was simply: How much has changed?
Has Japan, in making pledges Wednesday on an economic program to strengthen its economy, really committed itself to far-reaching changes? Do its pledges mark a turning point that will lead to a firmer yen and to greater economic stability for Asia? 
 Or are they merely warmed-over promises from yesterday? If so, will the currency intervention by the United States and Japan be overwhelmed within a few days by market forces, leading to an ever-cheaper yen and to greater economic turmoil around the world?
For now there are more questions than answers, but there is evidence for both propositions.
While the United States emphasized that Japan had agreed to more specific actions, almost all the elements of the economic program are already longstanding elements of Japanese policy.
"Recognizing that restructuring and revitalization of the Japanese economy are urgently needed, we will make every effort to restore its banking system to health, to achieve domestic demand-led growth, and to open and deregulate its markets," Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said in a statement after his conversation with President Clinton.
But Mr. Hashimoto has said the same things many times before. Indeed, his latest comment was not nearly as strong as his assertion a couple of years ago that he would restructure Japan "or else burn up in flames trying."
Likewise, Mr. Hashimoto pledged this time to abandon the "convoy system," whereby financial institutions move in tandem and are hurriedly repaired or given new gas whenever they risk falling behind. Yet Japanese officials have been saying since last year that the convoy system has already ended.
Many analysts believe that Japan is likely to tinker with the system rather than rapidly introduce fundamental changes, as the markets would like.
"There's this Japanese view that if they just correct the financial misadjustments, they'll be O.K," said Ronald A. Morse, a professor of economics and business administration at Reitaku University near Tokyo. Professor Morse said he doubted that any major change was likely soon.
Yet even if Japan has not made any stunning new commitments that might convince the markets, there are some reasons why Wednesday's joint intervention may mark a turning point. Above all, there is timing.
On Wednesday night, Japan's Parliament passed a supplementary budget that amounted to the go-ahead for a stimulus package, worth roughly $119 billion, that is the centerpiece of plans to revive the economy.
Japanese officials have been saying for months that Americans should not be too impatient, that the parliamentary process will take time, but that once passed, the package will revive the economy.
The Government has already made all the preparations to spend the money, simply waiting for the measure's passage to push the button, and so the funds are now going to trickle through Japan's economic arteries almost immediately. There is some disagreement about exactly how to measure the stimulus package and how effective it will be, but almost everyone agrees that it is a major and credible effort.
Another element of timing is that Prime Minister Hashimoto has long been expected to introduce new economic measures -- presumably more far-reaching efforts at restructuring than anything announced so far -- after elections for the upper house of Parliament on July 12. So if Washington and Tokyo can prop up the yen with promises and the odd billion dollars worth of market intervention for just a few more weeks, then the combination of the stimulus package and the new measures announced by Japan after the election may in turn support the yen.
There are a number of precedents for political action creating turning points in the market. In 1985, the United States engineered the Plaza Accord to end the strong dollar and bolster the value of other currencies, and then by April 1995 the yen had soared so high that Japan organized what has been called a "reverse Plaza Accord" to weaken its currency.
It then took only a little less than 80 yen to buy a dollar, but Japan managed to turn the trend around and the yen steadily sank ever since -- reaching an eight-year low of about 146 yen to the dollar earlier this week. So now the Governments are apparently aiming for a "reverse-reverse-Plaza Accord" that would rely on jawboning, intervention and shrewd timing to send the yen permanently to higher levels.
Still, there are some fundamental reasons to be skeptical about whether the current coordinated effort can really change the market environment for the yen. The currency has been tumbling in part because Japanese capital has been fleeing abroad in search of higher interest rates, and that is unlikely to change.
Moreover, even some Japanese Government officials worry that restructuring the economy along market lines -- while advantageous for the long run -- may in the short term create more anxieties.
Mr. Hashimoto pledged, for example, to "expeditiously restructure the financial system." It is not clear what that means, but many analysts believe that Japan has too many banks and that some should be put out of the public's misery. Thus a serious restructuring might lead to more bankruptcies and bank failures, and it is not clear that in the short run such actions would do much for public sentiment or the strength of the yen.
Whatever the package does for the Japanese economy and the yen, it presumably will be helpful to Mr. Hashimoto and his ruling Liberal Democratic Party. Mr. Hashimoto has been criticized in Japan for not doing enough to revive the economy, and he can now argue that he is working in conjunction with President Clinton to tackle the problems.

HEADLINE: THE GOLF REPORT;
New Generation Has Nothing to Fear

BYLINE: By AL BARKOW 

 BODY:
In a rare candid moment some years after the fact, Ben Hogan recalled he had contributed to his own incredible playoff loss to Jack Fleck in the 1955 United States Open, at San Francisco's Olympic Club, where this year's Open begins today.
On the second hole, Hogan had reached the green in regulation, and was waiting there for Fleck while the obscure municipal course pro struggled after a poor tee shot, taking considerable time to play from deep rough and a bunker. When Fleck at last arrived on the green, he said to Hogan, "Sorry to keep you waiting." Hogan replied, "That's O.K., we've got nothing else to do today." And with that reply, Hogan reminisced, he gave up his edge, his intimidation factor. Fleck won, 69-72. 
 In Hogan's day, a champion player, by virtue of his record and his manner of being as well, could cow a less-accomplished opponent. Hogan, with his dour and silent mien, was an intimidator supreme. Jack Nicklaus was not quite as grim, but his self-absorption was palpable. Opponents felt he didn't know they even existed. He did know, though, his effect on them. Nicklaus once remarked that when in contention coming down the stretch he had at least a stroke up on the others by simply being Nicklaus.
That sort of thing doesn't prevail anymore, it appears. Today's leading young players -- Tiger Woods, Justin Leonard, Ernie Els, David Duval, Lee Westwood, et al., simply are not afraid of anything or anyone. They are not terrified by the significance of an event, or the presence and previous accomplishments of other players, especially the older, established ones.
"I've never felt afraid of anyone out here, in golf," said the 25-year-old Westwood, the current British hot shot.
Why not? What makes the new generation of golfers so intrepid? The former P.G.A. Championship winner Bob Tway is one of many who make the point that today's young professionals experience so much high-quality competition on high-quality courses as teen-agers and in college that coming to the pro circuit is merely an extension of their golf life. Many of the players have been playing one another for years. So if intimidation is at least partly the product of dealing with something new, what's to fear?
Also, a large percentage of today's professional golfers come from a middle-class background. Their parents could afford to provide them with professional instruction, perhaps membership in a country club, the opportunity to travel, a college education and the money to play the amateur golf circuit. Previous generations of pros, in most cases, rose from less-fortunate economic situations. Young players who come to big-time golf from more comfortable circumstances simply feel at home, even deserving. Many of their predecessors often got into golf as caddies, not a bad line of work for a young person but one decidedly on the servant side of the spectrum. Poor youngsters are more apt to be awed by the accouterments of well being, at least when first encountered.
Frank Nobilo, the New Zealander playing the American circuit, is among those who feel the money that can be made in pro golf now is a component of fearlessness. "You can make so much now, in only one tournament, that it's leveled the playing field," he said. "Because you don't have to cut corners, be overly careful as a player, you can take more chances." Nobilo also said that pros now "have all the equipment experts out here, swing gurus, psychologists, all there for us with the latest and best information, so we don't have to hang around the old pros, get their confidence, to get insights on the game and how to play it."
Howard Twitty believes today's clubs and balls have to no little degree taken the artistry out of playing the game. Hence, there is no call to watch the old-timers play cut shots and draws and knockdowns, and ask them how they do it. "Technology has made so much of the game so much easier," Twitty said. "What with how far the ball goes and how much less it curves in the air, and because of the perfect grasses we play from, we don't need those finesse shots anymore."
But maybe there is more to it than equipment technology and economics. Perhaps there is something in the popular culture that is putting no fear in the hearts of young athletes. Television, for example. Past sports heroes were, in a way, mythological figures, in part because they weren't actually seen that often. But with the coming of television, and its extensive, not to say small-screen-intimate coverage, children can see for themselves that major leaguers will bobble the easy grounder, strike out swinging at a bad pitch, miss two free throws in a row, drop a pass in the end zone, or watch in living color every excruciating moment as Greg Norman fritters away a huge lead in the final round of the Masters. Seeing the stars make mistakes has more impact than reading about it.
Take this a step further. On television, the normally stone-faced Nick Faldo breaks down in tears upon winning a British Open. Nothing wrong with grown men crying in emotional times, of course, even when winning. Quite human, in fact. Which is the point. It corroborates what Westwood had drilled into him by his school-teacher father: "Dad said everyone puts their pants on one leg at a time," Westwood said. "The best players just make fewer mistakes."
So what is there to be intimidated by?

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Deliberately or Not, Rubin Set Up a Fall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Last Thursday, Robert E. Rubin, the Secretary of the Treasury, made comments to Congress that currency traders took as a green light to sell billions more yen, driving the currency to nearly an eight-year low.
The academic but economically correct testimony was interpreted as a declaration that the United States would not intervene in the currency markets to support the weakening Japanese yen. 
 Yesterday, as the dust cleared from an initially successful surprise intervention to support the yen, traders and analysts were wondering whether they had been set up for a fall by their interpretation, even if it was wrong, of Mr. Rubin's sell signal. After all, he did make his reputation trading on Wall Street.
His comments, they said, helped get more and more investors out on a limb on their bet against the yen. That meant that they scrambled for safety -- and to cut their losses -- much faster when Mr. Rubin threatened to cut them off. And that panic selling is what helped push the yen up 5.2 percent in one day against the dollar.
Currency traders and analysts would not say that Mr. Rubin did this on purpose. But they did agree that his remarks propelled the sharp fall in the yen on Thursday and Monday and stretched investors, making the snap back yesterday even bigger.
"The effect of those remarks were to make the market more susceptible," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "Certainly there will be speculation by market participants that they had been set up."
Traders and analysts agreed that yesterday's intervention, the first to support the yen since 1992 and the first of any kind since August 1995, was effective for a day. But they expect the yen will resume its decline unless Japan makes some surprising policy changes. Even after yesterday's rebound, the yen is still down 17 percent against the dollar over the last year and 41 percent from its high in April 1995.
Jeremy P. Fand, senior foreign exchange strategist at BankBoston, said speculators were buying dollars yesterday, betting that the intervention would not support the yen for long.
Mr. Rubin agrees that intervention is not effective for long without changes in policies that in this case support the yen. His emphasis of that point last week led to the additional heavy selling of yen. New policies are necessary because only a change in Japan's economic outlook -- the economy is in a recession -- will make Japan and the yen attractive to investors again.
But taking convincing action immediately will be difficult because elections are set for July and the Japanese Government, which has announced a long series of disappointing programs to stimulate the economy, has little credibility in the foreign exchange market. New promises of action yesterday, such as dealing with the mountain of bad bank debt, were generally dismissed.
"I am a little worried," said Robert White, the treasurer of Standard Chartered Bank. "We have taken this step to intervene with Japanese promises and the Japanese have been known to break their promises."
Noting the lack of new actions by the Japanese and Mr. Rubin's own distrust of intervention without policy changes, Mr. Lipsky said the whole operation "leaves the impression of an emergency measure that would temporarily stave off significant market instability."
One of the first tests for the yen will come after the meeting this weekend in Tokyo between Japanese officials and Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, and William J. McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, through which yesterday's intervention was done. If there are no positive surprises, more intervention might be needed.
Traders also said that they thought the intervention by the Clinton Administration was motivated by the recent threats from China that a further decline in the yen would force the Chinese to devalue their currency, setting off another round of devaluations in Asia that would further destabilize the region economically.
In timing yesterday's buying of yen for dollars, it appeared that the Treasury and the Federal Reserve were able to take advantage of two tactics of intervention. First, whether intentionally or not, they let the dollar rally far and fast and left traders with the impression they would not get in the way.
Intervening in this circumstance, which has been called a bear trap, can catch traders off guard, a key to intervention success. Some traders said they had seen some speculating hedge funds piling on their yen selling last week, which meant some faced the sharp losses needed to force them to sell dollars and buy yen yesterday. But most hedge funds had been selling yen for some time, so they probably still have profits over all.
The second tactic is pushing a currency in the direction it is already going. The Government was able to do this because of the sudden rally of the yen on Tuesday, as traders wondered finally whether something was up after the Treasury indicated Mr. Summers would travel to Japan.
Nicholas Sargen, the global market strategist for J. P. Morgan's private clients, doubts that Mr. Rubin tried to set up the market. "He risks losing his own credibility doing that," Mr. Sargen said.
Instead, he said that Mr. Rubin's comments last week "snowballed on him" and accelerated the crisis. And yesterday's move was an effort to make clear "that there is not a green light to go out there and sell yen."
If that is the case, Mr. Rubin proved he learned something else from his Wall Street career: how to take advantage of mistakes.

HEADLINE: Legislature Presses Toward Ending Session in Albany

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 17

 BODY:
As one of the most sluggish legislative sessions in memory drew toward a close today, lawmakers remained deeply divided on a host of major issues, from changing parole rules to creating charter schools to expanding health care for poor children.
With the State Legislature pressing to complete its business by Thursday, Gov. George E. Pataki and the leaders of the Democratic-led Assembly and the Republican-controlled State Senate said they could not agree on the legislation to end parole for all violent offenders, one of the Governor's major election-year initiatives. 
 The prospects also looked dim for about a dozen other issues, including a bill to provide health care for poor children up to age 18 and a plan to create charter schools that are publicly financed but operate independently of local school boards.
The session-ending malaise comes two months after the Legislature broke with its tradition of having extraordinarily late budgets and passed a record $71.6 billion budget that included generous spending on schools and tax cuts.
But much of the last few weeks have been bogged down in election-year politics and the animosity between the Republican Governor and the Democratic Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver. The gridlock is such that Mr. Pataki had scheduled a trip to Buffalo today to sign copies of his recently released autobiography. But he decided to cancel the trip to be on hand in the State Capitol just in case there might be a breakthrough on any of the legislative fronts.
"We will continue to meet through the afternoon and into the evening until we close on some of the issues or recognize that we can't," Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, told reporters this morning after emerging from a meeting with Mr. Pataki and Mr. Silver. "So it's just a process of trying to finalize where we are. The one thing we agree on is that we will be closed by tomorrow night."
The Governor and the legislative leaders directed their staffs to work through the night to try to seal some deals.
Legislative leaders have managed to reach agreement in a few areas. The most significant is on a bill that would provide the largest increase ever in pension benefits for the more than 300,000 current and retired state employees. The legislation now goes to the Governor, who has said he would be open to a reasonable pension bill.
Under the legislation, retired employees would receive pension increases ranging from 1.44 percent to 10.30 percent based on when they retired. The larger increases would go to the people who have been retired the longest, because the value of their pensions has been eroded by inflation.
Current employees, upon retirement, would have their pensions set on a new formula that provides increases to account for current inflation rates.
The legislation did not establish a permanent system of cost-of-living increases, which the public employee unions had wanted. But union leaders said it helped fix a basic inequity in the pension system.
"We are pleased with this agreement," said Denyce Duncan Lacy, a spokeswoman for the New York State Public Employees Federation. "But we'll be back again next year lobbying for a permanent solution to the pension."
The Legislature also agreed on a bill that would extend for another two and a half years a landmark program that required the state to begin closing its expensive and outdated psychiatric hospitals and to use the savings to expand a wide range of community mental health programs. The program, which was set to expire in 10 months, was intended to revolutionize care for the mentally ill.
The legislation is expected to be passed by both houses on Thursday and to be sent to the Governor for approval. Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said the administration was unaware of the legislation, but would be open to considering it.
This evening, the leaders of the Assembly said they would pass legislation that begins the process of legalizing casino gambling in New York. But it was not clear if the Assembly proposal would be accepted by the Senate, where a similar measure was defeated. The legislation would allow casinos in the Niagara Falls-Buffalo area, in the Catskills and in Warren County in upstate New York.
Mr. Pataki and the legislative leaders remained far apart on other major issues, though their differences could be resolved in the flurry of legislative horse trading that has historically dominated the end of the session.
There were signs today that legislative leaders, particularly Mr. Silver, would be willing to compromise with the Governor on issues dear to the administration in return for his agreement to restore some of the $1.6 billion he cut from the budget that the Legislature sent to him in April.
One area for potential compromise is the Governor's proposal to create independently run charter schools that would be alternatives to public schools. Mr. Silver has blocked the proposal but has left open the possibility that he would support it if the Governor agreed to restore money for teacher salaries, school construction and repairs and other areas in the budget, people with knowledge of the negotiations said.
Another major piece of legislation still being negotiated involves ending discretionary parole for all violent felons. Mr. Pataki and his allies in the Senate have been pushing hard to have the bill enacted. But the Democrats in the Assembly have said that they will only agree to such a bill if it includes a provision allowing some low-level offenders to attend drug treatment programs instead of going to prison. So far, Republicans have rejected that provision.
Yet another issue being negotiated is whether to pass a hotly debated bill that deals with police arbitration in New York City.
The bill would move jurisdiction for labor disputes between the city and the police union from a city office to a state agency.
The state board that arbitrates police labor disputes for other cities and towns in the state has generally given more generous settlements to the unions than local governments had offered.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has opposed the legislation and he persuaded Mr. Pataki to veto a similar measure in 1995. But under pressure from the police union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the Legislature overrode the veto.
Mr. Giuliani successfully challenged the law in court, but legislative leaders introduced the new bill to address legal problems in the first legislation.

HEADLINE: Albright's Remarks on Iran: 'Khatami Deserves Respect'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's speech last night to the Asia Society in New York, as provided by the State Department:
Since taking office, President Khatami has responded to the demands of the Iranian people by emphasizing the importance of dialogue among nations and cultures, and by acknowledging the world's growing interdependence. He has said that "a society intending to reach development cannot succeed without understanding Western civilization." I would say, in response, that the same can be said with respect to Eastern civilization and Islamic civilization. 
 President Khatami has said that the American Government deserves respect because it is a reflection of the great American people. I would say that President Khatami deserves respect because he is the choice of the Iranian people. . . .
In past years, Iran's opposition to the Middle East peace process and to those willing to negotiate with Israel has been vitriolic and violent. The Islamic Republic still refuses to recognize Israel, and its leaders continue to denounce Israel in inflammatory and unacceptable terms.
But last December, Iranian officials welcomed Chairman Arafat to the Islamic summit in Teheran and said that, although they did not agree with the logic of the peace process, they would not seek to impose their views and would accept what the Palestinians could accept.
In January, President Khatami publicly denounced terrorism and condemned the killing of innocent Israelis. He argued that terrorism was not only against Islam but also counterproductive to Iran's purposes. Iran, after all, has also been a victim of terrorism.
If these views are translated into a rejection of terrorism as a tool of Iranian statecraft, it would do much to dispel the concerns of the international community from Germany to the Persian Gulf, and from Argentina to Algeria.
There are other signs of change, as well. For example, Iran's record in the war against drugs has greatly improved -- at least within its own borders -- and it has received high marks from the U.N. for its treatment of more than two million Iraqi and Afghan refugees. . . .
The United States opposes -- and will continue to oppose -- any country selling or transferring to Iran materials and technologies that could be used to develop long-range missiles or weapons of mass destruction. Similarly, we oppose Iranian efforts to sponsor terror. Accordingly, our economic policies, including with respect to the export pipelines for Caspian oil and gas, remain unchanged.
But let me be clear. These policies are not -- as some Iranians allege -- anti-Islamic. Islam is the fastest-growing religious faith in the United States. We respect deeply its moral teachings and its role as a source of inspiration and instruction for hundreds of millions of people around the world. . . .
We are ready to explore further ways to build mutual confidence and avoid misunderstandings. The Islamic Republic should consider parallel steps. If such a process can be initiated and sustained in a way that addresses the concerns of both sides, then we in the United States can see the prospect of a very different relationship. As the wall of mistrust comes down, we can develop with the Islamic Republic, when it is ready, a road map leading to normal relations.

HEADLINE: House Votes to Dump Tax Code by 2003

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
After years of rhetoric about the complexities and inequities in the tax code, the House took a dramatic though almost wholly symbolic step today toward doing something about it.
By 219 to 209, it voted to require that Congress come up with a new tax system by Independence Day 2002 and scrap the current code by the end of that year. 
The vote, largely along party lines, was a victory for Republicans who have spent years expressing and cultivating unhappiness with the tax laws and the Internal Revenue Service. It was sharply criticized by President Clinton and Democrats as an election-year ploy that risked throwing the nation into economic chaos while avoiding any hard choices about what a new tax system would look like.
Because the White House has threatened to veto the measure, it will almost certainly not become law even if it passes the Senate, where its prospects are unclear.
But the vote gave Republicans a boost in their efforts to build support for alternatives to the progressive income tax: a single-rate flat tax, perhaps, or a national sales tax. And Republicans are certain to try to use the vote to paint Democrats, during the Congressional election campaign this fall, as defenders of a 555-million-word set of laws and regulations that gives taxpayers a headache.
"What we have today is a monstrosity," said Speaker Newt Gingrich, who ticked off statistics about the burdens imposed on businesses and individuals by the current system, including $200 billion a year spent on accountant and lawyer fees and other costs of complying, 8 billion pages a year of forms filed and 5.4 billion hours of work on them.
"This bill is a very important step in the right direction," Mr. Gingrich said as he accepted from the National Federation of Independent Business, the small-business lobbying group, petitions that bore 750,000 signatures and called for an end to the current tax system.
Republicans are generally united in a belief that pushing to throw out the current code is both good policy and good politics, and at the heart of the bill passed today was the notion that setting a deadline was the best way to force action. The legislation calls for a national dialogue on creating a new, unspecified system that is "fairer, less complicated and less burdensome to working Americans." It was watered down somewhat from its original form, which did not provide for putting any new system in place before termination of the existing code and which called for the current system to be scrapped by the end of 2001 instead of 2002.
For all their general fervor against the current system, though, Republicans have been unable to agree among themselves on a specific replacement.
One camp, led by Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, and Steve Forbes, who made the issue the centerpiece of his 1996 Presidential run, favor a flat tax. They maintain that their approach, in addition to being simpler, would enable almost everyone to pay taxes at a lower rate, although at the cost of eliminating many popular tax breaks, in some cases including the mortgage interest deduction.
Another camp, which includes Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is leaning toward some kind of national sales or consumption tax, which would eliminate the income tax altogether.
Democrats say they support improving the tax system or considering a new approach. But they say it would be reckless to kill off the current code without having even begun a serious debate on the alternatives, much less having worked out the complexities of managing a transition from one system to another.
Without knowing what tax system would be in place several years down the road, they say, people would have difficulty planning for decisions like home purchases, companies would face uncertainty about investment decisions, and the entire economy could suffer.
"I don't think we will ever live to see a more irresponsible act," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, the Ways and Means Committee's ranking Democrat, who called the bill nothing more than a stunt for use against Democrats on the campaign trail.
"Let's pass a law to terminate cancer," Mr. Rangel said. "If you vote against it, you support cancer."
Before the vote today, Mr. Clinton, in remarks to reporters at the White House, said he favored simplifying the tax system and had not ruled out any alternatives. But he said passage of the House bill would be a bad mistake, increasing the risks to the economy at home and abroad.
"The last thing in the world we need to do right now," he said in allusion to the economic turmoil that has swept Asia, "is to send some signal of instability that we've decided to get rid of our whole tax code without knowing what to replace it with."

HEADLINE: A Universal Quest for Bargains;
Japanese Flock to Outlet Center in the Hudson Valley

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: CENTRAL VALLEY, N.Y.

 BODY:
Machiko Takenaka, 25, a self-described "office lady" from Tokyo, was on a whirlwind tour of New York City. The day before, she had seen "Cats." She was bound for a Mets game in the afternoon. But on this lovely spring morning, she had carved out time for that supreme Japanese-tourist pastime: shopping. Gucci, Max Mara and Anne Klein were just a few of the stores on her itinerary.
Rather than hit Madison Avenue, however, she had boarded a bus at the Port Authority terminal, rolling north through the reed-cloaked marshlands of New Jersey, past car dealerships and tanning salons and into the foothills of the Catskill Mountains. There, a kind of retail heaven awaited her, a seemingly incongruous crossroads where luxury and bargain shopping meet. 
 Many New Yorkers are unaware of Woodbury Common, a 220-store complex an hour north of New York City where designers like Versace, Christian Dior and Prada (masquerading under the name Space) have quietly opened discount outlet stores in recent years. But to the Japanese tourist, the outlet center -- a kind of prefabricated New England village plunked down in the middle of nowhere -- is hallowed ground, a must-do destination for even the most abbreviated trip to New York.
"It has become famous in Japan," said Ms. Takenaka in halting English, her shoulder supporting a Prada bag that held the $300 she had budgeted for the day's shopping spree.
The yen has fallen against the dollar to its lowest level in years, and the economic crisis in Asia has led to a modest decline in Japanese tourism. But because of regulatory controls and an unwieldy distribution system in Japan, most consumer goods in the United States are still far cheaper for the Japanese than those in their own country.
"The Japanese love to shop," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report, a company in Upper Montclair, N.J., that tracks national consumer spending patterns. "They're very label-conscious and they want bargains."
"So when they come here," he said, "they see the prices and say, 'Oh my God, this is one-half the price it is over there,' despite the fact that the yen has lost so much of its value. I think that Woodbury Common is exceedingly well positioned to take advantage of that."
Madison Avenue is certainly more convenient than Woodbury Common for foreign tourists in New York City. But not wanting to compete with themselves, high-end designers prefer to place outlet stores, which sell excess inventory from previous seasons, a good distance from their bread and butter: full-price, in-season merchandise. For the status-seeking, bargain-conscious consumer, the trip to Central Valley is a small sacrifice.
Six major Japanese tour operators include a trip to the outlet center, either as part of their standard package or as an option. One operator, Ano Hallo Tours in New York, reported that a trek to Woodbury Common was the most popular daytime activity for the 16,000 Japanese tourists the company brings to New York each year, beating visits to the Statue of Liberty and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
At first, Chelsea GCA Realty, the company that owns and operates Woodbury Common Premium Outlets, as it is officially called, along with 20 similar centers across the country, sat back and marveled at the trend. Lately, however, Chelsea, with headquarters in Roseland, N.J., has begun to court the Japanese shopper.
The company now holds workshops every few months for employees at the outlet center, providing tips on how best to serve Japanese customers. Salesclerks are told that it is wrong to approach the customer aggressively. They are encouraged to place change on a tray, following Japanese custom, rather than in the shopper's hand.
The outlet center opened in 1985, and by 1995 had become a Japanese tourist attraction, a phenomenon not limited to metropolitan New York. The realty company said its outlet centers in Cabazon, Calif., outside Palm Springs, and in Waipahu, Hawaii, also see throngs of Japanese shoppers.
(What the unwary shopper may not realize is that some of the stores at Woodbury Common also sell clothing lines that they have created only for the outlet store, clothes made of cheaper fabrics, for instance.)
Earlier this year, Chelsea GCA started to advertise in the half-dozen Japanese women's magazines that appeal to so-called office ladies: young women who are hired by Japanese companies to perform low-level clerical work and serve tea. Such women are not only savvy about the latest fashions but also have disposable income, because they tend to live rent-free with their parents until they marry.
Chelsea has also hired an employee fluent in Japanese to help staff the information booth at the outlet center. It distributes Japanese-language size-conversion charts, a list of stores that carry clothes in sizes 2 and 4, which many Japanese women wear, and maps to the complex.
Some designer labels are more popular than others among young Japanese women, and Gucci, the high-end Italian designer, seems to occupy the summit. Gucci officials say 60 percent of the outlet store's business comes from Japanese shoppers. "When they get off the bus, they run, literally run, to the Gucci building," said Michele Rothstein, Chelsea GCA's vice president for marketing, who visits the center frequently. "On certain days, you see them on line waiting to get in. They're dressed in black, head to toe."
Max Mara, an Italian designer, is another big draw. "I'd say 40 percent to 50 percent of our business is coming from the Japanese," said Rose Liss, the store manager.
An example of the kind of bargain available at the Max Mara outlet store, Ms. Liss said, is a suit from the spring 1997 line that originally sold in Manhattan for $900 but that can now be snapped up for a mere $500.
Tomoe Harano, a 23-year-old salesclerk in a Calvin Klein store in Tokyo, was spending part of her vacation in New York looking for just those sorts of bargains. It wasn't yet lunchtime, and already she had spent $1,000 on clothes and accessories. Draping her arms were shopping bags from Coach, Tahari, Kenneth Cole, Esprit and Max Mara. Next stop: Ralph Lauren.
She gave a thumbs up at the Max Mara cash register as her traveling companion, Haruna Aoki, 28, a pattern maker for Calvin Klein in Tokyo, translated with a broad smile: "Japan does not have a shopping center like this."
The manager of the Tahari outlet store said she once received a call from a woman who wanted directions to Woodbury Common from the airport. "She had a chauffeur, and they were coming straight here," the manager, Ro Joyce, recalled. "I mean, she wasn't even stopping at her hotel first."
In 1995, the most recent year for which statistics are available, Japanese visitors to New York City spent more per day, $279, than visitors of any other nationality, according to a Federal survey of airline passengers. But Brazilians actually spent more per visit, the survey found. That is because the average stay for a Brazilian tourist in the city lasts six days, compared with three days for the Japanese traveler.
Some economists say the willingness of Japanese tourists to spend hundreds of dollars in the United States points up the flaws in Japan's economic framework. Japan is notorious, they say, for regulations that force companies from various industries to use certain distributors and discourage cost-cutting measures that could result in savings for consumers.
"Japan has a massive problem with getting competition into the system," said Steven Clemons, executive vice president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a policy center in Washington that studies domestic and international industry and trade.
"The purchasing power of these ladies flying clear across the world to spend money an hour north of the city demonstrates that if the Japanese Government got more competition into its system it would see extraordinary economic growth," Mr. Clemons added. "It's a big message for the Japanese Government to deregulate."
The Japanese Government sees things differently. Akihiko Tamura, a representative of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry at the Japanese Embassy in Washington, said he was bothered by the amount of shopping done by Japanese tourists in the United States.
But he defended the regulatory system in Japan. "I believe it's wrong to argue that every regulation is evil," he said. "Regulations are based on a balance of interests, not only for the consumer but the producer as well. Each regulation very frequently has some public reason to exist, be it safety or health or welfare."
As the Japanese economy has worsened in recent years and the buying power of the yen has declined, there is evidence that Japanese tourists are becoming increasingly cost-conscious. When articles on Woodbury Common first started to appear in the Japanese press in the late 1980's, for instance, there was scant mention that the outlet center sold discounted goods.
"The articles would focus only on the brands and the selection and the beautiful Hudson River Valley," Ms. Rothstein said. "We were like, 'Wait a minute, this is great value,' and they were like, 'Well, yeah, but it's just a nice place to visit with a lot of great labels.' Now, the value component has shifted to a much more prominent place in the story."
At times there seems to be a frantic quality to the buying at Woodbury Common, an enthusiasm barely contained by a paper shopping bag. Some shoppers first stop off at the Samsonite Company Store in anticipation of the day's haul. Or they come in at the end, laden with shopping bags like ornaments on a tree.
"We see this every day there is a tourist bus," said Carolynn Morrissey, acting assistant manager of the Samsonite store. "They unload their bags into their new suitcases and we get stuck with the garbage."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Rally After Moves To Bolster Yen

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market staged a powerful rally yesterday after the United States and Japan bought yen to bolster the sagging currency, which has threatened to plunge Asia into a deeper economic crisis.
Worries that financial instability in Japan and Southeast Asia would result in a global slowdown this year that would cut even deeper into the already slumping profits of American companies had punished share prices in the United States for the last few weeks. 
 But investors stampeded back into the market yesterday after the United States Government and the Bank of Japan moved to bolster the value of the Japanese yen, partly in the hope of preventing a deeper economic and currency crisis in Japan and the rest of Asia.
After plunging Monday more than 207 points, or 2.3 percent, on fears of a widening crisis in Asia, enthusiastic buying sent the Dow Jones industrial average soaring 164.17 points, or 1.89 percent, yesterday to close at 8,829.46.
Scores of companies that had been battered recently by a huge wave of selloffs roared back to life in one of the heaviest trading days of the year with more than 744 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange. While a wide majority of stocks gained, technology and blue-chip issues led the recovery.
"The market had been going down because of Japan -- Japan was the new wrinkle in Southeast Asia," said Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "But now it looks like there's intervention and that Japan's going to deal with its problems, and that is a clear positive for the markets."
In fact, Wall Street's big rally sparked a comeback in Japan early today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 4.4 percent, or 647.11 points, to 15,362.49.
The Government's decision to buy Japanese yen with dollars, coupled with promises that Japanese officials would address the deepening banking crisis there, also helped lift the value of the Japanese currency, which had fallen close to an eight-year low on Monday at 146.15 yen to the dollar.
Yesterday, the value of the yen reached 136.37.
United States bond prices, however, plummeted after rising sharply in the last week on the prospect that Asia's economic slowdown would benefit bondholders by dragging down commodity prices and helping stave off inflationary pressure. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.73 yesterday from 5.65 on Tuesday.
For investors yesterday's events were not a clear indication that corporate profits, which are expected to be hurt in the coming year by a strong dollar and falling demand in Asia, were no longer in jeopardy.
"The Asia problem is clearly not going to go away easily," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "Investors would like to believe it's going to go away, but it's already clearly had an impact on earnings."
Indeed, in the last few weeks several large multinational companies have warned that the Asian economic crisis would depress earnings growth this year.
Although the United States economy continues to grow at a robust pace, with few signs of inflation, slowing profit growth in the first quarter of the year and worries that Asia's festering crisis would pinch profits even more led to a sharp selloff beginning in mid-April, after the Dow peaked at 9,211.84.
But yesterday, investors helped ignite the Dow, which soared as much as 230 points before a late wave of selling pushed the index lower. Meanwhile, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 19.52, or 1.79 percent, to 1,107.11, and the Nasdaq composite gained 1.33 percent, to 1,776.40.
Oil stocks gained after the price of oil soared on reports that the leaders of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would move to establish more oil production cuts. Tobacco stocks, which rose modestly, may rise higher today because the Senate voted to reject a tobacco bill aimed at curbing smoking.
To prolong the rally, analysts say that Japanese officials are going to have to do much more than commit to banking reform and stimulus packages. "This is potentially a watershed event for the financial crisis," said Jeffrey Applegate, the chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers. "However, the real economy in Japan is still going down. But what was crucial for the markets was to see a policy response. And that's what you're seeing now."
Mr. Wien of Morgan Stanley added that a big selloff might yet come later this year if things do not change, at home and in Asia. "This is a rally on the promise Japan will do something," he said. "So we'll have to see what Japan does, and then assess whether it's enough."

The pictures bring to light certain weak points against which new drugs and perhaps vaccines may be designed, but they also confirm in some researchers the view that the AIDS vaccine recently approved for testing is unlikely to work. Vendor Ban Is Lifted, But Panel Will Revisit It

But the panel also voted to reconsider the issue this summer, after more testimony, leaving many vendors believing that they had won a reprieve, not a victory. B1

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. JOINS JAPAN IN SURPRISE MOVE TO SHORE UP YEN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
The United States took global financial markets by surprise today, joining Japan in buying yen to stop the precipitous fall of the Japanese currency. President Clinton said he hoped the move would stem the worsening Asian economic crisis.
The two countries spent an estimated $4 billion worth of dollars in a coordinated purchase of yen in the foreign-exchange markets, pushing up the yen more than 5 percent within hours. Stock markets reacted exuberantly, and the Dow Jones industrial average surged 164.17 points, or nearly 2 percent, erasing most of its steep losses earlier in the week on apprehensions about Japan's weakness. Page D1. 
 Speaking briefly in the Rose Garden this morning, Mr. Clinton said he approved the rare action to sell dollars and buy yen after speaking by telephone with Japan's Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, near midnight on Tuesday. The President said Mr. Hashimoto committed to specific economic changes that go beyond Japan's past pledges.
But a list of actions released by the Japanese Finance Ministry hours later -- promising closings of weak banks and accelerated spending on public works projects -- appear to restate and go only modestly beyond Japan's past agreements. These pledged to deregulate the economy, clean up a banking system awash in $600 billion worth of bad debts, and change the tax system to stimulate an economy suffering its worst downturn in the postwar era.
"We've got a chance to turn that situation in Asia around before it gets any worse," Mr. Clinton said today. "America needs a strong, growing, stable economy in Asia."
The action was evidently motivated, as well, by public statements from China, where Mr. Clinton begins a nine-day visit next week, that it might be forced to devalue its own currency if the yen continued to fall.
At a White House meeting on Tuesday night, Mr. Clinton's top economic and security aides warned that a Chinese devaluation could touch off a far more fearsome phase of the Asian crisis, which began nearly a year ago with sharp devaluations of some Southeast Asian currencies.
Some members of his Cabinet remained skeptical that Prime Minister Hashimoto would deliver on the vague promises he made today. The decision to intervene was hotly debated inside the Treasury and the Federal Reserve.
Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin, who has said currency intervention does not necessarily work, had tentatively decided not to recommend any action on Tuesday evening, but changed his mind only an hour before making a final recommendation to the President.
Mr. Rubin was ultimately swayed to act because of last-minute Japanese offers for a few more specific commitments and indications that traders in the currency markets, who had battered the yen to a series of eight-year lows in recent selloffs, were beginning to buy yen again.
That was a turnaround that Mr. Rubin, a former investment banker and currency trader, believed he could exploit and accelerate.
But the essential motivation was a growing sense in Washington and Asian capitals that the continued fall of the yen could ricochet to markets around the world, further destabilizing Russia, China and Latin America -- and perhaps then even the United States. "The chances were remote," Mr. Rubin said today. But he added that if a major crisis were to develop, "the effects in our own nation could be great."
Currency traders said the intervention, conducted by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, appeared to be on the order of $1.5 billion to $2 billion of dollar sales for yen, with a simultaneous move of similar magnitude by the Bank of Japan, the central bank there.
That is far less than the $20 billion Japan spent in April, with little effect, to support its own currency.
But the psychological effect of the American action today -- and the suggestion that more is on the way -- was immediate, if perhaps temporary. The Japanese currency, which touched 146 to the dollar earlier this week, fell back to about 137, a 5.2 percent drop that returned it to the levels of a month ago. The Dow Jones average and other stock indexes increased. In Asian dealings early Thursday, the yen strengthened to 136 to the dollar, Japanese stocks rose 4.4 percent and Hong Kong shares soared a further 6.4 percent.
Yet, it was far from clear that the joint effort by the Federal Reserve and Japanese would offer more than a respite from what a senior Administration official called "a massive crisis of confidence among investors in Japan."
John Lipsky, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said, "The timing and the context suggest a finger in the dike" -- a view echoed by many traders, who doubted that the yen's bounce back could last in the absence of a major change of course by Japan.
Mr. Rubin had told Congress last week that currency interventions were of limited use unless investors are "convinced by the economic fundamentals." That means a series of unpopular steps to clean up the Japanese economy -- bank closings, corporate downsizing, big deficit spending -- that few Japanese politicians want to even discuss in public before an election for the upper house of Parliament in mid-July.
Mr. Rubin insisted at the White House briefing today that he was not backing away from the Clinton Administration's strong-dollar policy, arguing that it had "served our interests very well."
Currency traders appeared to take that at face value, though today's action suggested that the United States viewed the dollar's value as nearing its upper limits.
Hours after the currency intervention began, the Administration sent Mr. Rubin's deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, and William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, to Tokyo for consultations. Underscoring the sense that the Asian crisis was fast worsening, the Group of Seven industrial nations announced that they would hold a meeting of deputy finance ministers Saturday in Tokyo.
The politics of President Clinton's trip to China also weighed heavily on today's decision. Over the weekend, China accused the United States and Japan of worsening the Asia crisis by letting the yen fall, and in a series of messages to Treasury officials in the last few days, it began hinting that pressure was growing to devalue China's currency, the yuan.
American officials have long feared that such a move would set off devaluations around the world.
"What this proves is that the depths of the Asian crisis are much, much worse than anticipated," C. Fred Bergsten, president of the Institute for International Economics here, said today. "What spurred this is that many in Asia are talking about their version of our Great Depression." Officials of the World Bank have also begun to use the word "depression," and they said today they now expected the Asian economic crisis to last years.
Japan has added to the problems immeasurably. Its economy accounts for 70 percent of all economic activity in Asia. So its deep recession -- the economy shrank at an annual rate of 5.3 percent in the first quarter of this year -- has added to the region's pain in several ways.
Japan is not buying goods produced in Southeast Asia. The flight of investors from Japan, including many Japanese who are now free to put their money into other currencies because of liberalized financial rules, has intensified troubles -- sending the yen spiraling downward 15 percent in recent months. That makes Japanese goods less expensive in the United States and other countries -- pushing out goods produced by other Asians.
As the yen dropped day after day, investors began to flee the currencies of other countries. For example, the Indonesian rupiah, which many expected to recover after the resignation of President Suharto, has sunk to new lows -- 15,250 to the dollar. Before the Asian economic crisis, it took about 2,400 rupiah to buy a dollar. As a result, Indonesian banks and businesses that borrowed abroad -- often from Japanese banks -- have stopped repaying debts. That worsens the problems in Tokyo.
Mr. Rubin has been saying for weeks that Japan is the biggest threat to Asia's recovery. But he had resisted calls to intervene in the markets, declaring that "ultimately, currency markets follow fundamentals." In this case, the fundamentals meant a restructuring of a Japanese economy from top to bottom.
It is a risky bet. If the markets determine soon that the changes in Japan are not genuine, currency traders may soon renew their selloff of the yen. That will force Mr. Rubin to decide whether to throw more money into the pot, in hopes of instilling fear in traders that they might get caught with too many dollars and too few yen.

After watching the yen fall to its lowest level in eight years, the United States and Japan staged a dramatic intervention in foreign exchange markets yesterday, spending billions of dollars to buy yen and prop up its value. The decision came less than a week after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin left the impression that the United States would not intervene.

HEADLINE: Study Sees High Revenue in a Governors Island Casino

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
A new study commissioned by the Mayor's office to look at the future of Governors Island has concluded that high-class gambling casino would provide the most revenue of any development option being considered -- more than enough to meet the expense of preserving the historic northern part of the island.
The study by the consulting firm of Coopers & Lybrand showed that a casino could generate as much as $57.5 million a year in revenue to the city, more than three times as much money as the combination of a hotel and conference center with residential development. Other uses generated even less. 
 The island, which is in New York Harbor and is owned by the Federal Government, has a number of historic buildings and offers stunning views of lower Manhattan, but it has been largely deserted since the Coast Guard shut down its operations there almost a year ago. President Clinton offered to turn the site over to New York provided the city and state could come up with a redevelopment plan that would benefit the public.
Parks advocates, preservationists and some politicians have urged the city to come up with proposals, fearing that otherwise the Government might sell the island to the highest bidder. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has repeatedly said the city could not afford the cost of restoring and maintaining the historic buildings unless the development plan generated significant revenues.
The Mayor said the city's major concern was to avoid "hundreds of millions of dollars of liability" if it accepts the President's offer.
"The purpose of this is to put some reality into a dream that has been largely unreal," Mr. Giuliani said. "Preliminary to doing something useful with Governors Island is knowing how much it will cost. It will cost a huge amount of money."
Gambling could be the source of that money. A separate study also released yesterday by the investment firm of Bear Stearns & Company, which was conducted independent of the city's study, estimated that a casino on Governors Island would attract 5.7 million visitors a year and generate $340 million in revenues.
But several hurdles must be removed before anyone pulls a slot-machine lever there. Casino gambling is still illegal in New York State, and to change the law, two separate legislative sessions must pass an amendment to the State Constitution and voters in New York City must vote in a referendum. In Washington, city legislators worried that President Clinton or Congress might retract the offer to New York if casino gambling was in the island's future.
"There is a strong contingent in Congress that hates gambling," Representative Carolyn B. Maloney said.
Representative Jerrold B. Nadler said, "As long as the Mayor keeps talking casino, he's stopping the process."
Representatives Maloney and Nadler are sponsoring a bill to set up a special commission composed of Federal, state and city appointees to address the island's future.
Deputy Mayor Randy Levine said that the city is still interested in other options and will soon request ideas from housing and commercial developers, as well as casinos. He said that on Monday, a group from Tivoli Gardens, the Copenhagen amusement park, visited the island.
Mayor Giuliani said the city estimates the annual cost of maintaining the island at more than $40 million. In addition, he released a report on public works improvements prepared by the consulting firm of Frederic R. Harris Inc. for Turner Construction Company under a city contract. It showed that the cost of improvements to roads, utilities and piers, among other things, would range from $20.5 million to $45.3 million, depending on the option chosen.
This study concerned, as did the analysis of economic benefits, only the 25 southernmost acres on the island, which were built on landfill from the Lexington Avenue subway. Neither study included any acquisition costs, though Mr. Giuliani said he feared that a budget-conscious Republican Congress would never allow President Clinton's $1 offer to become law -- particularly when existing legislation mandates its sale for $500 million.
The gambling projection includes 100,000 square feet of gambling space; a 1,000-room hotel; 2,200 gambling positions, including 1,500 slot machines and 120 tables, and a luxury spa and health club. A 24-hour ferry service was assumed. In addition, the study suggested that other residential and commercial possibilities could coexist with the casino, adding to the economic benefit.
The Bear Stearns report seemed to suggest that the city's assumptions might be too modest for utmost profitability. It suggested that 3,500 positions would be needed to "offer sufficient critical mass to exploit peak gaming periods fully."
The investment firm also said that 15,750 patrons would have to be taken to the island each day. By contrast, Coopers & Lybrand estimates a daily average of 8,000 visitors, with 12,000 coming during the peak days of Friday and Saturday.
The Bear Stearns report went further and looked at the entire gambling market in the city, and estimated potential revenues of $2.63 billion annually if casino gambling were legal. That would make the city third in the gambling market, behind Atlantic City and Las Vegas.
But opposition to gambling remains strong in New York State, cutting across class, ideology and religion. Representative Nadler suggested some of the basis for the antigambling sentiment when he asked if the city considered noneconomic factors in its study. "Did they factor in the costs of additional child abandonment, divorces and bankruptcies?" he asked. "Those things always happen."
Others also faulted the city for not taking more factors into account. Peg Breen, president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy, which has urged more open dialogue about Governors Island, said the city's study raises more questions than it answers. "Will we even get gambling?" she asked. "How long is it going to take? What happens to the island in the interim?"
But the Mayor seemed persuaded on the economics of gambling for Governors Island, though he acknowledged that political difficulties remain. "There are probably are other attractions," he said. "The one that works on paper is gaming."

HEADLINE: Schools Don't Need Web

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Keep Internet Funding for Schools" (editorial, June 12): The 1996 Telecommunications Act was intended to address the widening economic gap between low-income and affluent communities. Access to computers in underserved schools gives disadvantaged students a step up and frees constrained budgets to identify educational necessities. 
 In a recent seven-year study we found that home computers and Internet access could turn around a significant number of underachieving inner-city students and encourage learning among their family members.
 
HELEN BIRENBAUM
New York, June 12, 1998
 
The writer is executive director of the Stanton-Heiskell Center, CUNY Graduate School.

HEADLINE: Street Vendors Win Reprieve From Giuliani

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
Sidewalk vendors, who had faced banishment from many of their most lucrative corners, won a reprieve yesterday when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took the rare step of backing off a major crusade in his quality-of-life campaign.
Giuliani administration officials, who dominate the city panel that determines where vending is allowed, voted to rescind the 144-block ban on vending that was to take effect next month and to reconsider it later this summer after seeking additional testimony. 
 In Manhattan's financial district, some customers toasted the decision with bottles of Snapple bought from their favorite vendors' carts. But few peddlers joined in the celebration, saying that they believed they had won just a temporary reprieve.
Indeed, Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington said the administration planned to pursue the regulation of vendors. He said the panel, the Street Vendor Review Panel, was re-examining its votes of May 20 on the advice of lawyers and in response to public outcry.
"We know that as soon as we close one block, we're off to court," Mr. Washington said. "It doesn't hurt anything to take a second, back up and take in more evidence. We'll have a more bulletproof case, and at the same time do the right thing that strikes the right balance."
Dr. Ester R. Fuchs, the director of the Barnard-Columbia Center for Urban Policy, and a persistent Giuliani critic, said that the Mayor would have risked permanent damage to his reputation if he had pursued plans to put strong limits on vending.
"His targets since the last election have been the disenfranchised, or people who have little political power," she said. "The piece of this puzzle which the Mayor forgot was that the patrons of the street vendors are generally working people who probably voted for Rudy Giuliani."
Two of the Mayor's top advisers, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Giuliani had no intention of abandoning his crackdown on vendors, since he still felt that street peddlers undermined civility by causing congestion and sanitation problems. But one adviser said the Mayor realized he had "articulated badly" his reasons for the crackdown. The other said the Mayor was concerned about being perceived as "governing by fiat."
At his daily news conference yesterday, Mr. Giuliani said that he and his panel were trying to "strike the right balance" between street vendors and restaurants, which lose money to the carts.
"What they wanted to do was to listen to more businesses and more vendors to make sure that the plan they put into effect is a sensitive one and a good one, and accomplishes the purpose of allowing people to remain in business, and doesn't have a deleterious effect on the businesses that presently exist," Mr. Giuliani said.
Mr. Giuliani said he had not yet decided what changes the review panel -- made up of three Giuliani appointees and one member named by the City Council -- should make.
Jeffrey J. Cicio, president of the largest trade group, the Big Apple Food Vendors Association, laughed when he was told about the panel's action. "This is a just a smoke screen," he said. "They got a lot of bad press, and they realized they made a mistake. It got a little too hot in the kitchen, so they shut off the burners. But this Mayor is not giving up."
Mr. Cicio said he was pinning his hopes on the City Council, which is considering at least three bills to disband the Street Vendor Review Panel and regulate the carts in other ways.
Officials of business improvement districts, which are financed by an assessment on commercial land in certain parts of the city, requested most of the proposed street closings. But BID officials said they have unfairly absorbed the brunt of bad publicity for the panel's decisions and had encouraged a City Council proposal that would limit vendors to one cart for each intersection instead of closing whole blocks.
Thomas Cusick, president of a major BID, the Fifth Avenue Association, said he supported the cooling-off period. He said many of his colleagues in the BID's would continue to work for a compromise.
The planned street closings, originally to go into effect in late July, were concentrated in midtown and lower Manhattan. Although the food vendors inspired the most visible public support, the rules would also have applied to street artists and sellers of books and general merchandise.
Yesterday's meeting of the Street Vendor Review Panel had been called to begin consideration of a second round of closings, based on scores of petitions from a wide range of institutions, including community boards and the Museum of Modern Art. But the meeting lasted less than three minutes, and new closings never came up.
The chairwoman, Deborah R. Weeks, proposed reconsidering the closings approved on May 20, and to accept written comments about them until July 1. The panel would meet after that, and any street closings would go into effect in September at the earliest.

HEADLINE: Holbrooke Chosen To Be U.N. Envoy, Senior Officials Say

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to name Richard C. Holbrooke as the American representative at the United Nations, replacing Bill Richardson, who will become Secretary of Energy, senior Administration officials said today.
Mr. Clinton will announce the appointments on Thursday at a White House ceremony, the officials said. 
 The appointment of Mr. Holbrooke, the architect of the Dayton accords that brought a fragile peace to Bosnia, is meant to provide new energy and experience to the United Nations post while allowing Mr. Richardson to have an important domestic platform.
A long-serving member of the House of Representatives from New Mexico before joining the Administration, Mr. Richardson is considered a possible running mate for Vice President Al Gore, should he win the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000.
Mr. Gore is known to have been a strong supporter of Mr. Holbrooke for the United Nations position, which carries Cabinet rank, while Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright had initially opposed it and the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, held his fire, seeing the appointment as inevitable, officials said.
Mr. Holbrooke, 57, has been in and out of Government since he joined the Foreign Service in 1962 and spent his first tour in Vietnam. He is best known for the Dayton accords, negotiated in his term as Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs.
He was also Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs from 1977 to 1981.
Ms. Albright helped block Mr. Holbrooke's appointment to the United Nations post at the start of Mr. Clinton's second term, but was unable to do so this time, officials said. Ms. Albright and Mr. Holbrooke were originally rivals to run the State Department, and when she was picked she was reported to have felt that Mr. Holbrooke would be too disruptive to a new team.
Officials close to Ms. Albright dispute that account and said she thought very highly of Mr. Holbrooke and supported his appointment.
"A lot of people can have their suppositions and reservations, but Secretary Albright supported and recommended Richard Holbrooke for this job on the basis of his activism and his experience," a close aide to Ms. Albright said. "She has made clear that she wants to have the strongest possible team at the State Department working on our foreign policy, as evidenced by her choosing Tom Pickering, Stu Eizenstat and Strobe Talbott. And Richard Holbrooke is a powerful addition to it."
Mr. Holbrooke speaks freely with reporters and sometimes tries to move policy in independent ways. He did that in the Balkans last month, when he secured an agreement from the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, to talk with ethnic Albanian leaders in Kosovo by suspending the start of sanctions that Ms. Albright had pressed European allies to approve.
That initiative is now widely regarded as a mistake, because Mr. Milosevic used the suspension to crack down in Kosovo.
One official, insisting on anonymity, described Mr. Holbrooke as "like a black hole attracting all the spotlight and so taking it away from others." He wondered whether Mr. Clinton's foreign policy team would be able to keep the image of that unity they had worked so hard to maintain in the second term.
In this term, Mr. Clinton has been more likely to heed Mr. Gore's advice on personnel. Mr. Gore and Mr. Holbrooke originally grew close in Mr. Gore's failed Presidential candidacy in 1988. But Mr. Clinton and Mr. Holbrooke are also said to have established a good relationship.
It was Ms. Albright, as United Nations representative in Mr. Clinton's first term, who insisted that the post carry Cabinet rank and that she participate as a full member of the senior foreign policy team in the so-called Principals' Committee. She used the position to build her reputation for plain-speaking and telegenic foreign-policy sound bites, helping her become Secretary of State.
In public they praise each other highly, and Mr. Holbrooke, in his recent book about his efforts to bring peace to the Balkans, "To End a War," hailed Ms. Albright for her strong views about the need to exercise force on behalf of diplomacy and moral values.
Mr. Berger had also opposed Mr. Holbrooke's appointment to the United Nations at the beginning of the second term, but did not raise serious objections this time, officials said. Mr. Berger, who is vital to managing the policy differences among important Cabinet members and maintaining outward unanimity, is said to regard the appointment "as a management exercise," one official commented.
But the official acknowledged that the Administration was facing numerous foreign policy challenges like nuclear proliferation and economic crises in Asia and Russia.
Mr. Holbrooke, who did not return telephone calls today, has told friends that he was stung by criticism that he is not a team player. He is expected to work hard at dispelling such concerns, officials said today, and they praised him for his diligence in the Bosnia shuttle diplomacy missions, for instance, at keeping the Administration informed.
Mr. Holbrooke left Washington in 1996 to move to New York -- where his wife, Kati Marton, a writer, lives -- and became a vice chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston.
Mr. Richardson will replace Federico F. Pena, one of Mr. Clinton's longest-serving Cabinet officers, who announced in April that he would step down. Mr. Pena, a former Transportation Secretary and Mayor of Denver, said this month that he wanted to return to private business but has not announced specific plans.
Mr. Richardson was first elected to the House in 1982, and was a roving diplomatic trouble-shooter for Mr. Clinton.
