HEADLINE: Albright, in Overture to Iran, Seeks a 'Road Map' to Amity

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright called on Iran yesterday to join the United States in drawing up "a road map leading to normal relations." She made the remark as part of the Clinton Administration's first comprehensive reply to cautious overtures from Iran's moderate President.
Nearly 20 years after the 1979 Iranian Revolution ruptured relations with Washington and installed a fundamentalist Islamic Government in Teheran, Ms. Albright said it was time to find ways to bridge the gap between the two nations and the civilizations they represent. 
 "Failure to do so would be irresponsible," she said, insisting that the United States had no quarrel with Islam.
Ms. Albright, who is regarded as one of the Administration's harshest critics of Iran, changed course last night in a speech in New York to the Asia Society, and focused on promising aspects of the new Iranian Government. In her remarks, she hailed President Mohammad Khatami, who took office last summer, as a man who "deserves respect because he is the choice of the Iranian people." Excerpts, page A16.
President Khatami was elected with the strong support of women and others who hope for a relaxation of Islamic rule, but conservatives want to reverse the trend. Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's supreme leader, is a conservative.
While praising Iran for taking several steps to redress longstanding conflicts, Ms. Albright also demanded progress on human rights, a turning aside from terrorism, and evidence that Iran was not trying to develop weapons of mass destruction. She offered no specific incentives or promises of additional American actions, but said the United States was "ready to explore further ways to build mutual confidence and avoid misunderstanding."
Ms. Albright noted that the United States had relaxed rules on travel to and from Iran and supported cultural and academic exchanges.
"The Islamic Republic should consider parallel steps," she said. "If such a process can be initiated and sustained in a way that addresses the concerns of both sides, then we in the United States can see a very different relationship. As the wall of mistrust comes down, we can develop with the Islamic republic, when it is ready, a road map leading to normal relations."
The Secretary of State listed steps Iran has taken in recent months that have been viewed favorably in Washington, including giving public support to Yasir Arafat -- and not more radical leaders or groups -- as the voice of Palestinians.
She noted that President Khatami had denounced terrorism and condemned the killing of civilians in Israel in January. She also mentioned the record of Iran in fighting drugs and its efforts to help bring peace to Afghanistan in talks that involve both American and Iranian officials. Administration officials also say that other channels of communication have been opened with Iran, but would not give details about what they were.
"We view these developments with interest, both with regard to the possibility of Iran assuming its rightful place in the world community, and the chance for better bilateral ties," Ms. Albright said in a speech that looked across the region from Iran to Indonesia.
But Ms. Albright said that progress where it existed "must be balanced against the reality" of serious obstacles in such areas as terrorism and Iran's attempts to acquire weapons of mass destruction, including chemical and nuclear arms. Without progress on such issues, economic sanctions will remain in place, as will American opposition to the development of Iranian oil and gas pipelines, American officials said.
Ms. Albright also lamented "inflammatory and unacceptable" Iranian denunciations of Israel, which Teheran does not recognize. And she asked for more progress in ending serious abuses of human rights. She did not cite the case of Salman Rushdie, the Indian-born British writer on whom the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini pronounced a death sentence for blasphemy in 1989 because of his novel "The Satanic Verses," in which Muslims found derogatory references to their faith and its founder. A senior official said last night that this issue has always been part of the Administration's human rights agenda on Iran, and it was not necessary to mention it on every occasion.
Ms. Albright spoke against a backdrop of deep and unsettling changes in Asia that Administration officials said played a part in her opening to Iran. Nuclear tests in India and Pakistan have abruptly changed the atmosphere across the region, provoking concerns that Iran as well as Iraq could renew hopes of developing nuclear arms. At the moment the United States has no leverage in Iran and is losing support for its policy of continued sanctions against Iraq.
Furthermore, the Asian economic crisis is beginning to have ripple effects around the world, adding to the problems India and Pakistan will face because of the loss of World Bank loans and other financial aid as a result of the nuclear tests.
The Asian economic crisis figured in Ms. Albright's speech. On the day that President Clinton stepped in to support the faltering Japanese currency, she told the Japanese that "more needs to be done" to contain the crisis.
On Indonesia, which she described as "a country of critical strategic importance" to the United States, Ms. Albright stopped short of endorsing President B. J. Habibie's proposals for the gradual establishment of a genuinely democratic electoral system.
But in a gesture of confidence, she announced that all American diplomats evacuated from the country in May during the unrest that led to the fall of President Suharto would now return and that the United States would step up aid in food and support for democratic organizations.
Although Ms. Albright also touched on Korea, India, Pakistan and China, reiterating Administration policies, the largest part of her address was devoted to Iran and the Administration's long-delayed response to overtures made to the United States by President Khatami in an interview with CNN in January. In that interview, Mr. Khatami, who was elected a year ago despite the opposition of the country's conservative religious leadership, spoke of his respect for the American Government because it reflected "the great American people."
Ms. Albright went out of her way in her speech to demonstrate that the United States was not "anti-Islamic" and that Americans would do well to learn to understand "Eastern civilization and Islamic civilization."
"Islam is the fastest-growing religious faith in the United States," she said. "We respect deeply its moral teachings and its role as a source of inspiration and instruction for hundreds of millions of people around the world."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. and Japan Buy Yen To Bolster Falling Currency
The United States and Japan bought yen to stop the precipitous fall of the Japanese currency.
The action, which took currency markets by surprise, marks the first time in six years that the United States has sold dollars and purchased yen. President Clinton said he approved the move after speaking by telephone with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan, who committed to specific economic reforms that go beyond earlier pledges. Page A1. 

As currency trading resumed in Asia, many wondered how committed Japan was to making far-reaching economic changes. But there are precedents for a turning point in the direction of the yen. News Analysis. D4.
 
How to jump-start Japan's long-sputtering economy is the main question now facing that country. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. D2.
 
AOL Plans to Remain Independent
After weeks of merger talks with AT&T, America Online said it planned to remain independent. Investors had speculated that the Internet access provider might be acquired and had pushed shares of America Online up. The negotiations also indicate that the new chairman of AT&T, C. Michael Armstrong, wants to bolster the telecommunications company's Internet access and growth prospects. D2.
 
Senate Jettisons Tobacco Bill
The Senate jettisoned broad tobacco legislation meant to discourage teen-agers from smoking. The bill, which had been debated for a month, was set aside when supporters could not get the 60 votes needed to clear two procedural hurdles. A1.
 
Economy Remains Strong, Fed Says
The nation's economy remains strong, with employment high and inflation low, despite scattered spillover from Asia's economic ills, the Federal Reserve said in its survey of regional economic conditions. D3.
 
It's Jobs at Issue in G.M. Strike
The strike at two General Motors' parts plants seems to be centering on the transfer of jobs overseas. Striking employees say they are walking the picket line to protect their jobs. But G.M. says it needs to reduce costs further, perhaps by hiring nonunion and overseas labor at lower-cost plants. News Analysis. A20.
 
No Unanimity in the Executive Suite
Chief executives and their top lieutenants hold widely divergent views on issues like succession and training for the top job, a survey by the Association of Executive Search Consultants shows. D4.
 
House Seeking a New Tax System
The House voted to require Congress to come up with a new tax system by Independence Day 2002. A32.
 
Greenspan and Rubin Differ on Bill
Chances of overhauling financial services legislation this year dimmed as the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin differed on structure and regulation at a Senate Banking Committee hearing. D3.
 
A.M.A. Backs Present Leadership
Delegates to the American Medical Association stayed with their current leadership, rejecting a presidential candidate who was critical of an aborted deal to allow Sunbeam to use the A.M.A.'s name on its products. A32.
 
30-Year Treasury Prices Decline
Treasury prices declined as the dollar plunged against the yen. The 30-year bond's yield rose to 5.73 percent, from 5.65 percent. D7.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
When Design Huffed And Puffed, Then Went Pop

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
"THE Inflatable Moment," on view at the Urban Center, celebrates a time when, if you didn't have an idea, you just didn't show up. You'd be too embarrassed. How different from today's climate of fear, when showing up with an idea could get you fired.
Inflatable architecture, the show's subject, was a terrible idea, as it happens. As Lloyd Kahn, the architecture editor, wrote in the Whole Earth Catalogue, "Inflatables are trippy, cheap, light, imaginative spaces, not architecture at all. They're terrible to work in. The blazing redundant surfaces disorient; one wallows in space. When the sun goes behind a cloud you cease cooking and immediately start freezing." 
 Yes, but so what? In those days, a terrible idea was better than no idea. At times, a bad idea was even better than a good idea. Architects at that moment were exploring the relationship between metaphor and material reality. There's nothing like a bad idea for showing up the difference between them.
Organized by Marc Dessauce, an architectural historian who lives in New York, this big, sloppy, high-spirited show is the Architectural League's tribute to 1968, the year the counterculture was officially born amid campus upheavals and street demonstrations. Along with anniversary tributes like this show and a weekend conference last month at the Columbia University Buell Center for the Study of American Architecture, young designers today are also offering a small reprise of the inflatable moment. Inflate, a British design group, has displayed its blow-up bowls and vases at downtown design stores. The dreadful 1967 Inflatable chair can be purchased from a Web site. Even Ikea plans to introduce an Air Line of inflatable footstools and sofas this October.
No doubt it's a perennial dream: to lose gravity, float away on a cloud, rise above the world and the weight of grown-up responsibilities. Nitrous oxide is the best way to inhabit that dream, though the dentist's drill one must put up with to experience such bliss can be very off-putting. And the impulse to float away only partly explains the radical work of the late 1960's.
In those years, society at large was exploring the meshing of metaphor and materiality. In Paris, real cars were torched, real trees cut down, real bodies carted off to the pokey. Garbage strewn around the student-occupied Odeon theater gave off a genuine stench. But as many who were students at the time recall, the May events served primarily a metaphoric value. The counterculture was a generalized protest against a diffuse idea of cultural authority. Since architecture is traditionally an art of the Establishment, it was not surprising that some of the counterculture's earliest rumblings emanated from within architecture schools.
The main part of the show focuses on the work of Utopie, a group of French artists and writers who banded together in 1967 and devoted much of their energy to designing inflatable structures and promoting them in publications. The group included the architects Jean Aubert, Jean-Paul Jungmann and Antoine Stinco and the writers Jean Baudrillard, Isabelle Auricoste and Hubert Tonka. And the heart of the show consists of their student work, including diploma projects for the Ecole des Beaux-Arts.
These presentation drawings depict a variety of pneumatic building types, including housing, theaters, museums and other public buildings. Some of these are air-supported structures in which a pressurized interior supports a thin membrane. In others, the enclosure is held aloft by air-filled structural ribs. Many of them are transportable, and thus in theory do not require ownership of land. Air, so they thought, was free.
Mr. Dessauce writes that for members of Utopie, the inflatable structure occupied a middle ground between conventional practice and dropping out. The appeal of inflatables was precisely that they were not architecture at all and therefore were untainted by establishment associations. Lacking weight, they also lacked gravitas. Like tents, they were events rather than buildings -- happenings, in the parlance of the time -- and thus made no claim on endurance, much less on the eternity to which architecture often aspires.
Utopie's work, while squishy, is not as formless as you might expect. Jean-Paul Jungmann's Dyodon pneumatic house, for example, recalls the Buck Rogers designs of the elderly Frank Lloyd Wright, like his unbuilt plan from the late 1950's for a convention center on Ellis Island. (Wright's one venture into inflatables, a windowless rubber igloo designed in 1957, is also included here.) Most of the projects, though not rigidly structured, are formally more complex than the geodesic domes of Buckminster Fuller.
Fuller, who would routinely ask architects, What does your building weigh?, was clearly the inspiration for Aubert's 1966 Traveling Theater project, a soft dome of green fabric interlaced with air-filled structural tubes. But the framework also has the character of Gothic ribs. In fact, several projects in the show evoke the fantastic Modernismo Gothicism of Gaudi, and would not look out of place in the context of present-day Barcelona, with its brilliant program of innovative public spaces.
LOOKING back at this material now, one thinks, why were these people so dissatisfied? After all, they were living in Paris! City of Light! A city where even student cafe food is heaven! What place in this world or the next could be more Utopian than the Rive Gauche?
But the Utopie group was living in a time as well as a place. As architecture students in the 60's, they were cruelly conscious of the collapse of the utopia that had preceded them -- the modern movement's dream of the rational, radiant city of towers in a park. Students in the 1960's were living in the modern movement's future time frame, but things within that frame had not turned out as planned. All that propaganda, all that earnestness, and what was there to show for it? The Tour Montparnasse, a big black shadow on the Paris skyline. If students in the 1960's displayed an unwillingness to grow up, who could blame them? Who wanted to grow up and become a modern architect? Who wanted to be delusional?
This lends considerable poignancy to the second part of the show, a historical overview in which it can be seen that Utopie's utopia fared even worse than the modern kind. Based on an exhibition organized by Utopie in March 1968 at the Museum of Modern Art in Paris, this show pulls together a hodgepodge of pneumatic delights, including Quasar Khanh's inflatable lamps and Andy Warhol's silver Mylar pillows. As a group, these projects have all the charm of a deflated weather balloon.
But the truth is, this stuff actually looked tatty even when new. Khanh's lamp had a crooked hang. The Blow chair by Scolari, De Pas, D'Urbino, Lomazzi squeaked when you sat on it, a sound as endearing as nails on a blackboard. The United States Pavilion at the 1970 Osaka World's Fair looked terrific for five minutes, before leakage problems caused the dome to sag. In fashion photographs and shop windows, blow-up furnishings looked cool. At home, they were last night's party favors.
Perhaps inflatable buildings were too much like architecture after all. By 1970, the Utopie group had disbanded. Before long, the inflatable moment was ripe for satire. In 1972, the Architectural League presented a project by Marc Balet, a young Prix de Rome winner, at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Visitors were invited to toss effervescent tablets into buckets of water and envision the bubbles as architectural configurations. A pair of bubbles might be a duplex. Rotated 90 degrees, it became a ranch house.
Mr. Balet later went on toward other forms of inflation, first as art director of Warhol's Interview magazine, then as director of the advertising agency Balet & Albert. But as this show clearly documents, media hype was an integral part of 1968, and perhaps the most enduring aspect of the counterculture as a whole. Or to put a kinder spin on it, work like Utopie's aimed more to influence consciousness than to rebuild the world.
In hindsight, it is clear that the conceptual groundwork for "the inflatable moment" had actually been laid by the modern movement. Marcel Breuer had predicted that "in the end, we will all sit on a resilient column of air."
Mies van der Rohe's esthetic "of almost nothing" emphasized void spaces over solid walls. Utopie's reliance on advanced technology extended Le Corbusier's concept of the house as a machine for living in. That reliance was the major reason for Utopie's breakup.
How could utopia be built on the patents of the military-industrial complex? Even assuming that land could be borrowed and air pumped in free, what idealistic architect wanted to stake a vision to the Joint Chiefs of Staff?
And now we have airbags. Also, those little pillows you can buy at the airport to tuck behind your lower back. The trick is to fill them only half way, just until they gain a puddly consistency. The best time I had in the last 10 years was spent floating on a Batman raft in the blue water off Capri. And what I think about all the time is shoving off from the shore, drifting down the river on something light and lazy, while trees pass overhead and all else waits.
 
"The Inflatable Moment" runs through Aug. 29 at the Urban Center of the Architectural League of New York, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street).

CORRECTION-DATE: July 13, 1998, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a picture caption on June 18 about "The Inflatable Moment," a show on inflatable architecture at the Urban Center of the Architectural League of New York, misidentified the building at the 1970 Osaka World's Fair with leak problems that caused its dome to sag. It was the Pepsi-Cola Pavilion, not the United States Pavilion.

His effervescent cities burst. (Illustrations by Marc Balet (above and far left); Jean-Paul Jungmann, 1967 (top right)(pg. F1); HIGH SPIRITS -- U.S. Pavilion at 1970 Osaka World's Fair, above, looked terrific for five minutes before leakage problems developed. SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 25; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2242 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 13.
 
Now Playing
 
"COUSIN BETTE," starring Jessica Lange, Elisabeth Shue and Bob Hoskins. Directed by Des McAnuff (R, 108 minutes). Balzac's great novel of 1840's Paris, like Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities," of which it is an obvious forerunner, is far too big and sprawling to be compressed into a film of average length. The gifted theater director Mr. McAnuff, making his feature-film debut, has staged the novel's greedy social climbing and revenge as a cartoonish "Masterpiece Theater" spoof in which an avaricious courtesan (Ms. Shue) and an ambitious young sculptor (Aden Young), who wreak sexual havoc, are charmless buffoons. Ms. Lange is grimly opaque as a vengeful, scheming cousin who manipulates these narcissists into destroying the aristocratic relatives who have humiliated her (Stephen Holden). 

 
"DEEP IMPACT," starring Robert Duvall, Tea Leoni, Elijah Wood, Vanessa Redgrave, Maximilian Schell and Morgan Freeman. Directed by Mimi Leder (PG-13, 120 minutes). Apparently there is no better aid to family therapy than a murderously large meteor hurtling toward Earth. So this is a more sensitive sci-fi disaster film than most, with lovers bonding and old wounds healing as the summer's first colossal cinematic catastrophe looms. This thriller is vigorously made, but it provides less grisly mayhem than might be expected. As the planet faces extinction, attention is paid to rescuing art, antiques, elephants and flamingos. Special-effects wizardry provides a suitably devastating tidal wave (Janet Maslin).
 
"FEAR AND LOATHING IN LAS VEGAS," starring Johnny Depp and Benicio Del Toro. Directed by Terry Gilliam (R, 120 minutes). Mr. Gilliam, the visually ingenious cinematic maestro behind "Brazil" and "12 Monkeys," has filmed Hunter S. Thompson's 1971 classic of gonzo journalism with an astonishing fidelity to the book's psychedelic phantasmagoria. But if this is as close to recreating the sensory world of an acid trip that a mainstream film has ever come, the movie packs the book's vignettes into an overstuffed hodgepodge. Where the book conveyed a spirit of open-ended adventure in which each new caper could be spun out into its own little movie, the film rarely gives the book's appallingly funny anecdotes room to breathe. Mr. Depp, who has been made partially bald for the role of Raoul Duke, turns in a clever performance. And Mr. Del Toro's portrayal of Raoul's gun-waving sidekick and "attorney," Dr. Gonzo, is a tour de force of unfettered goonishness (Holden).
 
"GODZILLA," starring Matthew Broderick and Hank Azaria. Directed by Roland Emmerich (PG-13, 139 minutes). The ads for "Godzilla" proclaim that "size does matter." But it turns out that bigger doesn't necessarily mean better. The animatronic lizard that rises from the ocean and stomps on a number of New York City landmarks has thundering metallic footsteps but still has the impact of a weightless cartoon monster. The movie doesn't get scary until halfway through, when the beast's eggs hatch (in what's left of Madison Square Garden) and an army of more lifelike baby Godzillas threatens to devour the search party. The storytelling and acting in this $120 million wad of gummed-up popcorn reaches new depths of crudeness and ineptitude for a so-called Event Movie (Holden).
 
"HIGH ART," starring Ally Sheedy and Radha Mitchell. Directed by Lisa Cholodenko (R, 96 minutes). Ms. Sheedy gives a fierce, tricky performance in the role of a once-celebrated photograher, spooked by fame, who long ago retreated from the art world to live a reclusive, druggy life among lesbian friends. This steamily intense story follows her spider-fly relationship with Ms. Mitchell's bright-eyed, ambitious ingenue, who works for a desperately stylish photography magazine. Ms. Cholodenko's seductive, powerfully atmospheric first feature explores their relationship with intelligence and avidity. But it sacrifices any hope of raw edges and real emotion to its own chic sensibility, which proves so studiously alluring that it overwhelms the story. Patricia Clarkson does a scene-stealing turn as Ms. Sheedy's lover, a glamorously decadent German actress who never got past the Fassbinder years (Maslin).
 
"HOPE FLOATS," starring Sandra Bullock, Harry Connick Jr. and Gena Rowlands. Directed by Forest Whitaker (PG-13, 112 minutes). This pajama-party women's picture starts out on a talk show and stays there, raising issues like divorce, single parenthood, mother-daughter relationships, caring for aging relatives and summoning the courage to date after trauma. But Ms. Bullock, who is actually seen cheerleading here, gives her best approximation of America's sweetheart since "While You Were Sleeping," and her winning performance helps make up for the film's cute streak and rosy, commercial glow. Ms. Rowlands does a feisty, down-to-earth turn as the star's Texas mama, even if the story gives her taxidermy for an offbeat hobby. As the post-divorce dreamboat, Mr. Connick is on the tepid side. "The Horse Whisperer" does this kind of serene, resuscitating romance much better (Maslin).
 
* "THE HORSE WHISPERER," starring Robert Redford, Kristin Scott Thomas and Scarlett Johansson. Directed by Robert Redford (PG-13, 164 minutes). There's a blunt soap opera of a movie inside Nicholas Evans's widely popular novel. But Mr. Redford, directing himself for the first time with intelligence and restraint, has found a visually eloquent way to turn it into something much more thoughtful and tranquil. Magnificently photographed by Robert Richardson, this film is a wide-screen love affair with the West, and a story more of peace and healing than of ardor. Though it's long and its resolution is a problem, this is an enveloping film that richly rewards the viewer's attention (Maslin).
 
* "THE LAND GIRLS," starring Catherine McCormack, Rachel Weisz, Anna Friel and Steven Mackintosh. Directed by David Leland (R, 112 minutes). A sentimental valentine to the Women's Land Army, the legion of young women dispatched across England during World War II to assume jobs vacated by fighting men, this film presses familiar nostalgic buttons but not so aggressively that it makes you feel queasy. Good girl Stella (Ms. McCormack); bad girl Prue (Ms. Friel), and nerdy academic Ag (Ms. Weisz), women from varying backgrounds, share cramped quarters on the same Dorset farm where they plow fields, milk cows and have their romantic turns with the owner's frisky son, Joe (Mr. Mackintosh). Rich with period detail and atmosphere, the movie leaves the inner lives of its characters largely unexplored to paint a heroic canvas of romantic turmoil and noble self-sacrifice (Holden).
 
* "THE LAST DAYS OF DISCO," starring Kate Beckinsale and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Whit Stillman (R, 112 minutes). Mr. Stillman's smart, fretful, patrician characters turn up midway between "Metropolitan" and "Barcelona" in a film that charmingly mixes post-college career worries with improbable discomania. A delightful cast engages in nonstop flirtation and hair-splitting debate, rendered with Mr. Stillman's usual acuity and humor. Ms. Beckinsale, an English actress with a flawless American accent here and diffidence that's just as perfect, holds court beguilingly at the center of a bright and amusing crowd. The ideal film for anyone willing to entertain the notion that the spread of environmentalism was sparked by the revival of "Bambi" during the disco generation's formative years (Maslin).
 
* "A PERFECT MURDER," starring Michael Douglas, Gwyneth Paltrow and Viggo Mortensen. Directed by Andrew Davis (R, 107 minutes). The characters may be cardboard-thin in this film, a skillfully plotted update of Frederick Knott's play (and Alfred Hitchcock's film) "Dial M for Murder," but the nasty cat-and-mouse games they play are icily amusing. Mr. Douglas, looking more than ever like a wattled, riled-up rooster, is Steven Taylor, a shady Wall Street bond trader in deep financial trouble who hires his rich wife's handsome lover (Mr. Mortensen), a con man posing as a painter, to murder her. It's not as easy as he hopes. Ms. Paltrow, looking chic and twinkly, is the wife, Emily, a translator at the United Nations, who has her own agenda. The story takes enough surprising twists to keep you engrossed, and the high-style ambiance (especially the Taylors' Fifth Avenue apartment) is mouthwatering (Holden).
 
"SIX DAYS, SEVEN NIGHTS," starring Anne Heche and Harrison Ford. Directed by Ivan Reitman (PG-13, 146 minutes). This escapist romance for the Treadmill Generation is a workout in its own right, putting its stars through the wringer (and into a "From Here to Eternity" surf clinch complete with hiking boots). The leads are attractive and funny, and the screenplay strives for a Tracy-Hepburn dynamic, but this truly strenuous love story is as long on tropical scenery as it is short on new ideas. Once the stars are marooned in splendid isolation, the film has to cook up pirates and a snake in Ms. Heche's shorts just to keep afloat. In supporting roles, David Schwimmer makes a drippy beau for Ms. Heche; Temuera Morrison deserves his own pirate picture, and the ex-grocery clerk Jacqueline Obrados torches up the film as if Salma Hayek were in town (Maslin).
 
* "THE SPANISH PRISONER," starring Campbell Scott, Rebecca Pidgeon, Ben Gazzara and Steve Martin. Written and directed by David Mamet (PG, 112 minutes). The most engaging of Mr. Mamet's cinematic puzzles begins with an X-ray at an airport security check. And the audience will wish it had a similar device for reading the characters' sneaky minds. No such luck: the mystery here, in a handsome and Hitchcockian film named for an elaborate con game, stays tricky to the very end. Mr. Scott plays the inventor of a lucrative, stealable scientific process, with Mr. Gazzara as the boss who's in no hurry to compensate him for it. In an ensemble cast working entirely on the calculating Mamet wavelength, Mr. Martin plays a rich, debonair mystery man who tells the inventor all about his pretty young sister. In her performance as a pert, unaccountably off-kilter secretary, Ms. Pidgeon perfectly embodies the film's sleight of hand (Maslin).
 
* "TITANIC," starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Kate Winslet and Gloria Stuart. Directed by James Cameron (PG-13, 197 minutes). For once, a much-touted event movie is exactly that: a glorious throwback to the days when epic storytelling really filled the screen. Despite the astonishing technological advances behind Mr. Cameron's great visual spectacle, gimmicks are never allowed to intrude on the film's central illusion, that the audience is drawn back into the Gilded Age and intimately involved in the fateful voyage. For all its painstaking historical detail, this "Titanic" proves anything but quaint, thanks to the phenomenal immediacy of its sights and the pure Hollywood hokum of its story. As two young lovers whose romance is skillfully interwoven with historical detail, Ms. Winslet and Mr. DiCaprio are a duo with serious chemistry. With his "Gone With the Wind"-caliber ambitions, Mr. Cameron dared to dream of the impossible and came up with the movie of the year (Maslin).
 
* "THE TRUMAN SHOW," starring Jim Carrey, Laura Linney and Ed Harris. Directed by Peter Weir and written by Andrew Niccol (PG, 104 minutes). The ultimate in high-concept ingenuity. Hosannas and cartwheels for this ingenious media-age fantasy are over the top, but by comparison with Hollywood's usual notion of summer movie fare, it's definitely a dazzler. Jim Carrey, refreshingly free of shtick, gives an instantly iconic performance as a guinea pig for an entertainment-happy nation, a man whose whole life is a fraud contrived by Mr. Harris's so-called "televisionary." Mr. Carrey's innate edge of volatility gives the material, from a screenplay of transfixing sci-fi intensity, its trace of danger. Ms. Linney, as the actress playing a wife whose bluff could be called at any moment, is the story's spookiest character as well as its perkiest. Mr. Weir unifies the story's many nuances with great finesse (Maslin)
 
Film Series
 
"COMDEN AND GREEN." He was an unemployed actor from the Bronx. She was a New York University theater major from Brooklyn. Their names were Adolph Green and Betty Comden, and their collaboration, which began six decades ago, led to films like "On the Town," "The Barkleys of Broadway" and "Auntie Mame." Now, as part of its yearlong "NYC 100" celebration, the Film Forum is presenting a two-week festival of musicals written by Comden and Green, along with some of their favorite films. Showings are on Mondays. This weekend brings a double feature of Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen's "Singin' in the Rain" (1952), with Donald O'Connor and Debbie Reynolds, and Vincente Minnelli's "Band Wagon" (1953), with Fred Astaire, Cyd Charisse, Nanette Fabray and Oscar Levant. The series continues through June 25 at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, in the South Village. Tickets: $8.50; $4.50 for the elderly on weekdays. Screening schedule and information: (212) 727-8110.

HEADLINE: Short Supplies Imperil The Year-End Closeout

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THE best time to buy a new car is August or September, right? Perhaps not this year: The end-of-the-model-year clearance may have already begun.
Sellers usually offer their best deals in late summer and early fall, as dealers try to clear their lots and showrooms to make room for the next year's models. This year, however, supplies are already low, thanks to a hearty economy, near-record vehicle sales, generous sales incentives and a spreading auto worker strike against the General Motors Corporation. With fewer cars to sell, manufacturers are likely to cut back on their inducements to buyers. 
 "The axiom that the best deals of the year are in the third quarter, at the end of the model year, could take a hiatus this year," George Pipas, a Ford Motor Company spokesman, said in a telephone interview.
United States vehicle sales reached 1.5 million cars and trucks in May, making it the strongest month since September 1986. The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate reached 16.3 million, the best level since October 1987, and the trend appears to be continuing this month.
James P. Holden, the Chrysler Corporation's executive vice president for sales and marketing, said Chrysler's sales have been strong this month. In May, Chrysler sold 250,000 cars and trucks, a one-month record.
The strong car and truck sales are set against the backdrop of a robust economy, and low interest rates have brought a wave of mortgage refinancings, putting more money in Americans' pockets. But vehicle manufacturers have also offered sweeteners, spending as much as $1,700 a vehicle on sales incentives like cash rebates, low-interest loans and discount coupons in May and June, up from about $1,100 a year earlier.
In April, after G.M.'s share of the United States vehicle market fell below 30 percent, the company sent previous customers certificates of $500 to $1,000 to use toward the purchase of 50 models, above and beyond other incentives. Ford and Chrysler matched G.M.'s program with their own loyalty incentives and agreed to accept G.M.'s certificates. G.M. has declined to take coupons from Ford and Chrysler.
The loyalty programs expire on July 2 and are unlikely to be continued in their current form. "My guess is they will expire and be replaced with something else that is not quite as expensive for the auto makers," said David Healy, the auto analyst for Burnham Securities in New York.
 The industry is now closely watching strike developments at G.M., the largest auto maker. Since workers at two Michigan parts factories walked out two weeks ago, 19 of G.M.'s 29 North American assembly plants have shut down, idling 80,000 workers. Analysts say that if the strike is not settled soon it is likely to last into mid-July, when a two-week plant shutdown was previously scheduled. The strike, along with healthy spring sales, have caused supplies of G.M.'s cars and trucks, especially the most popular models, to dwindle.
Inventories are particularly low of two all-new compact cars, the Pontiac Grand Am/Oldsmobile Alero, that were just introduced; of the Chevrolet Tahoe/GMC Yukon sport utilities, and of the Chevrolet Malibu sedan. If the strike continues, it could interfere with production of G.M.'s most important models: all-new, full-size Chevrolet and GMC pickups that replace the company's highly profitable, best-selling vehicles.
"The longer the strike lasts, the more dealers will find themselves short of popular models," Mr. Healy said. "G.M. will have nothing to sell, so it won't need incentives."
This is not to say that incentives will disappear. The intense competition of 1998 may well intensify in the 1999 model year, which begins in October. "I don't think the long-term landscape has changed that much, but the short-term landscape may well change," Mr. Pipas said.
As Mr. Holden put it: "Consumer incentives will continue, but the war is over."

SECTION: Section A; Page 29; Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Every Currency Crumbles

BYLINE: By James Grant; James Grant is the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.

 BODY:
Currencies, being made of paper, are highly flammable, and governments are forever trying to put out the fires. Thus a half decade before the bonfire of the baht, the rupiah and the yen, there was the conflagration of the markka, the lira and the pound. The dollar, today's global standard of value, was smoldering ominously as recently as 1992.
Monetary crises are almost as old as money. What is different today is the size of these episodes. It isn't every monetary era that features recurrent seismic shifts in the exchange values of so-called major currencies. On Wednesday morning, after coordinated American and Japanese intervention, the weakling yen became 5 percent less weak in a matter of hours. 
 People with even a little bit of money ought to be asking what it's made of. J. S. G. Boggs, an American artist, has made an important contribution to monetary theory with his lifelike paintings of dollar bills. So authentic do these works appear -- at least at first glance, before Mr. Boggs's own signature ornamentation becomes apparent -- that the Secret Service has investigated him for counterfeiting. "All money is art," Mr. Boggs has responded.
Currency management is a political art. The intrinsic value of a unit of currency is the cost of the paper and printing. The stated value of a unit of currency derives from the confidence of the holder in the promises of the issuing government.
It cannot undergird confidence that the monetary fires are becoming six- and seven-alarmers. Writing in 1993 about the crisis of the European Rate Mechanism (in which George Soros bested the Bank of England by correctly anticipating a devaluation of the pound), a central bankers' organization commented: "Despite its geographical confinement to Europe, it is probably no exaggeration to say that the period from late 1991 to early 1993 witnessed the most severe and widespread foreign exchange market crisis since the breakdown of the Bretton Woods System 20 years ago." But the European crisis has been handily eclipsed by the Asian one.
Monetary systems have broken down every generation or so for the past century. The true-blue international gold standard didn't survive World War I. Its successor, a half-strength gold standard, didn't survive the Great Depression. The Bretton Woods regime -- in which the dollar was convertible into gold and the other, lesser currencies were convertible into the dollar -- didn't survive the inflationary period of the late 1960's and early 1970's.
Today, the unnamed successor to Bretton Woods is showing its years. The present-day system is also dollar-based, but it differs from Bretton Woods in that the dollar is no longer anchored to anything. It is defined as 100 cents and only as 100 cents. Its value is derived not from a specified weight of gold, as it was up until Aug. 15, 1971, but from the confidence of the market.
For the moment, the market is highly confident. So is the world at large. In 1996, the Federal Reserve Board estimated that some 60 percent of all American currency in existence circulates overseas. The dollar has become the Coca-Cola of monetary brands.
However, as Madison Avenue knows as well as Wall Street, brand loyalties are fickle. In the early 1890's, the United States Treasury was obliged to seek a bailout from the Morgan bank. During the great inflation of the 1970's, Italian hotel clerks, offered payments in dollars, rolled their eyes. The yen, today reckoned dangerously weak at 140 or so to the dollar, was 360 as recently as 1971. The tendency of the purchasing power of every paper currency down through the ages is to regress. Is there any good reason that the dollar, universally esteemed today, should be different?
None. Certainly, the deterioration of the American balance-of-payments position doesn't bode well for the dollar's long-term exchange rate. Consuming more than it produces, the United States must finance the shortfall. And it is privileged to be able to pay its overseas bills with dollars, the currency that it alone can legally produce. Thailand would be a richer country today if the world would accept baht, and nothing but baht, in exchange for goods and services. It won't, of course. America and the dollar are uniquely blessed.
Or were. France and Germany have led the movement to create a pan-European currency, one that would compete with the dollar as both a store of value and a medium of exchange. The euro, as the new monetary brand is called, constitutes the first serious competitive threat to the dollar since the glory days of the pound sterling.
In a world without a fixed standard of value, a currency is strong or weak only in relation to other currencies. The dollar's "strength," therefore, is a mirror image of -- for example -- the yen's "weakness." It is not necessarily a reflection of the excellence of the American economy.
And no degree of excellence can forestall a new monetary crisis indefinitely. Some monetary systems are better than others, and some last longer than others, but each and every one comes a cropper. The bezant, the standard gold coin of the Byzantine empire, was minted for 800 years at the same weight and fineness. The gold may still be in existence (in fact -- no small recommendation for gold bullion -- it probably is), but the empire has fallen.
After the 1994 crisis involving the Mexican peso, the world's financial establishment vowed to stave off a recurrence. Even as the experts delivered their speeches, however, Asian banks were overlending and Asian businesses were overborrowing; the credit-cum-currency eruption followed in short order. Naturally, officials and editorialists are now calling for even better fire prevention systems.
But "stability," the goal so sought after, is ever unattainable. The history of currencies is unambiguous. The law is, Ashes to ashes and dust to dust.

LENGTH: 201 words

HEADLINE: Lucent Sues Cisco Over Use of Technology

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: MURRAY HILL, N.J., June 18

 BODY:
Lucent Technologies, the largest United States phone-equipment maker, sued Cisco Systems today, contending that it violated patents on technologies Cisco uses in several types of computer-networking equipment.
 Lucent is seeking unspecified damages against Cisco, the No. 1 maker of equipment to link computers to the Internet. In the suit, filed in Federal District Court in Delaware, Lucent also seeks an injunction to stop further use of the technology. 
 As sales to corporate customers slow, Cisco is trying to increase business with phone companies and Internet service providers, which have often bought Lucent equipment.
While much underlying technology used in networking equipment was patented by Bell Labs, Lucent's forerunner, Cisco "has done a lot of their own work" developing their products, said Maribel Lopez of Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
The suit contends that most of Cisco's major product lines, including its most profitable routers and switches, use patented Lucent technology. A Lucent spokesman, John Callaghan, said his company had tried for 18 months to negotiate a licensing agreement with Cisco.
Cisco said it was reviewing the details of the suit.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Rise; G.M. Strike Is a Factor

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Jobless claims jumped by 13,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, in part because workers were idled by the recent strike at the General Motors Corporation, the Government said today.
The number of people filing new claims for unemployment benefits in mid-June rose to 327,000, the Labor Department said, in a week in which more than 50,000 people were affected by strikes in the auto industry. 
 Though not all of them would have been eligible to file claims immediately, Cindy Ambler, a Labor Department spokeswoman, said some of the first-time claimants in the figures for last week included G.M. strike-related applications in New Jersey and Kansas.
In the previous week, Government figures showed 314,000 people filed first-time claims for unemployment insurance benefits.
The rise brought the weekly average rate of new claims over the last four weeks -- a more accurate measurement -- to 322,000, up from 318,750 in the prior four-week period.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Retreats by 16.45 As Asia Optimism Shrinks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks retreated slightly yesterday from Wednesday's powerful rally, as optimism over a possible turnaround in Asia waned.
Stocks surged on Wednesday after the United States spent an estimated $4 billion worth of dollars to support the yen and Japan pledged to clean up a banking system that has $600 billion worth of bad debts. And stocks were sharply higher in many Asian markets again yesterday: the Nikkei index of 225 leading Japanese issues closed up 646.16 points, or 4.39 percent, and Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index closed up 511.62 points, or 6.39 percent. 
 But the global rally faded in Europe, where most markets recorded modest declines. Many investors are skeptical that Japan will take the necessary steps to shore up its troubled banking system.
"From what I can see, it's going to take a while longer" for Japan to turn its economy around, said Mark Seferovich, a money manager for Waddell & Reed Financial Inc., which manages $23 billion.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 207.01 points on Monday and surged 164.17 points points on Wednesday, was much steadier yesterday, falling 16.45 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,813.01.
Other indexes were lower. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 0.74, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 1,106.37. The Nasdaq composite index fell 3.70, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,772.70. Today, the market faces a so-called triple witching, the expiration of options on common stocks and stock indexes, and futures on stock indexes. The expiration often creates volatile markets as investors buy and sell shares to offset the options positions.
I.B.M. led the Dow's decline yesterday, falling 2 3/16 , to 108 13/16 . Japan accounted for 13 percent of the company's revenue in the first quarter, while the rest of Asia accounted for 5 percent of revenue, said Laura Conigliaro, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company.
"We have grown increasingly concerned about the worsening situation in Asia and the weakened yen," Ms. Conigliaro told clients in a report.
Philip Morris, one of the 30 Dow industrials, rose 1 1/8, to 39 9/16 , after the Senate on Wednesday rejected a tobacco bill that would have raised Federal cigarette taxes more than fourfold in less than five years. The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation gained 3/4, to 25 1/16 .
Drug stocks kept the S.& P, 500 from falling as much as other indexes as investors sought companies that will report steady earnings regardless of Asia's economic slowdown. Pfizer Inc. rose 2 1/8, to 114 3/8; Merck & Company gained 1 1/8, to 128 7/8; Abbott Laboratories rose 15/16 , to 40 7/8, and Schering-Plough Corporation rose 1 5/8, to 92 1/4.

HEADLINE: Texas Instruments to Eliminate 3,500 Jobs

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 18

 BODY:
The cutbacks coursing through the chip industry reached Texas Instruments Inc. today as the company announced plans to eliminate 3,500 jobs, or 8 percent of its work force. The company cited both the recent sale of several divisions and a weak, glutted market for chips, especially in Asia.
The cut follows word in April that National Semiconductor was chopping 1,400 jobs and Intel, 3,000 jobs, and word in June that Motorola was eliminating 15,000 jobs. 
 To further protect itself, Texas Instruments reached an agreement today to sell its computer memory chip business to Micron Technology Inc. for about $641 million in stock plus $190 million in debt. The deal, which was expected, will make Micron Technology the world's largest maker of memory chips, with about 18 percent of the market, several percentage points more than Samsung.
Though Texas Instruments is probably selling its memory chip operations at a loss, analysts pointed instead to the avoidance of continuing losses in that division. "Do I think it's positive for T.I.?" said John M. Geraghty of Credit Suisse First Boston. "Absolutely." In having to cut its staff, he added, Texas Instruments is no different from other chip makers. "All this capacity comes on stream and works very well," he said. "All of a sudden everyone turns around and says, 'Oops.' "
The chip companies are facing a global oversupply and falling prices for their products, aggravated by Asia's economic turmoil.
"We have said the worldwide semiconductor market would grow 5 percent or less this year," William A. Aylesworth, chief financial officer at Texas Instruments, said in an interview. "We would certainly emphasize the 'or less' today, especially with the weakness of the yen and other currencies and very depressed semiconductor prices."
Of the 3,500 jobs to be cut, about 2,500 will be in the United States, including 600 from the closing of a memory chip plant near the company's base in Dallas. The cutback will save the company about $270 million a year before taxes, but incentives and other costs will roughly equal the savings over the first year. The company anticipates some layoffs, with the number depending on how many workers depart voluntarily.
Having already sold off military electronics and laptop computer divisions, Texas Instruments will remain a maker of specialized chips, primarily those called digital signal processors, which are used in cellular phones, computer networking equipment, cars and computer components such as modems and hard drives. Though demand for these chips is growing rapidly, Mr. Aylesworth said that computer makers already had excessive inventories of components such as hard drives.
Micron Technology plans to capitalize on its position as the memory chip industry's low-cost producer. To make the necessary investments, especially in the purchased operations, Micron Technology won an agreement to borrow $750 million from Texas Instruments.
Texas Instruments in turn becomes Micron Technology's largest shareholder, with about 12 percent of the company. Texas Instruments will hold more than 16 percent if it exercises its right to convert most of its loan into more shares.
Micron Technology also reported today a third-quarter loss that was bigger than expected. The company, which is based in Boise, Idaho, posted a loss of $106.1 million, compared with earnings of $96.8 million in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: More Welfare Recipients Going to Work, Study Finds

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Millions of people have left the welfare rolls since Congress overhauled the Federal program two years ago, but what happened to them has been a puzzle for policy makers. Now, the most comprehensive study of the new system says more and more are going to work.
The General Accounting Office, a nonpartisan arm of Congress, said today that there had been sharp increases in the proportion of welfare recipients being placed in jobs. 
 The findings address one of the biggest questions about social welfare policy in the United States. Officials have expressed many opinions but until now have had only sketchy information about what happened to the people leaving welfare.
Since shortly after President Clinton took office, the number of people on welfare has fallen 37 percent, to 8.9 million in March 1998 from 14.1 million in January 1993. The number has dropped 27 percent since August 1996, when Mr. Clinton signed a bill ending the Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children.
The accounting office examined the experiences of seven states chosen to be representative of the nation as a whole. In five of the states, it found "significant increases" in the proportion of welfare recipients who obtained jobs.
"California, Louisiana and Maryland more than doubled their job placement rates from 1995 to 1997, and Oregon and Wisconsin increased their rates by more than 70 percent," the report said.
Texas had a slight decline in the proportion of welfare recipients who found jobs. Data from Connecticut, while not exactly comparable, showed a substantial increase in the number of families leaving welfare because of increased earnings.
The General Accounting Office reported that 17 percent of Maryland's welfare recipients were placed in jobs in 1997, up from 4 percent in 1995. In Louisiana, the proportion rose to 17 percent, from 6 percent, while in California it rose to 19 percent from 9 percent.
Many more people, beyond those who found employment, were required to participate in "work activities" that prepare them for jobs, the report said.
Representative Sander M. Levin of Michigan, the ranking Democrat on the House subcommittee responsible for welfare legislation, reacted to the report with cautious optimism. "So far, so good," Mr. Levin said, "but there's much left to be done."
In 1995 and 1996, opponents of the welfare bill predicted that states would try to outdo one another in cutting welfare benefits and adopting punitive measures to keep poor people away. In an interview today, Mr. Levin said, "We have not seen a race to the bottom."
But Mr. Levin said the progress of the last two years would be jeopardized if House Republicans cut spending on programs for poor people, as required under the budget blueprint approved by the House on June 5.
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., the Florida Republican who is chairman of the subcommittee, welcomed the report as evidence that "welfare reform is working."
Authors of the report were quick to point out that some important questions remained unanswered. The report does not show the effects of the 1996 law on the well-being of children. It does not measure the extent of hunger or homelessness among people removed from the welfare rolls. Nor does it show what will happen if the economy, now booming, turns sour.
The accounting office said people who left welfare in the last few years were "the most readily employable," while those remaining may have more difficulty getting jobs because they have fewer skills, less education or more serious medical problems.
In its report, the accounting office also made these points:
*Forty-two states have liberalized their rules on earned income so that welfare recipients can keep more of their cash assistance payments after they begin working. Nearly all states have increased their limits on the value of automobiles and other assets that people can own while receiving public assistance.
*The proportion of welfare recipients who are told to pursue education and job training has declined in the last three years. Instead, people are routinely told as soon as they apply for welfare to get jobs.
*Nineteen states have adopted stricter time limits on welfare than the five-year limit set by the 1996 Federal law. But most of these states make exceptions in some cases.
For example, welfare recipients in Connecticut may obtain a six-month extension of the state's 21-month time limit if they "have made a good-faith effort to comply with work requirements, but have been unable to find employment," the report said.
In Connecticut, the General Accounting Office found that 2,667 families had reached the 21-month time limit by December 1997. In this group, 1,666 families lost welfare benefits, but 1,001 families, representing more than one-third of the total, got extensions allowing them to continue receiving cash assistance.

HEADLINE: IRAQ IS SMUGGLING OIL TO THE TURKS UNDER GAZE OF U.S.

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Iraq is smuggling large volumes of oil into Turkey in violation of United Nations sanctions, United States and Turkish Government officials say.
The officials say the Clinton Administration has chosen to look the other way, aware that the smuggling benefits Turkey, a crucial ally in the American policy toward Iraq, and Kurds who deny the Iraqi Government of President Saddam Hussein control over northern Iraq. 
 Still, the region is replete with double-dealing and surprising alliances, and Administration officials acknowledge that the Kurdish leader benefiting from the smuggling betrayed the United States less than two years ago.
Thousands of trucks transport millions of tons of oil, diesel fuel and other refined products to Turkey annually, openly traversing roads that United States and allied warplanes fly over in northern Iraq, officials acknowledge.
The smuggling is enriching President Hussein's Government and family, these officials say, at a time when the Iraqi leader is chafing under the United Nations' restrictions on official oil exports, which have been in place since the Persian Gulf war eight years ago.
Until the United Nations determines that the Government has eliminated programs to develop weapons of mass destruction, it has prohibited Iraq from exporting oil except through a limited program to raise money for humanitarian relief.
But the Clinton Administration has decided not to try to stop the smuggling even though the United States is trying to hold together a coalition in support of economic sanctions against Iraq.
The smuggling has been going on for some years, and Clinton Administration officials say they have privately complained to the Government in Turkey, where the smuggled oil now makes up a big part of the fuel sold in the retail market. Officials say the Administration has never moved to curb the traffic, choosing instead to appease the Turks and the Kurdish faction that controls northern Iraq and the border crossing where the oil is smuggled.
"The tendency has been to turn a blind eye because the Turks are benefiting from it at a time when the Turks are complaining anyway about sanctions on Iraq," one Administration official said. The smuggling is creating jobs and helping the economy of southern Turkey, which has been badly hurt by the trade sanctions. "While Saddam is making money on it, the Turks and Kurds are too," the official said.
American officials add that other important nations involved in enforcing the United Nations sanctions against Iraq have also quietly decided to ignore the smuggling.
"I think the international community has decided not to object, not just us," one official said.
The smuggling dates back to 1992 and the aftermath of the gulf war, according to Clinton Administration officials. They emphasize that when the traffic began, the Bush Administration was in office and it too ignored the Turkish smuggling.
"I think this Administration inherited a decision from the Bush Administration not to object," one official said.
But the smuggling has clearly gone from being a minor loophole in the embargo against Iraqi oil into a much more significant source of income for Mr. Hussein and a well-entrenched outlet for the Iraqis. With no American or allied effort to impede the traffic, 50,000 to 60,000 barrels of Iraqi oil and fuel products a day are now being smuggled along the Turkish route, Clinton Administration officials estimate. Iraq smuggles a roughly equal amount of oil by sea, to Iran, Dubai and other spots. Together, the two routes account for up to 10 percent of Iraq's export capacity, American officials estimate.
United States warships, as part of a multinational force, have been trying for several years to curb sea-borne smuggling, stopping some barges and other vessels in international waters in the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said. Earlier this year, Iran briefly curbed the Iraqi oil smuggling along its waterways, but United States officials say the smuggling through the gulf route is now surging once again.
Kurdish leaders, Turkish trucking interests -- and undoubtedly Turkish Government officials along the border -- skim off money from the Turkish operation, American officials say. By contrast, they believe Mr. Hussein takes a much larger share of the spoils from the gulf smuggling.
Administration officials say Turkey has suffered so severely as a result of the sanctions on Iraq, with a loss of trade on its border, that the United States has decided to allow it to benefit from Iraqi oil smuggling. In addition, Administration officials say, the smuggling benefits the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Masoud Barzani, which taxes the oil as it passes through its territory.
"Turkey has paid a severe price for enforcing the sanctions against Iraq, and this offered a way for Turkey to get some recompense," an Administration official said.
"This helps the economy of southern Turkey and it helps Barzani," the official added. "It makes a small income for the Government of Iraq. It does not substantially increase the economy of Iraq in comparison to the prewar income it generated from oil exports."
Yet Kurdish leaders from the rival Patriotic Union of Kurdistan complain that the Clinton Administration's decision to allow Mr. Barzani to benefit from the smuggling is enriching a Kurdish leader who betrayed the United States less than two years ago.
Mr. Barzani, who was formerly on the payroll of the Central Intelligence Agency, double-crossed the C.I.A. by inviting the Iraqi Army into his territory in August 1996, crushing a United States covert program that was based on Kurdish support, according to United States intelligence officials.
Mr. Barzani's actions led to the scattering of thousands of Kurds and other dissidents who had supported the American effort to undermine support for President Hussein. About 6,500 Kurds were eventually given refuge in the United States after Mr. Barzani's betrayal.
American intelligence officials say they believe Mr. Barzani was enmeshed in Iraqi oil smuggling even when he was on the C.I.A. payroll involved in the covert program.
Now, rival Kurdish leaders say that the smuggling business is earning him millions of dollars while putting him directly into business with Uday Hussein, President Hussein's son. The rival Kurds say that at least part of the Barzani group'srevenues go to kickbacks to Uday. Independent oil experts agree that Uday Hussein appears to be in overall charge of smuggling operations.
But Clinton Administration officials say they do not believe that Mr. Barzani's involvement with the Hussein family has put him completely into its camp. Mr. Barzani's Kurdish group remains an independent force, they say, and continues to help deny Mr. Hussein control over northern Iraq. 'This has been going on for a long time, and it hasn't yet thrown him in with Saddam," one official said.
Over the last three or four years, Turkish and Kurdish officials say, the trade has grown so large that sometimes hundreds of trucks loaded with Iraqi oil have rumbled north each day. Hundreds of Turkish truckers have welded external fuel storage tanks onto their nonfuel trucks in order to cash in on the lucrative business.
The smuggled oil is primarily funneled across the Turkish border at the Khabour Bridge near the southeastern Turkish town of Silopi, according to American, Turkish and Kurdish officials.
One energy expert in the Turkish Government who spoke on the condition of anonymity estimated that Iraqi smuggling now accounts for about 25 percent of the Turkish fuel market, making it a significant concern to international oil companies trying to compete in Turkey.
Turkish Government officials, meanwhile, have been discussing ways to control the smuggling, in conjunction with their efforts to deregulate the country's fuel markets, Turkish officials said.
Officially, the United Nations prohibits all Iraqi oil exports except those that generate money for humanitarian aid in Iraq as well as for victims of the gulf war. In May, Secretary General Kofi Annan approved Iraq's plan for distributing food and medicine bought under this program, paving the way for Iraq to increase the amount of oil that it could export under the plan from $2 billion to $5.2 billion over the next six months.
All other Iraqi oil exports are officially banned, but in addition to the smuggling to Turkey and through the Persian Gulf, Iraq ships about 100,000 barrels of oil a day to Jordan. Jordan is almost completely dependent on Iraqi oil, and the shipments there have been informally accepted by the United Nations, American officials say.

GRAPHIC: Map of the Turkish-Iraqi border showing the route of oil smuggling: Iraqi oil smuggled into Turkey crosses the border near Silopi. (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: WORLD CUP '98;
15,000 World Cup Tickets Reported Stolen

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 18

 BODY:
An American tour company said today that 15,000 World Cup tickets were stolen from its Paris office this morning, the latest twist in the uproar over the sale of tickets for the monthlong tournament.
Gillian Pattison, a spokeswoman for Prime Sports International, said burglars broke into the company's offices early today, smashed a safe, grabbed more than $560,000 and made off with tickets for most of the remaining matches, including the final in St.-Denis on July 12. 
 The police confirmed that the robbery had taken place. But it was not clear why the company, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., had so much cash or so many tickets in its office.
A news release from the company offered a no-questions-asked reward of one million francs ($166,500) for information leading to the return of the tickets. It quoted a company official, Steve Yovetich, as saying the tickets, all promised to customers, were "important to our reputation."
Yovetich declined to respond to a telephone call, and Pattison said she could not elaborate beyond saying that all the tickets had been sold to "overseas customers" who would be reimbursed if the tickets were not recovered. Matt Thacker, an official at Prime Sports International in Beverly Hills, said he had no information, adding, "We are a little in the dark because of the time difference."
The theft came as complaints continued to pour in from thousands of supporters, including large Belgian, Brazilian and Japanese contingents, who say tour operators have promised them tickets that have not been delivered.
At least one Paris hotel had to call the police to calm an irate crowd of Brazilians whose promised tickets for the opening match 10 days ago had not appeared.
The police and prosecutors have opened investigations into possible fraud that have already led to the arrest of two officials linked to ISL Worldwide, the official marketing agency of the international soccer federation, FIFA, which organizes the World Cup.
As is customary in France with ongoing investigations, the police have declined to comment.
The World Cup, held every four years, has turned into an enormous business, with FIFA reaping large payments from the sale of television rights and sponsoring contracts.
As the fever to get tickets for games has mounted, prices for tickets have soared, with some reports suggesting that tickets for the final on July 12 may fetch over $15,000 each. There appear to be fortunes to be made on the black market, and advertisements have begun to appear daily in newspapers from people seeking tickets.
To date, the police and judicial investigations here have focused on ISL France, the French subsidiary of ISL Worldwide, which is based in Switzerland. The general director of the subsidiary, Marc Loison, and a consultant, Gilles Favard, have both been detained by the police for questioning on the possible fraudulent sale of tickets.
The arrests followed a lawsuit filed by a French lawyer, Francis Debacker, representing four Japanese tour operators who said they had paid for 15,000 tickets promised by Favard but never delivered. In theory, ISL France is supposed to market the World Cup but not sell any tickets.
The sale of tickets was directed by France's central organizing committee for the World Cup, which was further embarrassed today by reports that a confidential phone number leaked to a few privileged fans allowed them to buy huge blocks of seats when 170,000 tickets were put up for sale on a first-come, first-served basis on April 22.
Bruno Travade, a spokesman for the organizing committee, said the committee had asked France Telecom, the country's main telephone company, to conduct an investigation into the existence of a secret number and would file charges if necessary.
Official phone lines were constantly busy when the tickets went on sale, and newspapers here were full of calculations from mathematicians putting the odds of getting through at one in several million.
"The system of ticket sales was not organized in a perfect manner," said Sepp Blatter, the president of FIFA. "Indeed it was far from perfect."
As the ticket scandal raged, the police moved to stop trouble on another front. The sale of alcohol around a Paris stadium, the Parc des Princes, was banned during matches and for several hours before and after them. During the Germany-United States game on Monday, a number of German fans outside the stadium were arrested after minor clashes with the police.
Alcohol sales were also banned in the vicinity of five large video screens erected in the capital to show the games.
"We want to reassure Parisians of their security," Philippe Massoni, the chief of police, said. English soccer hooligans have not yet disturbed the peace of Paris, but reports of their behavior in the southern city of Marseilles have caused concern here despite the fact that England's next two games are in Toulouse and Lens.

HEADLINE: Asian Trouble Raised April's Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
The Commerce Department released trade statistics today showing that the American economy was taking a bigger knock from Asia's financial crisis than expected.
The department reported that the trade deficit for April expanded to a new monthly high of $14.5 billion, well above the $13.3 billion projected by many economists, and up sharply from $13.2 billion in March. 
 The rise was partly accounted for by technical changes in the way the Government measures aircraft exports, and reflected the swollen value of the dollar in relation to Asian currencies.
But the figures showed that the deepening economic slump through much of Asia was drying up demand for many types of goods, costing American exporters orders in what had been one of their fastest-growing markets.
Total exports in April fell by 2.5 percent, to $77.1 billion, the lowest level in 14 months. Imports decreased eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $91.6 billion.
The drop in exports suggested that economic growth was slowing from a robust pace earlier in the year. A slowdown would reduce the risks of an increase in inflation, which many analysts think is the main threat to sustained economic health. But it would also cut into job creation and further bite into corporate profits, a prospect that is already souring the party-like atmosphere on Wall Street.
The nation's largest exporter, the Boeing Company of Seattle, said today that it expected a deepening recession in Asia to cost it orders for 90 aircraft over the next five years. Although the company said no Asian airlines had yet canceled any orders, Boeing has already announced plans to slow production of its flagship 747 jumbo jet.
Farmers, manufacturers of industrial materials and auto makers are also feeling the export losses particularly hard, the Commerce Department said. Texas Instruments, the technology company, said today that it would cut 3,500 jobs worldwide -- 8 percent of its work force -- because of weak demand for semiconductors from Asia and deep price cuts by Asian competitors struggling to survive the downturns in their home markets.
"The trade situation has to have a real impact, and it points to a substantial slowdown in the U.S.," said James Glassman, an economist with Chase Securities in New York. "This is a serious shock we're having to absorb."
Mr. Glassman said he expected growth to slow to 1.5 percent in the second quarter from 4.8 percent in the first quarter, and to be roughly flat in the second half of the year before rebounding in 1999.
Other analysts are less pessimistic, saying the economy is likely to continue growing, albeit at a more modest pace, through the second half. And debate continues among economists about whether Asia's effects alone will cool the domestic economy sufficiently to avert a need for an inflation-fighting interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve.
But the trade figures underscored the stake the United States has in helping to bring Asia's downward economic spiral under control.
The Asian troubles have so far brought as many benefits as drawbacks to the United States, including lower interest rates that have helped fuel a housing boom and allowed many homeowners to save money by refinancing their mortgages. But in the long run, economists said, the nation needs financial stability and economic growth abroad to sustain the vibrant domestic expansion that formally began in 1991.
Fearful that a long slide in the value of the Japanese currency could exacerbate Asia's problems and infect the rest of the world, the Clinton Administration joined with Japanese officials on Wednesday to buy yen, a move that Administration officials acknowledged was only a temporary measure.
The White House has been pushing Japan to do more to revive its own economy and help the rest of Asia. And the Administration has been pressing Congress to provide more money for the International Monetary Fund in case the Asian instability spreads. I.M.F. financing legislation is currently stalled in Congress.
"The fact is we've got to see other economies around the world begin to come back, especially in Asia," said Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley, "in order for U.S. exports, which have become a main part of the U.S. economic success of the last five years, to continue to grow."
The trade deficit has steadily increased thus far through 1998 as Japan slipped into recession and the economies of Indonesia, Thailand, South Korea and other big markets shrank.
The growth in the American deficit has been pushed along in recent months by the steep decline in the yen's value, reflecting the deep-rooted financial and economic problems bedeviling Japan at a time when the United States has been enjoying steady growth and low inflation.
The dollar's rise against the yen makes American products more expensive in Japan and Japanese products less expensive in the United States. Although the trade deficit with Tokyo narrowed in April, to $5.4 billion from $5.8 billion in March, economists said they expected it to increase in coming months, reflecting the sharp run-up in the dollar's value between April and this week's intervention in the currency markets.
The deficit with China expanded in April to $4.3 billion from $3.8 billion a month earlier. President Clinton leaves next week on a trip to China, and he is expected to press the leadership there to lower trade barriers to improve their chances of joining the World Trade Organization and to help defuse political tensions with the United States.
The cumulative worldwide trade deficit for the first four months of the year stood at $49.3 billion, 33 percent higher than for the same period last year.
The cumulative deficit with the Pacific Rim nations alone for the first four months was $46.7 billion, a 38 percent increase over the similar period last year.
The Commerce Department also said today that the nation's current-account deficit, a broader measure of trade performance, expanded to $47.2 billion in the first quarter from $45 billion in the fourth quarter of 1997.
