HEADLINE: From Mental Illness to Yale to Murder Charge

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER with JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 18

 BODY:
For more than a decade, Michael B. Laudor had wrestled with the demons of schizophrenia, managing to eke out startling victories over the delusions and hallucinations, like a degree from Yale Law School and more than $2.1 million in book and movie contracts for his life story.
But today the disease seemed to have snatched its own brutal victory. Mr. Laudor was charged with the murder of his 37-year-old pregnant fiancee, Caroline Costello, a technology administrator at the Edison Project, the private firm that manages public schools. On Wednesday, her body, with more than 10 stab wounds in the back and neck, had been found in the kitchen of the apartment they shared on the banks of the Hudson in this suburban village, which had not seen a murder in 20 years. 
 A short time before the body was found, Mr. Laudor's mother, Ruth, concerned about a conversation she had had with her son, had called the police and asked them to check on the welfare of her son and Ms. Costello in the apartment.
Mr. Laudor, 35, was arrested at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., a place where, as a teen-ager, he had taken a summer program for gifted students. For reasons that were not clear, he fled to Cornell on Wednesday afternoon, driving Ms. Costello's black Honda to Binghamton and then catching the 10:15 P.M. Shortline bus to Ithaca. At Cornell, he flagged down a patrol car and told an officer that he had hurt his girlfriend and possibly killed her, said Simeon Moss, director of the Cornell News Service.
Taken into custody, he was alternately calm and agitated and, at one point, struck a Cornell police officer, who was treated at a local hospital.
This afternoon, Mr. Laudor, a tall, husky, bearded six-footer dressed in a blue Ithaca City Jail jumpsuit and bedroom slippers, was returned to the Hastings police station, next door to where he lived and visible from his balcony. There, he was formally charged with Ms. Costello's murder. He had no prior record for violence.
Friends spoke of two setbacks that seemed to weaken him in his fight against schizophrenia. In 1995, his father, Charles Laudor, an Adelphi economics professor who often talked him through the hallucinations and was a stabilizing influence in his life, died of prostate cancer. In recent months, the antipsychotic medications he had been taking no longer worked as well and doctors struggled futilely to find the right prescription. One friend said that in recent days he had stopped taking medication altogether.
"When I met him a year ago, the only way I would have known that something was wrong was that he spoke slowly," said another friend who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Other than that he was unbelievably charismatic, unbelievably bright, someone you'd never forget. Over the last year he definitely deteriorated. When I left him at the end of April he seemed diminished."
As a result of his recurring mental illness, he was withdrawn and depressed and making little progress in writing the life story on which the lucrative movie was going to be based, friends said today. They said they believed that the pressure of writing, even as he was unable to land a job as a law professor, contributed to his decline.
"I thought the book project would be good," said Vera Hassner Sharav, director of an advocacy group for mentally ill patients who worked on a program with Mr. Laudor in 1995. "But what I didn't like was that he'd complain that he couldn't get out of bed in the morning. Writing, especially for someone with his condition, can be so lonely."
Advocates for the mentally ill tried today to ward off any public conclusions that people with schizophrenia needed to be feared.
Laurie Flynn, executive director of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill in Washington, said that dramatic shifts in behavior can occur when people stop taking their medication.
There were signs that Mr. Laudor had reached a new and distinct crisis. On Wednesday, Ms. Costello, a wisp of a woman who typically worked 60 hours a week, told co-workers that she could not come in because of "a personal emergency," said her boss, Tom Boudrot, director of technology at the Edison Project.
Sometime in the morning or early afternoon, Mr. Laudor had also spoken by telephone to his mother, who lives in New Rochelle. Something in the conversation apparently disturbed Mrs. Laudor because at about 4:20 P.M., in what the police described as a distraught voice, she called the Hastings police station to let them know of her conversation with her son.
"The things being said may have been delusional and she asked us to check on their welfare," said Lieut. Vince Schiavone, executive officer of the village's Police Department, who spoke to the mother.
The police found the body and decided to go directly to the mother's New Rochelle home to inform her. Lieutenant Schiavone said that it was clear to the mother that it was her son who had killed Ms. Costello.
This afternoon, Ms. Costello's parents, William and Marilyn, flew in from Newton, Mass., where she grew up, to identify her body and talk to investigators.
Mr. Laudor's successes in the face of his schizophrenia were so striking that he was the subject of an article in The New York Times in 1995. The story told of a promising childhood in New Rochelle, where he was regarded as a genius so precocious that he was reading James Joyce's "Ulysses" in high school. With no apparent symptoms, he breezed through Yale in three years, graduating summa cum laude in 1984.
It was after college while working for a management consultant firm that he experienced his first brush with illness. He complained that his phones were tapped. Later, he began to hear bells in the night and to imagine that his room was in flames.
Randy Banner, a journalist who is a friend of the Laudor family, said that Michael's father would talk him down from his hallucinations, asking him, for example, to place his hands in the flame that he imagined.
His father helped him through Yale Law School, where he performed so brilliantly he was awarded a postdoctoral associateship. He also saw himself as a role model for the mentally ill, and in the Times interview expressed his displeasure with what he said were stereotypes of schizophrenics as violent. Two years ago, despite side effects from medication, he wrote a book proposal about his struggles. It won him a contract from Scribner that was worth more than $600,000 and a $1.5 million movie deal with Ron Howard's Imagine Entertainment.
Mr. Laudor and Ms. Costello, who was known as Carrie, had apparently met at Yale, where she received a bachelor's degree in literature.
"She was in love with him," Ms. Banner said. "She met Michael during his well period. Michael was the golden boy. He is handsome, kind, spiritual, a wonderful conversationalist, a wonderful sense of humor and he was destined for what everyone thought was greatness."
Friends said that Ms. Costello stuck with Mr. Laudor through his illness. After the windfall for the book and movie, they moved in together in Hastings. She agreed to marry him and began studying Judaism, Mr. Laudor's religion, with the intent of a possible conversion.
"She was a very 'up' person," Mr. Boudrot said. "I think it would take a person of that inner grain to look at a relationship that most people would say, 'Hey, this isn't for me,' and give it a fair shot. The eternal optimist. I think that's what most people would say about her."

HEADLINE: An Administration Report Finds Urban Improvement, but Hardly Fat City

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
A study of American cities by the Clinton Administration says the strong national economy has left most of them in their best financial shape in decades.
But the report, "The State of the Cities 1998," also finds that urban centers are still suffering from chronic problems afflicting the poor -- unemployment, inadequate housing and substandard education -- that could grow worse over the next five years as hundreds of thousands of city residents move off welfare. 
 To help those people, as well as the low-income wage earners against whom they will be competing for jobs, the Administration has asked Congress to approve an array of new or expanded programs for the 1999 fiscal year, in what the White House calls "the most wide-ranging budget for cities in more than a decade."
Administration officials could provide no total spending figure today for their urban initiative. But the largest part of their request comes from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which is seeking $1.8 billion beyond the appropriation of $24 billion it has received in each of the last five years.
"The success of the Clinton economy has meant real progress for America's cities," Andrew M. Cuomo, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said in a statement. "The President's urban agenda is helping cities to continue to recover from years of decline and making them better places to live and work. This is a midterm report card with an A grade for cities, but there is still homework to be done."
Although Congress is projecting a budget surplus of as much as $100 billion for 1999, it will not be easy for the Administration to get money for new programs. Among other reasons, Republicans in both houses are eager to use some of the surplus to cut taxes.
One Congressional aide familiar with housing budget negotiations now under way predicted that Congress would most likely authorize new spending for some existing programs -- providing additional housing vouchers, for instance, to allow inner-city residents to live closer to jobs or transportation lines -- but that money for new programs would be harder to come by.
The Administration's report, which Mr. Cuomo is to present to the annual convention of the United States Conference of Mayors, this weekend in Reno, provides ample evidence that the country's economic growth has significantly improved conditions in cities of all sizes.
Among the major findings is a 10.4 percent increase in employment among urban residents during the last five years. And, the report says, of all new low-skilled jobs created from 1994 to 1995, 34 percent were in cities, compared with 13 percent from 1991 to 1994.
But the gains continue to pale beside job growth in suburbs, the report says, a disparity that reflects a domino effect of adverse urban circumstances. As urban problems like crime and poor schools steadily persuade many middle-class residents to leave for the suburbs, commercial investment follows, draining cities of their tax base.
The report contends that the people who are hurt most are the lowest-wage earners, who have fewer job opportunities and often no practical means of transportation to reach jobs in the suburbs. The report contends that over the next five years, their ranks will increase by 353,000 as many current welfare recipients join the search for work.
Citing a recent study of 74 urban areas by the Conference of Mayors, the Administration's report says that within five years, employers are likely to find at least two applicants for the same low-paying job. Some cities, like Cleveland, Newark and Providence, are projecting 10 or more.
 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

COMPANY: CLINTON ADMINISTRATION (96%);

HEADLINE: The Japanese and Inertia

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 18

 BODY:
In a few weeks Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto will face nationwide elections as he presides over the worst recession in more than 50 years, a limp stock market and the highest unemployment rate since records began to be kept.
Yet experts overwhelmingly expect his governing Liberal Democratic Party to do very well. The latest polls show it with more than five times as much support as any other party. 
 Now Mr. Hashimoto is more likely than ever to do well, for President Clinton handed him a political gift on Wednesday by agreeing to a joint American-Japanese campaign to bolster the sagging yen. Whether the jawboning and billions of dollars in foreign-exchange intervention succeed in propping up the yen, they will almost certainly succeed in propping up Mr. Hashimoto.
Yet Mr. Hashimoto's relative popularity may be part of the problem.
The premise of Mr. Clinton's decision to go to Mr. Hashimoto's aid was that Japan would take, as Mr. Clinton put it, aggressive and bold steps that would justify a higher rate for the yen. But many analysts here say that the Japanese political process militates against fundamental change and that Mr. Hashimoto's relative popularity suggests that the public wants someone like him, a repairman for the old system rather than an architect for a new one.
To be sure, although Americans would like more, some repairs are still crucial. One that Japanese officials are focusing on would be for the banking system, and particularly the bad loans that overwhelm it. Page A6.
"Fundamentally it comes down to the fact that people in Japan generally don't think that things are so bad that they need to have fundamental change," the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan, Glenn S. Fukushima, said. "They realize that there are difficulties, that they need to handle them, and they are prepared to make certain changes. But change will often result in disruption of the current system, and I think that is something that people want to avoid as much as possible."
All this raises puzzling questions about the Japanese political process. In most industrialized countries there is a built-in corrective mechanism when an economy veers off course. Disgruntled voters evict the old team and choose new leaders who promise to do things differently. Yet despite eight years of economic stagnation the Japanese political system has not responded in that way.
One common explanation is that Japan has established an elaborate series of safety nets, so that even in a recession no one feels deeply distressed. Ronald A. Morse, a professor of economics and business administration at Reitaku University near Tokyo, calls Japan "an air bag society," because people are so protected from the effects of recession.
"Everybody has jobs, everybody has health care, and nobody's out on the street," Professor Morse said. "Even companies that are losing money aren't laying people off."
Certainly Japan does not have the feel of a country in a severe downturn. There are very few homeless people, soup kitchens, bankruptcies or vacant buildings. Although there are some differences in measurements, the record unemployment rate in Japan is still 4.1 percent, less than the 4.3 rate in the United States.
An old saying defines a recession as when your neighbor is laid off. When you are laid off it is a depression. By those definitions, for the great majority of Japanese this is still not a recession.
The sliding yen had been a visible and humiliating signal of Japanese economic weakness. But for now the joint American-Japanese intervention may have arrested the slide. In early Asian trading on Friday, the yen was quoted at 137.30 to the dollar, compared to 146 before the intervention. The gulf in perceptions inside and outside Japanese on the seriousness of the economic situation here is difficult to exaggerate.
To Americans and many Asians these days it sometimes seems that Japan's economy has caught fire and is threatening to ignite all of Asia and, perhaps, the United States and Europe, as well. For those fearing a global economic conflagration, nothing is more infuriating than the sight of Mr. Hashimoto as he passively watches the flames and seeming to do little more than blithely insisting that the fire will eventually subside.
In a similar situation Nero fiddled, but not for eight years -- that is the kind of grumbling one hears from American officials these days.
To Japanese officials the foreign carping seems foolish and petulant. Some say the American Government is simply nervous about its own bubble economy and is looking for a scapegoat to blame when stock prices inevitably collapse. And most Japanese say the risks are exaggerated.
"The realities of Japan's economy are not as bad as the world thinks," said Jiro Ushio, chairman of the influential Japan Association of Corporate Executives.
Moreover, many Japanese insist that their country is seriously addressing the recession and the Asian crisis. They note that the Japanese Government has put in place a huge stimulus package, the biggest in the nation's history, and that the Government has contributed far more to Asian bailouts than the United States.
"To suggest that we might be oblivious is not, I think, well founded," said Sadaaki Numata, the chief spokesman for the Foreign Ministry.
Noting that Japan has worked out a series of measures to combat the recession, he added, "We will implement the measures as soon as possible and we do hope that there will be a recovery and that the markets will respond."
In any case, for all the bewilderment and anger at Japan's reluctance to do more to stimulate its economy, seen up close Mr. Hashimoto's behavior makes some sense and appears in keeping with the public mood. After all, he just celebrated the Liberal Democratic Party's latest victory, on Sunday in a parliamentary by-election.
That was the sixth consecutive victory in by-elections for the Liberal Democrats, and polls suggest that they will also do very well in elections for the upper house on July 12. The upper house is much less significant than the lower house, but the election will nonetheless be an important test of sentiment, and Mr. Hashimoto seems ready to pass with flying colors.
A poll this week in the Yomiuri newspaper, taken just before the intervention to support the yen, found that the support for Mr. Hashimoto's Government had dipped, from 33 to 30 percent. But perhaps more important, 29 percent of those interviewed said they still supported the Liberal Democrats, compared to 5.5 percent for the leading opposition group, the Democratic Party.
Professor Morse argues that Japan suffers from cronyism and structural economic problems quite similar to those of South Korea and Indonesia. Those countries were bailed out by the International Monetary Fund on the condition that they accept painful reorganizations.
But Japan has not collapsed in the way that South Korea or Indonesia did, and so Professor Morse said he believed that the political process would not lead to a fundamental overhaul of the economy.
"The I.M.F. should have come into Japan, but it didn't," he said. "Japan is too big for anyone to mess with."

HEADLINE: Better Job Benefits Mean Lower Wages

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Benefits Dwindle Along With Wages for the Unskilled" (front page, June 14): Mandating that employers provide a full range of benefits to low-skilled workers will merely widen the gap between high- and low-skilled workers -- employers will cut wages and eliminate low-skill jobs. Wages and benefits for low-skilled workers could be improved by decreasing their numbers -- through changes in our immigration policy. 
 Over the past three decades the increased number of low-skilled immigrants to the United States has helped depress wages and job benefits for all low-skilled workers. This has been encouraged by lax enforcement of immigration law and the distribution of immigrant visas primarily on the basis of a person's relation to a resident alien or United States citizen rather than his likely contribution to the economy.
 
BARRY R. CHISWICK
Chicago, June 15, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of economics at the University of Illinois at Chicago.

HEADLINE: Better Job Benefits Mean Lower Wages

 BODY:

To the Editor:
William Finnegan (Op-Ed, June 12) recites a common error when he blames tax cuts of the 1970's and early 1980's for reduced public expenditures on young people. In fact, state, local and Federal revenues constitute approximately 40 percent of the United States gross domestic product, a post- World War II high. Since the end of the cold war, an increasing portion of those expenditures has been directed to social programs. 
 The problem is not the amount we spend but how we spend it. Medicare and Social Security eat up a disproportionate amount of government budgets. We should spend less on programs for the middle class and elderly and more on programs for young people, who are at the beginning of their lives.
 
ROBERT L. BIRNBAUM
Boston, June 14, 1998

LENGTH: 1028 words

HEADLINE: Japan's Premier Promises A New Broom at the Banks

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 18

 BODY:
Japan's leading politicians are thrashing out the details of what the Government hopes will emerge as a landmark blueprint to clean up the nation's bad debts.
The details of the plan are being closely guarded, but the Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, referred to it obliquely at a news conference today, pledging that the Government "will take drastic measures to resolve the bad-loan problem, which has been considerably dragging economic recovery." 
 And the blueprint is likely to be an important topic on Friday when the United States Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, meets with Japanese Government officials and party leaders.
After playing down the bad-loan problem for years, the Government now acknowledges that clearing away the loans may be the single most important factor in building confidence overseas and in giving a lift to the economy.
The problem loans -- which have grown to more than $600 billion, more than the size of the entire Chinese economy -- have been a drag on the economy for years, but now the Government seems increasingly determined to clean up the mess over the next three years.
"An economic recovery and disposal of bad loans are go hand in hand," Mr. Hashimoto said at the news conference today. He suggested that he would call a special session of Parliament late next month, after elections for the upper house on July 12, apparently to turn the plan into law.
Some foreign investors are wary of new promises from the Government because they have been let down so many times. But other analysts and economists say that while enormous uncertainties remain, there are signs that the Government may finally be ready to implement the Total Plan, as it is being called here.
The changes would take time but they could result in a sounder banking sector, a more vibrant real estate market and a healthier economy overall.
"Over time, Hashimoto's commitment to do something is getting stronger and stronger," said Masaru Yoshitomi, chief economist at the Long-Term Credit Bank.
But Mr. Yoshitomi argues that up until now, only the politicians have broken from the pack to tackle the bad debt while the regulators and the banks themselves have shown enormous reluctance.
The Total Plan is being hammered out by 34 high-level Liberal Democrat politicians and bureaucrats, who will convene a major session next Tuesday to review a draft. The chairman is Okiharu Yasuoka, a Liberal Democrat member of the lower house.
"It is being done at a very top level," said a senior Government official. "Few people know the details."
The plan has been through many versions and is still changing, and about $17 billion has been set aside for it in the Government's $123 billion stimulus package. As described by Government officials, economists and bankers, the Total Plan focuses on the bad loans and on the properties that Japanese banks are stuck with because they were the collateral for the loans.
In the past, banks have often set aside reserves for questionable loans but they generally have not sold those properties or liquidated the bad loans. One result has been a huge drag on the property market and a continuing burden on the banks.
The Total Plan calls for measures to encourage the banks to sell the properties and remove both the loans and the collateral from their books. This may be a wrenching process, because the sale of so much real estate could drive property prices lower and the obligation to face up to the problems could force weak banks out of business. This could be another blow to confidence in the Japanese economy.
But supporters say that the plan at least offers a way out of the mess, even if it is a risky and laborious passage.
One of the most controversial proposals -- it is not yet part of the Government plan -- is to set up a "bridge bank" that would essentially absorb the business of failed banks. The bridge bank would take over the good loans and deposits of failed banks and continue lending to their clients in order to minimize the disruption in the financial system.
This would be the clearest break from the current system in which all banks, strong and weak, are pulled along together by the Government.
"We really need a bridge bank," said Mr. Yoshitomi, a fervent advocate of an expanded version of the Total Plan.
The Government already has a Resolution and Collection Bank, which can absorb failed institutions, but its activities are not comprehensive enough to deal fully with bankrupt banks.
Ryuji Konishi, an economic consultant and former banking executive who favors the idea, compares the bridge bank to a fishnet that catches only the fish too weak to swim away on their own.
"The strong fish will jump over the net and survive, and the shrimps and sardines will have to go into the net," he said. "Unless you have a net, you can't do anything."
Not surprisingly, the weak banks are extremely sensitive to this proposal because they do not want to be, in effect, taken over by the Government.
Earlier this year, the Government also put together a $221 billion bank bailout that would support depositors and help the banks rebuild their capital.
But the banks have drawn only 1.8 trillion yen. Weak banks are reluctant to ask for money for fear that such an admission of weakness would drive down their share prices.
Some foreign investors would like to see the Government put up even more than 30 trillion yen, either through a bridge bank or another rescue package.
"Now it's not regarded as enough," said an executive at a foreign asset-management company. He said Japan needed a bigger bailout in which the weak banks would go out of business once and for all. "Many people would like to see some of these banks go to the wall," he said.
Thus, some bankers say the bridge bank is crucial.
"This time they really seem serious and are taking appropriate action," said a senior bank officer at a large Japanese bank. "What are the implications? The Government is going to take action. Maybe the Government will close weak banks after it prepares some structure to take over" questionable assets.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Jobless Rate Drops In New York City

 BODY:
New York City's unemployment rate continues to drop, according to statistics released yesterday by the State Department of Labor.
The unemployment rate fell to 7.7 percent in May, from 8.1 percent in April. The office of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said it was the city's lowest rate since January 1995. The figures still lag behind the statewide unemployment rate, 5.7 percent, and the national rate, 4.3 percent. 
 The Mayor's office said 2,900 jobs were created in May, with the largest numbers generated in sales and in business services, which include secretarial and clerk-related jobs.
The banking industry, however, lost 100 jobs and the communications and transportation fields lost about 500. Wall Street's securities business showed a slight rise of 300 jobs.

HEADLINE: What to Read? Ask a Computer;
New Strategy for Selling Books Makes Many Experts Uneasy

BYLINE: By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN; Samuel G. Freedman, a professor of journalism at Columbia University, is the author of three books, most recently "The Inheritance."

 BODY:
Clerking at a New Haven book shop one afternoon 15 years ago, a novelist named Kitty Florey watched two regular customers approach the display racks, their faces furrowed with consternation. "I get tired of these after a while," one said, indicating a stack of best sellers, "but I don't know what else to read." Ms. Florey bounded across the Oriental rugs to propose a few titles by Anne Tyler and Barbara Kingsolver. Her manager, just a pace behind, suggested Ms. Florey's own latest book.
On a recent morning in the TriBeCa offices of a software company called Muze, the same Kitty Florey typed into a computer the catalogue information and plot summary of "The Man in the Box," Thomas Moran's novel about an Austrian family that shelters a Jewish doctor from the Nazis. Then she listed the book under such categories as "caring and caretaking," "fugitives" and "Holocaust survivors." All the material became part of Muze's data base, which some 300 bookstores offer to customers. 
 Ms. Florey's evolution parallels American society's: from an old-fashioned, personal brand of taste-making to a high-tech variety made possible by what is known as agent software. This software, sometimes described with the more specific term "collaborative filtering," compiles information that consumers provide about their taste in the arts and past buying patterns and analyzes the data to recommend books, videos, films and CD's. It is used by major retailers like the on-line bookstore Amazon.com and the Columbia House music club. Microsoft recently paid $40 million to buy the agent-software company Firefly, and Amazon.com just leased Muze's software for its new on-line music store.
As such developments demonstrate, artificial intelligence is offering an alternative to -- or even a replacement for -- flesh-and-blood arbiters of culture. The consumer who decades ago took cues from a critic like Edmund Wilson or a mass-audience magazine like the original Life can now click on Muze or Firefly.
"All of us feel a little uncomfortable," says Ms. Florey, the senior fiction editor at Muze, "because we all come from a background of studying literature and believing great books are beyond categorization. At the same time, you feel like you're opening it up to people who wouldn't go down that path otherwise."
Ms. Florey's own divided feelings frame the larger debate. For the creators and buyers of agent software, it gives consumers a matchless tool for navigating through an overwhelming number of choices to find art they will cherish. For critics, including those conversant with computer technology, collaborative-filtering software threatens to take the idiosyncratic process of forming an esthetic and replace it with the soulless logic of code.
"People are losing their ability to really reason for themselves, to look at things for themselves," says Patricia Galvis Assmus, a fine-arts professor who directs the Center for Research in Art and Technology at the University of Massachusetts. "In one sense, collaborative filtering is not that different from a bibliography at the end of a scholarly report. And that's fine. The problem is that people rely on it solely and don't take the initiative beyond the software. In this country, people are so enthused with technology that browsing a library just isn't as attractive."
Dr. Assmus's vision does not persuade fellow scholars like David Thornburn, a professor of literature and director of the Communications Forum seminar series at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He has been pleased to click onto Amazon.com's Web site and find its Netperception software presenting him with book titles based on those he most recently bought.
"I don't feel as if cultural value is threatened by this software," Dr. Thornburn says. "It seems not to have a judging function but a consumer-advice function. I had bought 'Cold Mountain' for a gift, and the software was intelligent enough not to offer me every other best seller. It didn't recommend Tom Clancy. It recommended 'The God of Small Things,' " also a first novel of literary distinction.
"It made that distinction," he added. "It was accurate about the things I enjoy reading."
Agent software arose in the late 1980's from a mixture of commercial and cultural motives. John Hey, later one of the founders of the software company Likeminds, started out as an M.I.T. student and movie buff who wanted to be steered to films without having to learn plot details. Mr. Hey invented two forms of collaborative-filtering software, installed them in kiosks and sold the kiosks to video stores in the Cambridge area. The store's customers put in their ratings of films they rented, forming a reservoir of data that could be matched to the personal preferences entered by any user.
Muze developed a different approach. It began by leasing and digitizing printed catalogues of music and books. Then it hired people like Ms. Florey to cross-reference the entries by themes, categories, genres and subgenres. These range from such conventional terms as literary/avant-garde to those Muze has coined like galactic empires and space opera. Lately, the Muze staff has passionately debated whether to add the designation angst bunny for what Ms. Florey described as "young women in the Village with black clothes and lots of body piercings."
 
The Intelligence Is Not Artificial
Such discussions underscore the fact that the intelligence behind the software is not artificial; the raw material was provided by human beings, whether customers typing in their book preferences or editors in computer companies deciding how to categorize a particular book. What the software does, in computer jargon, is "find patterns in the noise" -- use mathematical formulas to determine which books or films or CD's had the greatest probability of matching either a consumer's stated preferences or actual record of purchases. Although not all retailers choose to do so, they can have the software adjusted to put extra emphasis on particular titles.
In whatever variation, collaborative-filtering software surged with the refinement of the Internet and the World Wide Web in the early 1990's. Likeminds, for instance, went on line for such clients as Columbia House, the cable network Cinemax and the Web site Moviecritic.com. What customers got was convenience in choosing a product; what retailers got was an identity and a marketing profile of each buyer.
Technological innovation, though, tells only half the story of the agent-software bonanza. The software entered the cultural marketplace just as the power of highbrow critics, general interest magazines and television networks unchallenged by cable was dissipating.
"One of the reasons for the mandarins and the shapers of opinion in the past is that there were limitations on the availability of information to people," says Stephen Kanzler, the president and chief executive officer of Likeminds. "Now the information is ubiquitous. You can look at the Louvre collection on the Net. The sifting of information and opinion is the problem. It's the old drinking-from-the-fire-hose problem. How do you sort through it? An agent can help a consumer get what he wants."
Ms. Florey of Muze is blunter. Speaking of the New Haven bookstore, she says: "At a place like the Foundry, we didn't need machines. The guy who owned it prided himself on knowing. At the superstores, there's nobody you can ask. They don't have booksellers who make their career out of loving books."
 
Brand Loyalty By Another Name
But precisely because agent software intends to cater to personal taste as a commercial strategy -- Likeminds' slogan is "Every individual a market" -- scholars like Carol Gigliotti of Ohio State University criticize it. "If you look at the Firefly Web site, you'll see this phrase, 'loyal and dynamic communities built on shared interest,' " says Dr. Gigliotti, a professor in the Advanced Computing Center for the Arts and Design and the project director for an on-line journal about computer ethics. "What these dynamic communities are about is brand loyalty. They're not about an idea, a value, a spiritual concept. They're about the market economy."
In cyberspace, where the prevailing political philosophy seems to be libertarian, the notion of a vast bazaar of information is populist. Even as a literary critic himself, Dr. Thornburn of M.I.T. contends that the pre-eminent cultural critics of mid-century America performed a disservice by creating "a false dichotomy between high culture and popular culture," stranding art forms like jazz. Agent software, in comparison, weights any and every opinion equally.
Which is part of what disturbs Dr. Gigliotti. "There's a big difference between knowledge and wisdom," she says. "And a great deal of what's on the Web has to do with information, which is confused with knowledge, which is confused with wisdom. Wisdom can understand knowledge and decipher information. We're allowing a very random, nonexperiential machine to say what we should like."
As the debate proceeds, Kitty Florey writes novels by night and enters data by day, her office shelves crowded with the London Review of Books, the Threepenny Review and a cheese sandwich on whole wheat. A few carrels over works Molly Siemers, the genre-fiction editor. As an English major at Vassar, Ms. Siemers wrote a thesis on the author Djuna Barnes's refusal to be categorized for her blackness or lesbianism.
On occasion, Ms. Florey and Ms. Siemers have paused in their categorizing duties to determine which books carried the most cross-references. The winner, as well as they can reckon, is "Tom Jones," without about 150. Proust also ranks high, as does "Middlemarch." And there are several unexpected competitors.
"I've given my own books dozens of themes," Ms. Florey says. "I'm shameless."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
TV News Magazines Hard, Medium and Lite

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
"CNN Newsstand," the new prime-time cable series, opened on a controversial note last week with allegations that the United States used nerve gas against American defectors during the Vietnam War. The network's chief military analyst, Maj. Gen. Perry Smith, retired, resigned in protest ("sleazy journalism" he called it) but the report prompted Defense Secretary William S. Cohen to order a fresh inquiry.
"CNN Newsstand" is the overall title for three hourlong weekly collaborations between the cable network and magazines in the Time-Warner empire. On Sundays, Time magazine, which carried the nerve-gas charges, is the partner from print; on Wednesdays, it's Fortune magazine and the beat is business; on Thursdays, it's Entertainment Weekly, and the beat is show business. 
 Time-Warner executives hope that this pooling of resources will lift CNN's ratings in slow periods when wars or the deaths of celebrities are not available. At least, it is hoped, the new entries will give CNN a leg up in the increasingly crowded news-magazine field. Whether you call it synergy or merger muscle, the new series is the best the company has come up with to hold onto some of the many viewers who flip channels after catching "Larry King Live."
Although the new business and entertainment programs -- plainly inspired by the popularity of other such shows -- are efficiently produced, with a mildly irreverent attitude toward the personalities they perforce celebrate, they do not promise to be the engines of success the network seeks. On first viewing, it is hard to see what they offer that is not already either in abundant supply elsewhere or not particularly worth supplying.
CNN's hope for making a mark among news fans resides in the Sunday night program. With two of the network's best-known personalities -- Bernard Shaw and Jeff Greenfield -- as anchors, it aspires to more weight and import than its companion entries.
Along with the main story about nerve gas, the premiere carried a segment on teen-age sex, a news magazine perennial. Particular attention for some reason was devoted to a Mormon community. There was nothing especially wrong with the report unless you were hoping for something surprising.
More provocative was a short final feature called "The Looking Glass," under the auspices of Mr. Greenfield, who has been occupying a prominent place as a commentator since moving to CNN some months ago. In this appearance, he chided his audience for hypocrisy for telling poll takers that they are sick of scandal and violence even as they tune into Jerry Springer and anything about the President's sex life instead of brooding over the tribulations of the Asian economy.
Mr. Greenfield is a leading proponent of one television school of how to treat Clintoniana. While others (see "Hardball" on CNBC) book assertive loudmouths to rattle their cages, the Greenfield school takes an introspective, above-the-commotion attitude. He draws rueful attention to being in a line of work that requires wheel-spinning, day after day, about who did or is doing what to whom in the latest celebrity melodrama, be it about O. J. Simpson, Diana, Princess of Wales, or Monica S. Lewinsky.
His good judgment or taste, as he would be quick to grant, can have no effect at all on coverage of such tempting tales, certainly not by his current employer. Yet there is something touching about the abashed concession by one of television's news stars that his tribe finds itself consigned to a journalistic netherworld, like tenors fated to sing "Pagliacci" on tour forever and ever.
The second edition of "Newsstand: CNN and Time" on Sunday led off with a report on the propensity of some N.B.A. athletes, millionaires all, for fathering illegitimate children and then failing to support them either financially or emotionally. From another report, we learned that the new drug of choice among youngsters is methamphetamine, street name "crank," which can produce symptoms of paranoia. And there was a brief epilogue of conflicting testimony on the nerve-gas story. With its combination of proven ingredients (money, sex, children, drugs) and its hard-edge reporting and soft-focus production, the program made a professional, if not spectacularly fresh package.
Although the Asian economy went unmentioned, a few minutes was given to the opinion, delivered by Walter Isaacson, managing editor of Time, that the recent nuclear tests by India and Pakistan were unsettling. His contribution seemed like an inexpensive gesture on behalf of Mr. Greenfield's campaign to acknowledge the existence of significant stories that are not natural news magazine audience grabbers.
In the same spirit, Mr. Shaw promised that "CNN Newsstand" would devote less time than the competition to the Clinton-Starr-Lewinsky operetta, a pledge that did not apply to his network. The next day and night found CNN on the case as usual; among the journalists assembled by "Larry King Live," that major merchandiser of celebrity chat, was CNN's senior analyst, Jeff Greenfield.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Open-Air Sculpture With a ZIP Code

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE postman never rings twice when he gets to Ezra Shales's house on a half-empty strip of Beach 43d Street in Edgemere, Queens. A double take is more likely. There is no bell; nor for that matter, any doors, walls or people. Just a bright yellow mailbox set into the sandy dirt by the cracked sidewalk.
Mr. Shales has a house in name only, and even that detail won't be decided until later today during a housewarming party on the block. For weeks, Mr. Shales has culled dozens of postcards that have arrived at his lonely mailbox with suggested names for his "Nominal Home," a sculpture set in a weed-covered lot near the Far Rockaway boardwalk. 
 The home consists of bales of hay scattered on the narrow lot. Each bale was slathered with plaster and labeled BED, DOOR, TABLE and even DOG, all built to crumble through rain, heat and time. Mr. Shales wants people to reconsider their ideas about the changing faces and fortunes of the city. Although the postman has got used to it, most people who walk down this deserted street just off the concrete arches of the A train think the home is a work in progress.
"You put a mailbox up on a street with no house, and you get mail there," Mr. Shales said with wry satisfaction. "Still, I like it when people ask me what it's going to be. There's a refusal to believe what you see. It tells you what people think about work, art and land. And vacant lots."
There are lots of lots on this stretch of the Rockaway Peninsula, thanks to ideas the city had in the 1960's about urban renewal. Once home to bungalows and beachgoers, Edgemere and nearby Arverne became desolate after blocks were razed for homes that were never built. Recently, modest plans emerged to build affordable housing and shops and reclaim some of the hundreds of empty acres.
"Part of my awareness of the city comes from having read about archeology and reading things like Alfred Kazin's 'A Walker in the City,' " said Mr. Shales, a museum educator. "In the city you think about how it flows, how things are built and fall apart."
He plopped his sculpture on a lot that a friend of a friend had purchased years ago at a city auction. "They were lifelong New Yorkers who had always hoped it would come back," he said. "Beautiful beachfront property, you know."
He cleared away some of the land, purchased some hay from a man who also supplies the race tracks, and printed 10,000 picture postcards of the sculpture, which he gave to friends, teachers and anybody else he could find. In fact, he considers the postcards and their suggested names as artistically important as the sculpture itself. Among the recommendations are: Housilly, Baleful and No Mo Ho.
"I'm making something here that people might not come all the way out here to see," he said. "You go to flea markets, though, and you see people buying and selling old postcards. It's a funny memento of a place they aren't even sure exists anymore."
MR. SHALES knows that some people deride conceptual art as being understood only by the black turtleneck crowd. Others look at public art, if at all, as high-priced corporate street furniture.
"Having this outside here, it's not about degrees, paper degrees or provenance," he said. "No pretensions. It just has a kind of street value. That's what people talk about when they talk about something having value. In economic terms."
Maybe that's why many people who pass by his house always ask if he is going to put a fence around it. For protection, you know. Like John Fillyaw, who stopped on the street a few days ago on the way to visit his girlfriend.
"What is that?" Mr. Fillyaw asked. "What is it going to be?"
"It already is," Mr. Shales replied.
"Just like that?" Mr. Fillyaw said. "You're putting up no fence? Nothing?"
Mr. Fillyaw tilted his head back as he beheld the lot. He liked it. He liked the idea of things changing. Of course, he has long heard talk about all kinds of changes promised for this neighborhood.
"I think years ago they were talking about bringing casinos out here," he said. "That would have been good for New York. Now Jersey's got it all."
As an electrician, he savored the thought of all the work that would have brought his way. All that money. But, ever the optimist, he ventured a suggestion.
"You need lights out here," he said to Mr. Shales. "I can put up some garden lights. All low voltage."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ezra Shales, museum educator and artist, at "Nominal Home," in Far Rockaway, Queens. The sculpture receives mail. (William Lopez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Denies It Intends to Rescue Two Banks

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 19

 BODY:
As a high-level United States delegation pressed Japanese leaders today to strengthen the economy and tackle bad loan problems, news reports appeared that the Government might rescue two major banks by merging them.
A report by Kyodo News Service, citing unidentified Government officials, said that the authorities were considering a merger of the Long-Term Credit Bank and Nippon Credit Bank, two of the nation's largest -- and weakest -- financial institutions. The Tokyo Stock Exchange suspended trading in shares of the banks as it tried to confirm the reports. 
 Both banks denied the reports by late afternoon and the Government said it would refrain from supporting feeble banks.
The Government "intends to let bad banks collapse, and it does not have any intention of bailing them out," said Kanezo Muraoka, the Government's Chief Cabinet Secretary, as quoted by Kyodo News.
In meetings today with Lawrence H. Summers, the United States Deputy Treasury Secretary, Japanese leaders stressed Japan's efforts to clear away the bad debt and invigorate the economy, while Mr. Summers called on Japan to continue fiscal stimulus, including tax cuts. Koichi Kato, secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party, told Mr. Summers that the Liberal Democrats would decide before elections in July on whether to create a new "bridge bank" that would help absorb the business of failed institutions. Such a bank would be a major step toward solving the bad debt problem, Kyodo News quoted Mr. Kato as saying.
Today, the financial markets seemed to welcome the reports of a possible merger between Long-Term Credit and Nippon Credit as a sign that mergers may be in the works to accelerate the disposal of bad loans and nudge along greater consolidation in the banking industry.
Investors have been worried for the last few weeks that Long-Term Credit could be facing difficulty in paying some routine debts.
Early this morning, the stock price of Long-Term Credit fell to an all-time low, plunging to 95 yen, down 31 yen from Thursday's close. After the reports, the stock bounced back to 120 yen before trading was suspended. Shares of Nippon Credit rose 10 yen, to 135 yen.
The share prices of both banks have taken a beating over the last couple of weeks, and investors have not forgotten the financial turmoil last November, when four financial institutions collapsed.
Reports of a potential merger between Long-Term Credit and Nippon Credit have been circulating in the market over the last couple of weeks. Long-Term Credit seems not to have been as active a borrower as it usually is in the money market, according to a banker at a large Japanese bank.
"They are not participating in the market," said the banker, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But we cannot say why." Long-Term Credit said through a spokesman that the bank's day-to-day money operations had been normal.
Nippon Credit is also under scrutiny amid its efforts to restructure 200 billion yen worth of debt. More than a year ago, the Government rescued the bank with an injection of new capital and issuance of new debt.
In the last few weeks, leaders in Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party have mentioned the possibility that another large bank could fail. A week ago, Taku Yamasaki, the party's top policy maker, tried to assure the markets that there would not be a failure any time soon.
Japan's banks are burdened by more than $600 billion in bad debts, and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto has said that cleaning them up is a top Government priority.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Politics or No, Brazil Plans to Sell Telebras

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16

 BODY:
Amid fierce election-year politics, the Brazilian Government has announced plans to go ahead late next month with the breakup and sale of Telebras, the giant Brazilian telephone holding company.
The Government has placed a minimum $11.7 billion price tag on its controlling share of the 12 Telebras-affiliated companies scheduled to be auctioned off on July 29. The sale would constitute the largest privatization in Latin America to date. 
 "It's a real opportunity and one of the few that exist right now," said John Mein, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Sao Paulo.
Opposition politicians are not so enthusiastic, however, and are threatening legal action to block or revoke the sale.
In preparing for the auction of Telebras, the Government broke the holding company into three fixed phone systems, eight cellular concessions and one long-distance company, and created an independent regulatory agency, Anatel, that will monitor the telecommunications industry.
The Telebras sale is expected to be followed by a second auction of so-called mirror licenses for competing companies. In 2002, the industry is to open to even broader competition.
Luiz Carlos Mendonca de Barros, Brazil's Communications Minister, has been gauging investor interest in New York and Europe. So far, he told reporters traveling with him, Telefonica de Espana and France Telecom have shown a keen interest in the sale. Among United States companies, Sprint, MCI, BellSouth and Airtouch are expected to submit bids.
The minimum price the Government has set for the sale is well below the $25 billion to $35 billion that Sergio Motta, Mr. Mendonca de Barros's predecessor, who died two months ago, had repeatedly said the privatization would fetch. Mr. Mendonca de Barros said the price had dropped largely because the Government opted to break up Telebras and sell licenses to create unlimited competition. The subsequent sale of those licenses could bring in an additional $8.7 billion by 2001, Government officials say.
In addition, the economic turbulence in Asia has made investors somewhat more skittish about emerging markets generally.
"A year ago, the whole sentiment toward Brazil and emerging markets was much more positive than today," said Rodrigo Fiais, an investment adviser at Banco Itacu here. "We're in a much more volatile period of investment decision making."
Direct investment in Brazil, however, has remained strong, Mr. Fiais said. Though the Brazilian stock market has dropped steeply in the last eight months, economists predict that the country will draw an average of $2 billion a month in direct foreign investment this year.
And interest in the telecommunications sector has been steadily building. With just 10 percent of the country's 160 million people owning telephones, Brazil is considered to be fairly bursting with pent-up demand for phone service.
Purificacion Carpinteyro, senior counsel and director for international regulatory affairs at MCI, said the company was specifically interested in Brazil's long-distance service. "MCI is not a short-term investor," she said in a telephone interview from Washington. "Brazil has a good future and a stable economy."
The sale is scheduled to take place three months before the first round of presidential elections in October. And the unexpectedly low floor price has turned the auction into a volatile election issue.
The American deposiory receipts of Telebras, which are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, are a convenient vehicle for investors to bet on the Brazilian economy, and their price has fallen sharply in recent months over uncertainty about emerging markets in general and about the Brazilian elections. Telebras A.D.R.'s closed Friday at $107.9375, down about 36 percent from their high of $169.25 last July.
 Also on Friday, Telefonica de Espana and a Brazilian media group agreed to pay 1.18 billion reais, or $1.02 billion, to increase their stake in Companhia Riograndense de Telecomunicacoes, known as CRT, one of four Brazilian telecommunications companies that do not belong to the state-owned Telebras system. The price was higher than analysts had expected.
In Brazil, the opposition candidate, Luiz Inacio (Lula) da Silva of the left-of-center Workers' Party, has called for an audit of the process by which the Telebras minimum price was set, and has vowed to scrutinize any contracts the Government awards. Mr. da Silva's vice-presidential running mate, Lionel Brizola, has vowed to revoke any privatization of the phone companies.
Mr. da Silva is arguing that the sale should be put off until market conditions improve, and he has accused the Government of going ahead with the sale "possibly to create a slush fund for the election campaign." President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, in response, threatened to sue his rival for slander, while his Communications Minister likened the criticism of privatization to Nazi propaganda.
Though the remarks against privatization might ordinarily be dismissed as mere election-year grandstanding, polls show Mr. da Silva running in a dead heat against President Cardoso, who is the first Brazilian President ever to run for re-election.
Economists and executives said the threat of legal challenges to the privatization could deter investors and drive down bids. "It'll scare them away," said Alexandre Barros, an economic consultant based in Brasilia. "Except for one wise contrarian who'll clean up."

HEADLINE: Expand the Javits Center

 BODY:
New York City's attraction as a site for trade shows and conventions has been one of the key elements in its economic growth. That makes it hard to understand why Mayor Rudolph Giuliani seems so indifferent to the fact that the Jacob Javits Convention Center is too small to accommodate the nation's largest trade shows, and growing less competitive every year. New York has long since fallen out of the top 10 when it comes to available exhibition space. It will drop further as other cities expand their facilities.
New York State, which runs the Javits Center, has been promoting a plan that would double its 760,000 square feet of exhibition space by creating a vast complex stretching all the way to 42d Street from the center's present site on the western end of 38th Street. Tying the center to 42d Street would pull the booming development of the Times Square area all the way to the Hudson River, while connecting the convention business to the city's entertainment hub. Larry Silverstein, a developer who owns part of the property the state would need, was apparently willing to swap the land for the right to build a hotel or apartment tower over the Javits expansion. But Mr. Silverstein recently said he was tired of waiting for the city to commit, and was going ahead with other plans for the property. 
 It would be amazing if Mr. Giuliani swallowed the state proposal whole. It would cost an estimated $700 million, and the state wants the city to pick up part of the tab. But rather than demanding changes or proposing alternatives, the city seems simply to be turning away -- as if the convention center were a state project for Syracuse rather than Manhattan. There have been no public comments, no objections and apparently no private negotiations.
Mr. Giuliani's critics contend that the Mayor does not want any other West Side program to compete with possible plans for a new Yankee Stadium, although the two structures would be on different sites. If so, Mr. Giuliani's strategy is all wrong. New York City must both keep the Yankees and pursue the economic development projects it needs to keep the economy growing. To suggest that both things are not possible would hurt, rather than help, the Mayor's cause. Building a world-class convention center would create jobs and assure the city's ability to attract major trade shows and exhibitions into the next century. The Mayor must cooperate with the state in reaching that goal.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
'Triple Witching' and Japan Worries Send Dow Lower

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell again yesterday as Wall Street closed out a volatile week just the way it began: with waves of large-scale selling.
 Shares tumbled across the board, hitting blue-chip issues the hardest, in an extremely heavy trading session that saw the Dow Jones industrial average drop 100.14 points, or 1.14 percent, to close at 8,712.87.
Wall Street analysts said yesterday's selloff was a result of trading related to "triple witching," the day when options on stocks, stock indexes and futures expire, which often creates market havoc. 
 But in a week filled with more serious concerns about economic distress in Japan -- and the possibility that such distress might set off a deeper economic slump in Asia -- it was no surprise that share prices slumped.
While prices were weak through much of the day, shares slid even more on news service reports that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had suggested that despite the United States intervention in buying the Japanese yen earlier this week, Japan's economic recovery might be long and difficult.
Those remarks helped lift bond prices yesterday, sending the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury issue, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, down to 5.66 percent from 5.70 percent a day earlier. The dollar also rallied against the yen as optimism about Japan's recovery soured.
"It's been a tough week," said Alfred Goldman, a market strategist with A. G. Edwards Inc. in St. Louis. "The big question is: How bad is the economic malaise in Asia?"
The last few weeks have not inspired optimism. Japan confirmed a week ago that it had fallen into a recession. And on Monday, the yen fell to an eight-year low against the dollar, heightening fears that the weakening yen could undermine other Asian currencies. That day, the Dow plummeted 207 points, or 2.3 percent, in one of the sharpest selloffs of the year. But on Wednesday , when the United States joined Japan in buying yen, the Dow rebounded 164.17 points, or 1.89 percent.
As part of the coordinated effort, the Japanese Government agreed to resolve its banking crisis, and take steps to right its economy. But if it cannot, investors are worried that American corporate profits could be weakened.
In the meantime, United States markets continue to be volatile. The Dow, which reached a record 9,211.84 in mid-April, slid as low at 8,627.93 on Monday, a drop of 7 percent from its peak.
Blue chips, however, have fared much better than smaller-company issues, which are generally flat, according to the Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks, which is up just three-tenths of 1 percent.
Even with the turbulence, though, both the Dow and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index are up more than 10 percent this year, and so is the Nasdaq composite index, where some big technology stocks trade. Indeed, yesterday the Nasdaq stock market gained nearly five-tenths of 1 percent in one of the few signs of strength in the market.
What Wall Street is worried about is a sharp slowdown in profit growth in the first quarter, and signs of more trouble ahead. Asia-related earnings warnings have already come from I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard, Boeing and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the widely followed investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, however, remains as bullish as ever, contending that the "supertanker" United States economy is strong enough to withstand the effects of turbulence in Asia.
In a telephone conference this week, she told investors that "even if Asia stays extremely weak," the economy and the market will remain strong, and she said the Dow could easily reach 9,300 by year's end.

HEADLINE: French Premier Says West Faces Quandary on Kosovo

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France said today that the West faced a serious quandary in the southern Serb province of Kosovo by trying to stop the violence there without appearing to side with the ethnic Albanians who are fighting for independence.
While France insists that any NATO action in or over Kosovo be authorized by the United Nations Security Council -- an authorization the Russians threaten to veto -- the world cannot ignore turmoil in Kosovo that threatens a regional explosion, Mr. Jospin said. 
 "We don't want a possible veto in the United Nations to be an excuse to do nothing in the face of massacres," Mr. Jospin told reporters today during his first visit to the United States as Prime Minister. "But the Russians face a dilemma, too," he added, which he said he discussed with President Clinton in their Oval Office meeting on Thursday.
"In the end, it's difficult for Russia to use its veto," Mr. Jospin said, because the Kremlin would have to choose between the good relations it needs with the West for its financial stability and its older, more rhetorical solidarity with its fellow Slavs in Yugoslavia.
"But there is a lot of convincing we have to do," he said, urging the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, "to come to his senses" and stop building support for the rebels of the Kosovo Liberation Army through his attacks on innocent civilians.
"Milosevic's attitude is irrational," Mr. Jospin said. "The international community accepts Kosovo as part of the Yugoslav federation, so the solution is autonomy. There is a crazy evolution of events and I hope Milosevic will come to his senses." Mr. Milosevic withdrew autonomy from the province in 1989.
Mr. Jospin, a Socialist, was elected a year ago in a major defeat for the conservative French President, Jacques Chirac.
The benefits of economic prosperity must be shared, he said today, as must the pain of economic adjustment, like the transition France is undergoing in its effort to adapt its state-dominated economy to the demands of global competition.
Although Mr. Chirac is ultimately responsible for France's foreign policy, there is a sharing of power between the President and Prime Minister, and Mr. Jospin has received first-class treatment from the Clinton Administration. In addition to meeting with Mr. Clinton, he has also met with the Vice President, and the Secretaries of State, Defense and Treasury.
Mr. Jospin, whose approval rating in France has never fallen below 50 percent, is a likely presidential candidate in 2002, and the Clinton Administration wants to get to know him better, officials said.
Mr. Jospin and Mr. Clinton together attended the opening of a new French-American business council intended to promote trade and investment.
In return, Mr. Jospin has been preaching a new period of global partnership with the United States and an end to the backbiting that marked the end of Mr. Clinton's first term. The French Foreign Minister at that time, Herve de Charette, and Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher rubbed each other the wrong way over issues ranging from Africa to the Middle East.
While their successors, Hubert Vedrine and Madeleine K. Albright, have had their differences -- over American sanctions on Iran, for instance, and over Iraq -- both have worked hard to emphasize common goals. Ms. Albright goes out of her way to speak the French she learned in a Swiss school, and Mr. Vedrine praises her at every occasion.
Mr. Jospin, for his part, insisted on speaking a vigorous, clear English, and his various toasts and speeches have praised the longstanding alliance between France and the United States and the increasing understanding in America of European integration and transformation.
Bringing a clearer idea of France to the United States was one of his prime goals, he said today. "Do not be misled by caricatures that would have you believe France to be so burdened by its singularities and faults as to be incapable of adjusting to the world now emerging," he said at the National Press Club. "France is in reality far removed from the gloomy picture some people paint."

HEADLINE: NEW RULES SOUGHT FOR CONTRACTORS

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Having declared victory in campaigns against corruption at garbage-carting companies and in the Fulton Fish Market, the Giuliani administration now has its sights on another target: New York City's giant $24 billion construction industry.
In a proposal to be submitted Monday to the City Council, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will ask for the power to determine through licensing regulations which companies are fit to work on public or private construction projects in the city. Contractors could be denied licenses if they were found to "lack good character, honesty and integrity" -- a broad standard that includes criminality, ties to organized crime, tax delinquency and a record of poor workmanship. 
 If enacted, the legislation is expected to have far-reaching effects on a huge industry with more than 9,000 companies and 90,000 workers who are responsible for projects ranging from the erection of skyscrapers to modest renovations in apartment buildings.
Administration officials said yesterday they were proposing the licensing procedure because they believe that persistent corruption within the industry has elevated the cost of construction in the city. Industry officials said they had not seen the Mayor's plan and declined comment.
The centerpiece of the proposal is a five-member New York City Construction Commission, appointed by the Mayor, with broad regulatory and investigative powers. Several large cities and scores of states, including New Jersey and Connecticut, have limited forms of regulation, but none as extensive as the administration proposes for New York City.
Under current laws, the city has virtually no licensing controls over companies that do private construction work. A contractor is required only to obtain a permit from the Buildings Department certifying that its plans comply with the city's zoning and building codes.
The city, however, can bar a construction company from obtaining municipal contracts on grounds that the company is considered professionally unqualified or that its officials lack integrity -- for example, if they have financial ties to organized-crime figures.
Administration officials say that abuses are still rife in the industry despite numerous law enforcement crackdowns over the last 20 years against mobsters, dishonest contractors, corrupt union officials and city inspectors who took bribes to overlook violations. According to the officials, the costs of construction in the city are 35 percent above the national average and they attribute most of the inflated prices to bid-rigging and other corrupt practices. Most prosecutors have favored licensing as a deterrent against organized crime and other corruption.
The bill also takes aim at contractors with poor safety records. Officials cited the deaths of two pedestrians this year who were struck by falling bricks, and the extensive problems caused last year by crumbling walls in a midtown office building, as evidence of the problem.
"This bill is about accountability," Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, said in an interview yesterday. "It is also about higher standards and personal and professional integrity in an industry that has been plagued by corruption and safety problems in the recent past and over many decades."
Mr. Mastro said he felt the city's proposal is on firm legal footing since similar mechanisms for regulating the waste-carting industry and the Fulton Fish Market have survived legal challenges.
Mayor Giuliani has credited the tough licensing policies for eliminating Mafia influence in the businesses, for increasing competition and for sharply lowering private garbage-removal costs and the wholesale prices of seafood.
The past initiatives of the Mayor, a Republican, were swiftly approved with strong support from Peter F. Vallone, a Democrat who is the Council's Speaker and majority leader.
But Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Vallone are now locked in an acrimonious budget dispute and Mr. Vallone's support for the construction-industry bill was not evident yesterday. In a terse statement, he said that the Mayor's office had not consulted him about the bill and that he was unaware of its contents.
"In the end, what we want is a bill that goes after corrupt businesses and does not hurt honest business people," Mr. Vallone said.
By seeking to regulate construction companies, the administration will be tackling a politically more powerful and affluent industry than trash haulers and fish merchants, who opposed the attempts to monitor their businesses and investigate their backgrounds.
The heads of construction-industry trade associations said they knew that a regulatory bill was being prepared but they declined to comment until they could study its language.
But some industry leaders, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the proposal would likely be seen by some in the business as costly intrusions in enterprises that are vital to the city's economic health.
The trade association officials said corruption and the influence of organized crime was not pervasive and that construction prices in the city were elevated by labor costs and by congestion that delays deliveries of equipment and supplies.
Under the Mayor's proposal, the licensing commission would have the following powers:
*To conduct background investigations and the fingerprinting of the principal officers and investors of companies applying for licenses.
*To examine the financial and tax records of company officials and investors.
*To deny licenses to companies affiliated with organized-crime figures or who employ subcontracting companies that the commission finds unfit for licenses.
*To demand as a condition of licensing that a company hire an independent auditor and monitor approved by the commission to oversee the company and to guarantee its integrity and fitness to operate in the city.
Company officials who violate commission regulations would be subject to misdemeanor charges and fines of up to $10,000 and six months in jail.
The proposal mandates that the commission phase in the licensing by beginning with the 400 to 500 major contractors that have obtained at least $3 million in contracts in the city in the last year.
In the mid-1980's, Mr. Giuliani, as the United States Attorney for the Southern District, and Mr. Mastro, as one of his top prosecutors, were involved in the conviction of more than 30 Mafia leaders and associates on racketeering charges involving multimillion-dollar construction contracts.
"Prosecutions alone have not solved the problem," Mr. Mastro said. "As part of a long-term strategy, comprehensive regulatory reform is needed to end the hidden 'mob taxes,' and the end results will benefit the public and businesses through lower building costs and rents in the city."

INTERNATIONAL A3-5
 
Colombia Agrees to Test Herbicide for Drug Control
Colombia has agreed to a United States demand to test a chemical to kill coca crops, even though the manufacturer has warned against its use there. The Environmental Protection Agency says the chemical, tebuthiuron, can poison ground water, and Colombian officials fear it will spoil land where peasants could grow food. A1
 
Clinton Urged to Meet Dissident
A group of 55 democracy advocates from China has called on President Clinton to meet with a prominent Beijing dissident during his visit to China next week. There was no immediate response from the White House, but diplomats said it was extremely unlikely that Mr. Clinton would do so. A3 

Hindus Attacked in Kashmir
Gunmen killed 25 Hindu men at wedding parties in Kashmir in one of the worst attacks since an insurgency began nine years ago in the region claimed by both India and Pakistan. It was the third time in six months that Hindu civilians were singled out by gunmen, whom Indian officials identified as Muslim guerrillas. A3
 
An I.M.F. Rebuff to Russia
The International Monetary Fund put Russia on notice that it did not plan to provide the $10 billion to $15 billion in additional assistance that the Kremlin had requested. The Russian Government, meanwhile, issued data indicating that 1998 was likely to be a year of economic stagnation or gradual decline. A4
 
Swiss Banks Make an Offer
Switzerland's three biggest commercial banks made a public offer of $600 million to settle claims from Holocaust victims who asserted that their families' assets were stolen. Jewish leaders immediately rejected the offer as "humiliating" and said that negotiations had broken down. A4
 
Pope Visits Austria
Pope John Paul II arrived in Austria on a mission to grapple with two of the most troubling problems of his papacy in the Western world -- bitter divisions within the ranks of the Church, and the alienation and indifference of the prosperous society around it. A4
 
Jospin Cautious on Kosovo
Lionel Jospin, left, making his first visit to the United States as Prime Minister of France, said that the West faced a serious quandary by trying to stop violence in the Serbian province of Kosovo without appearing to side with ethnic Albanians fighting for independence. He added that the attitude of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia was "irrational" and hoped he would "come to his senses." A5
 
Tension Over Cyprus Reignited
Greece and Turkey are at odds again over the divided island of Cyprus, with Greek planes landing on the island and Turkish planes flying overhead in response. The latest quarrel began on Tuesday, when Greek military planes landed at a Cypriot airfield. A5

A majority of the House, including 65 Republicans, voted to protect a bipartisan bill on overhauling the campaign finance law from the first Republican leadership effort to water it down by amending it. A1
 
Early Doubts on Fund-Raiser
The Democratic National Committee's finance director has said in a deposition that in March 1995 he raised the possibility that Johhny Chung, who pleaded guilty to campaign-related fraud charges last March, was a conduit for illegal money from China. A1
 
Action on Changing the I.R.S.
Congress moved closer to final passage of legislation that would overhaul the I.R.S., as House and Senate negotiators resolved many differences in the details of their bills. A8

Insurers Back Away on Viagra
