HEADLINE: Enough Blame to Go Around

BYLINE: By Alan Wolfe; Alan Wolfe's most recent book is "One Nation, After All."

 BODY:

Someone Else's House
 America's Unfinished Struggle
 for Integration.
 By Tamar Jacoby.
 Illustrated. 614 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $30. 
 Despite calls from the White House for a national conversation on race, the truth is that Americans have been conversing intensely about race since at least the early 1960's. Aroused by the moral dignity of the civil rights movement, spurred by urban rioting, undecided whether integration was a problem or a cure, Americans pondered the implications of the 1968 Kerner Commission report, reacted to the anger of a James Baldwin or a Malcolm X, debated the wisdom of affirmative action, welcomed the celebrity status of Bill Cosby and Oprah Winfrey and worried about deeply entrenched poverty among inner-city African-Americans. Compared with tariffs or antitrust policy, race has been at the center of domestic politics for over 30 years.
The problem with this continuing conversation has never been that we lacked things to say. The problem has been that so many people said the same thing. Racism, according to a widely held liberal consensus, was not eliminated when Jim Crow fell; it merely changed its form -- and its geographic location. The view was that persistent resistance to school and workplace integration in the North required something more than moral exhortation, something like affirmative action. But once confronted with policies and practices that might actually work, this account concluded, white Americans showed their true colors by resisting them. The United States remains, in the words popularized by Andrew Hacker, "two nations," divided by race in everything they say and do.
Dissenters from this consensus have always existed, but many of them were either conservatives unable to overcome the stigma of their opposition to the Civil Rights Act of 1964 or individuals whose incendiary language seemed to suggest a belief in white racial superiority. In the past few years, however, there has emerged a challenge to the liberal consensus among liberals (or former liberals), including Orlando Patterson, Fred Siegel, Jim Sleeper and Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom. While their work differs in methodology and conclusions, they are united on two important points. One is that whites have not resisted demands for racial justice but have accepted tremendous progress in race relations. The other is that those who claim to speak in the name of African-Americans do not always serve the interests of those for whom they supposedly speak. With the publication of "Someone Else's House," this new racial realism receives its best-written and most emotionally powerful treatment. But readers should be warned: Tamar Jacoby is so unsparing in her judgments that she ends up undermining the ideal of racial integration that she seeks to promote.
Jacoby, a freelance journalist writing in the tradition of J. Anthony Lukas and Nicholas Lemann, focuses on three cities: New York, marked by bitter conflicts between blacks and Jews; Detroit, which witnessed the most extensive white flight of any American city; and Atlanta, often heralded as a model of progressive race relations in the New South. The tale of each town is a tale of woe.
As Jacoby tells the story, New York's experiences with race show the damage that can be done when powerful white liberals, in the name of racial justice, refuse to condemn, and desperately continue to support, black activists whose message is filled with hate, whose actions are irresponsible and whose financial practices are often corrupt. McGeorge Bundy, who became president of the Ford Foundation in the mid-1960's, comes off in Jacoby's account as an upper-class Leninist. Persuaded that he knew best what New York needed -- "The idea," he said during his first few months on the job, "is to do things society is going to want after it has them" -- Bundy was apparently unperturbed by the social chaos he unleashed by sponsoring community control of New York City's schools. "You can't expect effort-free social revolution," this architect of counterrevolution in Vietnam pointed out.
Jacoby holds nothing back in her criticism of black militants: Rhody McCoy, Milton Galamison and, especially, Sonny Carson. She portrays the last of these men as a power-hungry psycho-terrorist. Carson would call Barry Gottehrer, an aide to Mayor John Lindsay, in the middle of the night to summon him to meetings with no purpose. He smashed a reporter's camera in front of Gottehrer, perhaps to see if the Mayor's assistant would protest. (He did not.) Worst of all, according to Jacoby, the furor over community control unleashed "a generation of 'little Sonny Carsons' irrevocably alienated from the white mainstream" -- including Al Sharpton, an impressionable teen-ager at the time, who learned from the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstrations that, in his own words, "confrontation works."
If New York presents the spectacle of white political leadership manipulated by black demagogues, Detroit, in Jacoby's treatment, was governed by a black demagogue from the moment Coleman Young was elected Mayor. As in New York, however, the damage to integration was biracial in nature, for Young, in his campaign to destroy Detroit in the name of saving it for black people, had plenty of help from myopic whites. Automobile executives were, Jacoby writes, willing to fork over millions "in thinly disguised riot insurance."
But the most irresponsible white leader in Detroit -- and perhaps in the whole country -- was a relatively obscure district court judge named Stephen Roth. Roth was responsible for the decision to order busing between inner-city Detroit and the surrounding suburbs. His ambitious plan would touch on the lives of 780,000 children living in 53 suburbs. Many would be bused for as much as an hour and a half each day. "The most intimate personal routines seemed to be hanging on one man's whimsy," Jacoby writes. With Coleman Young doing everything in his power to encourage whites to leave Detroit, and with Roth's decision forcing them to move to the outermost suburbs, it was not long before Detroit became one of the blackest cities in the United States -- and its suburbs among the whitest.
Everyone had high hopes for Atlanta, the city too rich and too busy to hate. Yet according to Jacoby, hatred there was -- aplenty. Black Atlantans blamed whites for the disappearance and deaths of 29 black children in the late 1970's and early 80's, only to lose interest in the case -- and, she argues, in the children as well -- when the murderer was discovered to be black. Indeed, the head of the parents' committee, convinced that the murderer was framed by a white conspiracy, said that "with this conviction, Wayne Williams, at 23, became the 30th victim of the Atlanta slayings."
Jacoby spends the bulk of her Atlanta chapters on construction and real estate deals, the stuff of local politics in the city's booming economy. Here, in her view, was affirmative action taken to its ultimate absurdity. Mayor Maynard Jackson's insistence that a high percentage of all contracts go to blacks worked to benefit a few already well-off black businessmen, not the bulk of Atlanta's minority community. White contractors would cynically go out and find a black name to put on their letterhead and continue to do business as usual. Atlanta tried to "shortcut the normal building up of a business class," Jacoby writes, adding that "it would have been hard to invent a scheme that did more to mock the dignity of the blacks involved."
Race coding also poisoned Atlanta's politics. Even as honorable a politician as Andrew Young found himself squeezed between blacks insistent on a slice of the action and whites resistant to black leadership. "Race relations?" Jacoby quotes an unidentified supporter of racial integration as saying. "We don't have race relations in Atlanta anymore."
From her moral tales, Jacoby suggests that the most important decisions Americans of all races have to make is whether integration is really what they want. Should they decide it is, they will then have to face up to its heavy responsibilities. Integration cannot take place without acculturation, which "is a long, slow process -- one that will require a kind of patience till now largely lacking on race matters." It will also require local black and white cooperation, more effective and responsible leadership and a retreat from color coding, none of them easy to bring about. Jacoby's contribution to our national conversation on race is a sharp admonition for everyone to just grow up.
But will people listen? Jacoby's research is prodigious and her narrative compelling. Unlike the way guilty white liberals in her book dealt with blacks, she accords African-American leaders the ultimate respect: criticism when criticism is due. Yet she does not make it easy for those who need to hear what she says. For one thing, Jacoby's unrelenting portrayal of racial demagogy fails to distinguish sufficiently between the genuine scoundrels and the merely opportunistic. Atlanta's politics-as-usual are hardly the same stuff as New York City's flirtation with social revolution; neither Maynard Jackson nor even Jesse Jackson -- who managed to link the killing of black children in Atlanta with Ronald Reagan and opponents of affirmative action -- is the moral equivalent of Sonny Carson.
A realist about race and politics, Jacoby nonetheless fails to ask what alternatives existed in Atlanta. The option of a long-term strategy for black economic development was not on the agenda there. What did exist was a choice between a building boom that would be all white and one that would, in the usual style of urban politics, broaden the claimants upon the public purse. Which is to say that for a black mayor, this was no choice at all. Jacoby's relentless negativity does not serve her well. To be sure, tensions between the races are strong in Atlanta. Yet Atlanta has also seen the most rapid growth of a black suburban middle class of any city in the country. Here is where the racial realists can cite proof for the thesis that race relations have dramatically improved in a relatively short period of time. By rarely acknowledging the good, Jacoby takes the sting out of the bad.
One of the great contributions made by America's racial realists is their insistence that real progress between the races has taken place in America. This, of course, is anathema to those pessimists convinced that whites will never accept blacks as full members of American society. Jacoby, who does not share the views of the pessimists, oddly shares their mood, only she attributes the failure of integration as much to black leaders as to white racists. To be sure, Jacoby professes her faith in integration, but the stories she tells, and the way she tells them, make her book seem at times to be the mirror image of works of black rage.
Her account would be a more persuasive treatment of blacks and whites if it were less black and white. Lost among the horror stories of the three cities whose history she tells is the fact that in each of those cities Americans of all races are intermingling with a frequency -- and with a willingness -- impossible as recently as the 1960's.
Jacoby is right to recall us to our faith in integration. Yet she is right to do so not because we have departed from integration's promise but because we have already achieved so many of its benefits.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

SECTION: Section 15; Page 12; Column 1; Women's Health 

LENGTH: 1703 words

HEADLINE: For Infertility Treatments, Now You're Covered, Now You're Not

BYLINE: By ANNE ADAMS LANG; Anne Adams Lang is a freelance journalist in New York who writes on politics and parenthood.

 BODY:
IT took Carla and Bruce P. three and a half gut-wrenching years of invasive medical treatments and more than $40,000 of their savings before Carla got pregnant in April. That makes them part of a small but growing population that beat what the New York State Task Force on Life and the Law recognizes as the "disease" of infertility.
Lucky? Indisputably. First because Carla, a legal assistant, and Bruce, a real-estate broker, succeeded when the biological odds are stacked against a 41-year-old woman conceiving even with high-tech intervention. Second because Carla's new insurance carrier, U.S. Healthcare, paid for the successful round of blood tests, sonograms, laboratory work, egg harvesting, in-vitro fertilization and implanting the resulting embryos. All this was performed by one of New York City's top reproductive medical teams, which was led by Dr. Cecilia Schmidt-Sarosi and her husband, Dr. Peter Sarosi, reproductive endocrinologists. 
 That insurance policy saved Carla and Bruce, who do not want their last name published, roughly $10,000 that they would have paid themselves if they had approached the managed-care company just one month later. On April 1, U.S. Healthcare, now merged with Aetna, canceled its coverage of in-vitro fertilization and other high-tech fertility treatments, making it available to employers only through a rider. "Because we were one of the few programs covering IVF, women flocked to us who could not find coverage elsewhere," said Jill Griffiths, a spokeswoman for Aetna Healthcare. The policy, she said, was simply too expensive to continue.
"We contacted them in March and when I read that the company had stopped the policy, my heart just dropped," Bruce said. "But we lucked out. We got coverage on a shoestring, and we just got in under the wire."
Insurance carriers are mostly like poltergeists haunting the field of reproductive medicine. They materialize with ephemeral policies that are changed or are withdrawn in a flash. Only about two weeks ago, for example, Group Health Insurance, one of the largest carriers in New York, announced that it is withdrawing its coverage for all assisted reproductive technology.
"Unless they operate in states with mandates to cover infertility treatments, such as Massachusetts, Illinois and Maryland, managed-care and indemnity insurers have ignored fertility coverage and gotten away with it," said Dr. Norbert Gleicher, who founded the Center for Human Reproduction, a Chicago-based chain of fertility treatment centers. "That's imminently about to change."
Dr. Gleicher, who recently contracted with Oxford Health Plans to do a joint venture with Columbia University, gave three reasons for the new interest in fertility coverage:
* Viagra. The White House decision to require Medicaid coverage of the drug that treats male sexual dysfunction, and mounting pressure on private insurance companies to do the same, has opened the floodgates to sexual-discrimination suits. "Once insurance companies conclude they have to cover Viagra, how can they not cover female infertility drugs?" Dr. Gleicher asked.
* Legal precedent. A police officer sued the city of Chicago for violating the Americans With Disabilities Act, saying infertility is a disability. "A disability is an impairment of a body system that inhibits a major life activity," said Patricia Collins, the lawyer who won the class-action suit this year. "The only question is whether procreation is a major life activity. My position is, if work is a major life activity, I would hope procreation is as well." Judge Susan B. Conlon agreed and the city settled, saying it would follow Illinois's guidelines.
* Economics. "Smart insurance companies are recognizing that it may be in their interest to cover, even to a limited extent, infertility because it brings an underground economy in fertility services above ground," Dr. Gleicher said. He explained that doctors often perform infertility treatments, like tubal surgeries, and list them as a different, often more costly procedure so that patients can secure coverage.
In a study to be published in September, William M. Mercer, a firm of human-resource consultants, concludes that the hidden costs of infertility treatments range from 27 cents to 50 cents a month for each member of the insurance plan. "Depending on co-pay arrangements and how well the plans are managed, it would cost in the neighborhood of 40 cents to 50 cents to provide coverage," said Lisa Astor, a consultant at Mercer. "Our thoughts are that employers are already paying for infertility whether they know it or not."
There is also a wave of consumer anger over the right to reproduce that threatens to engulf lawmakers in several states, including New York. Assemblyman David S. Sidikman has introduced a bill that would require insurers to cover the diagnosis and treatment of infertility. State Senator Seymour Lachman recently introduced a similar bill.
"People who make $250,000 a year are the ones swinging the out-of-pocket costs for assisted reproduction," said Pamela Madsen, the executive director of the New York chapter of Resolve, a support and advocacy group for infertile individuals. "Maybe they have to give up the vacation. The more middle class are giving up their homes, and the working poor are out of it altogether."
MRS. MADSEN and her husband gave birth to two children using IVF and, she said: "I have four embryos at Mount Sinai waiting for me in the freezer that I can't access. I'm tapped out, mortgaged out, credit-carded out. And we were lucky. We got our babies. We still live in a one-bedroom apartment. We had a nest egg when we got married; we had health insurance, and the system wasn't there for us. We are the norm."
Even without legislation forcing coverage, assisted-reproduction technology specialists are gearing up for change. "We're seeing more and more patients going to centers, which increases the volume and lowers the price," said Dr. Mark Sauer, the director of Columbia University's division of reproductive endocrinology. "Corporate groups, for-profit groups and H.M.O.'s are learning to split the heavy overhead of a university program like research, and streamline certain operations."
Managed care, Dr. Sauer said, could act as a great leveler, making fertility treatments "possible for people without the kind of resources to go to a fee-for-service boutique practice."
Dr. James Grifo, the head of New York University Medical Center's division of reproductive endocrinology, said his group is negotiating, albeit reluctantly, with a managed-care company. "We would prefer to control our own fate," he said. The problem is that large institutions like universities have less seed capital. "It's more onerous for them to start and support these kinds of programs," Dr. Grifo said.
Economic pressure has whittled the number of large academic medical institutions where new reproductive technologies are incubated. The many that remain need high volume, said Dr. Zev Rosenwaks, a professor of obstetrics and gynecology and the director of the New York Center for Reproductive Medicine and Infertility at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.
"We have over 100 staffers," Dr. Rosenwaks said. "You cannot run a program that's a good program, that has full research and all aspects of lab work without having a critical mass of patients."
THE Cornell program has grown to 750 patients a year from approximately 250 patients in 1988 to 1989. "We're constantly re-evaluating the costs," Dr. Rosenwaks added, while trying to accommodate a changing economic environment. That requires market savvy, which means, he said, being patient-friendly, including securing insurance coverage for IVF.
By contrast, Dr. Schmidt-Sarosi, noting that small can be profitable, said that a successful fertility clinic doesn't need the "heavy machinery of an academic setting."
"What do I need an academic telling me how to run my clinic?" said Dr. Schmidt-Sarosi, who recently left the clinical practice at New York University to open her own practice. "Our prices are competitive and lower. I don't have the overhead of hospitals. Those of us who practice look at what is the out-of-pocket cost. We streamline, so that if a patient is going to use drugs, we do IVF faster. It's more efficient."
As for managed care, she said it will probably bring down IVF costs to $5,000 per ovulation cycle from $10,000. That could lead her to consider joining a network of small, high-quality clinics to negotiate with good insurance companies.
Other practitioners have devised a kind of money-back guarantee approach to lowering costs. At the Shady Grove Fertility Center in Rockville, Md., for example, patients pay $18,000 up front for three full IVF cycles. Embryos are frozen and transferred without additional charges. If a patient doesn't take home a baby, the money, minus a deductible of $1,250 per cycle, is returned. "Then you still have money for adoption," said Dr. Michael Levy, a founder.
Diane Aronson, the executive director of Resolve, warns that such programs could be an incentive for doctors to implant more embryos than is medically sound, to maximize the chances of pregnancy on the first round. Ms. Aronson is also concerned about the possibility of unscrupulous clinic administrators practicing a bait-and-switch in which they lure patients with the promise of a money-back guarantee only to tell them that they don't qualify for that particular program.
Defending his practice, Dr. Levy said that every program could potentially exploit the consumer. "In a fee-for-service, it's unnecessary procedures; in capitated policies with a monetary limit, it's not doing necessary procedures, and in shared risk, it's by treating patients differently than you would treat others," he said. "When we looked at our data on shared risk, we analyzed whether we transferred more embryos, and we put back exactly the same number in fee-for-service."
He added: "I'd be very happy if there was no need for shared risk. In France, where it's covered, they do five times the amount of IVF as we do. There's a lot of politics hidden in this issue."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Cecilia Schmidt-Sarosi finds it is more cost-effective to run her own infertility practice, without the overhead of a hospital. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 15; Page 24; Column 1; Women's Health 

LENGTH: 1504 words

HEADLINE: Why Baked Catfish Holds Lessons for Their Hearts

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS; Frances Frank Marcus contributes to The New York Times from New Orleans.

DATELINE: UNIONTOWN, Ala.

 BODY:
DEEP in fried-catfish country, the meat bins of a small town's grocery store can be a nutritionist's bad dream. Browse the shelves: along with the ingredients for Southern staples like corn bread and fried chicken stretches a range of pig parts from head to foot, including brains and fatty ham hocks and tails. Pork chitlins for frying are available in 10-pound buckets; fatback by the slab. Fatty beef parts are popular, too. Lard flies off the shelves in eight-pound cans.
It is not surprising that heart disease, high-blood pressure, diabetes and obesity are common here. The diet dates to pre-Civil War days. The ancestors of many residents were slaves on Alabama's cotton plantations. For the town's 1,730 residents, there are three doctors, no hospitals, no ambulances, no 911 service. The population is 79 percent African-American; the jobless rate is edging toward 14 percent. The median family income is $12,469. 
 Uniontown, therefore, seems an unlikely place for a pioneering women's health study. But for a year and a half, academic researchers have been teaching women here how to stay well by changing their behavior: by exercising more, not smoking and doing the unthinkable -- banishing collard greens smothered in fatback and other traditional, high-fat favorites in the rural South. The study is focusing on prevention of cardiovascular disease, the nation's major killer of men and women, although research scientists and health professionals say most women view heart disease as a malady that primarily threatens men.
"Cardiovascular disease continues as the leading cause of death for women in the United States," said Dr. Carol Cornell, an assistant professor in the behavioral medicine unit at the University of Alabama, Birmingham, and the principal investigator for the study. "It kills almost twice as many women as all cancers combined."
African-American women are at particular risk, Dr. Cornell said, noting, "They are more likely to be overweight and less likely to engage in physical exercise."
A key part of the study is the program's instructors, who actually live here, acting like cheerleaders for good health. It is a carefully chosen team of 10 women as well as a teen-age girl and boy, who are viewed in the town as "natural helpers." These team members have been designated as community health advisers. They run the cooking, exercise and smoking-cessation clubs, which focus on disease prevention among African-American women age 40 and older but are not limited to them.
Using the leaders of a community to instill good health habits in low-income regions is "very appropriate," said Dr. Anuradha Rao, a cardiologist who directs the women's heart program at Tulane University Medical Center, in New Orleans. Tulane and Xavier University, also in New Orleans, are starting a similar project next month in one of the city's public housing sites.
Uniontown was chosen partly because its leading politician, State Representative Andrew Hayden, pushed for it. The study, to cost $2 million over five years, is part of a program sponsored by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, with financing coming from the National Institutes of Health and its Women's Health Initiative.
In early May, the big question was whether low-fat catfish would please everyone at a supper in the Uniontown recreation center, one of a series showcasing revered family recipes purged of their sins by two Auburn University nutritionists.
In a predinner interview, the project's community coordinator, Mary Slater, a retired Uniontown high-school teacher, said good habits have already become a permanent idea among many people here. About 70 people participate as cooks and tasters in the nutrition program, and 75 to 100 people now exercise regularly. Fifteen to 20 people have shown up at the less-popular quit-smoking classes.
Except for three team members, who are Vista workers and therefore receive a small stipend, the community health advisers are unpaid. What they have gained instead is self-confidence.
"I tell the people who come here that this is our project," Ms. Slater said. At a health fair last October, she and the advisers took their aerobics class to the streets, line-dancing in front of Uniontown's City Hall. "As you know," she said, "women have always carried the big end of the stick. Men look to us for everything, but they place us on a back burner."
Patricia L. Riley, the director of the C.D.C.'s prevention-research-center program, added, "It's amazing what's happened in a community like this that's so rural and so resource-bereft." She was referring to the zest she sees for cooking classes and exercising.
"We're telling the community that to be healthy, you don't have to have gyms," Ms. Riley said. "We're building on community talent with women who are cooking for their children and passing on behavior patterns to their children and their children's children."
By late afternoon, Uniontown was hungry for catfish, which came from farm ponds nearby and was then cleaned and sliced at the town's big catfish plant. The supper menu was really born-again soul food. The low-fat, golden brown catfish had been baked with a sprinkling of lemon juice, garlic powder and parsley flakes. The country-style green beans were flavored with low-fat smoked turkey breast, not bathed in pork fat. The fudgy brownies were prepared with prune puree and egg whites.
Before digging in, the diners first had to ponder the nutritionists' sermon on the evils of fat, sodium and heaping helpings of sugar. "If you eat a dill pickle you eat a teaspoon of salt," intoned Barbara Struempler, a professor in the department of nutrition and food science at Auburn University. "Salt adds up very quickly. The average American eats eight and a half pounds a year."
The crowd of 60, many dressed in flowery print dresses and suits appropriate for the prayer meetings they would be attending later on, sat at a U-shaped dining table as Dr. Struempler and her colleague, Faye Hall Jones, recited a litany of virtuous eating for her largely female audience.
Supper began with a certain self-consciousness for the day of reckoning: was baked catfish palatable enough to compete with deliciously wicked fried? Does it have a future in rural Alabama, where iron skillets are handed down generation to generation?
The first reviews were respectful but not wildly enthusiastic. "I really enjoyed the baked catfish," Ira Dozier, a teacher and a project manager for a middle-school enrichment program, told a visitor after a brief deliberation. "I've never liked baked fish before. The brownies were, well, different. They tasted like Fig Newtons."
Ellen P. Jones, a retired teacher, said dubiously: "Baked fish is better because you don't get all that fat. But I don't know how my husband's going to like it." She was carrying home a covered plate of some fish for him to try.
EXPLAINING the recipe short cuts -- using garlic powder instead of fresh, for example -- Dr. Struempler told a visitor: "We've found out that these mothers and grandmothers don't like to cook anymore than anyone else. We're into quick and dirty techniques."
Her toughest fat-cutting job? "Corn bread -- it had to be changed four times to get a product that was tasty and had a good mouth feel." The most practical tool to get fat off the meat? Scissors, which Dr. Struempler has distributed liberally to cooking club members.
The next evening, 22 women were line-dancing at the Community Life Center, the project's headquarters, after a warm-up and some stretching and step aerobics. The night was steamy, the room not air-conditioned, but the women pressed on. Nearby, in an old ballpark, some Uniontownites strode around a track where a team of municipal and volunteer workers had cleared trash and repaired lights.
One exerciser, Winnie Marie Scott, who is the town's librarian, said: "I have arthritis, but I exercise anyway. You walk, you stretch, inhale, exhale and feel much better when it's over."
The study's full findings won't be known until the project is evaluated in the year 2000, but there are signs of progress.
Since Della Smith, an adviser, began line-dancing and eating less salt last year, her blood pressure has dropped from borderline high to low, 107 over 71. "Before, my walking was not regular at all," she said. "Now, when I'm in town, I park a few blocks away from the post office and walk."
Watching the crowd leaving the dining hall after the catfish meal, Dr. Struempler said: "To do a year and a half community project and still have this participation is overwhelming. Many of these intervention programs die a slow death. This one has been just the opposite. It has picked up." At the very least, a community dinner in Uniontown is a big social event.
Next on the agenda is this month's lower-fat food fair -- baked chicken, potato salad and fruity iced tea for 200, along with a drink developed at Tuskegee University made of sweet potatoes.

HEADLINE: Word & Image;
Nuclear Reactions

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
Much of my adult life, I have unwittingly encouraged the spread of atomic weapons. Like most American reporters and editors, I have been a mostly silent partner in my country's utopian but arrogant diplomacy to limit membership in the nuclear club. We have conferred special status and prestige on nations that know how to blow up the world and let American, British, Russian, Chinese and French officials strut importantly in international forums because they had the bomb. And yet we conspired in the pretense that other nations could not be trusted with atomic arsenals.
Now that India and Pakistan have made it unmistakable that they possess the bomb -- and have surely aroused bomb envy in other places -- it is time to give account for our folly. 
 For decades, the media have given universal support to the utopian project known as Nonproliferation, a treaty-bound hoarding of atomic weaponry by the self-appointed guardian nations. They are pledged to withhold nuclear-weapons secrets and fuels from all other nations and to press them to renounce all A-bomb ambition. The founding members have sat smugly inside the club; those outside at midcentury were to be forever excluded.
Fat chance, I fleetingly thought. While agitating to get other Governments to sign the global nonproliferation treaty, the nuclear nations never once thought of giving up their own atomic bombs. The treaty of 1968 promised "progress" to end atomic arms races "at an early date," but that was mere boilerplate. The haves were convinced from the start that their status in the world, if not also their safety, required an atomic arsenal, even as they lectured others to renounce the weapons for their own good. This message affronted human nature as well as logic, but nonetheless defined American policy.
And we in the media routinely endorsed the flimflammery. Even as we campaigned against every other kind of segregation and discrimination, we rarely questioned the perverse logic of nonproliferation: that exclusion was a benefit for the excluded.
Groucho Marx said the only clubs he wouldn't join were the ones that would have him, I once said to McGeorge Bundy, the national security adviser to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. Don't you think most human beings pine to join the clubs from which they are barred?
You're absolutely right, Bundy replied. For the long run, it's an unnatural, untenable policy. But it's a delaying game. For now, the fewer the fingers on atomic triggers, the better off we are.
Despite their arguments for exclusivity, the founding members of the nuclear club demonstrated multiple motives for acquiring the bomb. The United States proved against Japan that a have-nation could knock out a have-not overnight and save a million infantry lives. The Russians, though impoverished at the end of World War II, proved that nuclear and thermonuclear weapons made their country an instant superpower. As Bundy later wrote in his history of the A-bomb, the British wanted their own bomb not as a response to military threat but out of an "almost instinctive" feeling that it would define their strength in a post-colonial age. The French built A-bombs to gain a vote in the club about their use, to match the British and to lord it over the Germans. And the Chinese barged in to challenge the "hegemonists" in Moscow and Washington.
Nonetheless, the United States and the American media proclaimed "nonproliferation" to be a virtue, and proliferation, open or secret, a vice. We deemed it natural that the C.I.A. should spy on every nation's laboratories. We cheered when Congress decreed economic punishment for nations caught building the bomb, whether they were foes like Iran, Iraq, South Africa, Libya and North Korea or friends like Argentina, Brazil, India and Pakistan.
Over the years, more than 40 nations acquired the reactors needed for nuclear research or power and probably a dozen acquired the fuels and know-how needed to stockpile explosive "devices" that could be quickly turned into bombs. Israel did that to protect itself in a sea of hostile neighbors but avoided sanctions by denying it had "a bomb." Pakistan started building atomic devices 25 years ago and India tested one in 1974, probably to impress China after a brief border war. There was thus no technological reason for India to ostentatiously test an A-bomb last month; like America and the Soviet Union of the Sputnik era, it used engineering prowess to raise the morale of its people and the stature of its politicians. Then Pakistan, a weaker rival, could do no less.
Among the advanced industrial nations, only Germany and Japan, the big losers in World War II, responded to international pressure and promised never to build atomic weapons. They chose, uniquely, to gain global respect by building economically strong societies. But even their restraint is unlikely to survive the atomic anarchy now unfolding.
As Americans, we should have insisted that "I've got mine, Jack" is not a formula for communal safety. Precisely because we give the world so much reason to admire our politics, our economics and our culture, it also desires our weaponry.
The most practical argument against proliferation is that mere possession of the bomb can never yield protection. True deterrence of an enemy requires an atomic force that can survive an attack and respond in kind. But as India and Pakistan are now proving, that will only intensify the quest for better missiles and extend their costly arms race.
If I and other observers had resisted the nuclear club's double standard and exposed its hollow assumptions about human nature, the world might by now have devised more effective international controls over atomic weapons. The have-nots might have been appeased if they had been given a major voice in a strong international inspection agency and the right to pry even into the monopolists' stockpiles -- including ours. Instead we have wasted the half century since Hiroshima and provoked a chain reaction that is truly prolific.

HEADLINE: The Wei That Wasn't

BYLINE: By Philip Caputo; Philip Caputo is author, most recently, of "Exiles," a collection of novellas, and of "A Rumor of War," a Vietnam memoir.

 BODY:
He sniffs the cigarettes first, draws them lengthwise under his nose and then lights them one after the other, the smoke curling in the soft bronze light that flows through his west window. "River light," the novelist John Cheever called that luminescence peculiar to New York City mornings. It does seem to rise off the Hudson before it enters the room where Wei Jingsheng sits and talks about the regime that imprisoned him for all but a few months of the last 18 years, before releasing him into exile in November.
"The Chinese Communist Party is indeed the evil empire," he says, echoing President Reagan. "If the Soviet Union was the evil empire, then the Chinese Communist regime is an even greater one -- or at least a slyer one." 
 That's a reference to the recent scandals involving the satellite industry and campaign contributions by Chinese nationals to the Democratic Party. "The Chinese Government is continuously trying to spread its influence and build its strength," he says. "The Chinese Communists have always used these methods. Perhaps only now with this evidence will more Americans pay more attention to it, and to their schemes. It should serve as a very clear warning."
Under the circumstances, Wei says, President Clinton clearly should have canceled the trip he is scheduled to embark on this week. "I believe Clinton, under these conditions, should not go. Clinton has not said what he plans to say or do, so I feel that he won't stray from the path of the wishes of the Chinese Communists. If he doesn't say clearly what he will do, then I believe it is a mistake to go under these conditions.
"If he does finally appear at Tiananmen Square -- although I think that would be a major political mistake -- then he should state clearly his support for the struggle, his sympathy for those who were killed and injured and his commitment to pressing for the release of the democracy activists still in prison. If he doesn't do these things, then his appearance may damage his standing in the eyes of every single Chinese. He should not adhere to the conditions attached by the Communists."
The President's trip is a kind of benchmark for Wei, who, with Wang Dan, a leading figure in the 1989 Tiananmen Square uprising, shares billing as China's most famous dissident. Clinton's presence in China, surrounded by his beaming hosts, provides a platform that has been largely missing in Wei's seven months of exile. The attention could help him press his campaign against Clinton's policy of "engagement" and cement his position as the primary spokesman for the dissidents. But it could just as easily backfire, if his ideas are brushed aside or, as Beijing so fervently hopes, dismissed as irrelevant.
Certainly, Wei is not silent; his recorded message to a crowd of thousands in Hong Kong in early June -- commemorating the ninth anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre -- made headlines around the world. But the questions linger: How many are listening? Whom does he speak for? And not just in the West, but in China as well. More immediately, did Wei make the right decision when he relented and accepted Beijing's offer of exile?
To most people, there would have been no choice whatsoever: whether to remain in prison or to accept an offer of medical parole and exile. But Wei is not like most people.
If he were, he never would have been imprisoned in the first place, for the crime of speaking his mind. He never would have endured, merely for refusing to recant his belief in democracy, solitary confinement in a cell where a bright light burned 24 hours a day, frequent beatings from other inmates and conditions so abysmal that he lost a dozen teeth and contracted high blood pressure, heart disease, arthritis and hepatitis during his two separate incarcerations.
In 1995, at the beginning of his second prison term, he was made an offer that few thought he could refuse: he would be freed if he accepted exile in the United States. He had become an international cause celebre, and the regime of President Jiang Zemin wanted to be rid of him. He had written, besides his incendiary public essays, impertinent (and often humorous) letters to Deng Xiaoping, China's late paramount leader, and was now making Jiang his new pen pal.
Execution was one option, but Wei was too famous to be dealt with so crudely. China wanted trade with the West, and international respectability. Clearly, the only thing to do with Wei was to export him. But he declined the offer, not once but twice.
"Wei didn't want to leave China because by being there, he would be a player," explains Philip Cunningham, a journalist and China scholar who edited a collection of Wei's prison letters to Deng and Jiang. "He wanted to be there even in jail rather than free in exile because the danger of exile is that you become irrelevant." But last fall, Wei finally accepted banishment. On Nov. 16, 1997, he was released from prison, taken to a Northwest Airlines plane in Beijing and flown to the United States.
What made him change his stand? We are in the small but comfortable apartment he occupies at Columbia University, where he is a visiting scholar. He is a stocky man of about 5 feet 8 or 9 inches, 48 years old, with a full head of black hair. There is no hint of gray. His youthful, robust appearance is miraculous, considering what he has been through.
"Two reasons," he answers through an interpreter. "My health was quickly deteriorating. So I had two choices. One was to leave the country, the other to die in prison. I felt there was no reason for me to die in prison for no worthy cause."
Wei slips another Marlboro out of the pack and lights up. "The second, which is more important, is that in recent years, the position of the Western countries toward the Chinese Communist Party has been softening, which has dealt a blow to the confidence of the Chinese people. It is important for me to come out and tell Western Governments the real situation, the realities in China and what effective roles they can play, and also to convey what the Chinese people would really like to say to the people of the Western countries."
That ought to be enough to keep 10 men busy. But after some thought, Wei gives me a third reason: he hopes to coordinate the activities of pro-democracy dissidents abroad. In effect, he would become the leader of the dissident movement, which could be far more difficult than persuading Western Governments to amend their China policies. The 500 or so active dissidents in this country are hopelessly fragmented by petty squabbles, jealousies and differences in opinion about how best to deal with Beijing.
It's a difficult agenda for a man who has little support other than his name and the enormous respect and good will it commands. Columbia provides Wei with an office and clerical assistance, but he does not teach or lecture on a regular basis. Rising at 9 A.M., he usually works late into the night, conferring with other dissidents.
Wei is determined not to retire to the scholar's cloister, as many other exiled dissidents have done. And yet, looking at him, dressed in slippers, a beige cotton shirt and gray trousers held up by black suspenders, his legs folded on a threadbare couch as he sips tea and smokes and smokes, it is hard to picture him maneuvering in the corridors of power.
He has tried, but to little effect. This winter, he traveled to London, Paris and Brussels, where he lobbied the European Union to ratify a United Nations resolution condemning China's human rights record. In the spring, after the 15-nation European Union voted not even to introduce the resolution, much less to pass it, Wei embarked on a 12-nation, seven-week tour of European capitals, calling on foreign secretaries and members of parliament to explain their decision.
He fared no better with the Clinton Administration, which in a reversal of longstanding policy, also withdrew support for the resolution this year. And now, in a further disappointment, President Clinton is off to China.
To Wei, there is no compromise with Beijing, no engagement and no partnership. "Clinton has an opportunity. I want him to make his support for human rights and democracy clear. If he does not do this, then he will not help the movement and he will not help the standing of himself and the United States in the eyes of the Chinese people. I think that Clinton's use of the word 'partnership' is completely wrong, since the Chinese Communists use the word 'enemy' in describing the United States. I don't think the American people want a partner like the Chinese Communists."
When Wei speaks, his baritone barely changes inflection and, whatever may be going on inside him, he gives an outward impression of serenity. Yet the position he has staked out for himself is nearly impossible. Here is a man without a political party or power of any kind beyond the moral authority vouchsafed by his sufferings, appointing himself roving ambassador for one-fifth of the world's population, trying to shape American foreign policy. I wonder if I'm in the presence of a Chinese Don Quixote, or a man who could become to China what Vaclav Havel is to the Czech Republic or Nelson Mandela is to South Africa.
There is a certain purity about Wei, but it's hard to tell sometimes if it is the purity of an egomaniac or a saint. Others have commented on Wei's saintly qualities: his lack of bitterness, his heroic readiness to sacrifice himself on the altar of principle, his unflagging composure. But in time, I realize that Wei is neither saint nor egomaniac. He is a man of integrity -- integrity in its fundamental meaning: he is united within himself. God knows, he had plenty of time, in the isolation of his cell, to think things through. He has emerged as a man with a seamless confidence in himself and in the truth of his ideas.
Wei has hundreds, if not thousands, of admirers and supporters in the West. Among many Chinese dissidents, he is an icon. Even those who disagree with his views on China are in awe of his courage and his ability to write and argue in clear, direct, forceful language.
But will that be enough? Now that Wei is out of prison and no longer a myth, there are dissidents as well as Western diplomats and scholars who think that his ideas are outdated and that Wei himself, though unquestionably a hero, is a hero from a bygone era. They question whether he is the right candidate to lead the dissident movement and to convey realities in China to Western leaders. They say that Wei, having been isolated for so long, clings to views and rhetoric frozen in the amber of the cold war.
"The more Wei speaks out, the more he reveals that he doesn't know the current situation," says Merle Goldman, a professor of Chinese history at Boston University and an expert on the dissident movement. "Through no fault of his own -- he was in prison for all but a few months of the last 18 years -- he has no clear idea what is going on in China or abroad."
The China of the 1990's is not the China of the 1970's under Mao, she notes. A rudimentary democracy has taken hold at the village level, where elections have been held this year. Although open dissent is still prohibited, citizens privately criticize the Government in ways that would have been unthinkable 25 years ago. It is a much more prosperous and at least somewhat freer country. When I mention to her that Wei has said that "millions of workers and peasants in China are truly starving," she exclaims, "That's not true!" and adds that Wei's penchant for injudicious comments like that could undermine his credibility.
Wei's defenders say it's too early to judge him, after only a little more than seven months in exile. "We're honoring him for his courage, not necessarily because he's an astute politician," says Robert Bernstein, the founding chairman of Human Rights Watch. "We don't know about that yet. Wei has sacrificed for his ideas and deserves a chance. Besides, it never hurts to put pressure on the regime."
Chen Xiaoping, a 36-year-old former journalist and law professor now studying at Harvard, was forced to leave China because of his pro-democracy activities. He says the youngest dissidents -- of whom Wang Dan is the most prominent -- almost literally don't understand the language that Wei speaks. When Wei gave a talk at Harvard, Chen says, "Some students asked him: 'Where are you coming from? This is traditional, not modern discourse.' He was talking like somebody from the Cultural Revolution.
"Wei is too old," Chen adds flatly. "In jail for 18 years, and because he was in prison for such a long time, he cannot understand the modern China."
The obvious implication is that the 29-year-old Wang, who was serving an 11-year sentence when released to American doctors this spring, understands China better -- the China, that is, of young entrepreneurs bearing cell phones instead of Mao's little red book. Wang's opinion on Clinton's visit does seem to be more nuanced than Wei's. "I feel extremely uncomfortable when I think about President Clinton walking on Tiananmen Square," Wang says. "But I understand that United States policy toward China should represent the interests of the American people. I just hope it also represents the moral standards of the American people."
Aware of the force his words carry in the dissident community, Wang, who is spending the summer at Harvard, adds diplomatically: "Both Mr. Wei Jingsheng and I believe that to promote a peaceful transformation toward democracy in China, international influence is crucial."
Almost no one disagrees with Wei's objectives: building a China where people aren't arrested without charges and tortured in prison, where workers trying to organize independent labor unions aren't crushed and freedom of speech and expression are not repressed.
Besides, as Bernstein points out, it's not as though the younger dissidents are accomplishing any more than Wei. "They aren't getting results, either," he says. "Of course there's more economic freedom. Of course the party is giving ground politically -- it has no choice."
The difference between Wei and his loyal critics is in figuring out how to get there from here. For Wei, the correct approach -- the only approach -- is to get tough. But this does not mean the complete suspension of relations, says Xiao Qiang of the organization Human Rights in China. "We don't want to fall into the trap of isolation versus engagement," he says. "We want a strong and effective human rights policy, on an equal footing with trade and security policy."
Wei puts it more succinctly. Dealing with China, he says, is like dealing with a "scoundrel on the street": the nicer you are, the more likely you are to get mugged.
Wei's history is a history of fighting dragons. He was born in 1950 in Beijing, where his father was a high-level official in the foreign ministry while his mother was a party cadre in a shoe-and-hat factory. A self-described "fanatical Maoist" as a teen-ager, he graduated in 1966 from a top high school reserved for party higher-ups and went into the countryside as a Red Guard during the tumultuous Cultural Revolution. But the stunning poverty he saw, and the unspeakable horrors wrought by Mao's policies -- like a village so ravaged by starvation that people sold their dying infants as food -- led him to condemn the Great Helmsman.
Wei gained international fame with the publication of his classic essay, "The Fifth Modernization: Democracy." Posted on the Democracy Wall in Beijing on Dec. 5, 1978, the essay exploded the myth that Deng Xiaoping's "four modernizations" -- radical economic reforms that excluded any political change -- would improve the lot of the masses. Wei argued that without true democracy all promises of a better life for China would remain just that.
Later, in another essay, "Do We Want Democracy or New Autocracy," he dared to attack Deng by name. Within a week, he was arrested, and then was sentenced to the first of his prison terms. Though he'd been held incommunicado, he remained defiant at his trial. Refusing to repudiate his criticisms, he proved himself to be not the passive victim of an authoritarian state but an agent of history, the author of his own tragic destiny.
Orville Schell, a China scholar at Berkeley and a strong Wei supporter, portrays him as both militant and ascetic, a kind of warrior monk who "stripped himself bare" of material possessions and emotional attachments so he could wage his lonely battle with despots unencumbered.
My own impression is of a solitary existential rebel straight out of the pages of Camus. Martyr, warrior-monk, existential rebel, I can hear all three incarnations speaking to me in the Manhattan apartment as he tells me that Clinton should demand greater democratization from Jiang's Government as a quid pro quo for a greater share of the American market.
So far, he says, the only beneficiaries of United States-China trade have been a few large corporations -- and Jiang's regime. The profits reaped by companies like Boeing and Motorola, as well as from European enterprises in China, have strengthened Beijing's hand and emboldened it to stifle all political opposition. "It's these corporations coming to China and cooperating closely with the Chinese Communist Party that has created a very bad image among the Chinese people of the U.S., of the American people, who they think care only about money and don't care about democracy and human rights."
Proponents of engagement contend that modernization is creating a middle and professional class that could eventually form the nucleus of a political opposition, and that a take-no-prisoners policy would isolate China and prove counterproductive. The examples of North Korea, Iraq, Libya and Cuba suggest that isolation, embargo, military action and other hardball tactics tend to perpetuate dictatorships rather than eliminate them.
But Wei finds his critics' arguments lacking in substance. Rather than re-examine his thinking, they should "re-examine their thinking," he says. "I don't believe my thinking at any point over the past 20 years has once been outdated. But I ask, What evidence is there to support their new thinking? Is the new thinking to cozy up to the Chinese Communist Government and turn away from their behavior? Where has that gotten us?"
Each year, gathering around a polished oval table in the Art Nouveau meeting room of the Norwegian Nobel Institute in Oslo, five members of the Nobel committee decide who will be the recipient of its Peace Prize. The award is given to pioneers of organized peace work, politicians and, in recent times, to human rights advocates. Wei has been nominated for the prize four years in a row, the last two years in concert with Wang Dan.
"Wei has stood up in the finest traditions of an Andrei Sakharov," Schell says. "All alone, he has stood against the gale force of a very powerful and intimidating state with dignity and intellectual clarity."
Former laureates like Oscar Arias Sanchez, Elie Wiesel and the Dalai Lama, American legislators like Jesse Helms and Nancy Pelosi, a Democratic representative from California, and several hundred professors from around the world have signed on to Wei's nomination.
In its glossy official booklet, the Nobel Institute makes it clear that well-organized campaigns have little influence on the committee's decisions and "may in fact be counterproductive." Thus, the effort to promote Wei's candidacy is almost by design low key and ad hoc.
The Chinese Government, meanwhile, has been doing what it can to undermine the nomination. Its campaign is also low key, for if the committee frowns at stumping for a particular candidate, attempts to knock a candidate out of the running really make it bristle.
But it is no secret that one of the last things President Jiang wants to see on CNN this December is Wei Jingsheng marching side by side with Wang Dan into the Oslo Town Hall to make a laureate's speech. Such a scene would represent several dangers for the Chinese Communist Party. For one, the prize could enhance Wei's already considerable stature, turning him into a giant around whom the fragmented dissident movement abroad might finally rally and unite. Pelosi notes that the prize would also encourage dissidents inside China.
Finally, there is the danger to China's pride.
The Nobel Prize sounds prestigious to people in China," says Xiao Qiang, of Human Rights in China. The 36-year-old former astrophysicist, who turned dissident after the Tiananmen Square crackdown, notes that no citizen of the People's Republic of China has ever won a Nobel in any category. It would be a symbolic blow to Jiang and his Government if the first were to be shared by two dissidents who had spent years in jail.
This perception has led to speculation that the regime has taken advantage of the fissures and jealousies within the democracy movement and recruited dissidents to discredit Wei and derail his nomination. Last year, a prominent dissident in China, Ren Wanding, sent an open letter to the Nobel committee, pleading with its members not to give the prize to Wei. The 52-year-old Wanding, who himself spent 11 years in prison, then called a news conference in Beijing and told foreign reporters that Wei was "not a symbol of Chinese democracy," and that his Western supporters were making a god of him. In November, a week after Wei's release, another veteran dissident, Xu Wenli, publicly rapped Wei for being conceited, for failing to recognize other dissidents' achievements and for being too soft on Deng Xiaoping.
Were Ren's and Xu's comments another example of disarray in the movement, or was something more sinister going on? Xiao leans toward the darker view.
"For the last two years, no dissident in China can call a press conference to say anything," he tells me amid the boxes and file folders of his cramped office. "They're not even allowed to have a birthday party.. . .Wanding, Xu, all dissidents are under 24-hour surveillance. The Government knows where they're at, what they're doing. Ren Wanding then calls a press conference for foreign reporters in Bejing to speak against Wei? It never would have happened without Government sanction or tolerance. Draw your own conclusions."
Wei has already drawn his. After telling me that he initially did not take the attacks too seriously, regarding Ren and Xu as "old friends," he says in a tone of regret that the two men have gone over to the other side. "We have no direct evidence or proofs of any sort," he quickly adds. "However, this is definitely not coincidental that after many years of silence, they should voice these criticisms. They are coordinating with the Chinese Communists to sabotage the work of the democracy movement."
There are nevertheless China scholars -- as well as Chinese dissidents definitely not in collusion with Beijing -- who also question Wei's nomination. They say he doesn't deserve it any more than several others who have suffered for their commitment to democracy.
Zhang Weiguo, a 42-year-old exile who posts a dissident Website, "New Century Net," out of his office in Berkeley, Calif., explains that some of these critics are merely envious, while others have legitimate concerns. "Why are there different opinions about Wei?" Zhang asks. "If Wei becomes the authority for democracy, then some fear their voices will be overwhelmed. If Wei is conferred with the mantle of democracy, then, these people fear, he will become a kind of cult figure, defeating the whole purpose of pluralism."
Those who view Wei in this light say he is wasting his energies and valuable moral capital, charging off in different directions, criticizing Western policies before he's had time to study the issues thoroughly. What he should do now, they advise, is learn English, work on his autobiography, establish his credentials as a political thinker and build support in the dissident community.
In the end, it is impossible to form a single opinion or impression of so complex a man. The skepticism voiced about his ideas and approach to the West's China policies appeals to the mind; but Wei's unflagging spirit, commitment and courage appeal to the heart. A lot of his critics are intellectuals, and intellectuals tend to distrust clarity, simplicity and directness even when what's clear and simple is the truth. And I think that Wei does speak the truth when he says that the interests of the Chinese Communist Party will never be the same as, but ever in opposition to, the real interests of the Chinese people.
As for Wei's spirit, those scholars and friends advising him to retire to the study and write and develop his intellectual resources may not be misleading him, but they are probably misreading him. Besides, there is something tepid about such counsel. To borrow an old, old phrase, it does not have the power to stir men's souls. Many other dissidents have followed that route, and it doesn't appear to have helped the cause of democracy in China or to have unified Chinese political exiles.
That said, Wei does need to brief himself on current conditions, in this country and his own. In the words of Cunningham, Wei's editor, Wei may not be a "first-class intellectual, but of all the prominent dissidents, he has "the appeal and spirit, the personality and the charisma, all the credentials to unify that fractious movement." But he will lose credibility if he doesn't catch up on all that happened in the world while he was in prison. It does neither himself nor his cause any good to paint Jiang's China in the chiaroscuro pigments of Mao's China, where people, literally, were forced to devour their children.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Jamaica Sweeps Off Its Welcome Mat

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
MORE than a million tourists have visited Jamaica in each of the past 10 years, and last year's count soared to 1.9 million. Much of that increase can be attributed to the growing number of cruise ship passengers, including 700,000 in 1997. But tourism officials in Jamaica fear that the recent pervasive harassment of visitors, which Prime Minister Percival J. Patterson called the single biggest problem facing the island's tourist industry, could put an end to a profitable source of income.
 To forestall that possibility, last month Jamaica increased fines by a whopping 100-fold on those who badger and otherwise harass tourists. Penalties for first-time offenders who badger tourists to buy or barter for drugs, sex and merchandise were raised to about $2,700 from $27, while fines for repeat offenders were raised to about $4,100 from $41. Jamaica also established night courts, making it possible for law enforcement officers to appear in court without having to abandon their beats. 
 "It's a little too early to say how well the fines are working, but we know we have a problem and we are determined to deal with it," said Stephanie Belcher, executive director of the island's Tourism Product Development Company, an arm of the Government.
 That observation was seconded by Karen Ford-Warner, director general of the office of the Prime Minister for Tourism, who is nevertheless pleased by early anecdotal evidence. "One cruise director told us he had already seen a remarkable transformation in the streets," she said.
 The recent no-nonsense crackdown follows a number of promised crackdowns that were either quickly abandoned or whose fines were negligible and thus ineffectual. But now the stakes are higher than ever. Tourism is by far Jamaica's biggest and most important industry, accounting for 45 percent of its $595.1 million foreign exchange, for 13.7 percent of its $6.2 billion gross domestic product and for one in every four jobs. Those percentages are among the highest in the Caribbean, a region that in turn is among the most heavily dependent on tourism in the world.
 Beyond that, Caribbean islands are increasingly competing with Florida, Mexico and other warm-weather destinations for North American tourists, who make up most of their visitors, including about 60 percent in the case of Jamaica. To add to Jamaica's woes, Canadian and European tourists have recently discovered Cuba, whose desperation for dollars has resulted in lower-priced vacation packages.
 Both the recent crackdown and the harassment that led to it have been building for some time. After the winter season of 1996-97 four cruise lines threatened to pull out of Montego Bay because of it, and Celebrity Cruises' Mercury did leave at the end of last year, substituting the Mexican port of Calica on the Yucatan peninsula. But Celebrity's Century still stops at Ocho Rios every two weeks, as do other ships. Carnival Cruise Line ships continue to call at Montego Bay and Ocho Rios. "We have gotten complaints about harassment," said Jennifer de la Cruz, a Carnival spokeswoman, "but not enough to negate our passengers' positive experiences by calling at Jamaica."
 But even the Tourism Product Development Company reported that 56 percent of those who responded to a visitor satisfaction survey last year said they were hassled to buy drugs, were followed, badgered for sex or pushed into taxis -- not just at the docks but elsewhere, especially in shopping areas. Last summer anti-harassment teams arrested many pimps, illegal taxi drivers and touts at the airports in Montego Bay and Kingston.
 That sweep followed by one month the warning from Prime Minister Patterson that "people are going to refuse to come to Jamaica, resulting in a virtual collapse of the tourism industry because of harassment." He added that no matter how enjoyable the beaches, the views or the music, if visitors are the subject of constant harassment, they simply will not return. While most Jamaicans are hospitable, he said, the "miscreants" had to be dealt with decisively, and that meant stiff fines.
 One reason the higher fines were not levied before last month is that the problem was widely thought to be a consequence of unemployment, a result of Jamaica's declining sugar and banana industries. Unemployment is still high -- 16.5 percent, according to the Statistical Institute of Jamaica -- but the risk of driving away tourists is now regarded as worse than the risks involved in cracking down. At the same time, though, the Government plans to invest about $1 million to establish craft villages in the major resort towns of Montego Bay, Ocho Rios, Negril and Port Antonio, and to provide training in job skills related to tourism.
 Mrs. Belcher, for one, has no illusions that expenditures for craft villages and for teaching job skills are a complete answer. "You do have some hardened criminals who have no desire to hold jobs," she said, "but that's why we also increased the fines."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Newport

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD; BARBARA LLOYD, who spends her summers near Newport, writes about yacht racing for The Times.

 BODY:
As if just waking from one of its historic slumbers, the city of Newport has recently emerged from a recession that seemed to hang on longer than elsewhere in New England. But now the feeling of vitality is everywhere -- from the fresh paint on 18th-century houses to the flower boxes on storefronts; from new restaurants downtown to the yachts large and small in Newport Harbor.
The sound of hammer on nail signals a new prosperity. But Newport is still learning how to deal with its fate as a burgeoning tourist town. Stricter controls on late-night soirees have quieted neighborhood din. And limitations on rental property have routed out overcrowded party houses. 
 With the changes, Newport seems willing to throw open its doors a little wider to visitors. What other city, after all, can claim such historic sites as the Wanton-Lyman-Hazard House, built around 1675, its oldest home; the Touro Synagogue, built in 1763, the oldest synagogue in North America; the Redwood Library, celebrating its 250th anniversary, the oldest library building in continuous use in this country, and a pre-Revolutionary War treasure trove of more than 400 buildings?
Rhode Island's City-by-the-Sea has the lure of wide beaches for swimming, grass courts for tennis, schooners for sailing and bicycle rentals for rides along Newport's rocky coast.
 
Events
A good way to bask in the opulence of turn-of-the-century Newport is to attend a chamber music concert in a mansion from the city's Gilded Age. The 30th Newport Music Festival, from July 10 to 26, offers 61 concerts -- morning, noon and night -- in the grand houses. The schedule includes concerts at the Breakers, the Elms, Marble House and Belcourt Castle.
Sergio Fiorentino, the Italian pianist, is scheduled to play at the festival opening July 10. In addition, 18 afternoon concerts are being devoted to the chamber music of Beethoven. Over all, 700 pieces will be performed next month by 75 international artists.
For a special, albeit costly evening, festival organizers are planning a champagne dinner party on July 22 at Rosecliff mansion. It will precede the American debut of Ulugbek Palvanov of Uzbekistan, winner of the first international Tbilisi piano competition of Georgia. The dinner and concert will cost $150. The festival will also include five midnight concerts in Marble House and Ochre Court, a building owned by Salve Regina University. Festival tickets: $15 to $44; (401) 849-0700.
For other music enthusiasts, Newport is a summer way station for jazz and folk. The New York organizer, George Wein, plans three concert series in Newport: the Ben & Jerry's Folk Festival, Aug. 7 to 9, with Lyle Lovett, the Indigo Girls and Ani DiFranco, among others; the JVC Jazz Festival, Aug. 14 to 16, with artists such as Al Jarreau, Aretha Franklin and David Sanborn; and, new this year, the Gibson Guitar Festival, July 25 and 26, with the Steve Morse Band and Bo Diddley, among others. Prices for concerts in the three series range from $20 to $55. Information: (401) 847-3700; tickets through Ticketmaster, such as the one in Providence, R.I., (401) 331-2211.
The heritage of the America's Cup still thrives in Newport despite the loss of the sailing trophy in 1983 after a century of dominance by the New York Yacht Club. Indeed, the New York group, which has an annex in Newport, plans to challenge New Zealand for the historic trophy in the year 2000. Walk along any wharf, and you will see more sailboat masts than powerboat sterns. There are as many as a dozen 12-meter yachts -- the type that raced for the America's Cup from 1958 to 1983 -- plying Newport Harbor and its outer bay.
On July 4 and 5, the Museum of Yachting's 12-Meter Regatta is expected to bring much of the admired fleet together. Included will be the 66-foot Courageous, which Ted Turner sailed to victory in the 1977 America's Cup. There will be another chance to see the Twelves under sail off Newport during the Wall Street and Corporate Challenge July 10 and 11. And at the end of summer, the Classic Yacht Regatta, also sponsored by the museum, is held on Labor Day weekend.
 
Sightseeing
Many of the 12-meter yachts are available for charter to groups, either by the half-day, at $1,200 for about 12 people, or full day, for $1,700, through America's Cup Charters, a local company, which will also offer evening sails this summer at $50 a person; (401) 846-9886. Sea scope Systems, another firm, charters two vintage powerboats as well as three classic 12-meter sailboats; (401) 847-5007.
For tours on vintage boats, both power and sail, call Classic Cruises of Newport, (800) 395-1343, or (401) 847-0299. An 80-minute ride on Rum Runner II, a restored 60-foot powerboat built in 1929, costs $15 a person; a 90-minute harbor tour on Madeleine, a 72-foot reproduction of a 19th-century schooner, costs $20 a person.
Partly through the largess of Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress who died in 1993, most of Newport's 17th- and 18th-century houses have been restored. The Museum of Newport History at Brick Market, at the foot of Washington Square, is the best starting point for learning about Newport's varied past. Built in the late 1700's, the market building contains Newport memorabilia from 1639 to the present, including audio recollections by lifelong Newporters and computer-assisted video tours. Open Monday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sunday 1 to 5 P.M. (401) 841-8770.
The Newport Historical Society, which manages the museum, conducts walking tours of the city's Colonial streets. A two-hour stroll through Historic Hill begins at the museum at 10 A.M. each Thursday through Saturday, and at 3 P.M. each Friday, for $7 a person. Tours along a section of the famous Cliff Walk, which follows the ocean for three miles, begin at 10 A.M. and at 3 P.M. each Saturday. Walks through the historic Point section, and the city's Victorian neighborhoods, are by appointment and also cost $7 each. Call (401) 846-0813.
Other walking tours are available through the Newport County Convention and Visitors Bureau, 23 America's Cup Avenue, (401) 849-8048. Tickets for boat and bus excursions can be purchased at the center through Viking Tours, (401) 847-6921, at $8 for a one-hour harbor cruise, to $28 for a four-hour bus tour.
Tickets to the fabled mansions must be purchased at the mansions; the visitors bureau sells tickets to three houses only. Information: (401) 847-1000.
To see Newport at your own pace, a 90-minute car-tour cassette tape costs $12.95 at the visitors bureau.
 
Where to Stay
Prices do not include a 12 percent tax in the Newport area.
Although the Inntowne, 6 Mary Street; (800) 457-7803, fax (401) 846-1534, is at one of Newport's busiest intersections, its 17 traditional-style rooms -- decorated with antiques and reproductions -- offer a haven from the streets as well as easy access to restaurants, the harbor and shopping. Rates for a double room start at $169.
The Hotel Viking, 1 Bellevue Avenue; (800) 556-7126, fax (401) 848-4864, is a five-story hotel built in 1926 at the top of Newport's Historic Hill area. In the 1970's, a three-story wing was added to the main brick building for a total of 184 rooms. Besides a restaurant, the hotel has a rooftop bar, and an indoor pool. Doubles from $139.
Budget: Parking and affordable rates are two reasons to stay at the Newport Gateway Hotel, 31 West Main Road in Middletown; (401) 847-2735, fax (401) 847-5434, on a busy route one mile out of Newport's center, and across from the city bus; a free shuttle service run by the hotel is also available. Its 47 rooms, recently renovated under new management, are distinctive and pleasant. Doubles from $75.
The Budget Host Inn, 1185 West Main Road, in Middletown; (800) 862-2006, fax (401) 848-7704, is three miles out of Newport. Insulated from a busy highway by a downward sloping driveway, the motel-like building surrounds a grassy play and picnic area. Its 78 rooms are clean and simple. Doubles from $68.
Luxury: Since its renovation last year, Vanderbilt Hall, 41 Mary Street; (888) 826-4255, fax (401) 846-0701, has become Newport's most stylish hotel. In the center of the Historic Hill district, it occupies a former boy's club built in 1909 by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt. The 50 rooms, most with grand detailing and woodwork, are lavishly decorated with European antiques. There is a period restaurant and indoor pool. Doubles from $195.
Mill Street Inn, 75 Mill Street; (888) 645-5784, fax (401) 848-5131, was built in the 1880's as a wood-finishing mill. Its brick walls and beamed ceilings add rustic charm to a mostly modern decor in 23 suites, some of which are on two levels. A breakfast buffet is served on a rooftop deck overlooking Newport Harbor. Doubles from $165.
 
Where to Eat
The Commodore's Room at The Black Pearl, (401) 846-5264, is a small, elegant dining room on Bannister's Wharf. Swordfish, salmon filet, lobster tails and, when in season, soft shell crabs sauteed in butter and garlic, are well prepared. Rack of lamb is a specialty, as is veal medallion with champagne sauce. A different, less expensive menu is served in the bar area. Dinner for two with wine: about $140.
The West Deck has waterfront access and plenty of parking (a lot next door sporadically charges $7 a night), both a rarity in Newport. The restaurant, at 1 Waites Wharf, (401) 847-3610, serves dishes such as potato-crusted salmon, seared tuna with lemon basil oil, and filet mignon with Stilton cheese and a port wine sauce. On the deck overlooking a marina, there is a lower-priced menu of grilled entrees. Dinner for two with wine in the dining room: about $125.
Mamma Luisa, at 673 Thames Street, (401) 848-5257, serves a variety of pastas and gnocchi, as well as meat and seafood dishes and vegetarian specials. A meal for two with wine: about $80.
Originally known for nacho platters and steaks, Brick Alley Pub, 140 Thames Street, (401) 849-6334, has expanded into a bustling lunch and dinner restaurant. It serves sandwiches and burgers but also has an extensive salad bar and such choices as sole, catfish and barbecued chicken. Dinner for two with wine: $60.
Local residents show up in droves for the breads and croissants at La Boulangerie Obelix, a tiny rustic restaurant and bakery that recently opened at 382 Spring Street, (401) 846-3377. There are creative sandwiches (chicken-mango salad, and prosciutto with asiago cheese), made with French country bread or focaccia. A light meal costs about $18 for two, including a soft drink and dessert.
Diagonally across from First Beach, Newport's city beach, is Flo's Clam Shack, 4 Wave Avenue, in Middletown, (401) 847-8141. Counter service only, but there are plenty of tables inside and out where one can sit and devour clam and lobster rolls, stuffed quahogs, clamcakes, chowder and calamari. Dinner for two with beer: $20.
