HEADLINE: The View From/Bridgeport;
A City as a Backdrop In a Fledgling Film Plan

BYLINE: By DOMINIC MARIANI 

 BODY:
SO you want to make movies. You need a decaying downtown for urban thrillers, exquisite 19th-century Victorian houses for gothic horror flicks, abandoned factories and mills for period pieces, a scenic waterfront for romance.
Bridgeport has all that -- and more. 
 That's why Howard Grossman of Westport and a group of Hollywood filmmakers, including some Oscar winners, formed the Film Makers Company and are putting $22 million into the old Bijou Theater downtown, hoping to make it a major motion picture studio. As Mr. Grossman, 44, a film and television producer, sees it, "Bridgeport is a brick and mortar town. And the film industry is a brick and mortar business."
Film Makers joins the Bluefish baseball team, the new Housatonic Community College, the new state police headquarters and the Harbor Place Development Project as the most recent additions to the city's economic renaissance. As Mayor Joseph Ganim sees it, "We're moving fast in the right direction."
Mr. Grossman first visited Fairfield County a decade ago when he bought the television rights to Sam Shepherd's play "True West" from Hal Thau, who lived in Weston. Mr. Grossman was living in Greenwich Village at the time and was struck by how beautiful the area was and yet so close to New York City. He moved to Weston, leaving for Westport 12 years later.
It was a short hop to Bridgeport. With the help of State Tax Commissioner Gene Gavin, a neighbor in Westport and a former member of the State Film Commission, Mr. Grossman started meeting with local business and political leaders. "I always believed the film business was an untapped resource here in Connecticut," Mr. Gavin said. "there is no reason why we can't do what Toronto and Charlotte, N.C., have done. We've got every cinematic backdrop."
Mr. Grossman said it has been estimated that the making of a full length feature film can generate revenues in the local community totaling as much as four times the cost of its production -- work for contractors, service industries and retail shops.
Although Film Makers will maintain an office on the West Coast, most of its principals live in or are moving to Fairfield County and plan to make the renovated Bijou a production center for motion pictures, television programs and interactive media. Mr. Grossman and his partners plan to buy the adjoining building and include a theme restaurant, a film company retail store, a theater to show historic films about Bridgeport and a museum. The company recently entered into a joint venture for post production work with the Palace Production Center in South Norwalk under which Palace is to invest $500,0000 for equipment that will enable the filmmakers to do such work as dubbing and looping.
Other founding partners of Film Makers include John Briley, who won an Academy Award for the screenplay of "Gandhi"; John Pecerall who won an Oscar for producing "The Deer Hunter"; Roy Capanella 2d, the son of the baseball legend and a writer, producer and director. All three plan to relocate to the area in the near future.
Film Makers also has an educational side: an cooperative working with the Bridgeport Department of Youth Services, and others to provide after-school programs in directing, producing, set design, editing, lighting, sound and costuming. This will be followed by more training, internships and possibly future employment.
Film Makers will be conducting a day camp program for 46 youths ages 14 through 18 from July 13 to Aug. 21, encouraging students to develop a story line and make a film.
Bill Stewart, an aide to Mayor Ganim, has helped set up the summer program for students from the East Side, the Hollow and the South End neighborhoods. "The kids from these areas would never get this exposure to an artistic community, of which they have absolutely no clue," Mr. Stewart said. "We hope that other community programs will begin to use the performing arts as an active component."
Mr. Grossman says Film Makers plans to make low-budget, commercially oriented, material-driven films. "Making movies," he said, "is not as expensive as people think."
To cut the high-cost screenplays, star salaries, special effects and directors' and producers' fees, "We use relationships between people who know each other, have independent blood and want more control over their projects than Hollywood allows," he said. "Most of all, we are willing to work under a low budget umbrella to get it done."
State Representative Chris Caruso, a Democrat of Bridgeport, drafted entertainment zone legislation when the city was considering a casino and is now trying to arrange additional state funding, grants and bonds for the film project.
"Arts and entertainment have proven to be great ways to revitalize cities," Mr. Caruso said, citing Pittsburgh and Cleveland as examples. "The film industry is clean, high-revenue business that has a ripple effect on a local community."
Film Makers has equity financing of $10 million. There are commitments from the state for $5 million in grants with up to $5 million more under consideration, all for capital improvements. In addition, Bridgeport qualifies as a Federal enterprise zone, so there are federal incentives.
The renovation of the Bijou, which opened in 1910 and is thought to be the oldest commercial theater in America, could take up to 18 months. In the meantime, Mr. Grossman is looking for temporary quarters. Preproduction on the first Film Makers film is scheduled to begin this month.

HEADLINE: ART;
Exhibit A (as in Art) in a Case for Conservation

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
NEARLY lost in the sprawling suburbs and high-tech industrial parks of Orange County, Calif., is the unassuming Irvine Museum. Tucked away on the 12th floor of a glass office tower between John Wayne Airport and the San Diego Freeway, it provides an unlikely setting for the world's largest collection of California Impressionist paintings.
Now, some of the finest works of this underappreciated genre have reached New York, bringing their airy palettes and play of California light to the National Academy Museum in a show titled "All Things Bright and Beautiful: California Impressionist Paintings From the Irvine Museum." 
 Collectively these paintings testify to the energy and passion of the little-known California Impressionists of 1890 to 1930. Their work reveals a reverence for the state's landscape, so often washed in its celebrated white light.
But the paintings tell another story too -- that of an iron-willed, sometimes combative real estate heiress named Joan Irvine Smith, whose family once owned the immense ranch upon which the modern city of Irvine, Calif., is built. Several of the 58 works on view here, selected from Mrs. Smith's 3,000-piece collection, were painted on the Irvine Ranch.
Mrs. Smith believes that the paintings, inspired by the unsullied valleys, virgin mountains and deserted coastline of early-20th-century California, bear witness to much of what the state has lost forever. She sees the art as an effective tool for teaching environmental preservation and balanced development. And she is the first to point out that most of her millions came from developing parts of the very land that she now hopes these paintings can help rescue.
"Conservation must be done in a way that doesn't destroy the economy," said Mrs. Smith, whose mother was a prominent Republican but who considers herself politically independent. "A strong economic base is needed to support environmental preservation, but you must have a balance."
The art, she said, "is a soft sell, a necessity to preserve the environment, not by hitting people over the head but as a form of consciousness-raising."
"It makes people think how imperative preservation really is," she added.
Some native Californians who visit the museum, she said, "see the paintings and say, 'Ah, this is what it looked like when I grew up!' Then they compare it to what is going on out there day by day."
"Out there" is visible through the museum's windows: a sometimes smoggy panorama of housing tracts and clogged freeways bordered by scarred mountains and, here and there, patches of the remaining natural habitat.
It wasn't always this way. The National Academy exhibition, on view through July 9 before moving to Chicago, depicts a seemingly mythical land of milky skies and honey hills. It betrays the artists' near-religious awe of all they saw around them. And it shows their mastery at depicting the rare light, shadows and color of California, especially the coral rays of the setting sun catching distant peaks.
Artists began arriving in California after the 1849 gold rush, many settling in San Francisco. Most of them had received formal training in New York or Chicago, and several had lived and painted in France -- in Paris and Giverny -- where they were influenced by Claude Monet.
MEANWHILE, artists in Southern California, most notably in Santa Barbara, Pasadena, San Diego and Laguna Beach (near Irvine), began experimenting with the Impressionist style. Soon after, Northern California artists also began to adopt the style, first in San Francisco and later in artist colonies formed in Monterey, Carmel and other places outside the city after much of it was destroyed in the earthquake and fires of 1906.
Like the French Impressionists, the Californians used bold new pigments, large, contrasting blocks of light and shadow, and broken brush strokes that sometimes only hinted at objects. And like the French, they weren't always appreciated by the art establishment. These artists largely shunned figurative and studio painting, preferring instead to carry their easels outside in the "plein air" fashion and paint the landscapes and seascapes around them.
The artists "sought to capture a fleeting moment of specific natural light," said Jean Stern, executive director of the Irvine Museum. "The clear and intense light appears often in these paintings. It defined the landscape. The biblical analogy of light as the creative instrument is appropriate. Without it, and the divine energy it represented, the land would not exist."
A stirring spirituality permeates many of the works and testifies to the artists' faith not only in God but in the sheer grandeur of nature. The German-born painter William Wendt is probably best known for such "artistic moralism." A founding member of the Laguna Beach Art Association in 1918, he became known for his depictions of rugged coastal hills, often basking in the warm glow of sunset. Even his titles, like "The Silent Summer Sea, 1915" and "There Is No Solitude, Even in Nature, 1906," reveal a certain religious poetry.
The best-known, best-loved and probably the best artist of the school was a native Californian, Guy Rose, who spent eight years at Giverny, though he probably never painted with Monet. Traveling up and down California, he perfected the feathery brush strokes of early Impressionism, incorporating delicate purples, blues and pinks. Like Monet, he often did serial paintings of the same scene at different times of day. With six works in the show, he is its most represented artist. His "Laguna Eucalyptus, 1916" and "Point Lobos, 1918" are among the exhibition's highlights.
Another notable artist in the show is Granville Redmond, who could not hear or speak and who suffered bouts of depression. He preferred the moody, tonalist paintings seen in his dark yet intensely spiritual "Nocturne," but he knew that wealthy patrons wanted his sunny trademark panoramas of poppy fields below snow-covered mountains, exemplified in the mural-like "California Landscape With Flowers."
The show also includes works by the Austrian-born Franz Bischoff, known for delicate floral paintings and vases as well as landscapes; the Hungarian-born Maurice Braun, who painted the burnt-sienna canyons of San Diego; John Gamble, a Santa Barbara resident who captured the intense purple of the lupines that covered the valleys, and Anna Hills, Joseph Kleitsch, Joseph Raphael, Arthur Rider, Elmer Wachtel and his wife, the watercolorist Marion Kavanagh Wachtel. (The exhibition also includes a smaller showing of California Impressionist paintings from the collections of Paul and Kathy Bagley and Thomas and Barbara Stiles, which closes on July 5.)
Six of the artists were National Academy members, and at least two paintings in the show -- Paul Dougherty's "Twisted Ledge" and Wendt's haunting "There Is No Solitude" -- were exhibited at the academy early this century. "It's like a homecoming for these artists, though most people here have never heard of them," said David Dearinger, the academy's chief curator (the show's guest curator is William H. Gerdts). Mr. Dearinger said that a "certain East Coast snobbism" may have kept California Impressionism from gaining a popular foothold in the East.
Mrs. Smith agreed. "Easterners don't think we can do anything out here in California," she said by telephone from her home, in San Juan Capistrano. "But the East Coast doesn't have the light, or the geography." Still, she credited one group of Easterners, the 19th-century Hudson River School, with being the first environmental painters. "They painted to protest the Industrial Revolution and destruction of the land," she said, "just like the Californians after them."
Mrs. Smith is a daughter of perhaps Orange County's most famous family (along with their friends, the Richard Nixons). In 1957 she succeeded her mother, Athalie Richardson Irvine Clarke, as a director of the Irvine Company, which was set up to manage and develop the family's sprawling livestock and produce ranch. For 25 years she clashed with other directors over the company's future and its plans to convert the ranch into a city. She pushed for responsible development of the ranch, insisting on a master plan that included preservation of natural areas. And she fought to donate 1,000 acres to build the University of California, Irvine.
In 1991, after a nine-year lawsuit, Mrs. Smith received $257 million for her interests in the company. She used some of that money to start her Impressionist collection and the Irvine Museum, which opened in January 1993; she also owns a gallery in Laguna Beach.
Her influence lingers. Last year, the Irvine Company and the Nature Conservancy joined to preserve 17,000 acres of endangered coastal sage scrub. "Some of these paintings might well have been painted on that land," Mrs. Smith said. "The artists would be very happy."

HEADLINE: FILM;
Able to Laugh at Their People, Not Just Cry for Them

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: SLIAMMON INDIAN RESERVE, British Columbia

 BODY:
ONE morning recently, Evan Adams, a 31-year-old American Indian actor, was telling stories in the small living room of his parents' home on this beautiful, heavily wooded stretch of the Canadian coast. Surrounded by his mother, three sisters and a brother, he explained in his singsong voice how he had terrified some of the participants in a first-aid course he had taken by reacting with passionate alarm toward a doll that was supposedly choking and its inflatable mother.
He was telling the story as a testament to his acting ability, but his normally soft-spoken sister Maureen slyly deflated the boast by asking, "Was it acting or were you excited about that blow-up doll?" 
 This gentle gibe brought gales of laughter from Mr. Adams's family, and it was just one episode in a day of wordplay among a group of people clearly comfortable communicating through sometimes bawdy humor and irony. That, of course, would be unremarkable in such a close-knit family except for the fact that Indians have generally been depicted in popular culture, and especially in movies, as earnest and stoic, sometimes pathetic and at times bloodthirsty, but rarely wry.
Indians have also been pictured as living in poor, if not squalid conditions. And in fact Mr. Adams, a Coast Salish Indian, said that he had eaten so much salmon as a child growing up in a subsistence economy based on fishing that he took to calling it "Indian bologna." But the economic poverty has often been interpreted as cultural impoverishment -- as an implication that Indian culture lacks a playful or a cerebral dimension.
That is one reason the new movie in which Mr. Adams is a co-star, "Smoke Signals," which opens Friday, is so distinctive. It's funny and complex, as well as poignant, casting a new light on the Indian sensibility.
"Smoke Signals," based on a book of short stories by Sherman Alexie titled "The Lone Ranger and Tonto Fistfight in Heaven," is the first feature-length movie written, directed and acted by American Indians. But the film, which won two awards at the Sundance festival in January and has been acclaimed by critics, is something more too: it is a step by a new generation of Indian artists toward finding an idiom for exploring their individual and cultural identities without resorting to self-pity, political correctness or Hollywood cliches.
The tone of "Smoke Signals," which documents the unexpected ways two young men living on the Coeur d'Alene reservation in Idaho come to terms with absent fathers, is brash and self-confident in its self-examination. In one scene, for instance, Thomas Builds-the-Fire (Mr. Adams) notes as he watches a western, "The only thing more pathetic than Indians on TV is Indians watching Indians on TV."
This movie, which was directed by the 28-year-old Chris Eyre, is the work not just of a group of creative people with full hearts but of aggressive achievers determined to stake their claim to high ground on the American cultural map. The best known of them is Mr. Alexie. A 31-year-old novelist and poet who grew up on the Spokane reservation in Washington, he was a producer of "Smoke Signals" and wrote its screenplay and is also producing a movie adapted from his recent novel "Indian Killer." He said in an interview that one of his primary goals was to take away from so-called white experts the responsibility for describing contemporary Indian culture. His aim, he said, is not to avoid criticism of Indian society but to make sure that it is Indians doing the criticizing and interpreting.
MR. ADAMS, an athletic-looking man with a broad smile, a long ponytail and wire-framed glasses, is also a good example of restless ambition -- but with a twist. He has acted in four full-length features; he will appear in "Indian Killer," and he is completing a script for a movie in which he will also act later this year, with Loretta Todd, a Cree from Northern Alberta, directing.
But beyond all that, Mr. Adams -- whose grandparents and several aunts died of tuberculosis -- will begin medical school at the University of Calgary this fall, to fulfill a goal of bringing something back to his reservation, a hamlet of 650 people about 100 miles north of Vancouver amid mountains, towering cedars and rich blue waters.
The people involved in "Smoke Signals" are not, in short, willing to passively accept conventional images of Indian life.
"Smoke Signals" is a slow-moving, often wistful drama that turns into a road movie as Thomas, a confident nerd who maintains his people's storytelling tradition in an offbeat manner, accompanies the angry, self-conscious Victor Joseph (Adam Beach) on a journey to Arizona. But the story is enlivened by a self-deprecating sense of humor, one of the most enduring Indian cultural characteristics, particularly on the reservations, the filmmakers say.
"Smoke Signals" is clearly a product of a post-Wounded Knee generation. The filmmakers paid tribute to the American Indian Movement, saying that those angry demonstrators of the 1970's had helped establish a contemporary tradition of Indian pride that made a movie like "Smoke Signals" possible. But the film has a far different sensibility. The characters are angry, but they're also silly, loving, careless, vulnerable, witty and persistent. They play basketball. They laugh at their squalor. At one point the only way they can go forward is by driving a car backward. They mock Indian stereotypes, and they embrace them. In fact, they are much like the group of people who made the film.
Mr. Eyre, a graduate of the film school at New York University, is a Cheyenne-Arapaho who was adopted as a baby and brought up by a white family in Oregon. He has spent the last few years tracking down his biological parents and embracing his Indian heritage. "Smoke Signals," the first feature he has directed, was integral to that process. "In this movie, we're all searching for home to different degrees," he said.
Mr. Beach, a 25-year-old Ojibway from north of Winnipeg, bluntly described how much of his own personal history was reflected in that of his character, Victor, who is haunted by the absence of a parent. He said the defining element of his early life was the death of his mother, who was killed by a drunken driver when he was 8; she was eight months pregnant at the time. His father drowned two months later. "Living with that loss and not understanding it, you kind of feel you're not in the right place," said Mr. Beach, an avid hockey player and rock musician. "I'm kind of looking for the right place in this movie."
Mr. Beach also described the making of "Smoke Signals" as a means by which he could confront his own anger about the loss of his parents. "It was the first time in my life I was able to get that out of myself," said Mr. Beach in describing the filming of the tearful closing sequence of the movie. "I remember I was crying on Chris's shoulder and saying, 'It still hurts.' And he'd say, 'Well, you have to go do it again.' "
And then there is Mr. Adams, who has been almost frenetic in his efforts both to investigate his culture through writing and acting and to serve his people as a doctor. His parallel career paths reflect a tension that runs through the lives of many Indians, he said: whether to concentrate on articulating a distinct cultural vision to the world outside the reservations or to focus on their own people. Mr. Adams is still undecided on which path will win out in his case, but he seems to be leaning in one direction.
"I do love acting and I'm working at it, but there are only a few times in an actor's career when he can do movies that are life changing or magical," he said. "That's not enough for me. I need to do something that really helps my people all the time."
Mr. Adams's father, Les, the captain of a tugboat, said he had long contemplated these issues. As he sat bobbing on his boat, he explained that he knew many years ago that Evan was capable of extraordinary accomplishments. And he said that he had sternly instructed his son to focus his ambition on the world beyond the reservation. But, he admitted, Evan made it clear early on that he had his own ideas about heritage and creativity. As a teen-ager, for example, Evan learned and performed traditional dances that had been little seen for years. Les Adams recalled bringing a friend, the chief of a nearby tribe, to one of Evan's performances and being struck to see his friend cry at one point.
"He said he had not seen those dances since he was a boy and that he never expected to see them again in his life," said Mr. Adams. "He was impressed that these young people wanted to bring them back."
Evan Adams did go away to a private high school when he was 14 and then to McGill University in Montreal. His father said he was crushed when Evan announced that he was leaving McGill after a year, to pursue acting.
The younger Mr. Adams said that part of his struggle over the years had come from his mixed feelings about living in a dominantly white society. "My family had a very high status on the reservation," he said, whose father was the elected chief of his tribe for a number of years. "I was low status in the town. It was a constant source of irritation and humiliation."
Ultimately, Mr. Adams enrolled at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver and completed his premed studies, while continuing to write and act, doing everything from Shakespeare to a play he wrote, "Snapshots," about how two Indian families deal with illness and death.
He described his swings from one world to the other while showing a reporter an extraordinary collection of totem poles, masks and other ceremonial objects preserved in the glass and concrete Museum of Anthropology on the University of British Columbia campus. He insisted that he was trying to find a way of revering the past while shaping a new kind of future that was true to both the Indian spirit and the modern spirit.
"The Indian way," he concluded, "is being adaptable and flexible."

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Vivid Reminders Of Jewish Life In the Old South

BYLINE: By DAVID GALEF; David Galef teaches English at the University of Mississippi.

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss.

 BODY:
THE engraved kiddush cup in the exhibit is exquisite, casting its silver glow against its black backdrop. Used to sanctify the Jewish sabbath, this cup is more than 300 years old and comes from the French region of Alsace. How did it end up in Baton Rogue, La.?
The traditional Jewish immigrant experience in America is usually thought to involve a passage from Eastern Europe through Ellis Island to the Lower East Side of Manhattan, but there have always been alternative routes. One of the more intriguing and lesser-known stories is how Jews from France and Germany arrived in New Orleans in the 1800's and made their way up the Mississippi. 
 "Alsace to America: Discovering a Southern Jewish Heritage," an exhibit sponsored by the Museum of the Southern Jewish Experience and now at the Mtel Center here through Aug. 31, is a multimedia presentation filling a real gap in our cultural memory. The show chronicles the arrival and dispersal of Jews from Alsace and Lorraine, where political and economic repression were daily realities. Not surprising, many Jews saw life in America as a widening of opportunity, glad to trade the Rhine for the Mississippi.
The route started in Alsace, with ships embarking from Le Havre or Hamburg and landing in New Orleans. The emigrants' trunks were filled with their heritage, as shown by the objects in the exhibit. A gouache-on-glass mizrah, used to indicate the eastern wall of the synagogue for prayer, is decorated with lions and flowers in a typically Alsatian pattern. A mappa, an embroidered prayer belt made from infant boys' swaddling clothes, has survived the rough transition from the Old World to the new country intact.
As always, the Jews carried their livelihood with them on their backs. A fine set of watchmaker's tools and a shoemaker's last are on proud display. Other Jews, also taking up where they had left off, became itinerant peddlers, providing everything from bolts of fabric to pots and pans for the farmers spread along the Delta. Of course, after enough sales, the immigrants were able to build their own stores and advertise: "I. Popkin, est. 1892, Jeweler" reads one sign in the show. The office of a Jewish cotton factor, a wholesale goods buyer for plantations, is reproduced with its original planter's desk, featuring dozens of pigeonholes and drawers.
Naturally, some accommodation was necessary to survive in the small towns they chose to live in, like doing business on the sabbath. The title of a 1993 memoir written by Eli N. Evans, who grew up in North Carolina, is telling: "The Lonely Days Were Sundays." But the Jews were a strong and welcome presence wherever they settled, often forming the main economic life of a town. As Jews moved into a region, their first step was to institute the Chevra Kadisha, or burial society, followed by establishing a congregation and finally building a synagogue. The one in Port Gibson, erected in 1891 and the oldest synagogue in Mississippi, has a Moorish-Byzantine design that -- not coincidentally -- resembles one in Alsace. The better-endowed B'Nai Israel synagogue in Natchez is larger, more ornate and surprisingly similar-looking to some of the adjacent churches.
The demographics are startling. Though Jews never amounted to more than 5 percent of the population in Natchez, for example, at their height they ran one-third of the city's businesses. They readily engaged in philanthropic and civic activities, serving as aldermen and mayors, and leaving an array of showplace homes that remains one of Natchez's biggest tourist draws. Far from the kind of anti-Semitism that the Ku Klux Klan later spearheaded, an unusual social mingling seems to have prevailed.
Some thumbnail biographies from the exhibit are particularly worth noting. Phillip Sartorius, for example, sailed from Bavaria in 1845, settled in Vicksburg, sired 19 children and was the first soldier wounded by Union forces in the battle of Millikin's Bend just outside Vicksburg. During the Civil War, some 5,000 Jews served in the Confederate Army.
In daily life, the blend of Southern and Jewish made for some curious sights, at least to modern viewers: a Sukkah booth hung with cotton, soybeans and corn husks, for example, or a challah on a Sabbath table against a window framing a cotton field. These and other images are the work of Bill Aron, a photographer whose pictures are displayed at the Museum of the Southern Jewish Experience's home base in Utica, a 40-minute drive from Jackson. (A supplementary exhibit, "The Architecture of Experience: Alsatian Jews at Home, Worship and Work," opened at the museum on June 14.) In an attempt to make visitors realize what has been lost, the museum is working on a "cultural corridors" tour from New Orleans to Memphis, with stops including Port Gibson, Natchez, Vicksburg and Woodville (once known as Little Jerusalem).
What happened? As the Jewish population grew in strength and numbers, a curious phenomenon occurred, assimilation. An abiding faith of America, in many cases it led to the disolution of tradition. But the other enemy of tradition was economic. If the golden age of Southern Jewry was in the 1890's, when cotton was king, the advent of the boll weevil around 1908 changed all that. With the main cash crop of the South literally eaten up, the merchant class quickly began losing its customers. A great many sons and daughters of the Southern Jews began their own emigration northward.
What remains? Most communities that once had a thriving Southern Jewish population now have barely sufficient numbers to keep its memory alive. As Macy B. Hart, executive director of the museum, notes: "We need to save what has fallen into ruin and disrepair. The temples themselves are the real museum. We want to use them as a teaching tool."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Lost Theatrical Form Returns With a Smile

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
THE setting is Washington in March 1933: the economy is deep into the Depression, the stock market is a wasteland, bread lines are long and banks are closing. The nation totters.
Herbert and Lou Hoover, the 31st President of the United States and his wife, are rattling around the White House on the eve of the day they must vacate the premises for the incoming Roosevelt family. Herbert faces the move with equanimity, but Lou wants revenge. She is planning to steal some White House silver and a portrait of George Washington -- it's not as if there aren't plenty more around the place. 
 Herbert tries to cheer her: "It could be worse -- I could have been re-elected." She goads him. This being their last night, she says, isn't there something he'd like to do that is not entirely proper? There is, which leads to the rude, gleefully childish blackout that ends the sketch titled "Franklin D. Roosevelt to Be Inaugurated Tomorrow."
This is just one of the numbers in the Drama Dept.'s enchanting resurrection of "As Thousands Cheer," the 1933 Irving Berlin-Moss Hart topical revue, which is at the Greenwich House Theater.
A 1933 topical revue that's still funny? Yes. One of the marvelous things about intelligently written, skillfully performed revue material is that the humor can shine through in front of audiences for whom the original associations have grown dim or, perhaps, never existed at all. Watch children watching a sketch whose point is utterly beyond them and they laugh at the right places. Such comedy has a rhythm that can be as infectiously comic as content, even when the subjects might be John D. Rockefeller Sr., the five-and-dime heiress Barbara Hutton, Mahatma Gandhi, Hollywood's morals czar Will Hays, unemployment, and thievery at the Automat.
The wonder here is that you can delight in both the content and the rhythm of "As Thousands Cheer," which is presented with nutty enthusiasm, and sometimes vitriol, as it sends up the American scene at one of the darkest moments in the country's history. Directed as a series of collegial, go-for-broke turns by Christopher Ashley, whose credits include "Jeffrey" and the recent Encores production of "Li'l Abner," the show is a kind of tabloid version of the original Broadway hit. It has been cut to run a breezy 75 minutes, played without an intermission by a cast of six acting and singing clowns, accompanied by a piano and a bass.
Like the Atlantic Theater Company, which recently revived "Once in a Lifetime," the classic 1930 George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart comedy, the Drama Dept. possesses an awareness of the theater's historical past that deepens and illuminates the company's present work. This was apparent six months ago in its ebullient, witty, very original deconstruction of Harriet Beecher Stowe's "Uncle Tom's Cabin or Life Among the Lowly."
In choosing to search for the life within "As Thousands Cheer," the Drama Dept. is rediscovering the art of the revue as it has evolved in the American theater from the days of minstrel shows. Spawned in its present form in the years before World War I, the intimate revue took over during the Depression, when soaring budgets made the elaborate, Ziegfeld-type spectacles too risky to produce. Revues have existed in all sizes and shapes from the teens, 20's, 30's and 40's into the 50's: a glorious grab-bag kind of theater, brainy beyond the aspirations of burlesque and vaudeville, composed of sketches, songs and dances, sometimes with a common theme and, most important, with a consistently skeptical point of view.
I think of London in 1947 and the first revue I ever saw, "Sweetest and Lowest," a hilarious, very jaundiced look at life in grimly austere, postwar Britain, starring an almost youthful Hermione Gingold. A highlight: a sendup of Noel Coward's role as a goodwill ambassador during the war ("While disguised as Mr. Eden/ He was smuggled into Sweden/ Where he cleverly put on 'Private Lives' "). The cheeky effrontery of undergraduate humor, which I then knew best, had been transformed into art.
By the early 1950's, television had already appropriated the variety-show format of revues, and Sid Caesar and Imogene Coca briefly made the entire country sketch comedy-conscious on "Your Show of Shows." Yet producers of theatrical revues persisted: Ben Bagley with his "Shoestring Revue of 1957," Julius Monk with his brilliant, mini-scaled shows in whatever nightclubs were available, and the indefatigable Leonard Sillman, whose "New Faces of 1952" was the most successful of all the "New Faces" shows he had been producing since the 30's.
Among the discoveries of the 1952 edition were Ronny Graham, Alice Ghostley, Paul Lynde and Eartha Kitt. As this show introduced Ms. Kitt, she introduced what was to become one of her signature songs, "Monotonous." The most memorable production number, choreographed for frenzy by Richard Barstow, was Michael Brown's exuberant hoedown, "Lizzie Borden," which has the refrain: "Oh you can't chop your papa up in/ Massachusetts/ Massachusetts is a long way from New York!"
Some of the priceless sketches: a Paul Lynde monologue in which a man with a Rotarian's desire to please, though still heavily bandaged and on crutches, relates what happened on the Trip of the Month Club's African safari he took with his late wife; a vignette about the Loman family in which Willy's frail, worried wife implores her sons to pay attention, to become bank robbers like their exhausted dad; and Ronny Graham's takeoff on Truman Capote, who is lying in a hammock and talking (if I remember correctly) about moss.
Gorgeous material, some of it written by a writer then billed as Melvin Brooks. He, of course, was also one of the contributors to "Your Show of Shows," which used a platoon of talents that included Neil Simon, Carl Reiner, Larry Gelbart and many others.
What is it about these revues that makes them so irresistible?
When they work, they capture the temper of the times with brevity, with an accuracy that sometimes shocks and with a gift for parody that restores sacred cows to human dimension. A blending of first-rate sketches laced with songs as funny and melodic as Berlin's for "As Thousands Cheer" can be among the most bracing of theatrical entertainments. We have let the genre go to seed.
For a while, it seemed as if television would meet the demand for sketch comedy, but then not even Sid Caesar could stick it out. Television eats up material like an office shredder. The incomparable Carol Burnett endured for 11 seasons and kept the quality way, way up. "Saturday Night Live" has had its golden moments, most of them many years ago. I think of an Edward R. Murrow "Person to Person" sort of parody in which the self-absorbed interviewer has his back to the television screen on which his guest, who looks like Elizabeth Taylor, starts choking to death on the chicken leg that has had her ravenous attention.
"Saturday Night Live" produced some great sketch actors: John Belushi, Dan Aykroyd and the best of them all, the grandly and subtly gifted Eddie Murphy. Remember his sketch about how white folks behave on the bus to work when black folks aren't around? Bells go off, music suddenly blares, saucily dressed waitresses appear, to serve martinis and canapes. The imagined merriment is nonstop and strictly segregated.
The show still introduces good new performers but, in what could be an attempt to affect a 1990's sort of cool, the sketches tend to be resolutely without point. The idea is that to express passion, even in a satirical way, is definitely un-cool.
THERE have been suggestions that the revue sketch is dated today, that audiences (especially television's) are not interested in it and much prefer shows that feature stand-up comics. Yet the range of subjects covered in stand-up is limited. It is usually so self-referential (dating, the difference between men and women, terrible sexual performance, parents, looks, weight) you might suspect that the comics and their audiences have turned their backs on the rest of the world.
If that's true, it's no wonder so few people bother to vote.
The time may have come for the theater to reclaim the topical revue. There is no shortage of writing talent available. Tick off the names: Larry Gelbart, Neil Simon, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, Terrence McNally, Wendy Wasserstein, A. R. Gurney, Christopher Durang, Whoopi Goldberg, Paul Rudnick, Nicky Silver, David Ives, Jane Wagner, Jon Robin Baitz, Douglas Carter Beane, David and Amy Sedaris, John Leguizamo -- and they are just some of the people we know about.
Meanwhile, you can see what a hit 1933 revue looks like as put on by people whose parents might not even have been born when the original production opened. "As Thousands Cheer" is a theme show, each sketch or song supposedly torn from a newspaper headline of the day. In this way, it was something of a prescient parody of the Living Newspapers that were to be put on under the sponsorship of the Federal Theater Project, which was established by the Works Progress Administration in 1935.
Unlike the Living Newspapers, however, which examined housing, health care, labor unions and the like, "As Thousands Cheer" mostly examines such issues as why a man might bite a dog and the private personas of public people, usually behaving badly. The Berlin score includes the steamy and funny "Heat Wave" and, for an abrupt change of mood, the poignant "Supper Time," which is cued by a headline about a lynching and was sung in the original show by Ethel Waters.
The members of the Drama Dept. cast are a delight. Some highlights: B. D. Wong (Gandhi and the man who bites a dog), Kevin Chamberlin (hilarious as the dog that's bitten and Mr. Hoover), Judy Kuhn (Joan Crawford, Barbara Hutton), Howard McGillin (John D. Rockefeller Sr., Douglas Fairbanks Jr.), Mary Beth Peil (Aimee Semple McPherson, Mrs. Hoover), and Paula Newsome, who plays and sings up a storm. Among her numbers are Berlin's superb "Harlem on My Mind" and "Supper Time." David Evans is on piano, Lou Bruno on bass. This is a very good crew.
Footnote to history: In her book, "Irving Berlin: A Daughter's Memoir," Mary Ellin Barrett reports that when "As Thousands Cheer" was trying out in Philadelphia, Clifton Webb, Marilyn Miller and Helen Broderick, the show's three white stars, refused to share the curtain call with Ethel Waters. Berlin's reaction was to suggest that this wasn't a show in need of curtain calls anyway, and that they should be cut. At the next performance the cast took its bows together.
 
'The Dying Gaul'
 Craig Lucas's fascinating new play, "The Dying Gaul," closed last Sunday night after a limited engagement at the Vineyard Theater, where a scheduling conflict made any extension impossible.
Too bad, but there are hopes that it will reopen in the fall for the unlimited run it deserves. Or, to put it another way: "The Dying Gaul" is even more theatrically imaginative and engaging than Mr. Lucas's "Prelude to a Kiss," the quirky fairy tale of a modern love story seen on Broadway in 1990.
"The Dying Gaul" is quite different. It is also a love story of sorts, but one in which anger and lust take a terrible toll, at least in part through the magic of Internet technology.
The setting is Hollywood and the principal characters are Robert, an aspiring screenwriter of mystical bent, in mourning for his lover who has recently died of AIDS; Jeffrey, a bisexual producer who buys Robert's first script and seduces him into a mutually satisfying, supposedly no-strings-attached affair, and Elaine, Jeffrey's wife, an intelligent, loving woman whose patience runs out.
The Vineyard production, staged by Mark Brokaw, was just about flawless, with Tim Hopper as Robert, Tony Goldwyn as Jeffrey, Linda Emond as Elaine and Robert Emmet Lunney as Robert's psychiatrist, who is as important to Mr. Lucas's intricate plotting as the existence of the Internet.
If Mr. Goldwyn appeared to stand out, it was because the role is so scarily flamboyant; his colleagues were equally centered in their performances. Adding to the classiness of the production: Allen Moyer's serenely handsome, vaguely Japanese unit set, which suggested Hollywood glitz as interpreted by a very expensive decorator in a minimalist mode.
"The Dying Gaul" indicates that Mr. Lucas is writing better than ever these days.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Riffing on the Past, With Surprising Results

BYLINE: By STEVEN DRUKMAN 

 BODY:
AFTER toiling for 20 years not exactly anonymously but far from the bright lights of fame as a freelance journalist, stand-up comic, playwright, screenwriter and movie director, nobody is more surprised to see "Side Man," a memory play about jazz performers, land on Broadway than its author, Warren Leight, 41.
In jazz parlance, sideman refers to a musician who works for hire on band jobs, who knows the standards by heart and who can solo dazzlingly but also blend in with an orchestra's sound. 
 The memories are based on Mr. Leight's father, Donald Leight, now 75, a trumpet player who worked with Claude Thornhill, Woody Herman and other bandleaders through the 1950's. As the author's script shows, sidemen, who sometimes sabotaged their careers with drugs and alcohol, gradually became marginalized with the advent of rock-and-roll.
But the main focus of the play is Mr. Leight's own childhood, he said recently over pastry in a Greenwich Village shop near his home. Clifford, the author's stand-in (played by Robert Sella), revisits his past, resuming the peacekeeper role he was forced to adopt in his parents' crumbling marriage. Ranging between 1953 and 1985, Mr. Leight mixes memories of his bitter, often hysterical mother (Wendy Makkena) and diffident, ineffectual father (FrankWood) with a joke-filled celebration of the journeymen musicians he knew as a child on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
"All my father's friends could remember the horn section from an obscure gig by such-and-such orchestra," Mr. Leight said, "but would walk right by their own children on the sidewalk and not recognize them."
"Side Man," directed by Michael Mayer, opens on Thursday at Stage Right at the Roundabout Theater Company, which is co-producing it with the Weissberger Theater Group and Peter Manning. The cast includes Kevin Geer, Michael Mastro, Joseph Lyle Taylor and Angelica Torn.
In March, when "Side Man" had a short run at the CSC theater Off Broadway, also directed by Mr. Mayer, it received excellent reviews. Shortly after, the screenwriter William Goldman was quoted in an interview in The New York Times as saying, "The best play I've seen in years is Warren Leight's 'Side Man.' "
Still, Mr. Leight, who has the genial, sometimes abstracted air of a professional graduate student, has been cautious. "So many people have said to me 'This is the next big thing' about my other projects -- which usually leads to unemployment and unreturned calls," he said with a rueful grin.
For Mr. Leight, his play is also autobiographical because: "I still see myself as a sideman in many ways. Coming from a jazz family, I always felt like I should earn a living. So for the last 20 years I've been a writer-for-hire, basically."
This may be why "Side Man" seems so charitable in its rendering of Gene, the title character. Peter Marks wrote in his review in The New York Times, that, "when it's over, you look for heroes and villains, and discover only people."
Mr. Leight's father, who lives west of the theater district in the Clinton section of Manhattan, recalled an era: "Sidemen only got attention inside the industry. In the 30's, the sidemen were also 'names' -- Gene Krupa, for example, was Benny Goodman's sideman -- but 15 years later, sidemen like that were unknown. Like theater and film, but more so in music, the leaders and headliners get all the public acclaim, and no one pays attention to who does the dirty work. Even in the Philharmonic, people are attracted to name conductors. But how many people can name four or five musicians in the orchestra?"
"Side Man" began as a staged reading in February 1996 in the basement of the West Bank Cafe on Theater Row. Mr. Leight, a member of the theater group Naked Angels, had had the play sent to Mr. Mayer, who liked it immediately. "The world he depicts is so truthful, so idiosyncratic, it completely charmed me," Mr. Mayer said. After the reading he directed it next during development at the New York Stage and Film Company's annual summer season at Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., where Mr. Manning produced it.
Mr. Mayer, a recent Tony Award nominee for his direction of "A View From the Bridge," a Roundabout revival that transferred to Broadway, said: "What attracted me to Warren's specific biography was how universal it is. It's not just a 'jazz play' or a 'biographical play.'
"The response from audiences has been, 'That's my story.' And I ask, 'Oh, your father was a jazz musician?' And they say, 'No, he was an accountant, but it's still my story."
Mr. Leight jokes about his difficult childhood. "I was a poor, scrawny kid from the Upper West Side -- very 10025," he said, referring to the zip code of his youth. "At least the 10024 kids had summer camp. I got drop-kicked to Stanford on a scholarship, but was out of place in Palo Alto with these Olympic team water polo players."
After graduating in 1977, he returned to New York, sold an article on "something like 'Where to Find a Public Bathroom in New York' " to The Village Voice, and became a career writer. The articles eventually formed the 1983 collection "The I Hate New York Guidebook" -- "my first succes d'estime," Mr. Leight said, "that's French for 'still living in a walkup.' "
His career has included a stint as the His columnist for Mademoiselle magazine while also writing for National Lampoon, providing cabaret material for a revue quartet, the High-Heeled Women, and performing his own stand-up routines.
"I had a year that was my 90-job year," he said. "At one point, I was ghostwriting for a guy who suddenly died. His widow said, 'Hurry up, the publishers will get suspicious if the last installment takes too long.' "
His "I Hate New York Guidebook" was the basis, along with Mayor Ed Koch's memoir, of the 1985 musical "Mayor." "It was a hit at the now-defunct Village Gate," Mr. Leight remembered, "and everyone said I wouldn't have to worry about work again -- which led, after its closing, to a long jobless streak, of course."
In recent years, he has found sporadic success in Hollywood, but has always remained a New Yorker. "I was looking for an apartment in Manhattan, and I'd see something I liked. Then I'd hear the rent and think: 'Yeah, I can afford that -- two days a week.' "
The experience prompted the screenplay for the 1993 film "The Night We Never Met" (which he also directed), a story of three people splitting the rent on an apartment but residing in it on alternate days, starring Matthew Broderick and Annabella Sciorra.
"Again, this one was going to be my big break," Mr. Leight said. "But it came out two weeks before 'Jurassic Park,' so it became this lovely sand castle that this enormous tsunami washed away."
After writing horror films and documentaries, Mr. Leight wrote a screenplay for what would become the movie "Dear God," starring Greg Kinnear, in 1996. "This was such a humiliating disaster," he said. "After six or seven drafts, it was taken from me. Suddenly, there were 60 speaking parts, a dog in a courtroom scene. I sat in a screening and thought, 'Time to write a play where I make no compromises.' "
The result was "Side Man." "Film is good money," Mr. Leight said, "but there's a reason: they pay you to go away. 'Side Man' is filled with my voice because it's my story."
The author's father saw the play at Vassar. "I didn't want him to," the younger Mr. Leight said, "but an old musician friend told him, 'Hey, your son wrote a play about you. It's in Poughkeepsie.' My father told me he was up all night afterward. I assumed it was the not-so-flattering portrayal, and then he said, 'Yeah, I couldn't figure out who was playing trumpet on "I Remember Clifford" in that scene.' "

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Fulfilling a Housing Promise in Atlantic City

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE redevelopment effort begun 11 years ago in the Northeast Inlet section of Atlantic City has filled many once-blighted blocks with rows of tidy new houses.
Yet the promise of renewal has only been half realized for this 100-acre oceanfront neighborhood in the shadow of the flashy Boardwalk casinos. 
 Projects under way or soon to begin, which together could add 112 residences to the 462 completed so far, will help fulfill that promise. In the process, they will introduce different housing types to the neighborhood, where some 1,200 residential units, complemented by recreational areas, eventually could be constructed.
While much of the housing built in the Inlet has been moderately priced attached town houses, the latest round of projects involves semi-attached houses as well as detached homes, including some to be built for purchasers on lots they will buy.
Another feature on the inlet will be the Housing Technology Demonstration Park, which will showcase homes constructed with emerging building technologies and designs. It is part of a $1 million state and federally financed research effort aimed at developing ways to reduce the costs of new construction by the Center for Architecture and Building Science Research at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark .
"The original plan was to develop the Inlet with multistory residential buildings," said James Kennedy, executive director of the state's Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, which targeted the Inlet for renewal in 1987. "But people wanted to live in single-family homes, so the compromise was the duplex houses."
The authority was created under a 1984 law to channel money from the gaming industry into urban revitalization projects throughout the state that the agency approves. So far it has invested $140 million in the Inlet, including the cost of relocating homeowners, and plans to pump in up to $20 million more. The Atlantic City Housing and Urban Redevelopment Agency is a planning partner.
Mr. Kennedy said the new housing would also help draw middle- and upper-middle income buyers and create "a balanced community." And the housing demonstration park will provide "prototypes to use throughout Atlantic City and the state that will help stretch our dollars," he said.
Through the 50's the Inlet was a grand seashore neighborhood with large elegant homes. But then the city began to decline when tourists went elsewhere and businesses and residents, including those in the Inlet, fled to the suburbs.
The neighborhood's struggle back has not been easy. Initially, some area homeowners and businesses unsuccessfully fought all the way to the State Supreme Court against selling their property, contesting the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority's general condemnation powers.
About 300 families were relocated and about 75 of them elected to return to new homes at the same cost of the old ones, the agency said.
Along with the new housing, recreational projects are under way, including the transformation of an entire block into a passive waterfront park. In addition, a $3.8 million marine education center is under construction at neighboring Gardner's Basin maritime park.
Mr. Kennedy said the second half of the rebuilding project is expected to be faster -- five years instead of 10 -- because the authority owns the land and improvements, including sewer and utility lines, are in place.
In turn, he added, the hope is that the subsidies needed to build projects and keep house prices low will decrease as production proceeds and that projects closest to the water would be built entirely by private funds. The subsidies, $50,000 to $100,000 per unit, are raised from low-interest taxable bonds the authority sells.
On one and a half blocks roughly bounded by Vermont, New Hampshire and Madison Avenues and Gramercy Place, work is proceeding on Madison Landing, comprising 62, mostly semi-detached houses as well as single-family detached homes. The $11.5 million project is being developed by Procida Realty & Construction of the Bronx.
THIS is the first project in Atlantic City for the company, known for its low and moderately priced inner-city housing developments in New York City. "Madison Landing is similar to our work in New York, so we see it is as a pretty good fit," said Mario J. Procida, president of the company. "The Inlet also is a logical growth spot where buyer interest is strong."
The two- and three-bedroom homes have 1,228 to 1,540 square feet of space; all have one-car garages, small backyards and front porches. Thirty-five homes in the initial 38-unit first phase have been sold, prompting the expansion of the project to its current size.
Prices for the first-phase units were $126,000 for the eight detached houses and ranged from $81,000 to $106,000 for the semi-detached homes. Prices for the homes in the second phase, which does not include detached units, have been raised to $88,000 to $109,000, Mr. Procida said, adding that "we are pushing the envelope in terms of price and in turn expanding the market." Completion is expected by the winter of 1999, he said.
Plans are also advancing on a project a block from the water. As now envisioned it calls for the development of 20 semi-attached houses and six detached homes on one block bordered by Maine, New Hampshire and Madison Avenues and Gramercy Place. There will also be up to 12 building lots, with 3,600 to 4,900 square feet each, that will be sold to purchasers on which to build detached homes. The sale of lots alone will be a first for the Inlet.
York Hunter Construction Services, based in Atlantic City, is the developer of the project, which has received preliminary approval from the authority. It is the first phase of a larger development, called Oceanside, that could eventually contain up to 142 homes.
This first phase "will jump-start that block and set the architectural tone for Oceanside, which I call Victorian seashore," said Edward Einhaus, the authority's director of housing development. He said the authority would set general design guidelines that call for the houses to have, among other things, open front porches and upstairs decks.
Robert P. Gross, managing director of York Hunter, said this first phase of the Oceanside project "will allow us to market the Inlet to a broader audience."
Though the prices and sizes of the homes his company will build have not yet been set, they are expected to be larger and more expensive than those built in the Inlet to date, he said, adding that prices for the building lots also have not been determined. Construction could start as early as this fall.
Meanwhile, construction began last week on the first of five houses within the Housing Technology Demonstration Park, which as now planned will contain 12 homes. Construction on the remaining seven homes is to start in October, said Peter Kastl, project manager and director of housing and building technology at the research center at the New Jersey Institute of Technology.
The institute is developing the park with $1.5 million from the Casino Reinvestment Authority, which also donated the five acres for the project, which will cover two blocks bounded by Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Madison Avenues and Gramercy Place.
The aim of the park, said Mr. Kastl is to "look at the hardware" involved in constructing houses, and how incorporating emerging technologies in the process can "reduce the cost to build and own affordable housing."
The homes will be built by construction companies selected by the institute based on their ability to produce a quality home at a lower cost using the housing concepts that the companies develop and meeting several design goals.
The homes will be detached and semi-attached with two to three bedrooms and 1,200 square feet of space. They will also include energy conservation technologies, making them economical to maintain, said Mr. Kastl.
Some of the initial homes, to be completed by year's end, will be built using prefabricated modules and insulated concrete; later ones, to be finished in 1999, will include steel frame and solar houses. The authority will sell the homes to qualified low- and moderate-income buyers.
"We feel Atlantic City is an ideal place for the park because of the large volume of traffic that comes here for conventions," said Mr. Kastl. "But the technologies used here can be applicable to affordable housing projects throughout the state and nation."

HEADLINE: Taking Care Of Those The Good Times Have Skipped

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
A HOMELESS woman who slept for four nights in the front portico of Union Baptist Church in Mystic opened the community's eyes to a story behind the headlines hailing economic prosperity: The good times are leaving many people in eastern Connecticut behind.
The woman, in her late 20's, was given food, clothing and temporary shelter at the church. After she found a job, she left and never returned. But her plight moved the senior pastor of Union Baptist profoundly. 
 "She left $1.50 in an envelope for the church," said the Rev. G. Kenneth Carpenter. "I never saw her again, and I started to wonder what happened to her. All through the winter, I wondered where the woman went. I couldn't stop asking myself where she would sleep during February."
The experience prompted Mr. Carpenter and Mark Santucci, rector of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mystic, to organize a group of people from churches and social service agencies to address homelessness in Groton and nearby towns. The pastors said they are concerned that a growing number of people may need emergency help as they exhaust their limited resources.
Eastern Connecticut, often referred to as "the other Connecticut" when compared with affluent Fairfield County, is still reeling from the shift in the state's economy away from manufacturing. But the long-term effect on workers in the region is not a popular topic of public discourse.
"There is a basic reluctance to admit what's going on," said Mary McAtee, director of the Connecticut Coalition to End Homelessness. "For a significant number of people in Connecticut, things are going well. But we know the economy isn't what it used to be. It's no longer possible to support a family on one income. And we don't have the financial security we expected. It used to be that if we worked hard and did our best, our economic situation would improve. That's not the case now."
When the nation's unemployment rate fell last April to 4.3 percent, the lowest since 1970, Allen Sinai, chief global economist for Primark Decision Economics, an economic information and advisory firm, was quoted as saying: "This is as good as it gets for American workers in a sparkling labor market. Increasingly, the pendulum is swinging to the American worker."
In reply to a question about Connecticut's economy, however, Mr. Sinai said his statement did not apply to all parts of the United States. "I have no trouble backing down from that statement when it comes to Connecticut, which is very much a stereotype of what the national picture was three years ago."
Although the state has recovered from severe job losses, the recovery has not been shared equally. Thousands of families have been losing ground, according to the Connecticut Alliance for Basic Human Needs, an organization that provides information about public policy issues. As the labor market shifts from higher-paying manufacturing jobs to lower-paying service employment, many of the jobs recovered pay 30 percent less than those that were lost.
Other figures compiled by the organization show that:
* Income inequity in Connecticut, the richest state in the nation, has been growing. From the late 1970's to the mid-1990's, the gap between families with the highest and lowest incomes increased faster than in any other state.
* During the last 10 years, the state's low and middle income families have seen their wages decrease, after adjusting for inflation.
* By the mid-1990's, the richest 20 percent of families in Connecticut had an average income of $147,000. The poorest 20 percent had an average income of $10,420.
* Between 1984 and 1995, the number of working poor families with children in the state doubled. Working poor is described as a family of four with a yearly income under the federal poverty level of $16,050.
The nation's economy is undoubtedly doing well by some standards, said Edward Deak, professor of economics at Fairfield University. "The unemployment rate, job creation and the rate of inflation -- all these things are stellar," he said. "But if you look behind the data, you'll find that manufacturing in the Midwest has bounced back, while coastal areas -- like Maryland, New England and the West Coast -- are much different in their economic structure and job opportunities than they were 25 years ago."
In eastern Connecticut, anecdotes reflect current stresses: One couple holds three jobs in order to support themselves and their two young children. A woman who works from 6 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. suddenly loses the day care she had arranged for her child. "Without day care and an extensive network of friends, many parents are putting their children in less than desirable settings. It's a tremendous burden on people trying to do the best thing," said Don Muirhead, director of human services in Windham, a town hurt by recent layoffs at Electric Boat and Pratt and Whitney as well as closings of other large employers during the 1970's and 80's.
The number of adult men and women using state-funded shelters has increased by approximately 10 percent over last year, according to the Connecticut Coalition to End Homelessness. Countless people are living with friends or relatives or on the streets. Some who use the shelters are employed but unable to cover the cost of their basic needs.
"We need to create real opportunities for jobs that pay, housing that's affordable and services in the community to help prevent crisis," Ms. McAtee said.
Workers with little education were able to develop skills in companies like Electric Boat in Groton that for decades earned them premium pay, Mr. Carpenter explained. "We supported that as a government," he said. "We enticed them and inflated their income beyond their training, and then the government pulled the rug out from under them. They couldn't get a job earning one-third the amount they earned before."
The far-reaching effects of job loss in eastern Connecticut have left some people so disheartened that they are unable to find employment, said Mr. Carpenter. "Once they are pushed out of the workplace," he said, "something takes place in their spirit. The hit is so great that they just can't pull things back together."
The people who are thriving, Mr. Deak said, are professionals with technical skills, while the worker with only a high school education and weak or highly specialized training is falling behind. "It isn't surprising that you see these pockets of poor economic performance," he said. "You may be able to find similar stories in some communities in the state's large cities."
The Pawcatuck Neighborhood Center -- which serves Stonington, North Stonington and Westerly, R.I. -- distributed 5,014 bags of food to needy families in the nine months from July 1, 1997 to April 30, 1998 -- the equivalent of more than 75,000 meals, up from 60,000 in the 1997-98 fiscal year. The total is expected to reach 80,000 by July 30 of this year, according to the director of the center, Billie Ward.
The problems that have left families and single people with no income include illness or injury resulting in loss of a job, layoff from work that does not qualify for unemployment compensation, downsizing of a work force, problems obtaining day care, seasonal work, domestic violence and separation or divorce, according to Ms. Ward.
Although some residents in center's area are wealthy, others are in financial crisis. And appearances are deceiving, Ms. Ward said. "You can't always tell by where they live or the car they drive," she said. "I have clients from Stonington Borough and Mystic. This is the other Connecticut."
In Killingly, in the northeast corner of the state, several factories and other businesses shut their doors during the past year. There used to be a certain number of jobs available to people with limited skills. But those positions have been taken by more highly skilled people, said David Shumway director of a 60-bed shelter in Killingly that is almost always full. In addition, cutbacks in city and state welfare have left most people who use the shelter with no income. "The question is whether or not they can get on their feet with part-time, minimum-wage jobs that have no benefits, because that's all there is," he said. "One of the biggest frauds of welfare reform success stories is the fact that the jobs that do exist are extremely limited. People work hard and stay poor."
The latest Census figures show that Connecticut's population is stagnating, as people leave the state in search of better jobs and places to retire. Experts connect the situation to the decline of the military industry, which pushed up costs of living and doing business in the state -- costs that have failed to drop in the new reality.
Recovery across the nation, particularly on the East and West Coasts, has depended on industries like financial services, computers and medical technology. And Connecticut is working to develop other industries, including biotechnology. "Not everyone has the resources to respond to the change," Mr. Deak said. "The question is what can be done to bring those people along."
