SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3132 words

HEADLINE: Mosquitoes Are Out To Get Us. But We're Out to Get Them.

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
A WHINE in the air. A sudden silence. That unmistakable stinging moment.
It is a sequence that has not changed, scientists say, for more than 100 million years, since the early descendants of the tropical Ur-mosquito were buzzing the Cretaceous era, enjoying a bit of Tyrannosaur tartare. 
 This year, the stinging, slapping and complaining have been gaining momentum. An El Nino-induced early spring gave the breeding season a jump start, and it has also been repeatedly drenched in mosquito-friendly rains. Whether the plague will continue is largely a matter of day-to-day weather conditions, the experts say, with occasional heavy rain promoting mosquitoes. But the indications are all extremely favorable. For the mosquitoes.
"It's hard to see how we're going to get out of this without a whole lot of mosquitoes," said Dominick Ninivaggi, who heads Suffolk County's $2 million mosquito control program, the largest in New York State with several thousand acres of its extensive salt-marshes known to be breeding sites.
North America counts about 170 species of mosquito, of which Long Island has 42. Not all of them bite humans. In fact, mosquitoes live on a diet of nectar. They pollinate flowers. In an adaptation that is usually mentioned to the accompaniment of bitter male laughter, only the females need blood. They use the protein for their eggs.
Researchers who identify species get to name them, which, it turns out, is an opportunity to exercise their senses of humor. Among the best-represented in this area is the genus Aedes, which includes the species excrucians, intrudens, provocans, sticticus and vexans. In the genus Coquillettidia, one species is named perturbans.
The counteroffensive has mobilized. Mondays and Tuesdays, inspectors in Suffolk and Nassau hunt for larvae. Tuesdays and Wednesdays, they check their traps for adults. Thursdays, from trucks and helicopters, workers fling larvacide pellets into the standing pools of brackish water hiding among the dunes along Jones Beach, into Long Island's vast stretches of salt marsh, and into the freshwater red maple swamps of Suffolk County. If all else fails, they fog adult mosquitoes with toxic mist.
But the whats and the whens and the whys of mosquito control are all different from -- and far more environmentally sensitive than -- what they used to be.
Prevention is the first order of business, and it takes the form of year-round wetlands management so environmentally friendly that nature conservancy agencies and groups have become willing partners. "The mosquitoes are in the wetlands, and the mosquito people work in wetlands, and we're interested in improving the quality of the wetlands for wildlife, and we find it's to our mutual benefit to work together," said Harry Knoch, regional wildlife director of the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
Last winter, 1,300 acres of sensitive salt marsh was restored in the first year of a decade-long, $10 million cooperative effort involving the state conservation department, the Suffolk County mosquito unit, the Long Island National Wildlife Refuges and Ducks Unlimited, a wetlands preservation group. Another 700 acres are being considered for restoration next winter, some of them in Nassau County, as part of the same effort, known as the Long Island Wetlands Restoration Initiative.
Workers have removed dikes from abandoned salt-hay farms, encouraging daily tidal flow, and have plugged ditches that drained the marshes twice daily. Although it increases the amount of standing water, this process helps to assure that fish can penetrate breeding areas. Workers even dig ponds so the fish can stay in mosquito-friendly spots even when water levels are low. The fish eat the larvae. The returning shore birds eat the fish. An ecological system gets healthier.
The wetlands management also discourages an invader weed called phragmites, which edges out the native wetlands grass, spartina, and is a better host to mosquito larvae.
"Some of us have money, some have equipment, some have manpower," Mr. Knoch said. "Collectively, we can do much more than any of us could do individually."
Nassau County mosquito inspectors don't even sample the water in nesting areas of the endangered piping plover without the company of a plover steward. It's a surprising twist for a field whose image, if it exists in the public imagination at all, is that of a huge, governmentally wielded can of Raid.
It was not always so. When Long Island's mosquito control started in the 1930's, before the era of DDT, cutting-edge technology meant ditches, and W.P.A. workers dug thousands of miles of them to drain salt marshes. Nassau County alone has nearly 1,000 miles of such ditches.
"The concept behind their work was that if you take the water off the marsh, you take out the mosquitoes," explained Craig Kessler, who heads the Long Island branch of Ducks Unlimited. "And that worked. But it also took out the food chain."
That resulted in a loss of habitat for the indigenous black duck and a "whole host of species," Mr. Kessler said, which are now being re-established in the restored marshes. Ducks Unlimited, an international group with 700,000 members, was founded in 1937 by Joseph Knapp, a hunter who realized that waterfowl breeding habitats were being destroyed by the encroachment of farms throughout the midwestern prairies. His great-grandaughter, Mr. Kessler noted, is Sibby Penny, a Southold resident. "She's quite active in our Peconic Bay chapter," he said.
Last winter's Restoration Initiative project included 470 acres at the Wertheim National Wildlife Refuge in Shirley, 90 acres at the Seatuck National Wildlife Refuge in Islip, and 100 acres of Suffolk County parkland in Sayville, according to Robert W. Parris, a project leader for the wildlife refuge.
The Restoration Initiative has focused on salt marshes so far, but the mosquito agencies have been quietly using similar procedures in freshwater swamps. Meandering ditches can reduce sheetwater, where larvae, which must breathe at the surface and feed on the bottom, flourish. But the ditches can be engineered not to dry the areas out, leaving the habitat intact for birds and other creatures. And standing water can be deepened into ponds and stocked with the guppy-sized mosquitofish, Gambusia affinis, a larval vacuum.
The mosquitofish has also proven useful for some manmade breeding grounds: those early drainage ditches meant to control mosquitoes, left untended, can fill and become new breeding areas.
Mosquito agencies try to spread the word to municipalities and homeowners that even tiny amounts of standing water can serve as breeding areas for some species. They tell stories of larvae in forgotten pails, swimming pool covers, even bottle caps.
Careful, thorough monitoring means that larvacides and other chemicals are only used when problems are documented. Inspectors drive around, sampling water for larvae and checking traps for adults. They count the take and identify the species in the lab. They send some to the state laboratory in Albany to be tested for disease. They take "landing counts," in which inspectors stand still for one minute and count how many mosquitoes land on them. Only when a portrait of a local mosquito population is complete is it time to prescribe a pesticidal treatment.
Expensive biorational agents -- substances that interfere with the life cycle of the mosquito, but with virtually nothing else -- are the weapons of choice for spraying. Some are preparations of bacteria that attack only larvae of a certain age. For instance, the helicopters buzzing Jones Beach in the early morning are usually spreading B.T.I. (Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis), which, when ingested by a larva, destroy its stomach. That, and a longer-acting biorational, Bacillus sphaericus, are accepted by even the most cautious environmentalists.
Other compounds mimic the mosquito's growth hormone, preventing larvae from emerging as adults, but leaving them alive and well as fish food.
The point is to get the mosquitoes as early as possible, before they take wing and spread out.
"If we can't control them in the early phase, with fish, or using environmental means, or chemical larvacides," said Greg Terrillion, who heads Nassau County's mosquito agency, "then we're upland fogging. And those materials just aren't as specific to mosquitoes."
On Long Island, the preferred "adulticide," as the fogging chemicals are known, is resmethrin, a synthetic version of a chrysanthemum derivative that attacks insects' nervous systems. It's a powerful material, sold under the brand name Scourge. But even it is used in an environmentally friendly compound, which evaporates entirely in minutes. Organophosphates, which are still used in neighboring states to kill adult mosquitoes, are not allowed in New York.
It's a far cry from the early methods, which, besides extensive ditching, included spraying sheetwater with heavy oil to smother larvae. And of course, DDT, a chlorinated hydrocarbon, was a popular pesticide, until evidence of its pervasive and long-lasting toxicity became widely known in the early 60's.
New York has some of the most restrictive pesticide regulations in the nation. Every use of pesticide must be reported to the state, in part so that researchers can see if there is any connection to Long Island's cancer level, which has been found to be high. When pesticides are used, only a person licensed by the state to apply them is allowed to handle and disperse the materials. "We need a full-time staff person just to make sure that we comply with all the laws," said Mr. Ninivaggi, the Suffolk mosquito man.
In terms of biting, some of Long Island's most troubling species are Culex pippians, the common house mosquito; Aedes vexans, the floodwater mosquito, and Aedes sollicitans, the salt-marsh mosquito. This mosquito lays its eggs at the rack line, the inland reach of the twice-monthly lunar tides. Untouched by the daily tides that would wash them away, the eggs go through a necessary drying phase, and then, at the new moon or the full moon, are soaked, enabling larvae to hatch. The biting will begin about a week later, perhaps 10 or 12 days later if the weather remains cool.
Left uncontrolled, the experts say, much of the South Shore would be uninhabitable.
A recent example in Nassau County proved the case. The mosquito problem had been reduced by the end of the 80's, thanks in part to the installation of sewers, which helped eliminate standing water. In 1992, with the recession hitting full force, Nassau County reduced its payroll by 3,000 workers, and the mosquito control unit was essentially eradicated.
Then, in 1996, one of the wettest summers on record, the mosquitoes took over Jones Beach, the county's most prolific mosquito breeding area.
"There were signs saying, 'No refunds due to insects,' " recalled Mr. Terrillion. "You'd see mom and dad, with the kids and the coolers, getting out of the car in the parking lot. And in the time it took them to walk to the sidewalk, they turned around and went back to the car."
In both Nassau and Suffolk, the mosquito agencies are divisions of the Department of Public Works, where there is enough equipment and manpower to do wetlands management. But, in testament to lingering fears of mosquito-borne diseases, which kill millions in less-developed areas of the world, both divisions work cooperatively with their county health departments.
"Just because people are not getting sick here doesn't mean we can relax," said Mr. Ninivaggi. "We're not just abating a nuisance."
The salt-marsh mosquito is widely believed to be a carrier of eastern equine encephalitis. It has been found in Long Island mosquitoes four of the last five years, Mr. Ninivaggi said, but the deadly disease is usually only a problem during long, hot summers in which the disease overruns birds, its host population, and begins spreading to horses. Humans are also susceptible, but such cases are rare.
Only one genus, Anopheles, carries malaria, and its only local species, quadrimaculatus, is not common on Long Island. Malaria is caused by a protozoan that mosquitoes ingest with blood and then inject into victims as part of their blood-thinning saliva. (The complex demands of the transfer process insure that H.I.V. cannot be spread by mosquito bite.)
Malaria hasn't been evident on the island since the 30's. But it has come as close as New Jersey, as recently as 1991. New Jersey state health officials say that two people were infected after local mosquitoes bit people who had come from the tropics with untreated malaria.
There is even a sort of killer bee of mosquitoes threatening to invade Long Island: Aedes albopictus, the Asian tiger mosquito. An aggressive daytime biter that breeds easily in urban settings, it has been spreading through the United States since its arrival from Asia, where it is an active disease carrier, in a boatload of used tires in 1985. Identified in New Jersey in 1995, the mosquito seems to have paused in its expansion. But ports and marinas on Long Island are being carefully watched.
"We've been looking for two years, but we haven't found any tigers yet," Mr. Ninivaggi said.
These days, watching is a crucial part of mosquito control. Inspectors have identified exactly which areas mosquitoes breed in. In Suffolk County, records of the locations are being painstakingly transferred into a computerized mapping system that will include complaint and treatment histories for each site. The "Service Request" computer screen has a little box marked "Compliments" next to the "Complaints" entry, but Mr. Ninivaggi just laughed. "We don't need a computer to keep track of compliments," he said.
 
SKEETER EATERS: FACT AND FICTION
Some predators of mosquitoes get little credit and some get way too much. Dr. Wayne Crans, chief entomologist of the New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, sets the record straight.
 
GAMBUSIA AFFINIS This inchlong freshwater fish eats hundreds of larvae an hour. It bears live young -- 120 to 400 a year -- and so requires no special environment to spawn. And unlike most fish, it tolerates warm, shallow standing water, making it ideal for adding to stormwater basins, ditches and freshwater marshes.
 
KILLIFISH Like Gambusia, these fish eat mosquito larvae, but are generally less tolerant of fetid water.
 
BATS Mosquitoes make up a very small percentage of insectivorous bats' natural diets. Research that suggested otherwise was based on 1950's echo-location studies, in which bats were released in rooms full of nothing but mosquitoes. Those bats ate up to 10 mosquitoes a minute. That finding has been extrapolated to suggest that an average-sized colony of 500 bats would remove at least a quarter million mosquitoes an hour. In fact, bats usually vastly prefer moths, beetles and other non-pest insects.
 
PURPLE MARTINS There is a bit of utterly false popular wisdom that says this bird can eat 2,000 to 14,000 mosquitoes a day. But that is based on the calculation of the number of insects it would take to maintain the purple martin's body weight. In fact, purple martins will eat a few mosquitoes, but they prefer dragonflies and other insects. And dragonflies eat mosquitoes.
 
DRAGONFLIES Immature dragonflies stand at the edge of ponds and pounce on mosquito larvae. Mature dragonflies fly "patrols" over ponds, catching mosquitoes in midair and eating them in flight. Dragonflies will even follow mosquito broods into fields. ANDREA KANNAPELL
 
The Repellent Truth
ONLY female mosquitoes bite, and only because they need a meal of blood to acquire the protein necessary to lay their eggs. These critters find their quarry by detecting the carbon dioxide from the animals' breath, as well as lactic acid and other, less studied byproducts of metabolism.
Scientists have confirmed that some people are much more attractive to mosquitoes than others: Sweaty people are more appealing than non-sweaters, adults more than children, men more than women, and larger people more than smaller people.
But the scientists don't know why this is so; if they did, they might have devised a truly effective mosquito repellent. Meanwhile, we're stuck with repellent wannabes and impostors, and some that actually are slightly more noxious to mosquitoes than they are to humans.
Some plants supposedly repel mosquitoes, but in "Mosquitoes and Mosquito Repellents: A Clinician's Guide," published in the June 1 edition of Annals of Internal Medicine, Mark S. Fradin writes that the best-known repellent plant, the Citrosa, a genetically engineered hybrid of lemon grass and geraniums, has been shown to be ineffective. So have bug zappers, which electrocute other varieties of insects but not mosquitoes, and novelty electronic devices that emit high-frequency sound waves.
That leaves topical repellents, which work by evaporating at the skin surface, creating a "fog" that wards off the insect. The most common is DEET (N,N,-diethyl-3-methylbenzamide) -- the active ingredient in commercial sprays like Off -- which was patented by the United States Army in 1946. The chemical can be toxic, particularly to children. Products with 10 percent to 35 percent concentrations of the chemical are considered adequate under normal conditions. High temperatures and sunscreen reduce its effectiveness.
Citronella, the oil of a grass, can be an effective but short-lived repellent, requiring frequent reapplication. It is the most common active ingredient in repellents marketed as "natural," like Buzz Away (5 percent), Herbal Armor (15 percent) and Green Ban for People (5 and 10 percent).
Several years ago, Avon Skin-So-Soft, a bath oil reputed to function as a repellent, was tested in laboratory conditions and found to provide 30 to 40 minutes' worth of protection against at least two mosquito species. (And there's the rub: Mosquito species are many and mobile, so you have no way of knowing which types are in your yard.) Avon has since added trace amounts of citronella oil to its Skin-So-Soft products.
A plant-based repellent that is new to the United States, Bite Blocker, combines soybean oil with geranium and coconut oil. Canadian studies show that it gave nearly 100 percent protection from some mosquito species for more than three hours.
A final category of repellent is a contact insecticide. Permethrin, a synthetic form of an African chrysanthemum, is the active ingredient in lice treatments as well as in aerial sprays that kill adult mosquitoes. It is applied to clothing and gear, like tents and sleeping bags, rather than to skin. ANDREA KANNAPELL

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
New Horizons For Frequent Fliers

 BODY:
Trans World Airlines has begun a new frequent-flier program, called Aviators, to replace its Frequent Flight Bonus program. Mileage from the old program has been transferred to Aviators. The new program offers benefits based on money spent as well as miles flown, quicker access to higher program levels and changes in award levels. Members are awarded one bonus Aviator mile for each dollar spent on full fares in first class, business or coach. Flights between cities less than 750 miles apart require only 15,000 miles for coach or 30,000 miles for first class. Longer domestic flights cost 25,000 miles for a coach ticket and 40,000 miles for first class. More information: (800) 325-4815.
Airtran, formerly Valujet, inaugurated its A-Plus Rewards program in March. Airtran customers earn free travel through the end of the year, redeemable on Airtran and several other airlines (America West, American, American Trans Air, Continental, Delta, Eastwind, Midway, Midwest Express, Northwest, Reno, Southwest, T.W.A., United and US Airways). 
 All travel must be either to or from Atlanta, Orlando or Washington.
Participants collect flight credit vouchers before departure. Those traveling in coach class receive one voucher for each one-way trip, those in business class receive two. Twelve vouchers are needed for a travel-reward certificate. One travel-reward certificate is required for a free round-trip ticket on any Airtran flight, and two certificates are required for a round-trip economy class ticket on another airline.
Free tickets on other airlines are available only for nonstop or direct round-trip flights to cities that Airtran does not serve within the United States (except Hawaii and Alaska) or to the Bahamas from Atlanta. Thirty days' notice and a Saturday-night stopover are required.
Redemption of a reward certificate for an Airtran flight does not require the Saturday-night stopover or 30-day advance notice. All credit vouchers must be redeemed for certificates by March 31, 1999. Certificates may be used for travel through December 2000. More information: (888) 327-5878.

HEADLINE: Q&A/Paul Collard;
The Arts Meet the City in New Haven

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
PAUL COLLARD was hired last fall to be the director of New Haven's International Festival of Arts and Ideas, now in its third year and running this Wednesday through Sunday.
Mr. Collard, 42 years old, is a native of Britain and attended Trinity College in Cambridge, England. In 1987 he wrote a report on the role that the arts play in the economic regeneration of cities. Just before his arrival in New Haven, Mr. Collard served as chief executive of Northern Sights, a visual arts festival in northern England. 
 In a recent interview in his office overlooking the New Haven Green, Mr. Collard seemed unable to contain his enthusiasm over this year's New Haven festival. He repeatedly knelt in his chair and leaned over a table to illustrate one point or another, talking in rapid-fire sentences and pulling on his mop of dark brown hair. He had just returned from the London world premiere of "Copenhagen," a play by the Royal National Theater of London that will be at the Long Wharf Theater as part of the festival. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. What was your role in the Northern Sights festival?
A. I directed the Visual Arts Festival in Newcastle in the north of England for 37 weeks in 1996. I think arts are at their best when most deeply rooted in the community in which they are taking place. The last coal mine in the Newcastle region closed down in the mid-1990's. There was incredible desolation. Then along came me and said, "We are doing a visual arts festival," I said, "It's up to you people. You are going to do it." That struck at the heart of many people's belief that you need all these experts to do art. And they did incredible things.
Q. What interested you in this job in New Haven?
A. I am interested in the role that the arts can play in terms of making profound social and economic changes within a community. There are two camps: A is "high art," or art for art's sake; B is "community art" where what comes out is not as important as the process. If you can connect A with B you get something remarkable.
People in the festival in New Haven had a similar ambition. There were profound social and economic issues that needed to be addressed, but they did not want to lose sight of the fact that the work needed to be of the highest quality.
Q. How did you go about getting to know the community?
A. During the first few weeks I met with lots of people in the community, asking them questions about where they see this city going and what they see as their role. I think there are two issues: the economic stabilization and regeneration of downtown, and the social issues.
This is a city of very rich and complex structure, with 126 ethnic communities, most of them completely invisible. Imagine the cultural life of New Haven to be an iceberg with only the tip of it showing.
We want to develop an arts festival that is more reflective of the whole society. I get told all the time that diversity is a problem. I come from a tradition that says diversity is what makes cities wonderful.
Q. How exactly will these people be involved in the festival?
A. Through the part of the festival we're calling Downtown. It used to be called Art on the Edge, and that was a very important part of the beginning of the process. This year we're putting it along Orange Street.
We went out to the neighborhoods and said, "We want you to create art that is reflective of your culture, of who you are." Eleven groups will be presenting at different venues. Some of them are neighborhood groups, some are local cultural groups. Each one is getting a visual artist to work with them and a budget to create their project. The total budget is $70,000 to $80,000. Each group will get between $2,000 and $2,500. In addition, we pay the performers and build the stages.
Q. Do you also have regional artists performing?
A. Yes. We wrote to 2,500 performance groups in Connecticut. Forty-two of them were selected, and they, plus the 11 local groups, will be performing on three stages set up along Orange Street.
Q. What is the relationship of the festival to city government?
A. The festival is an independent nonprofit organization. Its honorary chairs are Yale president Rick Levin, the Governor, John Rowland, and Mayor John DeStefano Jr. It's a partnership. I am a servant of the mayor even though I'm not on his payroll.
Q. How do you see the festival having an impact on the stabilization and regeneration of downtown?
A. If the economic regeneration agenda is going to work, it has to get people to come back to the city after the festival is over. The main guide to the festival has lots of ads for restaurants and shops downtown. We are being incredibly focused in our marketing. We did a targeted mailing of 125,000 for the ticketed events to people in the suburbs and beyond to come here and spend money. They would not get programming as good as this outside of New York City. The free stuff is not promoted to them.
Q. You have greatly expanded the children's offerings this year. What does that schedule look like?
A. We have a huge kids' program. We're going to have four days of nonstop programming on the Green during the afternoons. It's going to be very interactive, and not just arts, but ideas too, like hands-on science projects. We're targeting kids through their moms by doing a promotion with Stop & Shop and People's Bank.
Q. The "Ideas" part of the festival seems to get lost among all the arts offerings. This year that part is called "Big Ideas for the New Millennium." Have you put more emphasis on it than formerly?
A. Yes. We want it to be ideas about life in general, not just ideas about art. At the same time, we don't want to create an academic conference, but rather to address the concerns of ordinary people.
We're sponsoring a three-day event on cities that will address what works, the future of cities, and a design workshop specifically discussing New Haven's problems. We've commissioned a project by Tracie Morris called "Grown Over Ivy," which explores the relationship of Yale to the community. It's a series of intertwined monologues that are based on real interviews -- mostly with African-Americans who work at Yale but live in New Haven and have to make sense of that. The monologues have been fictionalized because they are so personal there was concern that people could be identified, but also because we wanted to transcend the particular.
Q.You have lined up some very popular acts for the free evening performances on the Green.
A.Yes. For example, Leahy, a Canadian-Irish group will be performing on Friday night, which will also serve as the kick-off for the Irish festival in North Haven that weekend. Little Richard is scheduled for Saturday. People told us if we bring El Gran Combo and the Barrio Boyzz to the Green on the same program -- which we're doing on the closing night of the festival -- we can expect 100,000 people.
Q.The festival you worked on in England was part of a larger vision of a millennium celebration. Do you think New Haven has a cultural vision?
A.I don't think you can run a successful cultural festival unless there's a cultural plan. We have become very involved in that, along with the arts council, the business community, Yale and city government. I chair the committee, which stands alone from the festival but in fact most of the people on the committee happen to be on the board of the festival.
Q.You came here with just a one-year contract. Do you think you'll be staying past the festival?
A.I'm in discussion with the board about staying longer. We both want that.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul Collard, director of New Haven's International Festival of Arts and Ideas, on stage at the Green. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The World: Sorry, You Can't Reach There From Here;
In Africa, Dreaming of a Wired World

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
AFTER relatively rich South Africa, which African country has the highest percentage of cellular phones among telephone users? Ghana? The Ivory Coast? Kenya? Nigeria?
None of the above. The correct answer is the desperately poor, badly shot-up Democratic Republic of the Congo, where the regular telephone system -- where it exists at all -- is so decrepit that cellular is often the only option. 
 Cheerleading for the dream of an African renaissance is all the rage these days on the continent, but without better telecommunications it will be as hard to spread wealth and democracy as it would have been for Florence and Chartres to spread Renaissance culture without the old Roman roads.
Only about 1 in 300 people in sub-Saharan Africa has a phone, making the financial opportunities huge. Most companies marketing heavily to rural Africa are pushing low-technology goods like beer, cigarettes, detergent and fertilizer. But impoverished Africans also need telephones to relay family news and money, just as many poor New Yorkers do when they patronize storefront phone shops.
For example, failing to come home for a funeral is a grave social offense in Africa. When a village doesn't have a phone, someone must go to the city simply to tell others that a villager has died.
 
A Phone in Every Village
"Africans spend a huge proportion of their meager incomes going places they could reach by phone," said Piers Letcher, a spokesman for the International Telecommunication Union, a Geneva-based United Nations affiliate. "People who need food will pay for telecommunications -- they're transferring money from their transportation budgets."
Contrary to common wisdom, rural telephones can make money if the goal is one phone in every village, not one in each hut. Bakary K. Njie, managing director of the national telephone company of tiny Gambia, took on the risk of laying a 250-mile fiber optic cable through the hinterland and attached 300 privately owned 24-hour phone centers. Villagers walked miles to line up outside the centers, which soon paid for the costly cable installation.
The continent's obstacles are huge, however, and politics is a bigger one than poverty, malarial jungles or the snows of Kilimanjaro. Hard as it is to wire the one billion people in China, at least they all live in one country -- Africa's 740 million people live in 55. Those African nations that don't have overwhelming problems like civil war have simpler ones, like bureaucratic sloth and dishonesty.
Each country has different telecommunications laws -- or none at all. And many governments earn a big chunk of their budgets through their doddering telephone monopolies. The money comes from tourists and executives in hotels that gouge so deeply that the phone bill often tops the room bill, and from the fees paid by American and European carriers for incoming calls connected through the monopolies.
 
Red Tape
There are also absurd inefficiencies. For example, in a colonial legacy, a call from South Africa to next-door Mozambique was until recently routed through both London and Lisbon. Even when a country wants to improve its phone service, pythons of red tape can encircle the effort.
Suspicion of complex technology is high. Bashir Ahmad el-Rufai, president of Intercellular Nigeria, said he had to approach 20 Nigerian banks to raise a mere $10 million for his network. "One banker asked us to line up a buyer for my telecom equipment if it didn't work -- as if it was used furniture I could get rid of," he said. Approaching foreign bankers was pointless, he added, because they are afraid of Nigerian corruption.
Later this year, the ultimate in phone technology is set to roll out: hand-held phones able to call from anywhere on the planet to anywhere else, thanks to new networks of dozens of low-orbit satellites. It's expensive but ideal for Africa's vast unwired spaces.
Getting bureaucrats in 55 countries to sign licenses is a nightmare, though. "A civil servant's job is fairly tenuous in Africa," said John A. Richardson, head of Iridium Africa, which has a satellite network. "Seeing us means writing a position paper for the minister, and so on. Why do that if you can get away with doing nothing?"
On the plus side, corruption seems to be abating. Mr. Richardson said he had been steered toward signing on local partners related to government officials, but had "never personally bumped into an overt or covert request for a bribe."
 
A New Frontier
Pekka Tarjanne, secretary general of the International Telecommunication Union, is an optimist for three reasons: technology is rapidly becoming cheaper, the fading of socialism means privatization is no longer a dirty word and minister of telecommunications is now an important post in many countries. In 36 countries, the post offices no longer run the national phone systems. In 10, there are competing cellular phone companies.
Even pie-in-the-sky ideas seem not so crazy these days. Joseph Okpaku, a Nigerian-American entrepreneur, attends conferences trying to rustle up funding for his dream company, Telecom Africa. His goals are to reverse the African diaspora, create pan-African affirmative action and make everyone involved rich. His vision is to recruit engineers around the world to come back to Africa to design and produce telecommunications equipment here.
Hopelessly romantic? Maybe not. Iridium is one of six new satellite companies competing to serve Africa, and one way they can make friends is to make their equipment here.
As Mr. Letcher of the International Telecommunication Union said, "If you can create 10,000 jobs in Africa, you'll land the deal."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Only about 1 in 300 Africans has a telephone, so centers like this one in South Africa are vital links to the outside world. (Graeme Williams for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Rental Builder Shifts to High Gear

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
THE circle of developers who build and then continue to own and manage rental apartments in Manhattan for the long term is small. "It's no more than six or eight people, maybe 10, and they all know each other," said Aby J. Rosen.
Now Mr. Rosen and two partners, Michael Fuchs and Trevor Davis, are moving to catapult themselves into that small circle of Manhattan owner-builders, among them several of long standing who are still producing new rental buildings. They include Leonard Litwin of Glenwood Management, the Resnick family through the Resnick Organization, the Elghanayan family of Rockrose Development and Daniel Brodsky, Bernard Spitzer and Donald Zucker. 
 Through a development partnership known as RFR Davis, Mr. Rosen, Mr. Fuchs and Mr. Davis have set in motion more new residential projects in Manhattan in the late 90's than any other development company, with perhaps the exception of The Related Companies, which is doing both commercial and residential development. Starting from zero only a few years ago, they are seeking to build a portfolio of several thousand apartments within a few short years. Most of their sites are on the East Side, where they are easily the most active builder.
"We plan to stay here, and to grow to 25 buildings, and create a concentrated portfolio," said Mr. Rosen, whose given name, Aby, is pronounced A-bee, accented on the first syllable. He and Mr. Fuchs, both 38 years old, are lifelong friends who grew up together in Frankfurt, Germany. Their partner, Mr. Davis, is from South Africa.
"We plan to have a total of 3,000 to 3,500 apartments," Mr. Rosen said. Most of them will be in new luxury buildings that they build themselves, he said.
In the 80's, market conditions were such that such an aspiration might have seemed implausible. At that time the market seemed incapable of supporting the rent levels that builders needed to justify the prices they were paying for land, and most new projects were built as condominiums.
But by the early 90's land prices had dropped, and before long rent levels were strengthening also, setting the stage for a resumption of rental building. "Condominiums make money but leave an investor with the problem of how to reinvest it," Mr. Davis said. He and other developers have now returned to building rentals, intending, as Mr. Davis put it, to build wealth for the next generation.
In 1994, when the group started buying land, there had been almost no new luxury residential construction for seven years, Mr. Davis said. To the three partners, luxury rental construction looked like the surest way to build a real estate asset base in New York City, where all three men say they want to keep their business roots. But it is also a flexible product, he said. "You always have the option of going the other way, converting to a condominium."
The partners already own 1,400 apartments in nine buildings. Most were acquired to assure longterm light and air for new buildings on neighboring lots, and in some cases to provide additional development rights in a merged zoning lot. Most of their building sites, however, are smaller than the 20,000 square feet -- 200 feet on the avenue and 100 feet on the sidestreet -- that many large builders prefer.
Only one of the new RFR buildings is completed and fully occupied so far. A rental at 300 East 64th Street, on the southeast corner of Second Avenue, it has 103 apartments and opened in 1996.
A second building, Eastbridge Landing, at 377 East 33d Street, on the west side of First Avenue between 33d and 34th Streets, is close to completion and is already 70 percent leased and 50 percent occupied. It has 209 apartments on its 22 floors.
Sixty of the apartments, on the third through the seventh floors, will be operated as the Envoy Club, a residential hotel for longterm occupants, scheduled to open in August. The club will be reached from a separate elevator in the lobby.
Another building, Wellington Tower, on the southwest corner of 82d Street at First Avenue, will have 156 apartments on 18 floors, with stores on the avenue side. Construction has reached the level of the sixth floor and occupancy is expected by the end of this year.
Beyond these projects lie well-advanced plans for the development of six more sites. Four of them are on the Upper East Side. One is the so-called Cottages site, on the west side of Third Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets. There the partnership plans a condominium named the Empire, replacing a Third Avenue blockfront structure that has stores on the ground level and one level of apartments above that face a handsome interior garden. Each of the garden apartments has its own garden in front, giving the group the semblance of a row of cottages.
A local group, the Coalition to Save the Cottages and Garden, has worked to preserve the garden as a landmark. It should become a permanent community amenity, accessible to all, as part of any reconstruction of the property, said Deborah Balcourt, a leader of the coalition.
The garden can be seen by the public through a gate at the 78th Street side of the property. At present it is an amenity for the Cottages tenants, but it is also used by the residents of the adjoining 12-story rental at 177 East 77th Street, who can enter it from their lobby. RFR acquired both properties from the same ownership. The Landmarks Preservation Commission has declined to hold a hearing on the issue.
There are six remaining residential tenants on the site for the new building, one of whom was an employee of the former ownership. The rest are longterm elderly residents, two of them rent-controlled and three rent-stabilized. Mr. Rosen said he expected construction to begin in the fall.
The other buildings planned for the Upper East Side are Century Tower, on the southeast corner of 90th Street and First Avenue; the Seville, on the southeast corner of Second Avenue and 77th Street, and the Impala, on an irregularly shaped lot with 100 feet of frontage on the east side of First Avenue on the midblock between 75th and 76th Streets, and additional frontage on the sidestreets.
ANOTHER site for future development is on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 38th Street. The building there, 425 Fifth Avenue, is to have 195 apartments, plus retail and office space and another Envoy Club residential hotel.
And in Tuckahoe, N.Y., construction will begin next month on RiverVue, the $32 million redevelopment of a former Revlon factory and surrounding property into 88 rental apartments and 13 for-sale town houses. The site is off Scarsdale Road and Lake Avenue, diagonally across Main Street from the Tuckahoe Metro North railroad station.
The site plan calls for a lighted riverwalk on the Yonkers side of the Bronx River, which runs through the 8.8-acre property, plus a tennis court and outdoor pool, and parking, both covered and uncovered, for 161 cars. In addition there will be a 126-unit assisted living project on the site, to be built and operated by Kapson Senior Quarters Corporation, of Woodbury, L.I.
Time is of the essence to RFR Davis. A construction schedule for new projects is already laid out through 2001. Although RFR Davis is the joint-venture development company, Mr. Davis has his own investment company, Davis & Partners, as well as a construction company, Davis Construction, and a management company, Wolf Management & Leasing, which runs the partners' buildings. HRH Construction Corporation, a division of the Starrett Corporation, is the construction manager on the RFR projects. It has set up a group of eight senior executives solely to handle the RFR assignment.
Separately, Mr. Rosen and Mr. Fuchs are allied in a real estate investment company, RFR Holding LLC, formed in 1991. But the recent ventures have been done in partnership with Mr. Davis. "RFR" stands for Rosen Fuchs Real Estate.
Only the Empire on Third Avenue and 77th Street, with 87 apartments on 34 floors, is planned as a condominium. Its apartments "will probably sell for about $1,000 a square foot," Mr. Rosen said. That suggests that most of them will cost more than $1 million. The rest of the Manhattan buildings are rentals. The financing is conventional, not the "80-20" tax-exempt financing that other builders have used recently, which provides low-income occupancy in 20 percent of the units. To stimulate variety in design concepts, a variety of design architects have been selected.
All the projects have been been built as-of-right, without special zoning approvals, and all use the Section 421a tax abatement offered by the city, which means that the rentals will be rent-stabilized for 10 years after construction. To get the abatement, the developer bought tax-abatement certificates that other builders generated by building mortgage-free low-income housing. RFR Davis itself is building 560 low-income apartments in seven projects -- in the Bronx, Staten Island, Brooklyn and Queens -- to generate these certificates.
Mr. Rosen and Mr. Fuchs are the sons of postwar commercial developers in Frankfurt. "We've known each other since kindergarten in 1962," Mr. Rosen said. His father, Isak, now 72 and retired, is an Auschwitz survivor. His mother, Anni, also survived the Nazi years, hidden under a false name for five years by a Christian family in Belgium.
Mr. Fuchs's father, Don, 78, is also retired. During the war he was hidden in the basement of a Christian friend in eastern Poland, the son said. His non-Jewish mother lived through the war in Lodz, Poland.
The sons are both married to Americans. Both couples live on the East Side, and both have two children. Mr. Rosen's are boys; Mr. Fuchs's are girls.
"We are lifelong friends who have invested together," Mr. Rosen said. "We came to the United States planning to start a company." Before they did it, Mr. Rosen spent three years working in the New York office of Jones Lang Wootton, the British real estate firm, attracting German investment capital to American real-estate ventures. Mr. Fuchs, who arrived in the United States in 1987, earned a business degree at the University of Southern California.
IN the early 90's, the real estate market was at its nadir and financing from American banks was tight. But RFR was buying, helped by a line of credit from German financial institutions and by funds from the partners' families, who were planning a gradual transfer of their investments from Germany to America.
The partners bought about 2.5 million square feet of midtown and downtown office space in the early 90's, Mr. Rosen said. Some of it has since been refinanced as values rose, he said, generating the equity for residential site acquisitions.
They also formed a company named Classic Realty, which owns 1,000 co-op apartments that have never been sold for owner occupancy. Among these are more than 500 apartments in the former Bing & Bing buildings on the Upper East Side, which were converted from rentals to co-ops or condominiums in the late 80's.
In 1995 the partners joined forces with Mr. Davis, whose father, Desmond Davis, ran a South African heavy-construction firm that bore his name. Mr. Davis, 43, started out doing doing subsidized home construction in South Africa in a business that was affiliated with his father's. He came to the United States seeking greater professional opportunity.
After studying architecture and engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he went to California and started to develop an office building in downtown San Diego, helped by family financing.
Eventually he sold that property and came to New York to work for Olympia & York U.S.A. on office buildings it was developing. He left Olympia & York after declining to transfer to London to work on its ill-fated Canary Wharf venture, and decided to try development on his own.
In 1993 he noticed a sign reading "Trafalgar House" in a partially excavated lot at Second Avenue and 64th Street, the announcement of a development plan that never materialized. He found the owner and put down $100,000 to secure the right to buy ther property for $2.5 million within a year. Within that year he also found RFR Holding, and the Second Avenue site became their first joint venture.
"We are all immigrants and every immigrant grows up dreaming of this great city," Mr. Davis said. "It's an amazing place to be, in good times and bad. And I've always wanted to build high-rises."
The first one, 300 East 64th Street, has turned out to attract a large number of short-stay occupants. About 10 of the leases are in corporate name, but in 15 more "that we know of" the leases are in an individual's name but the rent is paid by a corporation, said Felicia Harrison, who is in charge of leasing for Wolf Management.
In the first year of operation, there was a 40 percent turnover of the tenancy, Ms. Harrison said. She estimated that half the tenants are singles and that the average annual income of residents, including year-end bonuses, is $200,000.
Marianne Dolan, a 38-year-old investment professional working for a money management firm, rented a 17th-floor one-bedroom in 1996 and now pays $3,000 a month for it. She said she travels a great deal, gets to her apartment late at night, and is grateful for the fifth-floor sauna and steam room. She has worked in Chicago, San Francisco and Greenwich, Conn. "This is my first time in New York since college, and I'm loving it," she said. A single person needs an income of about $125,000 to $150,000 a year to afford the rent she is paying, Ms. Dolan estimated.
To cater to this type of tenant, the building has 76 one-bedroom apartments. Only 21 apartments are two bedrooms or larger.
IN contrast, the East 33d Street building, Eastbridge Landing, has many more two-bedroom apartments -- 52 of them -- but they are laid out in such a way as to make sharing easy by two adults not living intimately together. The apartments have central entrances and separated one-bedroom suites, each with its own bathroom, off to either side. The kitchen is at the center.
The architect for Eastbridge Landing is Costas A. Kondylis. "In two-bedroom apartments we've found it's preferable to have the bedrooms separated even when it's used by one family," Mr. Kondylis said. What began in several buildings as a floor plan suited for apartment sharing, because it promotes privacy, has become the rule rather than the exception in two-bedroom apartments, he said.
The rents at Eastbridge Landing average $1,950 for studios, $2,550 for one-bedrooms, and $4,100 for the two-bedroom two-bath apartments (with a range of $3,800 to $6,000). The building was provided with an 800-square-foot "business center" with a computer and modem, a fax machine, a copier and a phone. "We've learned that nowadays a lot of tenants like to work from home," Ms. Harrison said.
In later projects there are different design architects: H. Thomas O'Hara of Manhattan for Century Tower; the Office of Robert A. M. Stern Architects for the Seville and 425 Fifth Avenue, and for the town houses in Tuckahoe; Michael Graves of Princeton, N.J., for the Impala, and Hartman-Cox Architects, a Washington firm, for Wellington Tower and the Empire.
The New York firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman & Efron is doing the interior layouts for most of the buildings. Peter Claman, a principal in the firm, said that a distinguishing characteristic of the apartments done for RFR Davis was that all the units have washer-dryers, "even studios."
"The room sizes are larger and the kitchens are larger than in most other market-rate rentals," Mr. Claman said.
But perhaps the greatest asset of the new buildings will be their presence in highly desired East Side locations with little new housing production. Elena Arredonda, who is in her late 20's and works for the U.S. Tennis Association in White Plains, rented an apartment at 300 East 64th Street a year ago after looking at about 15 apartments in other buildings.
"I wanted a one-bedroom apartment in a building less than 10 years old, and I wanted to be in the East 60's," Ms. Arredonda said. "That doesn't leave many options."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Nevada Test Site;
Sign of the Times at a Once-Secret Base: For Rent

BYLINE: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFF 

DATELINE: MERCURY, Nev.

 BODY:
TO visit the Nevada Test Site, the nation's primary nuclear proving ground for more than four decades, and stand near a crater blasted deep into the desert bedrock, is an exercise in silence.
The dry lake beds and thorny plains where scientists detonated nuclear weapons during the cold war are now, in peacetime, mostly devoid of activity and hundreds of sheds and warehouses that once housed personnel and research facilities are now eerily empty. 
 So it may be surprising that this test range, as big as Rhode Island, polluted in places with radiation and shielded behind a veil of secrecy, is described in a brochure as "open for business."
And it may also be surprising that employees of the Federal Department of Energy, which controls the test site and the nation's nuclear program, now use phrases such as "commercial development" and "private investment" alongside traditional test site jargon like "kiloton yield."
In an effort to generate money and promote economic development here in southern Nevada following a moratorium on nuclear testing in 1992, the Government has begun to transform parts of this base -- where the staff has been cut from 10,000 to 2,500 -- into a business park of sorts.
Companies are invited to open facilities at the test site -- whose main entrance is near this small town 65 miles north of Las Vegas -- with the unusual lures of restricted access and absence of neighbors who, for example, might complain about the use of toxic chemicals.
The three-year-old program is similar to the Defense Department's effort to help communities hurt by military downsizing. But there are some important differences: The test site is under no threat of closing, has no plans to sell off land and is mandated to stay ready for nuclear tests in case international tensions rise.
"This is a site with characteristics that don't exist anywhere else," said Tim Carlson, president of the Nevada Test Site Development Corporation, the nonprofit organization financed by the Energy Department to market the test site. "In there, you find a niche. Take the aerospace industry, for example. Where else can you find restricted airspace in the United States? Where else can you launch a reusable rocket?"
The only tenant so far is Fluid Tech, a company that cleans equipment contaminated with low-level radiation. To its relief, it has found a warm welcome inside a massive abandoned hangar with steel blast doors, cleaning bays and an overhead crane. There, in the 60's, scientists tried to develop a nuclear-powered rocket.
FLUID TECH had built a facility in the nearby town of Amargosa Valley, but was blocked from opening by local opposition. Dean Rowsell, president of Fluid Tech, said that his company had avoided hassles by situating its operation in a desolate valley 15 miles inside the test site, even though the five-year lease cost "as much or more as in Las Vegas."
"But we're willing to pay it because we have a pretty good idea of the problems we'll go through there," he said, referring to environmental and political problems he would experience in Las Vegas.
Fluid Tech's staff of about 40 workers and those Government employees not housed on the base live in such surrounding communities as Las Vegas, Amargosa Valley, Tonopah and Pahrump, all within two hours' drive of the test-site entrance.
One company that expects to move to the test site within the next two years is Kistler Aerospace, which is planning to launch satellites from the base on the world's first fully reusable rocket. Launches require restricted airspace and dozens of square miles of flat open land for the rockets to return -- if all goes well -- using a parachute and airbags.
The company anticipates building a launch pad and several buildings for flight control and assembly, representing a $45 million investment. Robert Wang, chairman of Kistler Aerospace, said that his company was attracted by the availability of utilities (unlike remote sites elsewhere) and equipment and the potential of hiring part-time skilled personnel.
Other businesses expressing interest in signing on for one of the various vacant buildings or at an industrial park planned around the base airport include a company that recycles carbon, a liquid-oxygen manufacturer and a company that is developing hydrogen enriched natural gas for cars. One firm that is considering building a solar power plant on the test site is now negotiating with potential customers.
Businesses that move into the test site must still get state licensing and follow environmental laws, which are generally less restrictive in isolated locations. They must also get approval from a board, which weighs such factors as the impact of the business on national security, safety, interference with a neighboring Air Force base and the creation of high technology jobs that could go to laid-off test site workers.
That eliminates tennis-shoe manufacturers, for example, according to Richard D. Betteridge, an Energy Department official who is working to bring new activities to the test site. Even in the unlikely event that such a business would want to be so far from a city where workers could live, its presence at the test site would not benefit the Government's mission to create skilled jobs and diversify southern Nevada's growing, but still casino-dependent, economy, he said.
Mr. Betteridge added that one man who wanted to open a juvenile drug rehabilitation program was "obviously turned down in one telephone call." Other companies, he said, lose interest once they learn that the test site is not immune from regulation.
SOME people come out here and think 'I can do anything, I can pollute all I want,' " Mr. Betteridge said. "Once they find out that's not the case, they don't call back."
Among the marketing offerings are some for only temporary use, such as an existing hazardous chemical spill center, which companies like DuPont could lease for a few weeks to conduct safety drills. And officials at the test site are also trying to attract more government work, perhaps an antiterrorism center where engineers would blow up mock buildings to learn how to build with more durable materials. Universities are welcome to use the test site for research, an Energy Department said.
But much of the test site will probably never be considered for commerce. Parts of the base are reserved for secret military projects, future nuclear detonations and an underground nuclear-waste depository called Yucca Mountain, which is scheduled to open in the next century. In addition, there are occasional nuclear experiments not involving a chain reaction, crater fields, and a small portion of land contaminated by radiation.
Commercial development is a profound transformation for the test site, which has been the nation's primary venue for nuclear weapons testing since 1951. Over the years, 928 nuclear devices have been detonated, at first in the atmosphere, then deep underground after the harmful effects of radiation became better known.
The work stoked the economy in the neighboring rural counties and gave life to Mercury, the restricted Government town on the test site at which hundreds of scientists once spent the night in dormitories. After the Cold War ended and much of the staff left, the town's movie theater and bowling alley were closed.
If nuclear tests resume, the Energy Department says new companies at the test site will not be thrown out nor be contaminated by fallout. But some may be kept from their facilities as a precaution for, at most, a few days when tests are scheduled.
It is too soon to say whether there will be much of a demand in the business world to locate at the test site. However, Mr. Carlson explained that his goals in marketing the base were fairly modest.
"We're not going to make a major profit on this," he said, "but we want enough money to be able to continue the service and drop the cost of operating the test site."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Let There Be Peace, and Trade

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
ALL successful people, or at least the famous ones, have stories that are part of their personal mythologies: Richard M. Nixon and the lessons from his father's struggling grocery store, Babe Ruth and the aimed home run, Wild Bill Hickok and a fatal poker hand of aces and eights.
The story about Guy F. Tozzoli, an engineer, international trade expert and nominee for the Nobel Peace Prize, began on an afternoon in 1930 when he and his pal John Bignoli, both 8-year-olds growing up in North Bergen, went to see "All Quiet on the Western Front." He left the old Loew's Embassy at 74th Street and Bergenline Avenue transfixed by the closing image of Lew Ayres being shot by a sniper as he reached for a butterfly in the trench mud of World War I. 
 "I didn't realize it at the time, but I had just seen my first antiwar movie," Mr. Tozzoli said recently, seated on a cream-colored sofa in his corner office on the 77th floor of Tower One of the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan. "I came out of there wondering if I would have the courage to do what they did in that war."
He also came out wondering about the nature of war and peace, subjects that have returned to color his life in ways that could not have been foretold by a young engineer from New Jersey, a graduate of St. Peter's Prep in Jersey City and Fordham University, and a veteran safely returned from the Navy and World War II and a detour to the Korean War.
Instead of going to work for the contracting company of his father, Silvio, Mr. Tozzoli went to work for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. And from his early days developing airports and shipping facilities at the Port of Newark to his career as the builder of the World Trade Center and later the Port Authority's director of world trade, Mr. Tozzoli came to see world trade as not only a producer of money and jobs, but also as a promoter of the kind of international peace that so eluded the world in the century's big wars.
It was a connection that reached a kind of pinnacle for Mr. Tozzoli last year when he was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize, for which he has again been nominated this year. Mr. Tozzoli's transformation from champion of trade to soldier of peace came about in the kind of small, logical steps that engineers favor, steps that come from listening and making connections.
"I come back from two wars and I go to work at the port building piers," he said, "and who do I meet? Japanese, guys who went ashore at Iwo Jima before we did, and now we're working together!"
The young engineer began formulating one of his many ideas -- Tozzoli's Laws -- about the nature of business: "If we're doing business together, we're not going to fight each other because if I owe you money, you're not going to shoot me."
Mr. Tozzoli, 78, said he learned the same lesson over and over as he rose to become director of world trade for the Port Authority, working from the twin office towers he had helped build. Business people from around the country and around the world would often ask, "What's a trade center, and if it's good for New York, why shouldn't it be good for other cities?"
Once retired from the Port Authority, Mr. Tozzoli set out to institutionalize the answers to those questions by creating the World Trade Centers Association, a nonprofit group he founded and still heads. It helps business people create their own trade centers across the country and overseas, and then signs them up for membership in his organization.
That was in 1970. Today, the association has 326 members in 97 countries, all serving as clearinghouses for practical information about the import-export business, helping with translators, providing lists of banks, taking messages, offering meeting space and generally creating the one thing marketplaces still need: a place to meet.
"Why do we have bazaars?" Mr. Tozzoli demanded in his emphatic style. "To bring people together to do business. The same thing with shopping malls! It's all there to bring buyers and sellers together."
He calls the trade centers around the world "one-stop shopping centers" for world trade. But Mr. Tozzoli turned out to be helpful in more than just business.
Dealing with foreign governments required a diplomatic touch as well. China balked for three years at joining the World Trade Centers Association because Taiwan was already a member, Mr. Tozzoli said. The solution: to list members by city, not country, so the Taiwanese would not have to be carried as Republic of China. Beijing joined.
Later, as Prime Minister F. W. de Klerk opened talks with Nelson Mandela on ending apartheid in South Africa, the men chose the only neutral, non-political and non-ideological location they could think of as a site for negotiations: the World Trade Center in South Africa. Mr. Tozzoli carried off the same stealth diplomacy in what was then the Soviet Union, bringing in several countries that had no relations with Moscow to discuss trade.
He had become so well known as a diplomat of trade that a movement got under way last summer, starting in South Korea and working its way across Africa and Europe, to nominate the World Trade Centers Association and Mr. Tozzoli for the Nobel Peace Prize. Last year's prize went to an anti-land mine group, but he has been nominated again this year, with testimonials compiled in a little book, put out by the World Trade Centers Association, whose title, "Reaching for Butterflies," looks back over the years and the miles traveled to that matinee in North Bergen.
Here is Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former ruler of the Soviet Union and a 1990 recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize: Mr. Tozzoli and his association, he writes in the book, "is helping in the progressive circles of the world leaders in establishing the elimination of arms and other dangers and has been instrumental in finishing up the cold war."
And Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa, the 1984 Peace Prize winner: "Peace through trade is the goal of Mr. Tozzoli and the World Trade Centers Association. It is not only a goal, but, in many cases, it has become a reality."
And Mr. de Klerk: "I believe that the efforts of Mr. Tozzoli and his organization are an example of what open communications can do to further world peace and understanding."
Mr. Tozzoli, in an interview, put it this way:
"When you're promoting business, you're promoting peace. Because when I understand your aims and your culture, I don't have any reason to declare war on you, and instead we work together. When I started at the Port Authority in 1960, world trade was 3.6 percent of our gross domestic product, and now it's 20 percent. World trade and our advances in technology is what has created the prosperity that we have."
Now, Mr. Tozzoli has embarked on a new venture called the Trade Card, a result of a further round of listening to people's questions. Trade Card, which he has patented, is software that operates as a kind of credit card for international trade.
"People kept asking me, 'How can we reduce paperwork in an international transaction, and how can we reduce costs and increase control?' " Mr. Tozzoli said.
After all, he noted, the bank letters of credit on which many small importers depend place a large amount of control in the hands of the issuing lenders. If, say, the maker of baby carriages or bicycles is late in shipping an order, changes in the letter of credit must work their way back to the bank, with small fees applied along the way. Mr. Tozzoli says Trade Card software allows the two principals in an international deal to control the elements of an effort, from contract to delivery.
"If I have learned anything, it's never give up," Mr. Tozzoli said. "You always run into problems, but if you stay at it, you will find a way. That's the truth."
 
International Institute Helps Immigrants Cross Bridges to Their New Lives
WHILE waiting for word on the Nobel Peace Prize, Guy F. Tozzoli collected another award last month: the Rachel Davis Dubois Human Relations Award from the International Institute of New Jersey.
The 80-year-old International Institute, based in Jersey City, is a descendant of the immigrant aid groups that arose around the turn of the century, when newcomers flocked to settlement houses like Hull House in Chicago to learn English and other skills that would help ease their transition into American life.
These days, the International Institute helps more than 3,500 clients from 70 countries each year, said Dr. Nicholas Montalto, its executive director. Among its programs is an annual awards ceremony to honor promoters of peace and the attainment of the American dream.
On May 20, the institute's second annual American Dream Celebration presented its Dubois Award, named after a pioneer in multicultural education, to Mr. Tozzoli for his work in promoting world peace. Mr. Tozzoli, founder of the World Trade Centers Association, has used his contacts with world leaders to ease the transition from conflict to business cooperation. he was instrumental in helping South Africa's former prime minister, F. W. de Klerk, reach an accommodation for a democratic South Africa with Nelson Mandela.
The institute awarded its Golden Door award to John Bailye, an immigrant from Australia who heads his own software company, Dendrite International Inc., based in Morristown.
In presenting the Dubois award to Mr. Tozzoli, Dr. Montalto said: "Although you will never see any documentation of this, it is my understanding that Mr. Tozzoli had the highest vote tally for the Nobel Peace Prize next to the winner. He was the builder of the World Trade Center, and once it was constructed and successful, he has been worked all over the world to promote peaceful human relations."
Continuing programs at the institute include these projects:
* A cross-cultural mental health service that provides counseling to Haitian, Latino, Vietnamese and Russian-speaking clients using licensed bilingual therapists.
* An immigration law center that provides advice and assistance in family matters, labor certification, political asylum, deportation and immigration court procedures.
* An interpreter referral service that provides translators for court and pro-bono assignments in more than 25 languages.
* A program for immigrant artists that assists traditional and folk artists in developing their creative skills and marketing their work.
* A resettlement program for refugees, under contract to the Department of State.
Information about the institute is available by calling (201) 653-3888.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Teen-Age Job Safety

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
With a historically low unemployment rate, the United States Department of Labor expects more teen-agers than ever to be working this summer in fast-food stores, groceries, nursing homes, amusement parks and summer camps. In an effort to prevent deaths and injuries, the Labor Department has begun a "Work Safe This Summer" campaign to teach teen-agers, employers and parents about workplace safety.
The department estimates that half of working teen-agers will be employed this summer in fast-food outlets and grocery stores. Another third will work in nursing homes, schools, amusement parks and summer camps. And some will find employment on farms. 
 Automobile accidents are the leading cause of death for working teen-agers, but each year young workers are also seriously hurt or killed driving tractors or operating forklifts, the Labor Department said. Many young workers are burned by hot grease in fast-food outlets or injured in slips and falls. Others have lost fingers operating meat slicers or dough mixers. Still others are cut while handling sharp knives used to open boxes at grocery stores.
In response, the Labor Department has identified jobs that are too dangerous for teen-agers who are 17 and younger: driving, saw milling, roofing, excavating and operating power-driven meat slicers and using dough mixers, paper-balers and wood-working machines.
Labor Department workers will travel throughout the United States this summer to talk with employers, teen-agers, their parents and others to determine what can be done to reduce the number of deaths and injuries to working teen-agers.
Child labor laws are enforced by the Department of Labor's Wage and Hour Division, part of the Employment Standards Administrations. The number to call for more information is (212) 219-8743.

HEADLINE: OFF THE RACK;
They Almost Killed 'Best Places'! Now Try to Find It.

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK 

 BODY:
THE July issue of Money magazine contains its 12th annual survey of the best places to live in America -- sort of.
Tacked on like an unwanted stepchild, the survey is the last 2 pages of a 21-page section on "super deals." It lists only 12 cities and lacks its usual rich detail, which the magazine advises readers can be found at its World Wide Web site (www.money.com/ bestplaces), along with the full list of 300 cities and an interactive feature that lets users pick their own best places based on personal criteria. This assumes, of course, that readers have Internet access. 
 It's all part of Money's effort to remake itself and retain its commanding lead in the increasingly crowded field of personal-finance magazines. Such "best places" articles, which Money practically invented, have become widespread and overdone in recent years; some have turned quirky and gimmicky in an effort to stand out. All this apparently prompted Money editors to rethink their approach. Initially they were going to kill the survey, but then decided to run it in a truncated form.
They may want to think again.
Media reaction around the country has been huge. Local and regional newspapers gave the survey heavy play, as did did television and radio news broadcasts. It also made network TV news.
Part of the heavy coverage was because the magazine listed the Washington metropolitan area as the best big Eastern city in which to live. And, of course, every city wanted to know its place on the list.
The Washington selection was a surprise to many who were used to a litany of bad news coming out of the nation's capital about crime, drugs and schools. But for the city and its suburbs, clean air, good health care, low property taxes and cultural institutions helped tip the scale.
Money's favorite Midwestern city was Minneapolis; for the West, it was Seattle, and for the South, Norfolk, Va.
So an article that almost wasn't generated a lot of publicity for Money. By the way, Money's managing editor, Robert Safian, said he had decided "right now" to kill another survey, the magazine's seven-year-old annual college review, which usually runs in the September issue. Stand by.
 
A SECOND LOOK In Worth magazine's July-August issue, Jim Rogers, an economic columnist and the author of "Investment Biker," asserts that despite the bad publicity from its recent nuclear tests, India is emerging an an economic superpower. Citing its large middle class and skilled work force, Mr. Rogers says India will generate profits for investors over the next 5 to 15 years. He acknowledges however, that this depends on peace in the region. "Economic success has a way of making war look like an ever more costly proposition," he writes. "My guess is that India will see the light."
 
POLITICS AND COMPUTERS July's Smart Money, in a Washington column by Albert R. Hunt and Alan Murray, points to the political dangers facing Vice President Albert Gore Jr. if the worst fears about the so-called millennium bug, or the year 2000 problem, are realized. If the problem spirals out of control, they argue, the Clinton Administration and especially the Vice President -- who has aligned himself with high-technology issues -- won't escape the fallout. This is an issue on which the Republicans are already sharpening their knives.
 
MONEY FROM WATER The July issue of Individual Investor explores ways to profit from water, which is getting increasingly expensive as its demand soars. For instance, the magazine points out that it takes 40,000 gallons to produce enough steel for just one car. Some companies that it thinks could profit from this growing demand are American Water Works, Ionics, Nalco Chemical, United Water Resources and United States Filter.
 
DEAL TIME If you were prescient -- or lucky -- enough to have dumped some stock when the Dow topped 9,200 in April and that cash is burning a hole in your pocket, Money magazine's series of articles on super deals -- what the editors call great products at great prices -- may be just your thing.
For bargain-hungry shoppers, Money's pick of a high-end outlet mall is Woodbury Common Premium Outlets in Central Valley, N.Y. If you're in the market for a diaper bag for the baby, the recommendation goes to a deluxe model from Lands' End for $49.50. Looking for something a little more exotic? How about a MIG-15 UTI, a jet trainer used by the Soviet air force in the 1950's and 1960's? It can be yours, ready to fly, for $110,000 from Fantasy Flyers in Sante Fe, N.M.
If you like to travel, Money points to a $2,500 around-the-world ticket offered jointly by Air Canada, Lufthansa, SAS, Thai Airways, United Airlines and Varig. The ticket is good for up to a year and you can plan your trip as you go.
The articles have sidebars in which celebrities disclose their "best deal." Some are disingenuous, to say the least. Like Peter Lynch's collection of 3,116 pennies worth $31.16. Or the model Tyra Banks's $8.98 purse from Wal-Mart. Or Martha Stewart's $1 heart-shaped garden hoe.
But some are refreshingly honest, like Donald Trump's and Michael Dell's. The Donald cites 40 Wall Street, an office building he bought for $1 million two and a half years ago that is estimated to be worth $100 million today. Mr. Dell's best deal? The $1,000 he invested to found the Dell Computer Corporation on May 2, 1984.
 
ON LINE A new magazine, Online Investor, is aimed at those who use the Internet for financial research and investing. It is published every other month by MVP Media in Chicago. Jan Parr, the editor, said it might go monthly early next year. Money.com, a one-time special issue by Money magazine on the same subject, will be on newsstands until Aug. 10. A Money spokeswoman said it could become a regular publication.
 
BITS AND PIECES July's Bloomberg Personal explains how to read between the lines of a company's annual report . . . Kiplinger's July issue lays out more charges and fees that are in the works for credit card companies' "profit enemies" -- users who pay their bills in full each month.
