HEADLINE: Bringing a Son Up Right (Right Up to the Top)

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
AT the Fifth Avenue offices of Earl G. Graves Ltd., employees step with almost military precision. Secretaries in crisp yellow suits make sure appointments are kept to the minute, while a receptionist announces visitors within seconds of their arrival.
Inside the hunter-green office of the man whose name is on the door, however, the atmosphere is considerably homier, almost a suburban den: children's crayon notes and athletic awards cover the walls. This is fitting, since Earl Graves, the multimillionaire publisher of Black Enterprise Magazine and the chief executive of the nation's largest minority-controlled Pepsi-Cola franchise, is in business with all three of his adult sons. 
 Seated across from a picture of his two elder sons, Earl Jr. and John, facing off in a Yale-Brown basketball game, Mr. Graves swept his arm to take in the photograph as well as the opulent surroundings and said, "Someday, this will all be theirs."
In this classically sentimental expression of family succession -- the punch line of so many New Yorker cartoons -- Mr. Graves spoke earnestly for millions of fathers who, in every age, have groomed sons to follow in their footsteps.
A bulwark of American life since the days of small farms hacked from the wilderness, the tradition of sons' succeeding fathers in the workplace may be less routine now, in an era of working women, large public corporations and economic prosperity that gives offspring the freedom to strike out alone.
But father-to-son succession is alive and well in a surprising number of big New York enterprises, in fields as diverse as real estate, public relations and sports ownership. The men who own and run them are often at the core of the city's power structure. After completing the task of all good fathers -- hectoring sons to finish homework, mow the lawn and respect Mom -- they have taken on the added job of shaping ambitious, field-hardened mini-moguls.
Many of their sons, in their 20's, 30's and early 40's, are being groomed as the next generation of New York's power elite. They schmooze one another both inside and outside office hours, forming alliances that mirror those that their fathers enjoy.
"It's great to see so many of my friends' sons now friends with my own sons," said Howard J. Rubenstein, the public relations czar, who is a power broker in political and business circles.
"S.O.B.'s" is how his son Steven Rubenstein, 28, characterizes the 18-member breakfast club he started with Jeff Wilpon, 36, a son of Fred Wilpon, an owner of the the New York Mets baseball team.
That's Sons of Bosses.
Guests at the breakfast meetings have included Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew.
"We're all friends," Jeff Wilpon said of his fellow baby moguls around town, who include William Rudin, 43, a member of a prominent real estate family, and Jonathan Tisch, 44, an owner of the Regency Hotel and a son of Robert Tisch of the Loews Corporation.
"We do business," Mr. Wilpon said. "We socialize. I help them. They help me. It all runs together."
Today, Father's Day, is a reminder that a major attraction of fathers' and sons' working together is that it provides an opportunity to maintain intimate ties into the adult years of the younger generation -- rare in a highly mobile society.
"It's great to have a son with you," said Fred Wilpon, whose midtown office is on the same floor as Jeff's. "It continues the dialogue for the rest of your life."
To be sure, there are eager and ambitious daughters being groomed by fathers to take over businesses (and daughters and sons being groomed by mothers), but even in this modern world, the old, traditional way is still the path most commonly followed.
"It is surprising, but in 1998 the most predictable and most common person to take over the helm of a family business is the oldest son," said John Davis, a senior lecturer at the Harvard Business School and an author of "Generation to Generation" (Harvard University Press, 1997), a study of family succession.
Although the pride and satisfaction of grooming a son, and of being groomed by a father, are abundant, there are also manifest perils, according to Mr. Davis and other family business experts (not to say psychotherapists).
Fathers, Mr. Davis has written, often complain that sons are in too big a hurry to take over, or that sons too readily risk the company that was built from scratch by years of toil. For their part, sons say that fathers use business situations to instruct on how to live one's life, making sons feel as if they were still little boys.
Here are portraits of four New York families in the process of handing major businesses from fathers to sons:
 
The Wilpons
A Son in a Hurry To Run the Mets
From the time he was 10, Jeff Wilpon has been eager -- maybe too eager -- to follow his father. At that age he carried a homemade business card identifying himself as Director of Construction. His father, Fred Wilpon, was an owner of Sterling Equities, a real estate conglomerate he founded with his brother-in-law Saul Katz.
In 1980, when Jeff was a high school senior in Roslyn, N.Y., his father and uncle bought the Mets. Jeff was so gung-ho to join the front office that he gave up every boy's dream -- a potential career as a professional athlete. He had been drafted by the Montreal Expos out of college and believes he could have started at catcher in the major leagues, he said, but quit after one spring training session to join the family business.
"I always knew I wanted to do what my dad did," he said, sitting, like his father, with legs crossed in Fred Wilpon's office in Sterling Plaza, on Fifth Avenue at 47th Street. From time to time, his father glanced dotingly at him.
Robert W. Lear, a former chief executive of F. & M. Schaefer who is now executive in residence at the Columbia Business School, said that when being the owner's son is the main qualification for the top job of a big company, a business can find itself on shaky footing: many young men being groomed to take over by fathers would not make it as chief executives in publicly owned companies, where family ties are irrelevant. "They're not tough enough," Mr. Lear said.
Mindful of this, Fred Wilpon insisted that before his son join the family company, he should work for another builder, starting at the bottom, sweeping floors on job sites.
"I wanted him to wear boots and be in the field," said Fred Wilpon, adding that he sought to toughen his son by having him work for bosses who would not show favoritism.
Later, when Jeff joined Sterling Equities, he rose to his present position as chief officer of development and construction, overseeing planning for the new stadium that the Mets want built.
In Jeff's office there is a picture of his 2-year-old son in a Mets hat. Does Jeff expect his child to be the third generation to join the company?
"One hundred percent," he said.
 
The Rubensteins
Keeping Sons From Competing
 Howard J. Rubenstein used to throw the daily newspapers onto the kitchen table and have his two sons, Richard and Steven, read the articles and recite the answers to the classic journalism questions: who, what, when, where, why and how.
Mr. Rubenstein's own father was a reporter for The New York Herald Tribune and took him as a boy to fires and murder scenes. In turn, he said, "I wanted to teach my boys what I did." So he took them on the rounds of his trade as a publicity agent -- to hundreds of parties, dinners and political fund-raisers.
Mr. Rubenstein started both his sons in the mail room of the 160-employee family company, which represents clients like the Duchess of York and George Steinbrenner.
After getting advice from other fathers with more than one child in a family business, he assigned them to separate divisions to keep the peace. "They are very different people, and I didn't want them competing with each other," he said.
"Richard has a flair for entertainment," he added. "Steven is more civic-minded."
Today, Richard, 32, is head of two spinoff companies, one with entertainment and small-business clients, the other representing publicly owned companies. Steven, 28, represents real estate companies and political causes.
"I wanted each one of them to have their own areas of responsibility," their father said. "In the beginning, when they came in, they did not report to me. They were trained by other people. It gave them a far greater sense of independence and a way to prove their own merit.
"I'm their father. It's different if they came in reporting to me. Each one was helped by senior people."
When the day comes for Howard Rubenstein to step aside, the biggest question might be which son will inherit his palatial 30th-floor office on the Avenue of the Americas at 55th street, which overlooks Central Park and New Jersey and whose window sills are lined with 100-odd hard hats from the buildings of real estate and construction clients.
"It will be divided in half," Mr. Rubenstein said with a laugh.
"Let's get out the tape measure," Richard said.
 
The Graveses
Sons as Polished As Their Dad
 Earl Graves maintains that the family that skis together stays together. Not to mention the family that spends summer vacations together and sends its shoes out to be shined together.
Mr. Graves, his wife, his three sons, their wives and their children all take family ski trips to Vermont and Colorado, and they spend summer vacations at two facing houses in Sag Harbor, N.Y.
Every Tuesday, the father and sons take their shoes to the office to be sent out for shining. "You must be presentable -- you must look good," Mr. Graves instructs his sons, who all favor, as he does, power business suits with suspenders.
Despite the appearance of having raised a matched set, Mr. Graves said he never forced his sons to follow in his footsteps; instead, as they grew up in Scarsdale, N.Y., he tried to make the business world alluring by inviting corporate titans like Sanford I. Weill of the Travelers Group to the family dinner table.
Another paterfamilias who believed his sons should not taste success too easily, Mr. Graves refused to give them cars at college. He would lend them a vehicle, but if their grades fell he would take it back. He also had his sons cut grass and work in the company mail room during school vacations. Some summers, Michael, the youngest, drove a Pepsi truck. Today, at 31, he runs the family soft-drink distributorship, Pepsi-Cola of Washington.
John, 35, a lawyer, is general counsel to the family business. Earl Jr., 36, who is known as Butch, is president of Black Enterprise.
When they all first worked together, it wasn't always smooth. "Butch and Johnny, I would say, were very vocal in their disagreements," the senior Mr. Graves said. Former Ivy League basketball rivals, they would sometimes take disputes into the hallways.
"I would bring them into my office," Mr. Graves said, "and say: 'This is not a basketball court. We are executives. We must act like owners of the company.' "
 
The Sterns
A Daughter Wants a Shot, Too
 In the family of Leonard Stern, one gets the impression, there is very little sentimentality regarding father-son matters. His sons, Emanuel, 35, and Edward, 33, call him Leonard, not Dad.
"If I didn't think they could make it, I would pull them out," said the senior Mr. Stern, chairman of Hartz Mountain Industries, the pet-food conglomerate that also owns more than 175 buildings.
"If not, it would destroy their lives," he said. "The peer group for owners' children is very tough. You really have to prove yourself. I've seen too many kids whose grandparents started a company with ruined lives."
His children, who also include a daughter, Andrea, grew up knowing that the opportunity to join the business was always there, although they pursued highly individual paths at first. Emanuel helped open homeless shelters in the Bronx. Edward worked as a reporter for Spy magazine. Andrea was a photographer.
In his Manhattan office, which is furnished like a living room, Leonard Stern recalled that at one point he told the children: "The business is here if you want it. If not, I'm selling it off." He has a crisp manner and eyes that could pierce a statue. About the same time he divorced his children's mother and married Allison Stern, a former model, and the two became regulars in Manhattan's society circles. "It was my time to play," he said.
How soon after that did his children join the company?
"Instantly," he said with a smile.
He did not start his offspring at the bottom. "This mail room business is really a farce," he said. "Creating an artificial sweatshop when your father is the chairman is ridiculous."
Still, when it came to grooming them to inherit power, he was careful to give limited responsibilities at first, so that failure would not mean disaster. Emanuel began in retail real estate.
"It was only 3 percent of the company, so if I messed up it wouldn't have hit too hard financially," Emanuel said. "Leonard is not stupid." Today Emanuel runs much of Hartz Mountain's real estate, including the SoHo Grand Hotel and buildings in New Jersey.
His brother graduated from Spy to the pet-food division of the company, which he now runs, overseeing 2,400 employees.
For her part, Andrea founded The Long Island Village Voice, an offshoot of The Village Voice in New York, which the family owns. She has a staff of 23.
On the face of it, Leonard Stern would seem to favor his sons as business heirs over his daughter, who is, at 31, the youngest.
That would be typical of most men at the top of family empires, who groom sons to take over, whereas daughters are often given a lavish wedding, a nice trust fund and a job that may be glamorous, but not too important, for as long as they like. Raising a family, it is understood, is their first priority.
Leonard Stern denied that he has favored his sons over his daughter in the grooming department, but he noted that Andrea, who married last year, is struggling with the issue of whether to drop out and begin a family. She agreed that this was so.
"That's her life style problem to sort out," Leonard Stern said. "I'm not favoring one over the other, but if my sons wanted to stay home with kids, they just wouldn't be president of the division."
Mr. Lear, the Columbia executive in residence, said that very few women with families make it to the top of big public companies. "They are competing with men who are putting in 18 hours a day 7 days a week," he said.
Even though Andrea currently has far fewer responsibilities than her older brothers, she said she has just as much desire to make it to the top.
"Don't count me out yet," she said. "I'm just as driven and ambitious as my brothers are. My time clock is just different. We'll just see who takes over someday."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
New Stock Is Fueled By Nesting Boomers

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
One part Pottery Barn, one part J. Peterman catalogue, Restoration Hardware is the latest home store trying to capitalize on the nesting urges of baby boomers to come to market. Investors' urges sent the stock ballooning up to $26.25 a share, or 38 percent above the offering price of $19 on Friday, the first day of trading.
The chain's name is a bit deceiving. It does sell hardware, but none of it is really meant for restoring anything. The company's 47 stores are actually emporiums of big leather chairs, fancy dog biscuit mix and the odd Russian flashlight or wind-proof lighter, as well as doorknobs and lamps and the like. 
 The company was founded by Stephen Gordon in Eureka, Calif., in 1980 and has spread to malls in 22 states with an off-beat product mix that has some retail consultants calling it "Pottery Barn for boys."
Its oddball assortment of hard-to-find items like the Russian flashlight (which runs without a battery), old-fashioned wrenches, Patio Daddy-O grill cookbooks and various gadgets do indeed have the male appeal to distinguish Restoration Hardware from the mass of mall stores aiming to attract female shoppers. But the retailer's bread and butter -- 42 percent of its sales -- is furniture and lighting, most of it with an Americana aesthetic, and the key buyers of those products remain women. (Face it, it is a special kind of fellow who willingly sets out on a Saturday to survey some "rollerball" shower curtain rings.)
Expectations for the initial public offering were high, and Restoration Hardware did not disappoint. Exciting retail I.P.O.'s have been scarce in the last six months, and Restoration Hardware's road shows packed in all the major institutional investors.
"I was exceptionally impressed," said Bruce Bartlett, who manages Oppenheimer's Total Return Fund. "I try to invest in concepts that are leveraging the baby boom, and this concept hits it on the nose. It appeals to both genders and people in the upper income bracket."
What is more, retail stocks have been hot this year. The Standard & Poor's retail index is up 32 percent so far this year, compared with a 13 percent rise in the S.& P. 500. The home furnishings segment has traditionally been fragmented, and players like Crate and Barrel have shown how to grab market share.
But make no mistake: Restoration Hardware is expensive. At Friday's closing price, the company is already trading at roughly 45 times forward earnings, compared with a 17 multiple for Pier One or 31 for Williams-Sonoma. "Obviously this company has created an aura around selling chairs and tables and knobs," said Linda Killian, a portfolio manager at Renaissance Capital Corporation in Greenwich, Conn.
Of course, Restoration Hardware is just at the beginning of its run. The company plans to open 25 more stores this year, and roughly the same number in 1999. A catalogue to be introduced in September will raise the profile of the store's name. New shoppers will more than likely be tickled by the whole notion of romancing the Bosco sauce.
But like its shares, Restoration Hardware's goods are not cheap. That club chair, for instance, costs $850, and much of the store's furniture is priced much higher than Crate and Barrel or Pottery Barn offerings. From an investor's perspective, it may have more in common with a luxury retailer than with a Home Depot. If the economy or the American shopper's disposable income should dip, gourmet dog biscuit mix and expensive leather chairs are likely to be the first things consumers abandon.
"We think that the company itself has outstanding merchandising and good management," said Tara Schuchmann, a managing partner of Tara Capital Partners, a Dallas hedge fund with a retail focus. "The biggest question for us is how long can people afford their mortgage and still buy that cherry slate bed."
The company also likes to keep a lot of inventory in its stores, which crowds out selling space, Ms. Killian noted. It could find itself with bloated shelves at the end of a quarter.
According to the prospectus, Restoration Hardware loses money almost every quarter but the fourth of each year. Most retailers depend heavily on the fourth quarter, but a furnishings store shouldn't be as seasonal as, say, a toy store.
Another nit: Mr. Gordon and other officers redeemed 1.3 million common shares of common stock in May of 1997. But management still owns 30 percent of the stock after the offering.
If Restoration Hardware meets its goals of roughly 8 percent annual same-store sales growth and fat 68-percent earnings increases, investors who choose to hold the stock as long as they would a couch from the company's stores could find themselves happy indeed.
"People should have confidence that they can do what they want to do," Ms. Killian said. "In which case it will be an enduring, unique concept."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Restoration Hardware store in Portland, Ore. The company's stock began trading on the Nasdaq stock market on Friday.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Beware of Japanese Bearing Promises

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Like a bungee jumper who finally reached the end of his rope, the Japanese yen made a mighty bounce last week. The yen ended the week 7 percent above the eight-year low against the dollar it hit just days earlier.
The bounce came courtesy of the United States Treasury, which bought billions of dollars worth of yen in currency markets on Wednesday. What did Uncle Sam get for his big investment? Promises by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga to address their nation's economic problems. Something called "the Total Plan" is supposed to allow Japan's banks to escape their problem loans without causing a nationwide depression. 
 This is supposed to impress. In fact, it sounds like little more than hot air -- about which the Japanese know plenty.
It was Japan, after all, whose Nikkei 225 stock index rang in 1980 at 6,556 and exited the decade at 38,916, a rise of nearly sixfold. Yet even when the market was at its dizziest, high-level officials at Japanese banks angrily denied that the Nikkei might be a hot-air balloon. Punctured, the Nikkei now stands at 15,268, down 61 percent from its 1989 peak.
Robert E. Rubin, the United States Treasury Secretary, may believe that the Japanese promises are substantive enough to deserve a big-buck intervention. He may also think that the measures needed to revive the country's comatose economy will be taken. But others say the intervention was folly and that the yen will once again descend.
Trying to prop up the yen was a tactical error on the Treasury's part, argues Andrew Smithers, president of the economic consulting firm Smithers & Company in London, because Japan's bureaucracy has historically been antimarket.
"The Japanese believe markets are there not to tell you bad news, but to be manipulated so that you can alter the real world," Mr. Smithers said. By intervening, he contends, the Treasury has given financial support to the antimarket elements within Japan's bureaucracy.
Moreover, while dealing with bad bank loans is laudable, that alone is not enough. Japan needs to raise its falling exports, a strategy of which Japanese officials make no mention. In real, not nominal terms, Japan's current account surplus fell from 3.76 percent of gross domestic product last December to 3.27 percent in the first quarter of this year.
Because 45 percent of Japan's exports last year went to now-decimated Asian countries, Tokyo must look elsewhere to sell its goods. To compete in key markets like the United States and Germany, however, the yen will have to fall, not rise, against the dollar and the mark. Bolstering the yen just makes Japan's exports more difficult to push.
While world markets react warmly to Japanese promises, it's worth remembering that these folks have been known to pledge one thing and deliver another. Just last November, rumors swirled that Yamaichi International, Japan's fourth-largest brokerage firm, was near bankruptcy. Two of the firm's top-ranking executives came from Japan to meet with officials at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the New York Stock Exchange. The executives assured the regulators that Yamaichi, which had an American subsidiary, was solvent, and they reiterated their commitment to the American markets.
Not 10 days later, the firm petitioned Japan's Ministry of Finance for permission to cease operations.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Setting an Alarm to Tell You When to Sell a Stock

BYLINE: By ANNE TERGESEN 

 BODY:
IN a world where bull markets rage, interest rates sink and the endlessly repeated apple-pie advice is to buy and hold, more than a few investors have trepidations about selling. It can always seem to be too soon: The winners may have further to climb, the losers may be just about to redeem themselves, and patience may prevent a mistake, or having to admit one.
But sooner or later, everybody has to, or ought to, sell. And the way the market has been behaving lately, with the Dow diving 400 points in five days, then rebounding a bit, then dropping another 100.14 points on Friday, the mood of many investors may be headed for the sooner end of the spectrum. 
 Is now a good time to sell? There is no certain way to tell. Even professionals armed with sophisticated computer programs and years of experience say that selling is more art than science.
Still, without a disciplined approach to selling, investors risk making the common mistake of basing decisions on emotions like fear, pride, or greed rather than on a company's fundamentals, a practice that can be costly.
"All good money managers have sell strategies," said Stephen Janachowski, a founder of Brouwer & Janachowski, investment advisers in Tiburon, Calif. "Individual investors, if they are going to buy and sell stocks, should, too."
Some money managers cut their losses when a stock falls by a certain amount. Others single out high price-to-earnings ratios or earnings disappointments as reasons to say goodbye. But nearly all adopt selling criteria that force them to stick to their investment themes.
For example, Bruce Hutson, manager of the Marshall Equity Income Fund, always sells a stock when its yield dips 20 percent below the average yield for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- no ifs, ands or buts.
With dividend-to-stock-price ratios at historic lows, parting has become commonplace for Mr. Hutson's fund, which specializes in undervalued large companies and aims to beat the S.& P. 500's yield by at least a percentage point. General Electric, Maytag, and H. F. Ahmanson are a few of the stocks he recently excised from the portfolio because of low yields. Mr. Hutson also sets a "fully valued" target price for each stock he holds, and usually sells when a stock reaches its target.
Lately, Mr. Hutson's criteria have him selling more often than he would like -- his fund's turnover is 60 percent -- but the results are hard to argue with. The fund is up 17.7 percent in the last 12 months and is yielding 2.89 percent, well ahead of the S.& P. 500's 1.3-percent average, with less risk.
THER money managers leave themselves some leeway to make exceptions to selling rules. At the UAM FMA Small Company Portfolio, for example, warning bells sound when a stock approaches what the managers consider its full value, typically 20 percent or more above the purchase price, said Kathryn Vorisek, vice president of UAM. But if Ms. Vorisek and her colleagues decide the company's outlook has improved since the target was set, they can be persuaded to hold on.
The fund did just that with Flowers Industries, a baking company, and it was not sorry. Ms. Vorisek said a turnaround at the company's Mrs. Smith's division, a recent cost-cutting plan, and Flowers's growing stake in a revitalized Keebler justified successively higher target stock prices. The fund finally sold in March, after Flowers' market capitalization surpassed $1 billion, the upper limit on the fund's small-cap holdings.
The fund also has a "butcher rule" that calls for dumping anything that falls more than 25 percent after the fund buys it, but that too is not automatic, said Ms. Vorisek. On rare occasions, managers decide it signals a buying opportunity. This flexible approach has helped the fund beat the Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks by eight percentage points over the past 12 months.
Money managers say stop-loss limits like the butcher rule are particularly useful with volatile or thinly traded stocks. Dan Sullivan, who edits two newsletters and manages $175 million for himself and clients that include his 93-year-old mother, is quick to cut losses, sometimes selling one of the handful of fast-rising momentum stocks he owns on a dip as small as 10 percent. "The last thing you want is to be in them at the wrong time," said Mr. Sullivan, who has made his mother a millionaire even though her portfolio's return has lagged slightly behind the S.& P. 500 over 16 years.
Ms. Vorisek said a butcher rule has another advantage. It prevents managers from getting too attached to their favorite holdings. "It takes all the emotion out of a sale. You admit you probably made a mistake, sell the stock, and move on," she said.
An important corollary is what might be called the Satchel Paige rule: Don't look back. Even if a selling strategy produces one or two spectacular blunders, it is worth keeping if it has generated good returns over the long run, professional money managers say.
As president of the Brandywine Fund, Foster Friess focuses on small-cap and mid-cap stocks that sell for an average of 18 times 1999 earnings, while delivering fast earnings growth of 20 percent or more. When the fund buys a hot prospect, it generally makes room by selling a slower grower, a strategy Mr. Friess calls "pigs in the trough" because of the way hungry pigs displace satisfied ones.
In early January, Mr. Friess's pessimism about future earnings prospects convinced him that stocks in general were a bad bet, and he moved three-quarters of the fund's assets into cash. His timing was terrible, and he missed several months of double-digit gains in the market. Brandywine got back into stocks in March, when 1999 earnings estimates made them seem a better bargain, but the damage was done, and the fund's return slumped.
Even after an experience like that, though, Mr. Friess is unwilling to second-guess the sell discipline that served him well for so long. "You always regret not participating in the things that are going up, but at the same time, if you know a strategy has worked for 30 years, you don't want to abandon it," he said.
Money managers caution against trying to trim a selling strategy based on short-term results, and point out that transaction costs and capital-gains taxes ought to figure in every selling decision. Keeping a well-balanced and diversified portfolio can sometimes mean pruning part of an overgrown holding, even if the fundamentals do not call for a sale. And trying to outguess day-to-day price gyrations or bolts from the blue like big mergers is generally just as futile when selling as when buying.
"You have to ask, 'Does the combination of your buy and sell strategies outperform the market?' " said Richard Bernstein, chief quantitative strategist at Merrill Lynch. "Or should you just invest in an index fund and play golf?"

HEADLINE: The World;
It's a Sea! It's a Lake! No. It's a Pool of Oil.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
HALFWAY around the world, where the Caucasus meets the Middle East, a rush is on to exploit what could prove to be the world's richest oil bonanza. The stakes are so high that otherwise sane people are fighting each other for the chance to risk huge investments in a part of the world plagued by ethnic rivalries, civil wars, corrupt bureaucracies, faltering economies and big egos.
And that's not all. Some of these same people have also become intently interested in solving a curious question: Is the Caspian really a sea or just a lake? 
 If it weren't for oil and the breakup of the Soviet Union, that's the kind of question that might occupy scholars in some musty corner of some obscure university. But today, people need to know, and here's why:
The Caspian is a California-size body of salt water -- the world's largest landlocked body of water -- that may sit on as much as 200 billion barrels of oil, which would be 16 percent of the Earth's potential oil reserves. Even at today's low prices, that could add up to $3 trillion in oil.
If it is a lake, one set of rules about access to the oil would apply, with the nations that border it controlling the undersea wealth out to a few miles from their shores; the remainder in the middle -- like the hole in a donut -- would be treated as an international seabed. The oil in the middle could be exploited, sold and transported only if all five countries agreed on how to do it and on how to divide up the profits.
If the Caspian is considered a sea, however, the entire bed would be sliced into pieces, like a pie.
And since five nations now border the Caspian, and a lot of undiscovered reserves may lie in the large donut hole, the question is anything but academic.
The Caspian Sea is what it has been called for a long time, and under the international Convention on the Law of the Sea, it meets most of the qualifications.
On the other hand, the Soviet Union and Iran long ago found it convenient to treat the Caspian differently. Under their 1921 Treaty of Friendship, they made it a freely navigated lake whose resources -- caviar-filled sturgeon mostly -- were shared by the two bordering countries.
That worked well enough in the old days. But following the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991, the Caspian suddenly became the property of the five countries that border it: Russia on the north, Iran on the south, Kazakhstan and tiny Turkmenistan on the east and Azerbaijan on the west. What they want to exploit isn't free-roaming like the fish.
So the question underlying the lake-sea dispute is clear-cut: Who owns the oil under the sea and who controls the pipeline route by which it gets to market?
For Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan, which have the biggest known fields under their waters, the Caspian is a sea that would give them maximum control over their own slices.
Until recently, Russia and Iran, which have less oil and gas off their own shores, insisted that concern for the environment required joint sovereignty over the Caspian and its resources, a ludicrous position since Russia is by far the Caspian's largest polluter. Russia also argued that because the economies of the former Soviet republics were developed with Russian financial support, it deserved more. Russia must have "access to the resources of the Commonwealth of Independent States," Yuri Shafranik, who was then Energy Minister, said in 1994. "We, by virtue of our labor, mind, energy have created all this."
But last April, Russia began to modify its position after discovering more oil in its sector. President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan agreed in principle -- but failed to sign an agreement -- to divide the seabed and the oil under it into national sectors.
There was a catch. Mr. Yeltsin also said that the waters above the seabed would remain international. That means that all five countries would enjoy common use of the sea itself, with freedom of navigation, fishing rights and environmental protections.
Clever move. Russia, which still can't quite accept the fact that it has to make concessions to three former Soviet republics, is opposed to a plan for an undersea pipeline that would bypass Russia. But oil is no good unless it can be moved to market, so Russia's compromise would give it veto power over any pipeline plan on environmental grounds.
Even if Mr. Yeltsin signs an agreement with Kazakhstan to divide the Caspian, as he has said he will do next month, will Russia's Parliament go along? And even if the Russian view prevails, does that mean a navigational free-for-all in the Caspian?
"Freedom of navigation sounds good, but does that mean that any country can move its navy around at will even if it seems provocative to its neighbors?" asked Toby Gati, who was the Russia adviser on the National Security Council during President Clinton's first term. "What happens if one country's platform begins to leak oil? Can the others say, 'Get it out of here?' "
With Russia's new position, Iran becomes the odd man out, insisting that the Caspian cannot be divided into national sectors and that the oil belongs to all.
The only way Iran will agree is if the Caspian is sectioned into "equal shares," Iran's Foreign Minister, Kamal Kharrazi, said last month. That means Iran wants to control 20 percent of the seabed; the normal division according to international law would give Iran less than 10 percent.
 
An American Plot
Dr. Kharrazi also rejected the Russian idea of dividing the seabed one way and the waters another. "If there is going to be a division accepted by different countries, I'm sure that one legal regime has to be applied to the seabed as well as the waters of the Caspian Sea," he said.
Iran has also declared that any pipeline built under the Caspian would be a disaster to sturgeon and migrating birds. But its motive may be to delay the building of any undersea pipeline, in hopes that the United States will drop its opposition to a much shorter, cheaper pipeline that would go across Iran.
Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, regards the whole debate as part of an American-inspired plot to impose a military presence on Iran's northern border -- the Caspian -- just as it did on Iran's southern border, the Persian Gulf. "The U.S. oil companies' presence in the Caspian Sea is aimed at paving the ground for the U.S. military presence in this sensitive oil-rich region," he said recently.
Even the World Bank is confused. Recently, the bank's International Finance Corporation indicated that Azerbaijan could get financing for offshore development without a resolution of the lake-sea issue, a decision that has set off a legal battle inside the bank.
The American position is that it will accept any decision that will avoid a pipeline through Iran.
And as some participants in this debate cite legalities and environmental concerns, Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan are busy developing their offshore deposits, signing multi-billion-dollar contracts with international firms.
"While the lawyers are dithering, the investors are planting their flags," said S. Frederick Starr, an expert on Central Asia who writes extensively about the Caspian. "It's like land-staking in the American West. You get your wagon out there as soon as possible."

GRAPHIC: Photo: An oilman's nirvana on the Caspian Sea outside Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan. (James Hill for The New York Times)
 
Map: "The Geography of Greed"
Until 1991, the resources of the Caspian were shared by the Soviet Union and Iran. But since the Soviet breakup, three additional nations -- Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan -- have emerged as competitors for the vast oil reserves believed to lie under the water. Since development rights would differ if the Caspian were considered a lake or a sea, the competitors differ on how to define it. Here is the difference.
 
CASPIAN LAKE -- Iran argues most strongly for this definition, which gives all countries joint control in the middle, where new oil and gas reserves may be found.
 
THE CASPIAN SEA -- Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan argue the entire water should be divided into national sectors. (Source: PIW, Energy Intelligence Group)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2670 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Enigmatic Architect Of a Cable Resurgence

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
WHAT makes Leo run?
Over the last 16 months, Leo J. Hindery Jr. has been the good cop to John C. Malone's bad cop at Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's second-largest cable operator. 
 Since joining TCI in March of last year, Mr. Hindery has improved the company's image on Wall Street by selling cable systems to reduce its staggering debt. Delighted investors have shown their approval by sending TCI's long-depressed stock up 149 percent since the February 1997 announcement of his coming arrival.
In Washington, his assiduous schmoozing has won over even the most vociferous critics of Mr. Malone's often arrogant style. "I think in a very short period of time, Leo has tried to deliver a different kind of message about the company," said Andrew J. Schwartzman, president of the Media Access Project, a public interest law firm.
Along the way, Mr. Hindery has accumulated a personal fortune of at least $70 million, much of it from a huge TCI stock-option grant.
But there is more to Mr. Hindery than the stick-figure portrayal of a rich, hard-working president. Realistic as he has been in tackling TCI's problems, when it comes to his own life he has the puzzling habit of relating stories about the difficulties of his childhood that are at odds with the accounts of his family members.
At a 7 A.M. breakfast interview recently at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan, during one of his frequent business trips to New York, the 50-year-old executive recounted how he had left home at the age of 13 to fend for himself.
His parents didn't bother looking for him, he said, because "they didn't care if I left."
"It was cheaper having me out of the house," Mr. Hindery continued. He said he lost touch with his family -- was "living with people," that "the Jesuits got me through" and that he joined the merchant marine at age 16.
The rest of his family, however, doesn't remember it that way. In separate telephone interviews, Mr. Hindery's widowed mother, sister and brother all said that Mr. Hindery lived at home until he graduated from high school. His younger brother, Michael, a dean at Stanford Medical School, remembers that when Leo Hindery was in his early 20's, he got his kid brother a job at the mining company where he then worked, Utah International, based in San Francisco.
Moreover, the Rev. William F. LeRoux, assistant dean for university relations and Mr. Hindery's former professor at Seattle University, Mr. Hindery's alma mater, said that in his recollection, Mr. Hindery had remained close to his father throughout his college years. Father LeRoux, Michael Hindery and his mother, Marie, could not recall a stint by Leo Hindery in the merchant marine.
Confronted with these discrepancies late last week, Mr. Hindery said that his recollections of events that took place decades ago were less benign than those of others, and he stood by his accounts of a difficult childhood.
"I never exaggerate about that," he said. And he insisted that he had spent several summers working on a ship called the U.S.S. Avila off the Northwest coast.
"The past hurts, and I don't like it," Mr. Hindery said.
Abraham Zaleznik, Konosuke Matsushita professor of leadership emeritus at the Harvard Business School, said storytelling is a pattern among some American business leaders.
Dramatized accounts of childhood might well reflect "the need to create a mythology about himself that may protect him from more painful memories," Professor Zaleznik said. Business luminaries including Andrew Carnegie and Henry Ford, he said, have portrayed themselves as "the lonely figure who was hurt and injured and travels through life, overcoming all travails to become a success."
That an executive might exaggerate his past could send up red flags for an investor -- or spur confidence that his drive to succeed could work for the benefit of his employer.
FOR the time being, Mr. Hindery's energy seems well harnessed at TCI, which among cable operators is eclipsed in size only by Time Warner. His success in part may come from his skill in telling people what they want to hear while maintaining his positions. And he may have the ideal partner in Mr. Malone, TCI's chairman, who seems to care little about what people think of his company.
During Mr. Hindery's tenure, TCI has transformed itself from a company that customers, investors and regulators loved to hate into one of the more solid and image-conscious performers in the cable industry.
An incident at a cable-industry conference in Atlanta last month illustrated the soothing effect the president has had in his role as diplomatic counter to his blunt boss. Mr. Malone had just upset Congressional leaders and broadcasting executives by threatening to drop all-news cable services if the Federal Government forced TCI to carry high-definition television signals.
But before another Malone-induced media imbroglio could move into high gear, Mr. Hindery rushed out a conciliatory statement that "no cable customer will be disenfranchised from receiving an HDTV broadcast signal."
Make no mistake: TCI was not suddenly caving in to public pressure. But the company, which had rarely taken account of public opinion until Mr. Hindery came on board, was finally showing some savvy in playing industry politics. Mr. Hindery at least indicated that TCI would continue a dialogue with the Government about cable's role in the HDTV business.
Revamping TCI's image has been a gargantuan task. Mr. Malone, long considered a brilliant strategist and technical expert, built TCI into the nation's dominant cable operator by gobbling up cable systems but investing less than many other operators in customer services. Mr. Malone had no problem playing the corporate heavy, once even declaring that Reed E. Hundt, then the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, should be shot.
"John is a kind of John Wayne," observed Mr. Hundt, who left the commission last fall. "He didn't see a lot of reason for the Government to be in his business." Mr. Malone declined to be interviewed for this article.
Mr. Hindery's more measured approach to both the Government and the balance sheet appears to be paying off. To consolidate operations, he began to negotiate joint ventures with companies that had cable systems adjacent to TCI's. The ventures offered their owners economies of scale and let TCI focus more intently on its remaining cable systems.
Those deals, when completed, will let TCI reduce the debt on its own balance sheet by $4.7 billion, or 32 percent, to $9.6 billion, while still retaining a minority stake in the new companies. Meanwhile, the crucial ratio of debt to cash flow available to make interest and debt payments is expected to fall to about 4.5 by the end of the third quarter of 1998 from 6.1 at the end of 1996, improving TCI's credit rating and making its borrowings less costly.
True, the creation of these joint ventures will also reduce the number of TCI subscribers by 30 percent, to about 10 million. But it will streamline operations, since TCI will have 60 percent of its customers in 10 states, rather than sprawled across 24 states.
Mr. Hindery boasts that he is a master of reading people. "I know people. I know them better than anyone knows them. I don't talk about it much, but I never make mistakes," he said.
But he isn't always so good at getting along with them. Before going to TCI, Mr. Hindery founded various limited partnerships, collectively known as Intermedia Partners, to invest in cable systems. All three of his general partners left after disputes with him, according to several people formerly associated with the group. Mr. Hindery upset at least one of those partners by pressuring him to reduce his stake in the partnerships, one insider said.
Two of the former partners, Ed Allen and Ted Liebst, declined to comment, and the third, David Rozzelle, did not return phone calls. Mr. Hindery said simply that "they left."
So far, though, Mr. Hindery has apparently established good rapport with his underlings at TCI. A hard driver who puts in 15-hour days, he has replaced 25 managers, mostly from within. To give employees a stake in TCI's growth, he has nearly tripled the number of nonofficers and nondirectors in the stock-option program to 440 people, he said.
"I think there were about three people in the option program before," he said at the recent breakfast meeting -- the first of three he held that morning.
But perhaps most important, Mr. Hindery throws himself into the task of marketing TCI with unrestrained gusto. He can be as obsessive about promoting the company as he is about selling himself.
When an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter put out a lukewarm report on the company, for example, TCI angrily responded by taking away its investment banking business. "Malone was never that sensitive, but Leo takes what an analyst thinks of the stock as a personal thing," said one person close to the situation. Mr. Hindery countered that Primestar Partners, a satellite-TV consortium in which TCI is a member, has done business with Morgan Stanley since the incident.
Still, his efforts have helped polish the cable industry's image. Many people say the arrogance of the cable executives was at least partly responsible for the Cable Act of 1992, which reregulated the industry. By 1993, when Mr. Hundt took office at the F.C.C., 128 members of Congress and a third of the Senate told him that the the first round of cable price cuts were not adequate because the industry had effectively lobbied for regulation with huge loopholes.
Burdened by debt and Government regulation, TCI's stock declined from the end of 1993 to the start of 1997. Finally last year, as the stock languished and pressure mounted on the company, Mr. Malone himself brought Mr. Hindery aboard.
HE has proven a respectful subordinate. "John has a great sense of the industry and he sees things," Mr. Hindery said. "He is brilliant. I am clever. I am not as smart as John."
Diplomatic, yes; modest, no. "I think we all have our strengths and weaknesses," Mr. Hindery said. "John can be anything he wants to be, but it is better for us if I go run the company, and he figures out where we are going to take it."
Unlike Mr. Malone, who avoided industry association roles, Mr. Hindery has just been named head of the National Cable Television Association. And he is far more willing than Mr. Malone to work with Washington and community franchise boards.
For example, Mr. Hundt recalled that last summer, during a weeklong outing for media moguls organized by Allen & Company, the investment banking firm, Mr. Hindery laid out to him TCI's plan for selling cable systems. "He asked whether the F.C.C. could work with it," Mr. Hundt said. "He smoothed the way."
TCI, of course, has not entirely changed its spots. Mr. Hindery and Mr. Malone are currently arguing with broadcasters on how much bandwidth the broadcasters are entitled to for HDTV signals.
But Wall Street clearly likes the new team. True, its stock's 149 percent surge since the announcement that Mr. Hindery was coming on board has fallen short of the rival Cablevision Systems' 257.2 percent leap in that time, though it exceeds Comcast's doubling and has kept pace with the overall market.
More important, TCI has regained Wall Street's confidence. In an event almost unimaginable five years ago, the Association for Investment Management and Research in Charlottesville, Va., awarded TCI a prize for the most improved investor-relations program in the media industry last year. And there is an obvious effort to make an immensely complex annual report clearer.
Mr. Hindery is in the office or on the phone by 5 A.M. and says he doesn't need more than four or five hours' sleep a night. He attributes that drive to his "weird" childhood in Tacoma, Wash., where, he said, "I started paying for everything in my life when I was 9 years old.
"I used to work in the fields, and I would give the money to my family, partly because that was how my family worked and partly because I was so mad at them," he continued.
"I had a such a crummy childhood. You just can't know how cruel my parents were. Nobody beat me, but there was just a total absence of affection. I got a Christmas gift once. It was a belt, a size 38 belt. I weighed about 125 pounds."
Family members confirm that Mr. Hindery had a job picking berries at the age of 9. But they describe his childhood as reasonably structured, saying he held down such prosaic jobs as packing grocery bags at a Safeway supermarket. "Leo lived at home with us through high school and had the same treatment and gifts," said Michael Hindery, who insisted that he remained attached to his older brother for years after.
Mrs. Hindery acknowledges that she has had her share of emotional problems. In telephone interviews, she said she suffered from the eating disorders of anorexia and bulimia, had low self-esteem and was estranged from all three of her children. And both Hindery brothers agree that their parents, who had not gone to college, insisted on hard work. "I worked in shipyards full time to put myself through school," Leo Hindery said. "I went to sea and I drove trucks, and I picked crops. I did every crummy job."
After graduating from Seattle University, he said, he attended Stanford's business school, subsequently going to work for Utah International, a mining company. After General Electric acquired the company in 1976 (it has since sold it), he moved to Wall Street, where he served as managing director and chief financial officer of A. G. Becker Paribas, the investment banking firm. He entered the media world when he was hired by the Chronicle Publishing Company in San Francisco, where he was chief financial officer.
Like many executives at the notably fractious Chronicle, his performance at the media company got mixed reviews. Some members of the Theriot family, which owns the company, felt he was too ambitious, while others applauded him for helping to bring deal making to the stodgy concern.
In 1988, he decided to go out on his own, and raised $200 million to buy cable systems through a series of partnerships, creating Intermedia.
Then, last year, Mr. Malone offered Mr. Hindery the chance to run TCI. Mr. Hindery says he accepted because of his affection for Mr. Malone, whom he knew through industry circles, and because he welcomed the chance to straighten out the nation's second-largest cable operator.
MONEY wasn't a consideration, he says. Even so, there was certainly a lot of it. First, Mr. Hindery sold his stake in Intermedia's cable systems to TCI for $55 million in stock and cash. Mr. Hindery left $20 million of that in the company, though with strings attached to encourage employees and advisers to stay on and run it.
And at TCI, Mr. Hindery got himself a lucrative options grant. By the company's own reckoning, his 4.425 million options were worth $27.7 million when they were granted. Adding in two other grants that were not valued, the executive-compensation expert Graef Crystal estimates the total value at more than $35 million, making Mr. Hindery the recipient of one of 1997's largest option packages.
"It couldn't have been more well deserved," Mr. Hindery said.
If the stock has gone up since his arrival, it is in part because Mr. Hindery works like a maniac, a style even his family can find taxing. Mr. Hindery described himself as somewhat of an absentee father to his teen-age daughter, and his wife said that living with her husband was rather like having an eccentric uncle in the attic. "You get used to it after a while," she said.
Eccentricity might well be Mr. Hindery's defining characteristic, driving both his need to perhaps embellish his life story and his need to succeed. Indirectly, then, his very eccentricity seems to have brought some management sanity to Tele-Communications. Whether it will always play such a positive role is a harder call.

LENGTH: 2107 words

HEADLINE: The New Monster Of The Midway;
Premier Parks Thrives by Not Being Disney

BYLINE: By EDWIN MCDOWELL 

DATELINE: Oklahoma City

 BODY:
AS Frontier City rose near here alongside legendary Route 66 in 1958, not even its owners could have harbored illusions that the 60-acre amusement park would ever rival the talk of the industry, the three-year-old Disneyland. Indeed, by the time a local real estate development company bought a controlling stake in 1982, the park was so rundown that the new owner planned to demolish it and put up an office and retail complex instead.
Today, most of Route 66 is only a memory, replaced by Interstate 35. Yet Frontier City still stands, spruced up and profitable. 
 For when Frontier escaped the wrecking ball -- courtesy of plummeting oil prices, which sent Oklahoma's economy into a tailspin -- the owner had little choice but to operate the park itself. And in the years since, that potentially disastrous investment has turned into a gusher: its owner, Premier Parks Inc., is now the second-biggest theme park operator in the world, behind only the Walt Disney Company itself.
 Like the cars of a roller coaster inching up the first big rise, the company that would eventually become Premier took its time getting ready to expand, spending more than a decade to collect a dozen or so small parks around the country. And then this year, seemingly from out of nowhere, Premier shifted into high gear.
 In February, it stunned the industry by agree-ing to pay nearly $1 billion in cash for the dozen Six Flags parks owned by Time Warner Entertainment and an investor group led by Boston Ventures. A month later, it went international, buying a 49.9 percent stake in six parks in Europe. And it is not done yet.
"Clearly, there are opportunities for more acquisitions," said Kieran Burke, Premier's understated 41-year-old chair-man and chief executive.
Disney is hardly in danger of losing its top spot any time soon. The 31 parks now in Premier's stable had about 38 million admissions last year, much less than half the estimated 86 million that Disney packed into its 6 parks. (Disney's Animal Kingdom in Florida, its seventh park, opened in April.)
And Disney and Premier aren't really even direct competitors. Premier operates regional parks, mostly for day trippers, many of whom become season ticket holders and drop in frequently during summer, if only for a few hours at a time. Disney runs destination parks, which have much higher ticket prices and serve as magnets for its large resorts. Moreover, while Disney operates its five parks in the United States year-round, all but one of Premier's parks are seasonal.
Indeed, Premier executives insist that they don't have Mickey on the mind.
"We never viewed our long-term goals or performance as competition with Disney," said Mr. Burke, a Harvard-trained lawyer.
Yet at least one other comparison is quite telling. "While Disney remains the park industry leader, with the theme parks their best-performing business over the past year, Premier is growing faster than the entire Disney company," said Larry C. Petrella, an analyst with Lehman Brothers.
Investors have sent the company's stock up 75 percent since the Six Flags deal was announced. The stock, which closed on Friday at $59.0625, has more than tripled since Premier went public on June 4, 1996, a reflection of the company's sizzling financial performance: attendance, revenues and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization have increased by 7, 9 and 12 times, respectively, since 1993.
For now, the question is whether Premier's management is up to the tasks it has set for itself. The purchase of Six Flags, after all, is a bit like a minor league team buying the New York Yankees.
Six Flags' 1997 revenues were $708.7 million, more than three times Premier's $193.9 million. Six Flags drew about 27 million visitors last year, with four of its parks, including Great Adventure in Jackson, N.J., accounting for more than 3 million each. By contrast, Premier's total attendance was less than 11 million, and only one of its parks, Elitch Gardens in Denver, reached even 1.5 million.
But analysts regard Mr. Burke and his team as better theme park operators than were Time Warner's managers. Ned P. Zachar, senior managing director of Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities, said he expected Premier to consolidate operations and improve margins. How hands-on is Premier management? Mr. Burke and other senior executives get hourly updates by computer of attendance figures at each park.
FOR his part, Mr. Burke thinks it's time for a breather. "Over the next 12 months," he said, "we'll be focused largely on integrating our newest parks."
The company is making a tender offer for the remaining interest in the six European parks it operates with Walibi S.A. It paid Walibi $43 million for its 49.9 percent stake in March. And tomorrow, it plans to add the Six Flags name to its Kentucky Kingdom park in Louisville, the first of a number of proposed name changes.
As part of the Six Flags deal, Premier also obtained the exclusive right for 55 years to use Warner Brothers characters like Bugs Bunny and Tweety Bird, in its American and Canadian parks. Analysts expect the characters to bolster attendance and merchandise sales at Premier's original properties.
Premier derived 51.2 percent of its revenue last year from the sale of food, merchandise, games and rides, or about $8.50 a person. But the average expenditure at Six Flags is nearly $10 higher, said Mr. Petrella of Lehman.
Moreover, a recent report by Nationsbanc Montgomery estimated that merchandise sales averaged only about $1 per person at Premier but about $5 at Six Flags. So every additional dollar per person that Premier can generate from the cartoon characters, the report said, "could translate into incremental revenue of $12 million to $13 million."
Given Premier's high-speed financial ride, it would be fitting to report that Mr. Burke went into the amusement park business because he was unable to shake a childhood passion for roller coasters, or that beneath his Harvard pinstripes beats the heart of a buttoned-down Barnum. But the fact is that while he enjoyed visiting parks as a child, Mr. Burke, the Bronx-born son of a homicide detective, did not contract the amusement park virus until he joined Premier's predecessor, Tierco Group, in 1989.
By then, Mr. Burke had taught high school English, practiced corporate and real estate law and worked as an investment banker at Drexel Burnham Lambert. Through his work at Drexel, he came to know some of the family members who controlled Tierco. When offered the chief executive's position there, he readily accepted.
Now an amusement park junkie, Mr. Burke regularly takes his four children, aged 6 to 13, on the rides at Premier parks and those of the competition. So do most other Premier executives, including James F. Dannhauser, the chief financial officer and also a Harvard law graduate, and Gary Story, the president and chief operating officer, who started in the amusement park business at 16 and has managed parks from Mexico to Australia. (Mr. Burke and Mr. Dannhauser are based in New York; Mr. Story and most other senior executives have offices in Oklahoma City.)
Rides, after all, are the heart of the business -- the draw that brings people back again and again. When Premier added a river rapids ride at Frontier City in 1990, for example, attendance increased by 60,000 that year and has continued to rise.
(The Oklahoma City park was briefly closed for cleaning and safety inspections after it was hit a little more than a week ago by a tornado and high winds that caused a few injuries and some minor damage.)
Premier prides itself on running family parks with rides for all ages. At its Adventure World in Largo, Md., for example, visitors may choose from a water park, 14 children's rides and 34 adult rides, including Roar, a world-class wooden roller coaster.
Interviewed recently at the park, Selina Bankert was about to take her three sons home to Annapolis, Md., for their naps. She would be back many more times this summer, she said, because she was a second-year season ticket holder, and her 5-year-old son, John, and his 2-year-old twin brothers, Scott and Paul, loved the park.
"It's a good value for us," she said of her season ticket, which she bought for $44, "because we come at least once a week for an hour or two."
Across the country, at the 109-year-old Elitch Gardens in Denver, Tommy and Adaire Toms of York, Neb., are among some 75,000 season ticket holders. This day, the Toms, who spend a good deal of time in the Denver area, were accompanying their son, daughter-in-law and two of their 11 grandchildren.
"We came here soon after our first date in 1955," Mr. Toms said.
"We danced to all the big bands," Mrs. Toms remembered, ticking off several band leaders, including Harry James and Les Brown, whose photographs hang on the walls of the park's rebuilt Trocadero ballroom.
Waving to their grandchildren suspended in the air inside a huge teacup -- one of 48 rides in the park, including a $30 million package of new attractions installed last year -- Mrs. Toms said, "It's still a great place to spend a day with kids."
Tim O'Brien, an editor of the weekly Amusement Business magazine in Nashville, said that while Premier parks have generally shunned the glitz -- and high prices -- that accompany the better-known high-technology rides, "their rides have always been good and have been getting better." Those at Six Flags are "just awesome," he added.
When all is said and done, the smaller attendance and lower admission prices at Premier parks have had no noticeable effect on the company's financial performance -- except maybe to enhance it, by impressing on management the value of running a lean operation.
After acquiring Elitch Gardens last year, Premier promptly moved park executives from a high-rise office tower to the park itself. And Premier is now in the process of trimming the ranks at Six Flags Astroworld Houston, which had 140 full-time employees, twice the number at Elitch, where attendance is about the same.
The seasonal operation of Premier's parks is another reason for the company's success, Mr. Burke said. "It enables us to operate with fewer full-time employees year-round," he said. "We also do a rigorous budgeting process from September to December, we refurbish every ride at every park, and we plan our marketing campaigns, our telemarketing and our group sales."
Still another explanation of the company's strength goes back to the early days with Frontier City. The company realized that it had become part of "a fragmented industry with a lot of parks out there that didn't have the necessary capital or management skills," Mr. Burke said. "So we knew if we could demonstrate to the financial community that we could turn Frontier around, we could acquire other parks."
Before its purchase of Six Flags, Premier concentrated on acquisitions in areas that had at least a million people within a 100-mile radius, and today it has parks in 16 of the top 25 markets, including Atlanta, Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles, New York, San Francisco and Washington. With the Six Flags purchase, some 175 million Americans live within 150 miles of a Premier park.
Along the way, Premier maintained a low enough profile to execute its game plan virtually undetected. That is why so much of the industry and Wall Street were taken by surprise when Premier bought Six Flags for $965 million, plus the assumption of about $890 million of debt.
"On the surface, Premier paid a pretty full price," said Mr. Zachar of Nationsbanc Montgomery. "But Six Flags' cash flow last year was about $160 million, and those parks were undermanaged, so there are still margins to grow."
How? "Warner's made money from its parks," Mr. Burke said, "but they were in the amusement park business not so much for the revenue as for the sale of merchandise and the exposure of their characters. But our only business is parks. So this transaction allows each of us to concentrate on our core business."
Analysts share his confidence. Both Mr. Petrella of Lehman and Jill S. Krutick of Salomon Smith Barney say the company's stock could trade at $70 or more in 12 to 18 months.
Once the 12-month breather is over, where will the Premier roller coaster go next? Possibly it will range farther abroad to areas that are only now awakening to the lure of amusement parks, namely Europe, Asia and Latin America. Many foreign markets, Mr. Burke said, are as fragmented as the United States was in the 60's and 70's.
That could make for a thrilling ride.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 654 words

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
A Gentler Breeze Is Blowing Through Moscow

BYLINE: By PHILIP TAUBMAN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
The warmth and lingering daylight of a Moscow summer could make even the harshest periods of Soviet rule seem less demented. The appearance of flowers and fresh fruits and vegetables in barren markets temporarily lifted the city's spirits, creating the illusion that this was just another European capital marking time until the August holidays.
Now it is no longer an illusion. Moscow may not be Paris or Rome, but it is no longer a world apart. The differences of dress, demeanor and politics that made Moscow so distinctively depressing have melted away. From its monumental traffic jams to its supermarkets, boutiques and elegant restaurants, Moscow is a big, bustling, brash metropolis exploding with energy and entrepreneurial activity. 
 To see the city again after an absence of three years, and to compare it to the Soviet citadel of 10 years ago where I worked as a correspondent, is to appreciate anew how far Russia has traveled since the demise of Communism. The economy is shaky, corruption is ubiquitous and the power of the wealthiest bankers and businessmen remains largely unchecked, but these and other deformities should not overshadow the political and economic changes that have transformed Russia in just a few years. Almost as swiftly as the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution sealed Russia in hermetic isolation, the arrival of democracy and capitalism have set it free and tied it to the West, culturally and economically.
Moscow is the epicenter of change, and the locus of wealth, in the new Russia. It will be some time before the rest of the country, including St. Petersburg, comes anywhere close to matching the standard of living now enjoyed by many Muscovites.
One of the best seats for observing the new Russia is on the terrace outside the cavernous McDonald's at Pushkin Square. Though the novelty of Big Macs has faded, the restaurant still has cachet with Russians and serves as a mecca for affluent young Muscovites. They arrive in Jeep Cherokees and Toyota Land Cruisers, cell phones in hand. The men are dressed nattily in light-weight pleated trousers, colorful sport shirts and tasseled loafers, the women in short skirts, tight tops and stylish Italian shoes. The scene seems almost unimaginable to someone who lived here a decade ago.
The McDonald's also attracts working-class customers who have become indistinguishable in appearance from their counterparts in London or New York. The nondescript Soviet wardrobe has almost entirely vanished, replaced by jeans, colorful outfits and Nike or Reebok shoes. Even eyeglasses and sunglasses are sleek. After decades of enforced conformity in everything from clothing to politics, Russians have seized the chance to assert their individuality.
Across from the McDonald's is a small plaza that is part of the boulevard that circles central Moscow. Once a cheerless place with a few scruffy benches and an expanse of dirt, it is now the site of a leafy beer garden where people congregate after work, engaging in easy conversation as the daylight stretches far into the evening. The talk is of business and politics, romance and vacation plans. The fear that once permeated Moscow and made it so inhospitable to such gatherings is gone.
The press is full of lively debate and invective, the television news a cascade of irreverent reports. Even more remarkable is the Internet, where information of all kinds is available about the Government and the economy. Where implacable customs agents once enforced Soviet censorship at Sheremetyevo airport, there is now an unobstructed "green channel" for passengers with nothing to declare.
The new Russia is an unfinished work. It is a land that favors the young and those unbroken by Communism and has little patience or compassion for those unable to adapt. But Moscow, at least, is increasingly a city where people can enjoy life. Considering its history, that is no mean feat.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial
