HEADLINE: Yin and Yang;
In Asia, America's Foe Is Also Friend

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS President Clinton crams for his trip to China this week, he must be yearning for those simpler days, not so long ago, when it was much easier to explain to Americans the distinction between friends and foes in Asia.
During the first Clinton Presidential campaign, the Chinese Government was the menace, run by dictators "coddled" by President Bush as they oppressed Tibet, threatened Taiwan, forced abortions and swiped American technology. Then there was Japan, America's biggest military ally and partner in Asia. Sure, the Japanese kept out American car parts and computer chips, barriers that Mr. Clinton vowed to smash. But whenever trade quarrels got really nasty, cooler heads in Washington would remind people that it was Japan -- market oriented and host to American troops -- that Washington could count on in times of crisis. 
 But no one then could imagine the kind of crisis Asia faces today: economic meltdown. And if you listen closely to the oratory of Washington before the most important foreign trip of Bill Clinton's Presidency, things sound very different. On Tuesday Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin took to the podium of the White House to declare that "China has been an island of stability in Asia" -- a savvy, responsible player in the global effort to tamp down the economic firestorm that started in Asia a year ago.
And Japan? The view from Washington these days is that it is spreading the bubonic plague of the markets -- wild instability -- while refusing to take the cure. When Mr. Rubin went to the Oval Office Monday night to tell Mr. Clinton that the United States had to reverse policy, spending billions in the currency markets to prop up the yen, he described it as a desperation effort to save Japan from itself. Inside the Treasury, his aides have a new title for the Japanese Finance Minister, Hikaru Matsunaga: Minister for the Destruction of the World Economy.
This huge shift in perspective is not universal, of course. Many in Congress still view China as a security threat, and last week they kicked into high gear the hearings over whether the Chinese are exploiting liberalized American commercial export laws to improve their spy satellites and nuclear missiles. Not surprisingly, the White House is drafting and re-drafting the remarks Mr. Clinton will deliver in China to make sure he presses the themes of human rights and nonproliferation.
 
Threat and Ally
In calm times this would be a delicate balancing act. But it is made far more complex by the realities of Asia's economic turmoil. China may remain America's huge military threat, but it has emerged in recent months as an equally huge economic ally -- insuring, at least for now, that crisis does not become catastrophe. And Japan, home to the American bases that keep Chinese power in check, has become an economic drunk driver. Its steps to deregulate the economy, reform its banks and cut taxes are widely viewed as inadequate, and no one even talks anymore about turning Japan into an engine of Asian recovery.
"Whether you run a country or a company, you better figure out how to live without Japan for a while," says John S. Wadsworth Jr., chairman of Morgan Stanley Asia.
 
Seizing a Moment
Naturally the Chinese see this an opportunity. In return for a pledge to hold their currency stable -- which President Clinton is expected to seek this week, and which is in China's interest anyway -- they want acknowledgment of China as the new economic leader of Asia. That's a stretch (China's economy is still a fifth the size of Japan's) but nothing makes the Chinese happier than when American officials repeat Mr. Rubin's mantra that "sometime in the next century China will be the world's largest economy." After all, a decade ago the Japanese thought that trophy would belong to them.
China's constant reminders of American-Chinese cooperation in World War II, fighting side-by-side against you-know-who, are part of a campaign to portray China as Asia's leader and America's indispensable partner. It's no secret why the Chinese insisted that Mr. Clinton only visit China on this trip: They wanted the imagery of Air Force One flying right past Japan. (To make amends, Japan's Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, has been invited to visit Washington in July.)
"The stars are lined up for them, because Japan is in such disfavor around the world," said Jeffrey Garten, the dean of the Yale School of Management. "They know that we have no one else to turn to for managing the economic crisis."
Mr. Garten suspects the Chinese have a more specific agenda in mind. They want to swap continued cooperation for America's commitment to get them into the World Trade Organization and a pledge to draw back American support for Taiwan. The Chinese have made no secret of their unhappiness with a revision of the security treaty between Japan and the United States last year, which they viewed as part of a broader effort to contain Chinese military power.
 
Time Bomb
It's never been easy for the United States to maintain an equilibrium in its relations with Japan and China. One has always been in vogue, the other out. But rarely have things been this complicated, when American security interests and American economic interests have pulled in different directions.
And add to that another wrinkle. The Clinton Administration is praising China's economic management today in part to encourage it to defuse an economic time bomb down the road: China itself.
"China today has the characteristics of every Asian country that was hit by the crisis -- but worse," says Michael Walton, the director of poverty reduction at the World Bank. Take a look at some numbers you are not likely to hear President Clinton rattle off in the next two weeks. Somewhere between 25 and 30 percent of all the loans on the books of Chinese banks are not being paid back and probably never will be. That means there is now at least $270 billion in bad debt in China (compared with $600 billion in much richer Japan). Moody's Investor Services warned on Friday that China's big state banks are "in reality heavily insolvent."
But what about those impressive skyscrapers in Shanghai that Mr. Clinton will roar past in his motorcade on the way to a roundtable with cell-phone-toting Chinese entrepreneurs? Vast numbers of them are sitting empty. And while the entrepreneurs represent China's future, up in the industrial northeast unemployment rates are running near 30 percent. The numbers are getting worse as Zhu Rongji, China's new Prime Minister, shuts down vast steel plants and mines that Mao opened 40 years ago with a bunch of nifty slogans but no business plan.
 
The Wall
So what has protected China from the economic calamity that has hit its neighbors? A second Great Wall: its currency, which is not freely convertible. That means the speculators of the world can't move money freely in and out of China. Sealed off from the markets, China has sidestepped George Soros and his friends, pegging its currency to a fixed exchange rate with the dollar. (It helps that the Chinese have built up a war chest of $150 billion in foreign reserves.)
But there are ways for the world to get around the wall. As the dollar has soared, China's exports -- the fuel of its economic growth -- have become far more expensive overseas. Suddenly the countries whose currencies have dropped so dramatically -- Korea, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia -- are selling goods more cheaply and cutting into China's market share. And that is reducing China's growth rate at the moment it desperately needs money to finance its perilous transition to a market economy.
So it is no surprise that when the Japanese yen fell to scary new lows last week, the Chinese began to scream. Japan's economy is so big that it could force another round of huge currency devaluations -- a second, far more fearsome phase of the Asia crisis. Chinese leaders began threatening to devalue their own currency. China's nervousness is one reason Mr. Rubin intervened in the markets to bail out the yen.
But the Treasury Secretary made no secret of the fact that he was forced to select among bad choices. He wanted to force Japan to make structural changes before he helped the yen -- massive deregulation, tax cuts, shutting down the sickest banks. The Chinese, he notes, have addressed their problems far more directly than Japan has.
What he got last week was a new commitment from Japan -- one that may or may not be worth any more than previous commitments. If it isn't, then he has only bought a little time. And sooner or later, Japan's troubles could become China's -- and the world's.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
On the Other Hand

BYLINE: By Eric Schmitt 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SHOULD China benefit from American technology? The United States is pulled both ways. Few embody the tug of war better than Representative Dana Rohrabacher, a conservative Republican from a California district with high-technology industry. Lately, in criticizing transfers to China approved by the Clinton Administration, he seems caught in the contradictions of American policy. Look at what he said four years ago, and what he says now. ERIC SCHMITT 
 At a September 1994 House hearing on space, Mr. Rohrabacher favored looser restrictions:
If the No. 1 threat to the United States today seems to me not coming from a military threat but instead an economic threat to our well-being, don't these restrictions that we are talking about . . . put us at a disadvantage in terms of this major threat to our well-being in terms of the international economic competition in the area of high technology? Maybe you could tell me specifically what specific damage to our national security would be caused if we would just transfer all communications satellites from the munitions list to a commercial dual-use list. . . .
I would hope that our industrial leaders who are making these decisions do not fall back to the position that they just want to protect the use of old technologies from the new competitive threats that are coming from China and the former Soviet Union. . . .
We are very concerned that in this new era that we are entering, post cold-war era, era of global competition, we can't have our top businessmen hampered by bureaucratic roadblocks.
But he was for tightening them last month as he voted to ban the export of American satellites to be launched on Chinese rockets:
How is it that the Communist Chinese have improved their missile capability? You better sit down, Mr. and Mrs. America, because it appears that several large American high-tech corporations, in collusion with the Clinton Administration, provided technology to the Communist Chinese that perfected their nuclear weapons delivery systems. . . .
It takes the wind right out of your lungs, does it not, just to think about it? If this is true, it is the worst technological betrayal of the American people since the Rosenbergs. This is nothing less than a catastrophe for the security of our nation and the safety of our people. . . .

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

MARKETS
Even With Yen Supported, Stocks Bounce About
A bystander could be forgiven for thinking the stock markets had gone off their lithium. The Dow industrials skidded 207.01 points on Monday, to 8,627.93, only to soar 164.17 points on Wednesday and fall 100.14 on Friday. The blue-chip average ended the week at 8,712.87, down 122.07 from last week. Behind the stock market's zig was the currency market's zag. The fall reflected fears that Asia's economic crisis would hurt profits of American companies. Then the United States and Japan bought yen to bolster the sagging currency, and investors stampeded back into the markets, only to have second thoughts about the Asian situation on Friday. The yen, which had neared an eight-year low on Monday at 146.15 yen to the dollar, recovered to end the week at 136.10. 

WALL STREET
Goldman Going Public
Clearly the tradition that Wall Street holds most dear is profit. So little wonder that Goldman, Sachs & Company, the Street's last big private investment bank and by many measures its most successful, decided to end its 130-year partnership and go public. The move could make Goldman a prime player in the financial industry's rush to consolidate and allow the partners to capitalize on the long-running bull market. Right? No, contended Jon S. Corzine and Henry M. Paulson Jr., co-chairmen and co-chief executives of the big investment bank. Mr. Corzine said, "This is not about money or cashing out." Mr. Paulson added, "We don't think that being a financial conglomerate is the way to go." They did say, however, that they intended to make some acquisitions and to expand in Europe and Japan.
 
TOBACCO
Sound, Fury and Then Silence
After a month of contentious debate and too few votes for passage, the Senate jettisoned a comprehensive tobacco bill that would have resolved much of the litigation against tobacco companies. Although there appeared to be almost no hope that it could be revived this year, leaders of both parties vowed not to give up. Speaker Newt Gingrich said he would put forward a low-budget alternative to the Senate bill, intended to discourage teen-agers from smoking. Above, Kelly Tietjen, 13, and Alex Stevens, 14, smoke in a park in Princeton, N.J. President Clinton pledged to continue the fight, saying: "It's not dead over the long run because the public health need is great. "
 
AUTOS
Strike Cripples G.M.
General Motors' North American operations were crippled, with 100,000 employees out of work, most of its assembly plants shut down and nearly 100 parts factories idle. At issue in what began as a U.A.W. strike at two key Michigan parts plants are not only short-term job security and workplace safety disputes, but also a larger struggle over how far G.M. will go in adopting at home the manufacturing techniques it is introducing abroad. G.M.'s operations in Brazil, where outside suppliers assemble many parts for new cars before delivering them to the assembly plant, are the company's most profitable, efficient and flexible. The United Automobile Workers see G.M.'s reliance on outside suppliers as a threat.
 
COMPANIES
Buffett's Insurance Policy
Berkshire Hathaway, which is controlled by Warren E. Buffett, announced a $22 billion deal to acquire the insurer General Re. Berkshire's already considerable insurance portfolio includes Geico. . . . America Online, the nation's largest cyberspace company, E-mailed employees to say that it had discussed being acquired by AT&T but would remain independent. . . . The Walt Disney Company announced a complex $900 million deal to buy 43 percent of Infoseek, a service that helps guide users to what they want on the World Wide Web.
 
THE ECONOMY
Reports Are Mixed
The American economy has continued its excellent performance, the Federal Reserve said in its "beige book" survey of regional economic conditions, citing high employment levels and stable prices. But the Consumer Price Index rose a seasonally adjusted three-tenths of a percent in May, the Labor Department said, bringing inflation for the first five months of the year to a 1.5 percent annual rate. The rise, although moderate, was the largest in 17 months. The Commerce Department reported that the trade deficit for April expanded to a new monthly record of $14.5 billion, well above the $13.3 billion projected by many economists, in large part because Asia's crisis has reduced demand for goods.
 
MANAGED CARE
A California Failure
After two and a half years, three chief executives and $11 million in losses, California Advantage is filing for bankruptcy. That's the managed care company that the California Medical Association and 7,500 of its member physicians created to take on the state's big health maintenance organizations. Dr. Jack C. Lewin, a family practitioner and executive vice president of the association, said that by offering subscribers easy access to thousands of specialists, it tended to attract those who were the sickest and costliest to treat. California Advantage, which said it needed 40,000 subscribers to break even, is going out of business with about 6,000.
 
PEOPLE
It's Tough at the Top
Richard Branson, below, the British entrepreneur whose diverse Virgin Group holdings include airlines, high-speed trains, retail stores and soft drinks, says he wants to start a low-cost airline tentatively called Virgin America. So far he has been blocked by Federal restrictions that prevent foreigners from controlling domestic airlines. . . . Live by the chain saw, die by the chain saw. Albert J. Dunlap never winced at the moniker "Chain Saw Al"; rather, he frequently boasted of the thousands he had thrown out of work to lift a company's stock price. Add one to the list of the downsized. A board room revolt at Sunbeam led by some of his hand-picked directors decided the ailing company needed a new boss (See articles, page 4). . . . As Barney's emerges from bankruptcy, Bob and Gene Pressman, the founder's grandsons, are stepping down as co-chief executives.
 
TAXES
Washington's Silly Season
What better way to win favor with voters than to oppose taxes? The House, citing the complexities and inequities in the tax code, voted 219 to 209 to require that Congress come up with a new tax system by Independence Day 2002 and scrap the current code by the end of that year. Clint Stretch, director of tax policy for Deloitte & Touche, said wryly that it was easy to vote that way because the members of Congress knew the President would veto any such law, rescuing them from their folly. "Sun-setting" the tax code would make financial planning impossible for both individuals and businesses, Mr. Stretch said, citing such issues as whether to rent or buy a home, whether to put money into I.R.A.'s or other retirement plans and whether to take capital gains on stocks. And businesses would not know whether and how to invest in new plants and equipment.

HEADLINE: U.S. Details 6 Neutral Countries' Role in Aiding Nazis

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
Ever since the current uproar erupted over the fate of looted Nazi gold, the role that Switzerland played in helping to finance Hitler's war machine has been the focus of debate.
But as investigators in the United States and other countries have scoured musty archives of World War II for clues, they have repeatedly stumbled over evidence raising broader questions about the nature of neutrality during the war. 
 Those questions have now come to the fore in a State Department report that takes a broad look at the role played by all of the major neutral countries in aiding Nazi Germany.
The report -- which looks at Spain, Sweden, Turkey, Portugal and Argentina, in addition to Switzerland -- highlights the degree to which each country created its own definition of neutrality to survive and to prosper at a time when all the old rules had been thrown to the wind.
"Our report indicates the complexity of the notion of neutrality," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, Under Secretary of State for Economic, Business and Agricultural Affairs, who coordinated the State Department research effort.
The standards for acceptable behavior by belligerents and neutral countries had been part of the European tradition for hundreds of years. But they offered little guidance to countries facing the blitzkrieg, legal scholars and historians said.
"The rules in place were designed for wars that were not crusades," said Detlev Vagts, an expert on international law at Harvard Law School. "The rules were designed for much smaller wars."
Gordon Craig, a leading scholar of German history and professor emeritus at Stanford University, said: "When you come right down to it, what standards could be applied to the neutrals during that war? It was very difficult to be a small nation in a Europe dominated by Hitler."
And so those legal guidelines that did exist were often simply discarded, or consistently violated, by many of the neutrals.
"It is clear that these countries were committing unneutral acts even by the standards of the times," Mr. Eizenstat said.
Sweden was among the most aggressive in stretching the meaning of neutrality throughout the war, the report found. Surrounded by German forces in Norway, Denmark and Finland, Sweden was vulnerable throughout the first few years of the war to German intimidation.
The Swedes allowed German troops to cross their neutral territory to join the German invasion of the Soviet Union, and also allowed 250,000 German troops to use the Swedish railroad system to travel between occupied Norway and Germany. The Swedish Navy provided escort service for German military supply ships, while Swedish industry helped the Germans make up for the losses suffered in their critical ball-bearing industry from Allied bombing raids.
Spain went even further, creating a new international status by declaring that it was a "nonbelligerent," rather than a neutral. Franco's fascist regime intended the claim of nonbelligerence to signal that it was leaning Hitler's way but was not willing to give up the benefits of staying on the sidelines. Yet even without officially joining the Axis, Spain provided as many as 40,000 troops, supposedly volunteers, to fight on the Russian front alongside the Germans in what was called the Spanish Blue Division.
Spain also remained an important German source of wolfram ore, a mineral used in making tungsten, a very hard metal critical to the German industrial base, the report says.
Each neutral's definition of acceptable neutral behavior clearly shifted along with the fortunes of war.
At the onset, for example, Turkey joined an alliance with Britain and France. But after the fall of France in 1940, it dropped out and followed Spain's lead, declaring itself a nonbelligerent. The British tried repeatedly to coax Turkey back into their camp, but the Turks refused to declare war on the Axis until Feb. 23, 1945 -- just as Germany was being crushed.
In the meantime, Turkey enjoyed the benefits of a bidding war between Germany and the Allies for its chromite ore. Essential in the manufacture of stainless steel, chromite was one of the few raw materials considered essential to the German war effort for which there were no adequate sources in German-held territory.
The State Department report is most critical of the neutrals for their refusal to give up their trade and financial relationships with the Nazis late in the war, when Germany had long since lost its ability to threaten or intimidate. In many cases, the neutrals kept trading with the Germans until the end.
"The war could have been shortened by months or years if the neutrals had cut back on their trade with Germany by 1943," Mr. Eizenstat said.
Gerhard Weinberg, a World War II scholar at the University of North Carolina, put it this way: "The No. 1 motivating factor for these countries was making money. The fact that they were making agreements just before the end shows that they still wanted to make as much money as possible from trade with the Germans."
What is more, the neutrals were reluctant after the war to give in to Allied demands to return looted gold they had received in trade with Germany.
Indeed, even though the Allies asked only that the neutrals return gold they had received directly from Germany -- and not the Nazi gold that had been transferred through Switzerland -- the neutrals were still "tenacious in not returning gold," Mr. Eizenstat noted.
Still, the State Department report is being criticized for adding relatively little to the historical record. Critics say it is nothing more than a diplomatic effort to divert attention from Switzerland's role in aiding the Nazis by showing that other countries did, too.
"If you are working at State, you want to not be seen as aiming all your arrows at Switzerland," said Sidney Zabludoff, an international economist who has written a study on Nazi gold sponsored by the World Jewish Congress. "I think because the report tried to be diplomatic and deal with a number of issues about neutral countries, it lost its focus."
But Mr. Eizenstat stresses that the new report is actually just as damning of Switzerland as the previous State Department report on gold looted by the Nazis, since it details how important Switzerland was in financing German purchases of critical exports from other neutral countries. The five other neutrals examined took in about $300 million in gold from Germany -- much of it looted -- and about three-fourths went through the Swiss National Bank, according to the State Department.
In effect Switzerland was serving as Germany's central banker, giving it the financial power to keep buying from other neutrals -- and keep fighting.
"This report continues to point the finger at the Swiss," Mr. Eizenstat said, "but it also looks at the neutrals to see what uses the looted gold was put to."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 10; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 846 words

HEADLINE: Japanese Offer No New Measures, Just Pledges, to Bolster the Yen

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 20

 BODY:
The Japanese Government pledged before a meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations today that it would revive its economy and repair its banking system, but it fell short of saying anything new or specific.
The failure to spell out further measures to restructure the economy seemed a step backward from the expectations that had been raised just a few days earlier. When the United States joined with Japan on Wednesday to intervene in foreign exchange markets to prop up the yen, President Clinton and other American officials strongly hinted that Japan was ready to take new steps to bolster its economy, but today those steps seemed more elusive than ever. 
 In fact, the Japanese Government insisted that it had made no promises of further restructuring in exchange for American support for its currency.
"If you ask if there are secret agreements between the United States and Japan: there are none," Eisuke Sakakibara, Deputy Finance Minister for International Affairs, said this evening at the conclusion of the G-7 meeting of deputy finance ministers.
Financial markets throughout the world surged in the last few days in part on the expectation that the yen's long slide had ended and that Japan would undertake new policies to improve its economy. It is not clear how the markets will react in the coming week to the lack of any clear new steps to emerge this weekend.
The United States Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence Summers, who is in Tokyo to attend the meeting and hold talks with officials here, called his discussions with Japanese officials "very useful" and said that they were aware of the urgency of the situation.
"What is going to be most important going forward is the steps that Japan takes to take advantage of this window of opportunity," said Mr. Summers at a news conference today. "There is a clear recognition of the need to move rapidly."
But he would not say whether Japan had outlined new economic measures or how confident he was that it would respond decisively.
The meeting of G-7 officials, expanded to include representatives of 10 Asian countries, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, was intended to put pressure on Japan to take further steps and to reassure the financial markets that there was a new determination on Japan's part to address its problems. But the vagueness of the simple statement issued by the meeting's participants today suggested that it would not be easy to keep up the momentum for cooperation if Japan does not move fast to mend its economy.
In the statement, the United States and other countries agreed to "monitor developments" and cooperate "as appropriate" in the foreign exchange markets, but there was no mention of any effort to reverse the decline of the yen, which has fallen by 42 percent against the dollar since its peak in 1995.
"We issued a statement expressing our seriousness and urgency of the matter," Mr. Sakakibara said. "I think they believe our seriousness."
One problem is that Japan has repeatedly promised before to tackle its economic and banking troubles. And while it is pushing through with a grand scheme, called the "Big Bang," to restructure the financial industry, it has backtracked on some of its previous pledges to liberalize its markets and to create a more open financial environment.
Japan is also preparing a proposal, called the "Total Plan," to eliminate the huge bad debts that threaten the nation's banking system. But this was in the works well before the American-Japanese intervention.
It is not clear whether President Clinton and other Americans were expecting Japan to announce a major new effort to bolster the economy. But Japanese officials seemed puzzled by what Mr. Clinton and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin were thinking when they suggested that bold new actions by Japan were in the works to justify a higher value for the yen. "I'm very much afraid that he doesn't understand what's going on in Japan," a senior Finance Ministry official said of Mr. Rubin.
Mr. Summers emphasized that Japan needed to increase transparency in the way its financial industry operates and to tackle the bad loans. Japan also needs to work out a mechanism to deal with troubled financial institutions, some of which are on a lifeline from the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank.
Japan is just about to start carrying out a $120 billion fiscal stimulus package that includes at least $58 billion in real spending and $30 billion in temporary income tax cuts. It has also set aside nearly $220 billion to bail out the nation's banks, which are burdened by more than $600 billion in bad or doubtful debt.
Already, economists say that Japan is likely to see growth in the third quarter this year. But regulators, officials and economists abroad are still concerned that Japan is not moving fast or far enough to alter radically the nature of its financial system and the overall economy. So they fear that once the public money runs out, Japan's economy may slump again.

HEADLINE: China's Entry in World Trade Organization Is Called Unlikely

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 20

 BODY:
China is not ready to make the economic changes necessary to join the World Trade Organization, the top American trade negotiator said here this evening after two days of talks with Chinese officials, casting ice water on any lingering hopes that a trade breakthrough might be announced during President Clinton's state visit in the coming week.
"There's a lot of talk, but China is not yet ready to walk the walk," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States Trade Representative, saying that China has made too few of the concessions to open its markets to outsiders that Western countries demand as a condition of entry into the 132-nation organization that sets the rules for world trade. 
 Chinese trade officials were not immediately available for comment on Ms. Barshefsky's remarks. In the past, China, which has been trying to enter the organization for 11 years, has been defensive about the membership issue, describing the opposition to its entry as unfair and politically motivated.
But now that the country is in the midst of a politically risky revamping of state enterprises, which has raised unemployment, coupled with the fact that it is also facing the Asian financial crisis, some senior leaders may in private be relieved at the prospect of putting off W.T.O. membership and its potentially painful obligations.
"The Chinese Government has not yet decided whether W.T.O. accession is compatible with its domestic agenda," said Ms. Barshefsky in a meeting with reporters. "I don't believe the leaders are confident that it would leave them flexibility in the way they pursue internal reforms," she added.
In return for minimizing trade barriers, members of the trade organization enjoy better access to the markets of other members, which include all the developed Western nations, Japan and many developing nations.
Trade negotiations between China and the United States, which has taken the lead among Western nations in part because its own trade deficit with China is huge, have been crawling at best for some time, and diplomats have recently played down expectations for progress during the coming summit meeting.
Though membership in the global trade body has been a political goal of China's leaders, in recent months it has become clear that enthusiasm for accession has been far from universal. Some ministries and industries in what remains a largely state-run, bureaucratic economy have worried about the rapid opening of ailing domestic industries to foreign competition, and an end to the monopoly positions of state-run commodity traders as well as banks, insurance companies and other service sectors.
The major areas of dispute, in addition to high tariffs on many imported goods, include restrictions on agricultural imports and on the ability of outside companies to gain a foothold in such service industries as financial services, accounting, tourism, law and telecommunications, American officials say.
Over time, there is a "positive trajectory" in the talks, Ms. Barshefsky said, but the progress is "slow and uneven."
"Plainly they have not come to grips fully with the changes that would be required to join the W.T.O., Ms. Barshefsky said of Chinese leadership. "I also believe they have not come to grips fully with the fact that W.T.O. is not a political organization, it's a commercial organization."
China has publicly insisted it should be admitted to the trade body under special, more lenient conditions granted to less developed countries. But Ms. Barshefsky said that this question of national status had been irrelevant in actual negotiations; rather, the frequent and protracted talks over the last two years have focused on what specific commitments China would make to provide genuine market access.
While China's leaders may be glad to put off potentially destabilizing changes in trade policy, Ms. Barshefsky warned that the status quo was not acceptable either. In the current trend, she said, by the end of this year the United States alone will have a $60 billion trade deficit with China, while Europe and Japan also face major deficits. Chinese officials say the figures are overstated.
In the long term, the opening of markets required by the trade organization should aid the domestic transition to a more free and productive economy, Ms. Barshefsky said, noting that Mexico had used its external opening to great domestic benefit. But the Chinese leaders are too preoccupied with the costs and dangers of their domestic reforms to focus on those potential gains, she said.

HEADLINE: Jobs as Abundant As Summer Dreams For Young Workers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: GAFFNEY, S.C.

 BODY:
Unaware of just how much muscle she had, Sharai Correll took a job as a waitress recently at the local Cracker Barrel restaurant, the kind of steady, air-conditioned summer work that generations of teen-agers with limited options would have far preferred to, say, scrounging for lawns to cut.
But one day of orientation was enough for Ms. Correll, an 18-year old premed student. She quit abruptly and took a job as a sales clerk at Fila, a shoe and sportswear retailer that is one of the employers at the 68-store Carolina Factory Shops complex in this town of 25,875 competing almost desperately for summer help. 
 "Working here is a lot easier than working at Cracker Barrel," said Ms. Correll, who also briefly entertained offers from the Dress Barn and the Gap and was ambitious enough to take a second job working mostly weekends at the Upstate Carolina Medical Center.
"Five jobs in two days!" she exclaimed, amazed at the leverage she and friends command in the market for summer work, where many students have long had to settle for unappealing or low-paying jobs.
The benefits of America's lowest unemployment rate in three decades are unmistakable in South Carolina. Heavy doses of foreign investment have helped drive the statewide jobless rate down to 2.5 percent this spring from 4.4 percent a year earlier, according to figures from the United States Department of Labor.
The experience of South Carolina's young job seekers is not replicated everywhere. In New York City, for example, finding a summer job remains a challenge. Yet, even in the city, economists say a decline in unemployment should open up more jobs for young people. Page 22.
And in many places around the country, tight job markets mean youth unemployment is at its lowest point in a decade.
Here, summer work is likely to come at pay well above the $5.15 minimum wage. Young workers typically enjoy hefty discounts on purchases, often can demand enough flexibility to allow the occasional long weekend at the beach and may even collect a bonus of $200 or more for lasting the whole summer.
Indeed, a recent swing through the northwestern and central parts of the state found a litany of employer grief about the inability to attract needed workers, in many cases with adverse effects on business.
For example, even though vacation season for regular workers is not yet in full stride, it already takes longer for customers in Columbia, the state capital, to get through the checkout line at some supermarkets. The jobless rate has dived to an unheard of 1.4 percent, and even lifeguard jobs, among the most coveted, go begging.
"I could use about four kids right now," said John Ferguson, the manager of a Piggly Wiggly grocery store in an affluent section of Columbia. "My level of service is not what I want it to be."
Another, more far-reaching result of surging demand for summer workers is that young blacks here are increasingly being drawn into the labor market.
Nationally, the unemployment rate for 16- to 19-year-old blacks remains sky high, at 29.4 percent in May, compared with 14.2 percent for young people of all races. Still, joblessness among black teen-agers is down -- from 33.9 percent a year ago. And the shift is a significant development in South Carolina, where the population is 30.1 percent black, about two and a half times the national figure.
Jamie Devine, 18, who is black, is working this summer as a loan administrator at Carolina First, a regional bank, doing tasks such as calculating loan payoffs for people taking out new mortgages.
"If you want a job, you can get a job," said Mr. Devine, who is putting in a full week for more than $8 an hour after working part time at the bank during the year while attending Benedict College in Columbia. "It teaches you discipline."
Betsy B. Boineau, a vice president who oversees Carolina First's paid internship program, told of one black teen-ager from the College of Charleston who was hired as a teller this summer but quit to take an even better job two days after starting work.
"I was so disappointed," Ms. Boineau said. "It gets harder and harder to get good people."
Even rural areas of South Carolina, which once offered little but arduous farm work, provide a choice of appealing jobs this summer. In Joanna, a speck of a place midway between Greenville and Columbia, Brooke Bradley, 16, happily tends a video store -- much of the time watching movies -- for $5.25 an hour after changing her mind about a job offer from Pizza Hut.
"I just called them back and canceled it," she said. "This is more steady."
Some employers have been unable to find extra summer hands at all, among them the Phoenix, an elegant Greenville inn. "If six qualified college kids walked in right now, they'd have a job," said Walter Gallman, the banquet manager, citing his need for waiters, bellmen and front desk people who, he said, could average $300 a week for 25 or 30 hours of work.
"It's incredible. I've never seen a summer like this -- there's help wanted everywhere," said Douglas Woodward, research director at the University of South Carolina's Darla Moore School of Business. "Any 16-year-old who wants a job can find one in this state right now."
Acute demand for young workers has not pushed wages up drastically this summer; employers are still trying to compete on working conditions and perquisites. But at a job fair in Greenville sponsored by the Urban League of the Upstate, recruiters for United Parcel Service said that the $8.50 to $9.50 an hour they could offer under the company's national pay scales had become relatively less attractive as competitors' pay creeped higher.
Not so long ago, "we were leaps and bounds above" the competition, said Jim Mahaffey, one of the recruiters. "There's not a whole lot we can do except go out and beat the bushes."
Even students who want jobs but do not want to give up their summer at the beach are bargaining from a strong position.
The Myrtle Beach Pavilion, a huge resort complex of rides and attractions, which employs as many as 1,600 people at the season's peak, still needs to find 300 more workers, said Scott Radwick, who is in charge of hiring for the resort's owner, Burroughs & Chapin.
With housing scarce, increases in hourly pay of 10 or 15 cents this season may not do the job.
"Every employer around here is resigned to the fact that it's going to be a tough hiring season," Mr. Radwick said.

HEADLINE: In Albany, a Year to Turn Defeats Into Election Issues

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 20

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki began the year with a modest list of things he wanted out of the Legislature: end parole for violent felons, permit charter schools, allow casino gambling, toughen penalties for juvenile criminals.
He got none of those. But while the 1998 legislative session, which ended Friday, may look like a bust for the Republican Governor, it gave him a few handy issues to use as he runs for re-election this year, particularly the time-worn theme that Democrats are soft on crime. 
 He signaled as much in a news conference on Friday afternoon in which he reviewed a session that was widely seen as one of the least eventful in memory. Mr. Pataki bemoaned the gridlock in the Capitol, and blamed the Democrats who control the Assembly.
"Every single criminal-justice change we've tried to get was fought tooth and nail in the Assembly," he said. "I just think there are an awful lot of people in the Assembly, particularly the Assembly leadership, who go back to the old philosophy that it's society's fault when someone is a violent criminal."
Mr. Pataki's political advisers calculated that there was not much he needed, politically, from this session, and they may have been right. Polls show him with huge leads over his Democratic rivals, and the Governor seemed to spend more time this year touring the state to promote his record than working in the Capitol to enhance it.
Even his allies in the Legislature say that except for the parole issue, he did not break a sweat this year lobbying for his agenda.
He can tell communities in western New York and the Catskills that see casinos as their best hope for economic development that he tried, but he did not push the issue hard enough to raise the ire of conservatives who oppose gambling. And he can tell minority communities that favor charter schools that he fought their fight, only to be thwarted by the Assembly's top Democrats, though the Republicans who control the Senate were in no hurry to go down that road, either.
In a way, it was a year made for political posturing, and not just because of the coming election. In years past, lawmakers often hitched smaller issues to larger ones, giving them leverage to get more things done.
But this year, for the first time since Mr. Pataki was elected in 1994, there were no momentous issues hanging over the lawmakers' heads, no budget crisis, no plan for deep cuts, no rent controls ready to expire, no deadline for welfare reform. As legislators noted repeatedly all year, there was nothing that, for either side, had to be done.
In the final days of the session, there were a few notable pieces of legislation passed, including one requiring that people infected with H.I.V. be reported to the State Health Department and their sexual partners notified. Lawmakers also agreed on a program of inspections and emissions-testing for heavy trucks and buses, something long sought by environmentalists. And a deal was struck on the management of the new Hudson River park in Manhattan that places some limits on development along the river.
For the Assembly Democrats, especially Speaker Sheldon Silver, the session went much as it did for Mr. Pataki. They, too, calculated that there was not much they needed, politically. They, too, entered the year with a limited agenda, and in defeat found election-year ammunition.
Mr. Pataki's broad budget vetoes in April denied the Democrats much of what they wanted, including a $500 million increase in spending on school construction and a tripling of spending on child care. Mr. Silver refused to negotiate with Mr. Pataki and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, on restoring some of the vetoed items, saying it was all or nothing.
From the start, the Speaker made it clear that he would rather have the issue to use against Mr. Pataki than have a fraction of the money back. And as the session ended, Mr. Silver kept up his attacks on the Governor with an eye toward the November election.
"I would think that the people of this state will recognize that while Wall Street is booming, Main Street is not booming in New York," he said. "The Governor chose to veto some very sound proposals that were passed through legislators of both parties."
The Assembly Democrats called for steps to reduce New York's auto insurance rates, knowing well that the Republicans would reject them. Again, even before the session had ended, the defeat had become a campaign issue, as the Democrats running against the Governor piggy-backed on the Assembly's plans and blamed Mr. Pataki for high premiums.
It was telling that when asked what he considered the major achievement of the session, Mr. Silver cited not a piece of legislation, but a process: the negotiation of a budget through public conference committees with the Senate, rather than in private talks.
Somewhat obscured by the furor over the vetoes was the Democrats' achievement of some of the things they wanted most this year, including a large increase in basic school aid, expansion of the state's health care program for poor children, and a process for people to appeal when their health insurance companies deny coverage for certain treatments.
And in other areas, they may have inoculated themselves against attack.
The Assembly passed a criminal-justice package that included the Governor's proposal to end parole, though it also included other measures that Mr. Pataki and the Senate refused to accept. In the end, no law was enacted, but the Democrats can go home and tell voters that they, too, voted to abolish parole.
So attractive was that measure as a piece of political cover that all the Republicans in the Assembly voted for it as well, for fear that they would be accused of opposing the anti-parole measure.
In the final week, Mr. Silver offered to work out a compromise in conference committees, a proposal the Republicans rejected. Of the Governor, he said, "He believes he has it better as a campaign issue than as a law, that it suits his purposes."

HEADLINE: Still Tough in New York, but Getting Better

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Finding a summer job is far harder for teen-agers in New York City than it is for their peers in most of the nation for reasons ranging from a shortage of lawns to mow to competition from recent immigrants.
They are not alone, of course. Teen-agers in Los Angeles, Miami and other cities also have a much tougher time finding employment. 
 But in New York, at least, the outlook is improving. Economists say the city's summer job market seems to be the best in years, both because overall unemployment has dropped and because retailing is promising more entry-level, temporary and part-time jobs.
"Retail activity has been one of the biggest growth areas, and it is a sector that tends to hire kids over the summer," said John L. Weiting, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
He said the growth in retail sales had combined with a strong surge in adult employment -- 83,000 jobs were created in the city during the 12 months that ended in May -- to create "the backdrop for a greatly improved summer jobs market."
The usual challenges confronting city teen-agers are reflected in Government data, which for years have shown that the unemployment rate among New York teen-agers is about double that for the nation.
One unalterable cause for the disparity, experts say, is the sheer size and economic landscape of the city, in which jobs suitable for young people are sometimes simply too far from where they live.
Economists say another problem is that the city, compared with its suburbs, provides relatively few of the jobs related to summer recreation that are part of growing up in much of the nation. Demand for camp counselors, lifeguards, golf course caddies and gardeners' helpers is always sparse in the city compared with many other places.
"Tourism is very strong in the city, but the kind of jobs it generates are at the high end in expensive restaurants, hotels and other places that really don't hire many young people," said Jim Brown, an analyst for the New York Labor Department.
But despite the hurdles teen-agers continue to face in the city, the experts say more opportunities exist this summer, particularly for those willing to work in a store.
"The really positive thing about the increased retail activity is that it is not concentrated in one or two areas, it is spread around the city," Mr. Brown said. "That means teen-agers have a better chance of finding a summer job close to home."

HEADLINE: As Colombia Picks New Chief, Rebels Voice Their View

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 20

 BODY:
For months now, the campaign posters and rallies for Horacio Serpa of the Liberal Party have championed him as the presidential candidate best able to negotiate an end to the civil conflict that has virtually dismembered this Andean nation, leaving some 31,000 dead.
Mr. Serpa's campaign has promised that this former Interior Minister, who is from the working-class oil port of Barrancabermeja, could draw on his ties to the political left to find the elusive path to peace. 
The only risk to this election strategy, political analysts warned, was it might make Mr. Serpa appear overly friendly toward the rebels and undermine his credibility with the military and business elite.
But in these final days of campaigning for the election of a successor to President Ernesto Samper on Sunday, the two main rebel groups issued stinging criticisms of Mr. Serpa.
The biggest group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known by its Spanish acronym FARC, blamed him for the breakdown in peace talks with the Government six years ago, and accused him of waving the banner of peace solely for electoral gain.
In a move worthy of his nickname ("Sure Shot"), Manuel Marulanda, a rebel leader who had not been photographed publicly in 10 years, held talks at his secret hideout with a representative of Mr. Serpa's Conservative Party rival, Andres Pastrana, and allowed a picture of the meeting to be published in newspapers here.
The smaller National Liberation Army criticized both candidates.
The surprising turnaround in the two candidates' stands as peace negotiators is only the latest in a series of strange twists in the election that will end the presidency of Mr. Samper, who has spent most of his turbulent term fending off accusations that Cali drug dealers financed his election. In the first round of the election, on May 31, Mr. Serpa won 34.64 percent of the votes and Mr. Pastrana 34.32 percent.
If the bywords of the candidates have been "peace" and "change," the word political analysts here frequently resort to is "paradoxical."
While the country is reeling in almost every sense after four years of Mr. Samper -- economically, socially and politically -- the leading candidate in voter surveys until today has been Mr. Samper's staunchest defender and hand-picked successor, Mr. Serpa.
In his letter of resignation as Mr. Samper's Interior Minister last year, Mr. Serpa wrote, "You, Mr. President, have set an example of equanimity, dignity and patriotism, and under your leadership the Government will, with good fortune, overcome the enormous challenges that have arisen."
Nevertheless, Mr. Serpa said in a pre-election debate that he would not rule out extraditing his former boss to the United States should Washington seek this.
By contrast Mr. Pastrana, whom voters might have thought more likely to surrender the unpopular President to the American authorities, rejected extradition.
In a final voter survey published in the daily El Tiempo today, the two candidates were tied, with Mr. Pastrana leading by less than 1 percent.
Mr. Pastrana, 44, who is favored by the business community here, is the son of former President Misael Pastrana. A former Mayor of Bogota, he could, in theory, make the most convincing case for offering Colombia a fresh start, since he has been out of government for the last four years.
His television campaign advertisements list the violence, corruption and other troubles of Colombia over the last four years with Mr. Samper's face gradually fading into that of Mr. Serpa.
But Mr. Pastrana lacks the charisma of Mr. Serpa, 55, who has managed to put the Conservatives on the defensive by predicting that he will privatize state industries. Mr. Pastrana has been reduced to pledging his opposition to privatization.
Mr. Pastrana has produced a more detailed peace proposal than Mr. Serpa. As part of a settlement, he has proposed ending the use of herbicides to kill drug crops, calling instead for an internationally backed plan to offer coca-growing peasants alternative ways to earn a living.
Mr. Pastrana lacks the media backing and the Government support enjoyed by Mr. Serpa. The Government ombudsman's recent review of election campaign coverage showed television stations, which depend on the Government for their operating licenses, giving substantially more air time to Mr. Serpa.
Noemi Sanin, an independent presidential candidate whose unexpectedly strong showing in the first round of voting has turned her into an arbiter of political morality, has also denounced the Samper Government for doling out free publicity to Mr. Serpa on the Government-run television station and for publicly supporting his candidacy.
Ms. Sanin, whose 2.6 million votes could provide the winning margin for Mr. Pastrana, has declined to support either candidate.
Jorge A. Castro, a 59-year-old egg wholesaler, said he supported Mr. Serpa because "he knows our country's problems."
Asked if Mr. Serpa was not responsible for some of them, Mr. Castro gathered up a handful of coins. He picked out a silver-colored coin to represent Mr. Samper, as the chief who was responsible for his Government's actions, and a brass one to represent Mr. Serpa.
"See, they're not even the same color," he said.
The most pressing issue, along with the economic troubles, has been negotiating an end to the conflict that the military here has been unable to win in the last 30 years.
Each candidates has said that if elected, he would take charge of negotiations with the guerrillas, with Mr. Pastrana adding on Friday that he would seek a meeting with Mr. Marulanda, the FARC leader, next week. Both candidates have said they would agree to a guerrilla demand for the withdrawal of Government security forces from five municipalities as a requirement for negotiations.
But it was Mr. Samper's agreement to pull back troops from the five municipalities, a move that the rebels had been seeking unsuccessfully for three years, that prompted the rebels' public attack on Mr. Serpa.
"Now, with electoral ends to win votes and guarantee the triumph of Dr. Serpa," President Samper "offers to evacuate," said a communique from the rebels, which also criticized Mr. Serpa's record as a peacemaker over the last 12 years.
As chief peace negotiator under President Cesar Gaviria, the rebels say, Mr. Serpa closed peace talks in Mexico, ushering in the "total war" offensive against the guerrillas. As Interior Minister under Mr. Samper, he saw the creation of armed citizen's defense groups known as convivirs, which the guerrillas and human rights groups both contended were mechanisms to legalize paramilitary death squads.
A Colombian court has now ruled the defense groups illegal.
On Thursday, Mr. Serpa said he would name Alvaro Uribe Velez, the former Governor of Antioquia who led the creation of defense groups around Medellin, as his Defense Minister, apparently in an effort to establish his credentials among the military and conservative landowners.
"There's a rhetoric of peace, but in practice there's been an increase in terror while he's been in government," said Carlos Franco, a former guerrilla of the Marxist April 19 Movement, known as the M-19, who has joined other political figures to support Mr. Pastrana. "I think all this led the FARC to conclude that Serpa's chances of negotiating peace were low."

HEADLINE: Education Is Watchword in Election

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 19

 BODY:
Ask Phil Maloof for his most important legislative proposal if he is sent to Congress in a special election on Tuesday, and he has a ready reply: "We need more computers in the classroom for kids."
His Republican rival, Heather Wilson, was so eager to highlight her bona fides on education that she did not mention that she was a Rhodes Scholar or an arms negotiator in the Bush Administration. Instead, she noted that she had been one of five finalists to be superintendent of the Albuquerque public schools. 
 Around the nation, candidates for state and local office are talking far more about education than any other theme. Nowhere is that better demonstrated than here in New Mexico's First Congressional District, where a race to succeed Representative Steven H. Schiff, a Republican who died in March, sometimes resembles a contest for a seat on the local school board more than an election to the United States Congress.
Mrs. Wilson has tried to skewer Mr. Maloof, a Democratic member of the State Senate, with television commercials that accuse him of skipping sessions of the chamber's higher education committee. Everywhere he goes, Mr. Maloof emphasizes his endorsement from principals of seven schools in his Senate district. His commercials attack Mrs. Wilson for not voting in the last three school board elections here.
Beyond the focus on education, the closely contested campaign -- the only full-scale Congressional election before November -- offers an important preview of what awaits voters (and even the candidates) as the midterm election year unfolds.
Attack commercials are alive and well. For all their pledges to stay on the high ground, Mr. Maloof and Mrs. Wilson have not been timid about flinging oratorical mud. Both sides agree that the campaign in this usually placid state is the nastiest they have seen here in years.
Judging by this race, it is also clear that Democrats still intend to demonize Speaker Newt Gingrich, as they did successfully in the 1996 elections. In a new Maloof commercial, the announcer warns that Mrs. Wilson would abolish the Department of Education. "Tell Heather Wilson to stop siding with Newt Gingrich," he says as side-by-side photographs of Mr. Gingrich and Mrs. Wilson pop on the screen. (Republicans, by contrast, have not featured Mr. Clinton, who is fairly popular in this state.)
The commercials of the 37-year-old Mrs. Wilson, a former head of the State Department of Children, Youth and Families, portray the 31-year-old Mr. Maloof as an empty suit. "I just don't think he understands the issues," the announcer intones. "Phil's just too young."
One explanation for the intense personal attacks may be another reality of the 1998 campaign: With the hardy economy, the campaigns here are having a particularly hard time engaging uninterested voters. As a result, the Maloof and Wilson campaigns are running particularly aggressive telephone and literature drives to get people to the polls on Tuesday. Except for an organization advocating term limits, which is running advertisements backing Mr. Maloof, outside interest groups are preserving their advertising budgets for the regular House races.
While this race offers important clues for November, it is crucial in its own right, which helps explain why Hillary Rodham Clinton and Tipper Gore, as well as Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, and Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island, are coming here this weekend to campaign for Mr. Maloof. Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, is scheduled to campaign here for Mrs. Wilson.
If Mr. Maloof manages to wrest the seat from Republicans, then Democrats would have to pick up only 10 seats in November to retake the House. Officials on both sides agree that whoever wins the election on Tuesday to complete Mr. Schiff's term will be the favorite when the candidates face off again in November. (Earlier this month the two candidates won their parties' primaries for the general election.)
"The winner has all the momentum going into the fall," said Steve Grossman, national chairman of the Democratic Party.
The latest polls show the race dead even in the district, which is split roughly between Republicans and Democrats. But polls show that the Green Party candidate, Robert Anderson, is gaining ground and could siphon votes from Mr. Maloof.
But Mrs. Wilson is still trying to recover from a 60-second Maloof commercial that says she "abused her position of power" when she was in the Cabinet by trying to remove a confidential case file with potentially embarrassing information about her husband, Jay Hone.
Mrs. Wilson asserted that the advertisement was "full of lies." Her aides concede, however, that it has been the single most damaging development in the campaign. "We lost eight points overnight," said Steve Bell, Mrs. Wilson's chief strategist. "It was like a torpedo amid ships."
Beyond their deep ideological differences, Mrs. Wilson and Mr. Maloof could not be more dissimilar in their personal styles, backgrounds and personalities. Mr. Maloof is from one of New Mexico's wealthiest and most prominent families, which made its fortune in the hotel, casino, liquor and banking industries. His father, George J. Maloof, was so prominent that there is a bronze statue of him in downtown Albuquerque, with the inscription, "philanthropist/humanitarian."
Mr. Maloof has dipped into the family fortune to lend at least $1.2 million to his campaign, and is expected to spend closer to $2 million; Mrs. Wilson has raised nearly $1 million.
Mr. Maloof's biggest weaknesses are that he lacks a deep command of many issues, is prone to misstatements and often comes off as uncomfortable, even frightened, at campaign forums, particularly when he ventures beyond the stock Democratic talking points that he repeats again and again. At debates, while he appears earnest, he sometimes relies on briefing books. The missteps are so frequent that the National Republican Congressional Committee has enough material to regularly put out a flier titled, "Mal-OOPS!"
At their last televised debate, on Thursday night, Mr. Maloof was asked whether he would support programs to protect the Mexican gray wolf and spotted owl, even if they cost jobs. Instead of answering the question, Mr. Maloof noted that he was supported by environmental groups and favored the Endangered Species Act, and added, "I enjoy camping -- it's something I really enjoy." Then he quickly tried to change the subject to education, only to be admonished by the moderator.
Mrs. Wilson has sought to make Mr. Maloof's wealth an issue, a strategy Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis of California used in defeating a multimillionaire rival, Al Checchi, in that state's Democratic primary for governor this month. Her slogan, "You just can't buy the experience Heather Wilson has," is an adaptation of the Davis slogan, "Experience money can't buy."
But in an interview, Mr. Maloof was at a loss to explain the differences between his race and that of Mr. Checchi. "I don't know what hurt him," he said.
Mrs. Wilson, a former Air Force captain who was on the National Security Council staff in the Bush Administration, is far more articulate. But she has never run for elective office before and lacks Mr. Maloof's deep roots in the community.
Mrs. Wilson moved to the state less than seven years ago, and her accent sounds more like she is from her native New Hampshire than from the Southwest. She was the choice of Senator Pete V. Domenici, the state's senior Senator.
For all her smoothness on the stump, her own pollsters have found that voters are put off by Mrs. Wilson's officious and sometimes stiff manner and her preference for eye-glazing policy discussions. Determined to make herself likable, Mrs. Wilson tries to smile her way through campaign appearances.
Mr. Bell, who has taken a leave as Mr. Domenici's chief of staff to run the Wilson campaign in the final weeks, likens Mrs. Wilson to Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who is highly respected but also one of the more colorless lawmakers in Washington.
Asked in an interview why she has hit so hard on what she describes as Mr. Maloof's unpreparedness, Mrs. Wilson said: "There are a lot of people in Congress and in public life, average people of average intelligence. Or even below average intelligence. I don't think that's it, really. There's something else. Maybe it's confidence or experience."
Particularly in the final days of the campaign, officials on both sides said their own polls showed that education had shot up as by far the most critical issue.
"All the polling shows that the undecided vote is the female vote," said Tom Hujar, Mr. Maloof's chief consultant, "so both candidates are going very heavily in terms of their appeals toward women. So education is in the forefront."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;
No Budging in Negotiations

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
There is still time for National Basketball Association players to form a team and compete for the United States in Athens this summer, just as there is still time for the players and owners to agree on a deal that would insure labor peace before the current collective bargaining agreement expires on July 1.
But given the stubborn climate of recent negotiations, neither appears likely. Even with a meeting scheduled for Monday in Manhattan, both sides appear headed toward a long, tense summer of bargaining. With major monetary issues on the table, the league faces the growing possibility of losing games to labor strife for the first time. 
 "Eventually, you have to make a deal," said Russ Granik, the league's deputy commissioner, who is heading the negotiations on behalf of the owners. "The only question is when and how much damage you do before you get to that point."
Billy Hunter, the executive director of the players' association, proposed last Wednesday that both sides agree to a moratorium rather than the owners' locking out the players. A lockout would prohibit any N.B.A. business between players and teams, meaning the free-agent signing period, set to begin July 1, would be postponed indefinitely.
But the owners will not accept any deal that allows more contracts or trades to be signed and consummated under the current rules. Barring major concessions, two league officials confirmed Friday, a lockout is imminent.
Using the world championships in Athens as a platform, the 12 N.B.A. players selected to the team have decided to boycott the games until a labor agreement is reached. USA Basketball, the organization that selects teams for international play, stoked the fires last week, saying it would send another team to Athens.
There is hope for Grant Hill, Gary Payton and friends to play overseas. FIBA, which oversees international competition, has privately intimated to USA Basketball that it would accommodate last-minute replacements in order to field the best team possible. It is a move that would clear the way for N.B.A. players to decide to compete shortly before the games begin on July 29.
But while rosters and dates are negotiable, apparently the players are not budging. "In all probability, if there is a lockout, the players will be inclined to vote not to go," Hunter said.
According to a lawyer familiar with the negotiations, the owners want to install a hard salary cap, essentially a fixed amount each team can spend in a season, without exceptions. Over the next two or three seasons, teams would also like to phase out the Larry Bird exception, in which teams can pay their own free agents whatever they want, regardless of the salary cap.
For the owners, the ultimate goal is to reduce salaries over a three-year period so that they do not exceed 48 to 50 percent of revenues. They also would like to limit individual salaries so that one or two players do not gobble up all the money on a roster.
Whereas the owners see their proposals as finally bringing some economic balance to a league of $100 million-or-bust contracts, the players view the approach as taking back what it is already theirs.
"They're not even on the same planet right now," said a union official who requested anonymity.
The perception among players is that Commissioner David Stern is wedded to the idea that they will give in if they have to miss paychecks. The players' resolve may indeed be tested.
 
Draft Variables
This is what preparation for the N.B.A. has come to: A guy who had not played five-on-five basketball until two years ago may end up going No. 1 in Wednesday's draft.
Now hedging on whether they will select Arizona point guard Mike Bibby with the first pick, the Los Angeles Clippers may take the University of Pacific's 7-foot-1-inch Nigerian, Michael Olowokandi, this week in Vancouver, British Columbia. The club is said to be divided on which player it will choose, leaving the door open for the first five or six selections.
Vancouver, which is said to be interested in taking the Kansas forward Paul Pierce at No. 2, is still entertaining offers from teams for its pick. The Denver Nuggets, who have the third pick, are worried the Toronto Raptors will move up from No. 4 to No. 2 in order to take Olowokandi or Bibby, thus forcing them to take Pierce instead of the big man they covet.
Kansas' Raef LaFrentz, North Carolina's Antawn Jamison, Vince Carter and the St. Louis shooting guard Larry Hughes all figure to be in the next group of players, along with Michigan's Robert (Tractor) Traylor and Utah's Michael Doleac.
 
Filling Out the Bulls
With the season put on hold, so, too, is the future of the Chicago Bulls.
Bulls Chairman Jerry Reinsdorf continues to express desire about re-signing Michael Jordan, Scottie Pippen and Dennis Rodman to prevent the franchise from falling into immediate decay.
If Jordan can persuade Pippen to somehow overcome his long-held resentment against management in the next few months or whenever the owners and players settle their labor war, the possibility of a reunion for one more season exists.
But if Chicago loses Pippen and Rodman -- along with Coach Phil Jackson, as expected -- look for General Manager Jerry Krause to make some kind of push for the free agent Jayson Williams to fill the rebounding void.
If Chicago could not offer Williams the money the Nets can, it would not be beyond the Bulls to sell their corporate culture to Williams and give him reassurances that he will not retire a poor man. What's more, Toni Kukoc has shown over the past few months that he can pick up much of Pippen's offensive contributions.
For Jordan to come back, he needs to be convinced he can still compete for a title. If Pippen leaves, acquiring another All-Star in Chicago is the only difference between him staying for one or two more seasons or leaving the game again.

HEADLINE: Pittsburgh Is Showcase For Women In Policing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, June 17

 BODY:
A small placard hangs on a wall in Comdr. Maurita J. Bryant's office so that she can always see it from behind her desk. It reads, "Of course women don't work as hard as men; they do it right the first time."
As one of 14 commanders on the Pittsburgh police force, Ms. Bryant gets more than her share of opportunities to do things right the first time. And so do hundreds of other women in blue who patrol the streets of the nation's 48th largest city. 
 On a police force of 1,100 officers, 25 percent are women, the highest percentage of any law-enforcement agency in the United States and more than twice the average percentage, says a recent study by the National Center for Women and Policing, a Los Angeles division of the Feminist Majority Foundation.
The survey, which reflects the composition of 100 agencies in 1997, also found that the Pittsburgh force included the nation's highest percentage of women in command positions, 37.5 percent. In addition to Commander Bryant, whose district has the highest crime rate in the city, five other women in Pittsburgh are commanders, a rank just below assistant chief and deputy chief.
Pittsburgh is just one of a number of major cities where crime rates are steadily falling, and neither Commander Bryant nor any other senior official on the force attributes the trend to the large number of women who are officers. More likely, they agreed, new community policing techniques and updated technology were helping the department to turn from a reactive style, largely responding to 911 calls, to a preventive approach.
Nonetheless, Commander Bryant and other women on the Pittsburgh force say the skills women bring to the job add vital components to policing. Women, they say, are more inclined than men to use communication skills to quell potentially violent situations, and they can bring an extra sensitivity to situations involving children and rape victims.
"When you bring diversity to any work environment, especially policing, you add to the overall performance of the whole department," said Chief Robert McNeilly, who agreed with many women on the force who said that the days when male officers were reluctant to have women as partners were generally over.
But for all the progress women have made on the Pittsburgh force, many fear a backslide. A 1976 court order demanding that for every white man hired, the force had to hire a woman and two members of minorities, one a man and one a woman, expired in 1991. Ever since, the number of women and members of minorities joining the force has slowed. And in a recent lawsuit against the city, eight white men who failed to get jobs on the force, won settlements in a reverse discrimination case.
Officials here say the main impediment to recruiting highly qualified women -- and men -- is the strong national economy, which is enabling private industry to offer higher pay for entry-level positions to people who would be attracted to a career in law enforcement. In addition, municipal budget constraints, as elsewhere, have slowed hiring. Chief McNeilly said he did not expect the city to replace officers who retired or resigned for more than a year.
But those explanations ring hollow to people who track the advances of women in law enforcement. Recalling the days of the court order, Penny Harrington, president of the group that conducted the survey, said, "When they were forced to find women, they found them."
Chief McNeilly and Mayor Tom Murphy said they remained sensitive to the issue and they vowed to take new approaches to find qualified women for the force. They said they intended to step up their recruiting efforts and to focus on women leaving the military as a likely pool of candidates.
But Ms. Harrington criticized that approach, calling it "the old way" of thinking. "Why not look on college campuses, nursing schools, look for paralegals and social workers?" she asked. "They already have the mindset to help people, not kill them."
For the time being, at least, Pittsburgh remains a showcase for women in policing. The survey found that only five other cities -- Detroit, Miami, Philadelphia, Washington and Toledo -- had police forces in which women accounted for 20 percent of officers. In all those cities but Miami, the strong presence of women was aided by a court order, the survey found. On Miami's force of 2,920 officers, no woman serves in a command position.
By contrast, the survey found that 42 agencies -- including the police departments in Nassau County, in New York, and Newark; the state police in New York and New Jersey, and the Port Authority of New York-New Jersey -- had fewer than 10 percent female officers in 1997.
Commander Bryant, 45, who is black and a divorced mother of two grown daughters, leads a district of 124 officers and supervisors who patrol a zone where more homicides are committed than in any other district in the city. She joined the force in 1977, when she was just looking for a dependable job, she said, "and the idea of having a female supervisor was unheard of."
As she rose in rank over the years, she said, attitudes slowly changed as men on the force grew more comfortable with women because of the skills women brought to the job.
In many situations, Commander Bryant said, women serve as a soothing balance to the macho tendencies of male officers, a situation that is influencing men on the force.
Linda Rosato-Barone, 40, the commander of another high-crime zone, who joined the force in 1979, agreed, saying: "I think adding women to the force has helped make the men more sensitive. They hate to hear that they are becoming touchy-feely; they prefer the image of tough and strong. I beg to differ. They're human beings like everyone else."
Recalling her days as a patrol officer, Commander Bryant said, "There were situations where if I had approached them like a man, acting super tough, I'd have gotten knocked on my butt."
Job skills aside, women on the force say there is still some resentment among male colleagues, especially older officers who were on the force before the court order changed its makeup. Sgt. Jim O'Brien, a veteran of 28 years who works in Commander Bryant's zone, said he, among other men, was slow to "welcome women with open arms."
"The majority of men accept the women now," he said. "But there are always a few who still don't."
Commander Bryant, who grew up in a housing project and saw police officers as people to be feared, conceded that old ways die hard among some officers. But most men working under her command, she said, dare not display any signs of discomfort or disrespect.
"I don't hear any snickers," she said. "When you have to discipline a male officer, with white guys you usually see a level of red in their face, and with black guys, you see them tense their jaw muscles. It's interesting to watch."
But the surest sign of progress, she said, may be the blackboard in the men's room, on which officers scribble complaints and nasty remarks -- or so she is told.
"So far," she said with a smile, "I don't think I've been on it."
