HEADLINE: Iran's Parliament Ousts a Minister but President Rehires Him

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, June 21

 BODY:
In a high-stakes political battle filled with recriminations and rage, Iran's Parliament voted today to dismiss one of the closest allies of Mohammad Khatami, the reform-minded President.
Mr. Khatami swiftly retaliated. He made Abdullah Noori, the ousted Minister of the Interior, a Vice President.
Parliament is controlled by Mr. Khatami's enemies. Its action today is the most serious political setback to his presidency since his landslide victory 13 months ago as well as graphic proof of Mr. Khatami's limited room for maneuver in Iran's Islamic Republic. 
 The vote comes just three days after Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright warmly praised Mr. Khatami and the direction in which he seems to be taking the country, and she held out the prospect of eventual normalization of relations with Iran.
The vote, 137 to 117 with 11 abstentions, came in a secret ballot after several hours of impassioned debate in which Mr. Noori was accused of arrogantly dismissing officials who did not share his politics, fostering an unstable economic environment and putting the country's security at risk.
The vote was as much an attack against Mr. Khatami as it was against Mr. Noori, and it is part of a wider campaign led by conservative members of the clergy to discredit officials loyal to the President.
The parliamentary session was broadcast live on radio and later on television as millions of Iranian viewers were awaiting the live broadcast of the World Cup soccer match between the United States and Iran at 11:30 P.M. Both opponents and supporters of Mr. Noori stepped up to the lectern in the center of the modest parliamentary hall to air their views.
"If the current trend continues, the result will be something like Lebanon of a few years ago, or Yugoslavia," said Mohammad Reza Bahonar, a Deputy Speaker of Parliament, predicting partition of the country. "Mr. Noori's attitude is dangerous to the political future of the country."
In another angry speech, Marzieh Vahid-Dastjerdi, an obstetrician and representative from Teheran who was dressed in the traditional black chador, accused Mr. Noori of replacing 1,700 officials, primarily because they "were not thinking like you." She also attacked Mr. Noori's definition of freedom, saying, "For us, freedom doesn't mean that counterrevolutionary groups can do whatever they want and create anarchy."
In support of Mr. Noori, Majid Ansari, a member of Parliament from Teheran, accused the minister's enemies of exaggerating Iran's troubles as if "Iran is on the verge of war."
Mr. Noori sat stone-faced during the speeches before offering a defense.
"I do not claim I never made a mistake," he said. But he accused his enemies of a plot to alienate Iran's young people from the true meaning of the Islamic revolution.
Mr. Noori was reflecting the position voiced repeatedly by Mr. Khatami and his supporters that what is at stake is nothing less than the soul of the nation. According to this line of thinking, unless Iran becomes freer at home and more open to the outside world, it will lose the allegiance of the generation born in the 19 years since the monarchy was overthrown.
Mr. Khatami has therefore committed himself to the creation of a "civil society" and the "rule of law" at home and has reached out to improve relations with both the Arab world and the West.
But Mr. Khatami is fiercely opposed by those clerics -- and their followers -- who believe that the core beliefs of the revolution are being sacrificed.
"If Parliament does not give me the vote of confidence, I will thank God that he has lifted this heavy responsibility from my shoulders, and I will see this as God's mercy," Mr. Noori said in his speech. "And if I get the vote of confidence, I will be energized once again."
He added, "Whether Abdullah Noori remains or not, until the last second of my life I will remain the servant of the system, the revolution and the leadership."
Members of Parliament cast white ballots to dismiss Mr. Noori, purple ballots to keep him and yellow ballots to abstain. Then Ali Akbar Nateq-Noori, the Speaker of Parliament, announced in sober tones, "Mr. Abdullah Noori failed to win a vote of confidence." Several of the members shouted, "God is great!"
Mr. Nateq-Noori had been the front-runner for President and lost in an upset to Mr. Khatami.
On Thursday, Mr. Khatami defended Mr. Noori, calling him "one of the strongest ministers in the Cabinet." The President predicted that Mr. Noori's "absence from the Cabinet will entail massive damage for the Government and the country."
Although Mr. Khatami acknowledged that Parliament had the right under the Constitution to dismiss Mr. Noori, he reiterated his determination to give the people the freedoms they hold under the law. "I and my administration are very serious about this principle," he said. "Of course, it has costs which must be paid, just like building a bridge or a factory."
In introducing the dismissal motion last month, 31 members of Parliament accused Mr. Noori of "creating tension in society, giving provocative interviews and speeches in different provinces and appointing inexperienced people to managerial posts in the ministry."
Mr. Noori, 49, a mid-ranking cleric from Isfahan, has been an outspoken proponent of Mr. Khatami's commitment to impose a rule of law and has come under fire for issuing permits to allow groups to conduct peaceful demonstrations.
Under the Constitution, the country's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and not the President, controls the judiciary, as well as the military, radio and television and the intelligence and security services.
But Mr. Khatami has encouraged Mr. Noori to challenge decisions by the judiciary -- particularly the arrest of Teheran's Mayor, Gholamhossein Karabaschi, who is on trial on corruption and embezzlement charges. The trial is broadcast on television in the evenings.
Mr. Noori has also strongly supported Mr. Karabaschi and has openly criticized the chief of the judiciary, Ayatollah Mohammed Yazdi, for arresting the Mayor in April without telling Mr. Noori.
He said at the time, "When the Mayor of Teheran, who is a member of the Cabinet, is arrested without informing the Interior Minister or even the President and some public media resort to rumor-mongering; when the Mayor, with all his experience, is prevented from having any visitors and an arrest warrant that is totally inconsistent with the charges is issued for him; when propaganda campaigns against the Mayor and his colleagues are launched for several consecutive months from every side and he remains silent, like a wronged person, in the interest of the state, what hope can an ordinary citizen have that the law will defend his rights?"
After several thousand people demonstrated in favor of the Mayor, he was released on bail.
In a direct affront to Parliament, Mr. Khatami today cited Mr. Noori's "capabilities" and created a job for him: Vice President for Development and Social Affairs. The job keeps Mr. Noori in the Cabinet and does not require Parliament's approval.
In another sign that he had no intention of surrendering to Parliament, Mr. Khatami appointed Mostafa Tajzadeh, a Deputy Minister of the Interior, as the acting minister. Mr. Tajzadeh, a staunch supporter of the President, was also criticized today by some Parliament members.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Compromised Visitor

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Never has a U.S. President traveled to Beijing at such a disadvantage: Bill Clinton has reason to suspect that the Chinese leaders possess information about "the China connection" to his campaigns, but he does not know what it is.
He knows that they know much more than anyone about the penetration of the White House by Asian fronts for Chinese intelligence. They have all the details about Indonesia's Riady family's long-term investment in his career, and probably of instructions to influence his post-election change of trade policy. 
 Mr. Clinton must assume it is in China's interest to provide an escape hatch for 50 fleeing witnesses, to deny being the source of millions in campaign contributions and to keep secret Democratic money laundering done by Hong Kong and Macao banks. China will want to conceal from the Justice Department and Congress the illegal donations to, and policy penetration of, the White House and D.N.C.
In obstructing any investigation, the interests of China run parallel to those of this compromised U.S. President. Both Clinton and the Chinese want nothing further to come out. Accept, if you wish, the protestations of Clinton defenders that his campaign organization was duped by John Huang, Charlie Trie and Maria Hsia, and was ignorant of the source of the Asian funds solicited from Johnny Chung. Buy, if you like, the notion that the payments had nothing to do with flip-flops on trade and the technology-transfer triumph over the Pentagon by anything-goes Commerce.
But even if China's quid was not "solely" responsible for Clinton's quo, the fact remains that secret Chinese money passed and U.S. policy changed. The unspoken truth haunting this summit is that China's leaders have something on this President.
Would they use this illicit leverage to gain a concession? Of course not; Chinese diplomacy can be exquisitely subtle. No winks of understanding will be needed.
In this charade, Mr. Clinton will formally ask the Chinese to cooperate with the Congress and the Department of Justice, and China's Jiang will formally promise to help. Perhaps an expendable non-official middleman will be designated to take a gentle fall, helping Janet Reno to avoid having to seek independent counsel. And the relieved Clinton will owe Jiang a big one.
In light of his personal negotiating difficulty, and recognizing the need for the U.S. to exchange summit visits with a major power, what can we reasonably ask our President to do?
1. Before leaving for Beijing, stop claiming that all critics seek only to "isolate" a billion people. Clinton's tired straw-man argument insults both human-rights activists and hard-line strategists. I wrote that for Nixon, and the grapes of wrath don't take a second squeezing.
2. On arrival, don't waste your mandatory human-rights message on the accompanying press corps. Instead, insist on making it a major theme of your live broadcast-telecast to the Chinese people, and be sure the interpreter is our man. Meet and be photographed with authentic dissidents and offer to host a White House meeting between Jiang and the Dalai Lama.
3. In negotiations, deal with verification of promises to curtail the spread of nukes and missiles; don't try to con the world with a phony p.r. stunt of "re-targeting" missiles. We all know they can be aimed again at U.S. cities within 10 minutes -- and now much more accurately, thanks to the victory of Clinton Commerce and the big donors over the Pentagon.
4. Surface the concern in our intelligence community with experiments in China to gain the ability to combat our "critical infrastructure." A brigade of official hackers with the mission of destroying our computer communications and satellites is even more worrisome than a beachhead in Long Beach, Calif.
5. Try financial jujitsu. When China threatened to devalue its yuan unless the U.S. and Japan bolstered the yen, the U.S. jumped to do Beijing's bidding. Now Clinton should heap praise on Chinese "economic stability" -- making it harder for China to devalue when the pressure in Japan builds again.
Finally, let Jiang know that the next U.S. President might not be so vulnerable to revelations of Chinese manipulation, and will not forget any advantage taken of this one.

HEADLINE: Colombian President's Accuser Handily Wins Presidency

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 21

 BODY:
Colombians voted a resounding end today to the scandal-ridden presidency of Ernesto Samper, electing as his successor the man who first accused Mr. Samper of accepting money from drug dealers.
The election of the opponent, Andres Pastrana, the Conservative former Mayor of Bogota, over Horacio Serpa of the Liberal Party, President Samper's Interior Minister and most loyal advocate, opens a new chapter in Colombia's relations with the United States, which have boiled over with bitterness and suspicion in Mr. Samper's four years in power. 
 With more than 96 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Pastrana had won 50.3 percent of the vote, to 46.25 for Mr. Serpa.
"The country clearly came out to vote for change," Mr. Pastrana said.
The unusually strong showing of Mr. Pastrana, who won a higher number of votes than any previously elected president, and a high turnout was in sharp contrast to opinion surveys, all of which had shown the two candidates virtually tied and had predicted a low turnout.
"It's a rejection of all the negative things the country has been living through for the last four years, the Government policies, unemployment, corruption and a style of politics that's very tied to patronage," said Rodrigo Losada, a political scientist at Javeriana University.
Alfredo Rangel, a former national security adviser who said he was "absolutely surprised" by the results, agreed. "The Liberal Party political machine couldn't pull it off," Mr. Rangel said. "And it was mobilized to the maximum."
Mr. Rangel predicted that relations with the United States would dramatically improve with Mr. Pastrana's election, probably entering a new era of closeness and cooperation between the two countries.
Mr. Serpa, in defending Mr. Samper, had frequently lashed out publicly against American officials, at one point calling the former United States Ambassador here, Myles R. Frechette, "the crazy gringo."
Mr. Serpa conceded defeat tonight, saying, "I congratulate Andres Pastrana for his election as Colombia's next President and I call on all my fellow countrymen to support him and accompany him in the difficult task he faces."
Under Mr. Samper, who was accused of having accepted $6 million from drug dealers in his campaign and whose United States visa was revoked two years ago, American officials cultivated ties with other individuals or agencies like the Police Chief, Gen. Rosso Jose Serrano, while largely avoiding direct encounters with the President.
"Very definitively, voters punished the Samper Government," Mr. Rangel said. "It's an overwhelming rejection of continuity."
Although Mr. Pastrana may enjoy strong electoral backing, the Congress remains heavily Liberal. A Liberal deputy who has been supporting Mr. Pastrana's candidacy, Ingrid Betancur, said Mr. Pastrana would probably seek a referendum to elect a new Congress as part of an overall drive for political reform if he could not govern with the current Congress.
As President-Elect, Mr. Pastrana's first order of business is expected to be a meeting with the leader of the largest rebel group that has been battling Government security forces for more than 30 years, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. He pledged to hold such a meeting as early as next week, if security permits.
The two candidates' potential ability to negotiate an end to the civil conflict that has claimed more than 30,000 lives in Colombia was, along with the economy, a top issue in the campaign. With the strong support of the business community and his Conservative credentials unquestioned by the military, Mr. Pastrana appears to have wide latitude for tackling the most difficult problems.
In the final days of campaigning, Mr. Pastrana had said he would meet the rebel leader, Manuel Marulanda, who had met with Mr. Pastrana's campaign chief the week before.
Mr. Marulanda allowed the release of a photograph of his talking with the campaign manager in what appeared to be a silent endorsement of Mr. Pastrana. That move struck at the heart of Mr. Serpa's claim to be the candidate most capable of negotiating peace talks, and it increased Mr. Pastrana's standing among voters weary of the seemingly intractable civil conflict.
Mr. Pastrana has pledged to lead negotiations personally with the leftist rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and with the smaller National Liberation Army and has agreed to a guerrilla demand that Government security forces evacuate five municipalities during any peace negotiations. He has also pledged separate parallel talks with right-wing paramilitary leaders, who have been demanding a say in any peace negotiations.
Mr. Pastrana has not ruled out a settlement that would incorporate the rebels in the Government, allowing them political control of areas that they already control. Under such an agreement, the Government would eventually end the fumigation of drug crops, holding the rebels responsible for eliminating drug crops in their areas. Mr. Pastrana has proposed an international aid plan to support alternative development in coca-growing regions, as well.
The mood in Bogota was festive and energetic today, with cars festooned with posters and stickers for the candidates careering down the avenues and taking over street corners. Youngsters painted their faces in the red, blue and yellow of the Colombian flag and waved flags from car windows. At scattered stoplights Mr. Pastrana's supporters exhorted drivers to vote for their candidate, while across the street, supporters of Mr. Serpa shouted the praises of their hopeful.
In Bogota those encounters were free of violence. But in the countryside scattered fighting between guerrillas and Government security forces was reported.
At polling places like the working-class district of South Candelaria and the stylish outdoor polling stations in northern Bogota voters appeared divided and none too pleased with either candidate.
An executive, Jorge Ramirez, 46, stood with his dog outside the room where he was going to vote. He said he could not decide for whom to vote and listed his country's troubles.
"Violence, mismanagement, bad administration," Mr. Ramirez said. "The corruption of the upper classes, which is poisoning our country day by day. There are things the country cannot forget."
But later, he said he decided to vote for Mr. Serpa, faulting Mr. Pastrana for his poor performance as Mayor of Bogota from 1988 to 1990.
In poorer neighborhoods Mr. Pastrana, son of former President Misael Pastrana, was frequently resented for his political pedigree, while Mr. Serpa was embraced for having risen above his working-class background in the oil port of Barrancabermeja. But those aspiring to the middle class, holding management jobs or owning their own businesses, appeared to favor Mr. Pastrana.
Epaminondas Navarrete, who said he had been working for 48 of his 56 years, said that both candidates made grand promises, but that Mr. Serpa's pledge to shrink the work week to 40 hours from 48 as a means of combatting unemployment would hurt his business.
"I don't know which one to believe," he said. "but I think I believe Pastrana more than Serpa."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The victorious presidential candidate in Colombia, Andres Pastrana, flanked by his wife, Nora Puyana, and son Santiago after voting yesterday in Bogota. Mr. Pastrana is a former Mayor of the capital. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: SOME PRICES JUMP DESPITE A PATTERN OF LOW INFLATION

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
While the national inflation rate stays persistently low, reminiscent of the 1950's and 60's, prices have been rising noticeably in recent months for a variety of everyday items -- from fast-food hamburgers to auto maintenance to dental care.
The increases have been sharp enough in some cases not only to catch people's attention but to provoke their annoyance. 
 Consider the experience of John Gachelin, a 28-year-old marketing executive, who moved with his wife to Dallas from Chicago, in part to lower their living costs. Unlike Illinois, Texas has no state income tax. And houses cost less. But in the seven months since the move, the Gachelins have been hit with steep price increases to rent videos, change the oil in their two cars, buy cigarettes (he smokes), use a pay phone and buy hardcover books.
"The pay phone really surprised me," said Mr. Gachelin, who earns $40,000 a year. "I put in a quarter one day, and I found that I had to deposit 35 cents. But, hey, what can you do about it?"
What softens the blow for the Gachelins and many others are the prices that are not rising. Most of the essentials -- food, gasoline, cars, furniture, appliances, most apparel -- are holding steady in price or becoming cheaper. That is why the Consumer Price Index, which is an average of the prices of thousands of goods and services, has risen by only 1.7 percent over the last year.
It is the extras in life -- along with a few striking essentials, like home prices and rents -- that are becoming noticeably more expensive, and that is raising eyebrows. The University of Michigan's weekly consumer surveys may be registering the smallest percentage of Americans in 30 years worried about inflation, but they are also registering a growing annoyance.
"Almost everyone has this asymmetric reaction," said Richard Curtin, director of the surveys. "When prices go down or don't rise much, people don't say, 'On average, inflation is 1 or 2 percent.' Their attention is drawn to the items that went up in price, and they are annoyed. When prices go down or hold steady, they don't pay special attention; they just think that was a good buy."
Just how can the overall inflation rate remain so low while so many individual prices seem to be rising smartly? The answer lies in the way the Consumer Price Index is calculated. The Government checks 80,000 different prices each month, many of them for manufactured goods and commodities -- toys and cars, for example, and gasoline and food. These prices figure heavily in the averaging process that produces the Consumer Price Index. But over the last year, the prices of manufactured goods and commodities have remained steady, in part because of the pressure of global competition, and that has held down the overall index.
The price increases these days are centered in the service sector, where prices are rising rather smartly for a growing number of items. These increases, however, are not widespread enough to pull up the overall index beyond its current low level.
"The price increases in services have certainly outpaced those for products and commodities in the Consumer Price Index," said Patrick Jackman, chief of the group at the Bureau of Labor Statistics that compiles the index. If the trend continues, the index could edge up gradually. That, in fact, has happened in the last two months.
The expanding list of rising prices is partly a reflection of the robust economy. As incomes rise and unemployment falls, people become more ambitious in their purchases and more tolerant of price increases, even while complaining. So they go along with a Manhattan merchant, for example, who has raised the price of his custom-made suits by $100, to between $750 and $1,095.
"I needed to be at this level three or four years ago," said Andrew Kozinn, the third-generation owner of Saint Laurie Merchant Tailors on Broadway near 19th Street. He recently opened his first uptown store, on Park Avenue at 51st Street, to draw more customers from the banks, investment houses and office towers in the area. "I could not have raised my prices or opened that store," Mr. Kozinn said, "without this feeling of prosperity among so many people."
Merchants in general have become bolder in pushing up prices. That is particularly the case if what they sell is much in demand these days and short in supply, like custom-made men's suits or rental apartments. Or they are services available from no one else -- Walt Disney's theme parks, for example, and the state-run ferry system that carries 25 million riders a year between Seattle and the numerous island communities in Puget Sound.
Disney's admission price to its theme parks in Orlando, Fla., rose nearly 5 percent in April, to $42, and the state-run ferry system's tickets went up 7 percent, on average, in May. The new fares range up to $30 on the longest route. The state ferry commission said the increases were required to finance expansion of the fleet; the service is heavily used by tourists and commuters. The commuters expressed resignation. Many said, in a questionnaire, that they had no reasonable alternative to the ferry.
The ferry price increase, the first since 1994, reflects an increasingly common practice in the private sector. "Our clients have been struggling with price resistance for so long that any cunning they can use to grab an extra price, they use," said Daniel Yankelovich, chairman of the polling company DYG, whose clients are mostly corporations. "The list of significant increases is almost a profile of what people can get away with."
Prices in the last year have gone up significantly more than the inflation rate in more than 30 categories. This is evident in the data collected by the Bureau of Labor Statistics and in more than two dozen interviews with company executives and representatives of trade and consumer organizations.
The list includes price increases already much in the news: fees for using automated-teller machines, for example, car rentals, airline fares for last-minute travelers, hotel rates, monthly apartment rentals and housing prices, although the cost of running a house has gone down for those who have refinanced mortgages.
Other increases run the gamut of services: legal fees, dental care, H.M.O. insurance premiums, parking lot rates, some fast-food restaurant prices, long-distance phone calls made within a state, accountants' fees, school tuition at all levels and charges for vehicle maintenance.
Entertainment is also more expensive -- cable television rates are up, as are tickets to most theme parks and sports events, entrance fees for some national parks and even wine. The price of a funeral also keeps going up.
Rising costs are sometimes cited as justification for the price increases. The Boston Red Sox, in announcing a ticket price increase at Fenway Park, argued that the money would go in part to pay the salaries of expensive baseball players. Procter & Gamble invoked higher paper costs as the reason for a 6 percent increase in the prices of bath and facial tissues in January. And Burger King blamed the rising minimum wage, which has pushed up the earnings of many of its employees, as a reason for cutting back sharply on the discounting of its Whopper hamburger.
Since March, the Whopper has been sold increasingly at its full price of $1.99 to $2.19, and the once-frequent discounts, to 99 cents, have been gradually eliminated, said Kim Miller, a Burger King spokeswoman. "We have decided consciously to shift the battle to taste, not price," she said.
Still, there is the problem of getting customers in the door. Americans have grown accustomed to discounts and bargains, and Burger King still offers 99-cent specials. But now it generally features less costly food than the Whopper -- a small milkshake, for example, or onion rings or fries. The hope is that once in the door, customers will spring for the Whopper.
Even Mr. Kozinn, the Manhattan clothier, has, as a lure, a giant yellow tape measure placed decorously in the window of his Park Avenue store. In red ink, the word "sale" stands out against the yellow background. John Lynch, a lawyer, sometimes has suits made at Mr. Kozinn's establishment for the sale price; usually they feature less expensive fabric. But last winter, he picked out a pricey British cloth, a blue woolen, and paid $795 for it. That same suit, six months earlier, had sold for $695.
"I am very thin and I have no seat," he said, "and I would have to spend almost as much to properly tailor a suit purchased off the rack. Still, $795 is a stretch and I would probably draw the line if the price went up another $100, or if I got concerned about the economy."
That same sort of ceiling seemed to govern an increase in pay phone rates in many states. Deregulation permitted the increase, but an attempt by local phone companies, which own many of the pay phones, to impose a 50-cent minimum in some Midwestern states resulted in a sharp decline in use. The customer resistance disappeared at a 35-cent minimum, and that became the norm in many states starting last October, although not in New York, which still charges 25 cents.
"The notion was that the market should set the price," said James Smith, a spokesman for Bell Atlantic, which provides service in the Northeast, "and 35 cents has turned out to be the market price."
Sooner or later, of course, the market will have something else to say about prices. "It will be interesting," said Mr. Jackman of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, "to see what happens when the economy slows down."

HEADLINE: Japanese Yen Weakens a Bit Against Dollar, but Stocks Rise

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, June 22

 BODY:
Just two days before President Clinton departs for China, financial markets in Asia reacted cautiously today to the weekend's political and diplomatic efforts to stabilize the Japanese yen and other Asia currencies.
The yen dipped modestly in value against the dollar in early Tokyo trading today, after Japan offered promises, but no specific measures, to revive its limping economy. 
 The Japanese currency weakened to 137.35 to the dollar, from 136.10 yen in New York on Friday, erasing just a bit of the gains brought about by the intervention of the United States and Japan last week. Before the intervention by Japanese and American authorities last week, the yen had reached 144 to the dollar.
Japanese stocks were stable, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues up 12.34, to 15,280.32, at midmorning.
Currency traders were wary in selling off the yen because of the possibility that the United States and Japan might intervene in the currency markets again, as they did on Wednesday, to prop up the yen. Their cautious stance also reflected concern about being on the wrong side of a bet if Japan does take steps to strengthen its economy.
"Maybe people's thinking has grown up a little and they realize this is not going to happen overnight," said Richard Jerram, economist at ING Barings Securities (Japan) Ltd., referring to the process of reviving Japan's economy. "It's going to take the next few months."
"Everyone is skeptical" about Japan's commitment to introducing structural change, he said, adding: "But if they do deliver, it's so huge that a currency-negative approach would be costly."
At a hastily called meeting Saturday of delegates from the Group of Seven industrialized nations and 10 Asian nations, Japan reiterated its commitment to clean up the nation's bad banking loans and to take steps to revive its economy. But despite expectations, Japan offered no new or concrete plans.
In what appeared to be an attempt to fend off an attack on the yen, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto held an emergency meeting this morning on the nation's bad banking loans with Koichi Kato, the secretary general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party. The meeting came as newspapers reported that a large Japanese bank, the Long-Term Credit Bank, which is saddled with billions of dollars in bad loans, was desperately looking for a rescue merger to escape collapse.
A further rapid decline of the yen would threaten financial stability in Asia and could escalate the economic turmoil in the region to a new level, particularly if China moved to devalue its currency.
Asian leaders have been unnerved by the prospect of China devaluing its currency. A devaluation by China could lead to a round of devaluations around the region, as other countries aim to cheapen their exports.
President Clinton said on Friday that the impact of currency instability on China played an important role in the decision by United States authorities to intervene and support the value of the yen last week.
"The most important thing is to try to alter the conditions which, if they continued to worsen, would make them feel compelled to devalue," President Clinton told Bloomberg News in an interview.
His remarks highlighted the role that China is playing in helping to maintain financial stability in Asia. China itself seems to have tried to bring about some coordinated response on the decline of the yen and had publicly voiced concern over the tumbling yen in the last two weeks.

HEADLINE: Distrust and Fear in the G.M. Strike

 BODY:
The United Automobile Workers' strike against General Motors in Flint, Mich., is an indication of just how deep distrust can still run in an industry where workers and management all too often have seen each other as enemies whose every action is viewed with hostility.
This strike began in that atmosphere. Each side believes the other failed to live up to promises made more than a year ago. The company says workers are refusing to implement agreements to improve productivity, while the workers accuse management of not making promised investments to improve the plant and fear management secretly wants to move their jobs to Mexico or to non-union suppliers. Neither side thinks it can rely on the word of the other, and there is no sign that the strike, which began June 5, will end soon. Workers and the company are suffering as the strike forces G.M. to close most of its North American assembly lines. 
 For the workers themselves, there is no reason to fear losing their jobs. The U.A.W.'s contract with G.M. guarantees that current union workers can keep working until they retire. But G.M.'s hourly work force in America has been declining steadily with attrition and is now less than half the level of two decades ago. The workers fear their children will not have the opportunities they had to get well-paid auto industry jobs.
With the American economy booming, G.M. is making money, a fact that makes it harder for the company to plead necessity as it pushes for higher productivity. But the world auto industry has substantial overcapacity, and some kind of shakeout is probably inevitable. For American plants to continue to compete in making affordable cars, companies and workers must find a way to cooperate. Ford and Chrysler have done a far better job of this than has General Motors, which is enduring its 16th strike in five years.
This strike will be settled at some point, and G.M. cars will again roll off the assembly lines. But if the two sides do not find a way to change the atmosphere of distrust and hostility, the chances of G.M.'s regaining its competitive edge -- and of being in a position to hire the children of current workers -- will not be good.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
Israeli Cabinet Approves Expansion of Jerusalem
The Israeli Cabinet approved a plan to expand the city of Jerusalem's control far beyond its current borders despite protests from Palestinians and Washington's warning that the plan was "provocative." Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that the plan did not violate peace accords with the Palestinian, under which the final status of Jerusalem is to be negotiated. A1
 
Parliament Rebuffs Khatami
Iran's Parliament voted to dismiss Interior Minister Abdullah Noori, a close ally of the country's reform-minded President Mohammed Khatami. Mr. Khatami swiftly retaliated by making Mr. Noori a Vice President. The jostling was part of a wider campaign by conservative members of the clergy to discredit officials loyal to the President. A9 

Colombian Leader Ousted
Colombians voted a resounding end to the scandal-ridden Presidency of Ernesto Samper by electing Andres Pastrana, the man who first accused Mr. Samper of accepting $6 million from drug dealers, to succeed him. The election could open a new chapter in Colombia's relations with the United States, which were bitter during Mr. Samper's administration. A3
 
China Policy Is Disputed
Congressional leaders' increasing furor over the Clinton Administration's engagement policy with China has taken center stage in Washington as President Clinton prepares to go to China this week. Congressional leaders, mostly Republican, argue that the executive branch is ignoring a pattern of Chinese exports of dangerous nuclear, chemical and ballistic missile technology. At the White House there is an equal frustration with Congress for trying to "micromanage" relations with China. A6
 
Just two days before President Clinton departs for China, financial markets in Asia reacted cautiously to political and diplomatic efforts over the weekend to stabilize the Japanese yen and other Asian currencies. The yen dipped modestly in value against the dollar in early Tokyo trading, after Japan offered promises, but no specific measures, to revive its limping economy. A5
 
Pope Appeals for Unity
Pope John Paul II instructed Austria's bishops to stop their public bickering, on the last day of his visit to Austria. The Pope's three masses were eagerly attended by believers, but the crowds were small and restrained compared with the vast gatherings that greeted him on recent trips to Nigeria and Cuba. A10
 
Explosion Near Beirut Embassy
Bombs exploded near the fortified American Embassy compound in a suburb north of Beirut, but there were no casualties, security officials said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the explosions, which occurred about a half-mile from the compound. Security officials said the embassy, the site of two suicide bombings in the past, was not the intended target. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A12-16
 
Starr Talks With Lewinsky Are Far From an Agreement
Five months after investigators began exploring allegations of a sexual relationship between President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky, new lawyers for the former White House intern have returned to the same standoff with Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, that her previous lawyers confronted. Details of the negotiations between Mr. Starr and Ms. Lewinsky's legal team suggest the two sides are still far from an agreement that would lead to her testimony. A16
 
Prices Defy Low Inflation
While the national inflation rate stays persistently low, reminiscent of the 1950's and 60's, prices have been rising noticeably in recent months for a variety of everyday items -- from fast-food hamburgers to auto maintenance to dental care. The increases have been sharp enough in some cases not only to catch people's attention but to provoke their annoyance. A1
 
A New Symbol of Old Age
Centenarians are proportionately the country's fastest growing age group. Demographers say there are now 30,000 to 50,000, up from the 1980 estimate of 15,000. It is estimated that by the middle of the next century, more than 800,000 Americans will be over 100. And so many are making it to 100 in relatively good health, as life expectancies increase, that centenarians have become a symbol of the country's age boom, and a metaphor for the dramatic shift in attitude about the meaning of old age. A1
 
Race to Pass Spending Bills
Representative Robert L. Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, says, "Not everybody's going to get what they want," as the House and Senate get down to passing the 13 spending bills that keep the Government running in the weeks before Congress adjourns for the November elections. Even though experts are forecasting a budget surplus of as much as $64 billion this year, the process is already showing the strains of the spending limits imposed by last year's balanced-budget agreement. Immigration Law Criticized
Immigration lawyers and advocates for refugees say Federal immigration laws are applied unevenly and important decisions -- from how long it takes to review an asylum seeker's case, to whether he or she is quickly paroled or detained for months -- seem to hinge more on the number of beds available at a detention center has than on a cohesive national policy. A 1997 law allows the refugees to be paroled on a case-by-case basis and only for "urgent humanitarian reasons or significant public benefit." The Immigration and Naturalization Service allows its 33 district directors to exercise their discretion in deciding whether to keep detainees behind bars. B1

HEADLINE: Stiff Rules Gut Welfare Rolls At Two Offices

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
For years, the poor, the hungry and the jobless have poured into the squat welfare office on Bergen Street in Brooklyn where city workers eased the pangs of poverty with government checks. But today, the primary goal at the office, as a city manual for the workers states, is to discourage people from applying at all.
People who push through the smudged glass doors are told to look for jobs, not welfare, and to lean on relatives, not city charity. Those who insist on seeking public assistance must hunt for as many as 20 jobs before getting a formal interview. And two months after workers began delivering the new message in Brooklyn and at another office in Queens, the number of welfare applications there has plummeted. 
 While 60 percent of the people who walked into those two offices once ended up on welfare, fewer than 10 percent land on the dole now, city officials said. It is too early to say whether the staggering decline can be maintained or replicated citywide, but the Giuliani administration's strategy will soon transform the lives of needy adults and children all across New York City.
The policy shift, which is to be adopted by all city welfare offices over the next nine months, signals the expansion of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to steer the city away from its traditionally liberal approach to the needy as he increasingly emphasizes self-reliance over government dependence.
"People shouldn't have welfare anymore," said Mark Hoover, a deputy commissioner at the city's Human Resources Administration, which runs the city welfare programs, during a meeting with officials from community groups earlier this month. "What they should have is work and work opportunities."
But the city manual describes employment as a "secondary goal." The "primary goal," it says, is diverting people from applying for public assistance while at the same time offering stopgap subsidies like rent assistance and food stamps. And it remains unclear whether the people discouraged from applying for welfare actually find jobs or simply languish in poverty. City officials declined to release those statistics, saying they were now analyzing them.
Tightening access to welfare is increasingly popular across the country, but the strict, systematic approach is new for a city that has focused more recently on moving welfare recipients into workfare. Over the last three years, the number of welfare applications approved citywide has held steady at about 55 percent, city records show.
But in January, when Mr. Giuliani outlined the priorities for his second term, he vowed to transform welfare offices into "job centers" where the poor would be steered toward jobs, not government checks. City officials said the plan would ultimately reduce welfare applications across the city and strengthen poor communities with its renewed emphasis on work. In the neighborhood surrounding the Boerum Hill office in Brooklyn alone, for instance, the strategy is expected to reduce the welfare rolls by 30 percent over the next three years.
Advocates for the poor, who like several former welfare officials were stunned by the sharp drop in applications, fear that city workers are concentrating less on jobs than on discouraging people from applying for welfare. They say discouraging poor, unskilled people is easier than helping them find jobs in New York City, where the unemployment rate is 7.7 percent, compared with the national rate of 4.3 percent.
"This is a bogus policy designed to reduce the welfare rolls," said Helen Lee, a staff attorney at the Legal Aid Society, who has begun monitoring the job centers along with other lawyers for the poor. "We're afraid needy people aren't getting welfare when they need it."
But city officials say that many people find jobs and that those who need welfare get it. Even those who leave the centers without jobs or welfare often go home with food stamps and Medicaid that will help stabilize their lives while they search for work, city officials say.
Once applicants learn that they must show proof of a daily job search before obtaining welfare, and once they hear that welfare recipients must sweep streets or answer telephones in exchange for their benefits, many decide they would rather struggle on their own, city officials say.
"More people are successfully finding jobs and making other choices than before," said Mr. Hoover, who worked as a welfare administrator in Wisconsin, which reduced the number of welfare applications with a similar strategy. "We feel that families are going to benefit from this."
While the debate between city officials and advocates for the poor remains unresolved, welfare applicants continue to find a dizzying new world behind the dingy cement walls of the Greenwood Job Center in Brooklyn.
The caseworkers call themselves financial planners. And the applicants, called job seekers, watch videos describing job openings at nursing homes, restaurants and drug stores as they wait in pink and gray plastic chairs for their interviews.
"Welfare is time limited," signs on the walls say in a reminder to all who come. "A job is your future."
In the old days, people filled out welfare applications on the first visit and waited at home until the formal eligibility interview, which was scheduled for about five days later. Today, job seekers cannot fill out applications until the second visit, and they must search for work before the eligibility interview and during the month or so while the application is assessed.
All the while, financial planners help clients explore "alternatives for independence," telling mothers to seek child support, urging former soldiers to apply for veterans benefits, requiring laid-off workers to file for unemployment benefits and assessing whether relatives or churches can help them.
Damaris Ferrer, 22, her pregnant belly bulging beneath her T-shirt, was told to consider relying on her mother, who has supported her with a $537 monthly Social Security check since Ms. Ferrer left her job as cashier in October. After learning about the strict job search requirements, Ms. Ferrer decided to do just that, at least until the baby is born and she can find another job.
"I was hoping for some help," she said last week. "But I'm just going to stay with my mother until she throws me out."
Valerie Rodriguez, an 18-year-old mother, said she also left Greenwood without being allowed to apply for welfare, food stamps or health insurance last week. It was her second visit, she said, and she was told to come back for a third.
But her brother, a waiter who supports Ms. Rodriguez and her 2-year-old son with his $180 weekly check while she studies for her high school equivalency exam, decided it would be easier for him to find a second job than for his sister to get public assistance.
"We've been struggling on our own for all this time," said Ms. Rodgriguez, her ponytail swinging and her nose-ring sparkling as she shrugged away the worry in her older brother's eyes. "I guess we'll just keep struggling."
In the eyes of city officials, they are success stories, women who considered their options and chose to avoid the culture of dependency. Advocates for the poor, however, question whether people who find it too cumbersome to apply for help can be truly considered successes.
Ms. Rodriguez, for instance, who never applied for free health insurance, plans to rely on Tylenol and prayer since she lacks a job or Medicaid to cover her medical expenses.
But city officials emphasize that poor people will get needed services if they agree to abide by the new guidelines, and emergencies will be addressed immediately. And some welfare applicants support the city's strategy, including Franklin Conde, 40, who is unemployed and now searching for work under the new strict rules.
"This will motivate you," said Mr. Conde, who applied for welfare after being unable to find work as an engineer's assistant. "Whoever established this program is on the right track."
Welfare specialists say there is little research to dispute or support that contention, and say city officials should track people who opt not to apply for welfare to determine whether they find jobs or languish in poverty. City officials say they plan to do that, but they have been reluctant in the past to track people who have left the welfare rolls.
Without careful research, the welfare specialists say, it will be difficult to determine whether the plan empowers the poor or makes desperate lives more miserable.
"You have to be open to the possibility that the city is right, that welfare is bad, that dependency breeds more dependency and robs people of self-sufficiency," said Gordon Berlin, a senior vice president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a nonprofit group that evaluates the impact of welfare policy.
"But you also have to be open to the idea that they're wrong," said Mr. Berlin, who was responsible for budget and policy at the Human Resources Administration in the late 1980's. "And if they are, people will have less income, less support, less stable housing. If they are really stretched thin, then children and families can get hurt."

HEADLINE: Contract Offers Job Security For 50,000 In Hospitals

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Thirty-five private hospitals and nursing homes in New York City reached a tentative agreement yesterday that provides far-reaching job-security provisions for 50,000 workers despite the wrenching upheaval in the city's health-care industry.
At a time when many experts are estimating that New York's hospitals have to cut their work force by 15 percent over the next five years, the agreement reduces pressures for layoffs by tapping the union's pension plan to finance an unusual early retirement program. 
 The 40-month contract, negotiated by 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, provides for diverting more than $135 million from the union's overfunded pension plan to finance the early retirements -- most payments would be $25,000 in cash -- to encourage at least 3,000 hospital workers to retire early.
This early retirement plan was made possible, both sides acknowledged, by the Wall Street boom, which fattened the pension plan's assets, and by some unusual bargaining.
Dennis Rivera, 1199's president, announced the contract yesterday after two days of nonstop negotiations with the League of Voluntary Hospitals, a group of 35 private nonprofit institutions including Beth Israel, Montefiore, Mount Sinai, St. Luke's-Roosevelt and St. Vincent's hospitals.
As in the current contract, the new agreement virtually bars layoffs of workers hired before Sept. 17, 1992, saying they can be laid off only if the institution closes or is in perilous financial condition. Union officials estimate that the rule applies to 75 percent of the union's workers at the hospitals.
If workers hired after that date are laid off, they are to receive, with the help of unemployment insurance, 80 percent of their pay for two years -- up from one year in the current contract. In addition, they are given the right to the first job opening for which they are qualified at any of the 35 institutions.
"This contract will offer virtual job security," said Mr. Rivera, who said that the contract provides no-layoff guarantees to more employees than any other multi-employer contract in the nation. He predicted that if any less experienced workers were laid off, almost all could find other jobs in league institutions within two years.
Both sides said the agreement would enable the hospitals to reduce employment gradually, and thus become more efficient and keep costs for patients under control.
After the negotiations were completed at 10:30 yesterday morning, Mr. Rivera was visibly exhausted in a news conference at 1199's headquarters on West 43d Street, saying at one point that he needed to sit down. The union's 150-member negotiating committee unanimously approved the agreement yesterday, and workers are to vote on it over the next two weeks.
In announcing details of the agreement, Mr. Rivera said he was calling off plans for the 50,000 workers to go on strike on June 30, the day their current contract expires.
The new contract covers laundry, housekeeping and food workers, custodial staff and X-ray and laboratory technicians -- as a group they average $30,000 a year in wages. The contract provides for a 3 percent raise for the first year, an $1,800 lump sum payment in the second year and a 3 percent raise over the contract's last 16 months.
Appearing beside Mr. Rivera at the news conference, Bruce McIver, president of the hospitals league, said: "Neither of us got everything we wanted. There was a lot of compromise." Nonetheless, the hospitals obtained several important concessions, including a lump-sum payment rather than a wage increase in the second year.
The Wall Street boom has increased the pension fund's assets, which are invested in stocks and bonds, to $5.3 billion from $3 billion in recent years, leaving it enough money to pay pension obligations even if employers stopped contributing for five years. Thanks to such overfunding, the contract gives the health-care institutions more than $100 million in savings in their pension contributions. The hospitals will not have to contribute to the pension fund for 10 months, and during the rest of the contract will pay 6.25 percent of payroll in pension contributions, down from 6.75 percent.
Mr. McIver insisted that the contract was not overly generous and would not create an undue strain on the hospitals. "A 6 percent wage increase over 40 months isn't bad," he said.
Mr. Rivera said he was proudest of the contract's job-security provisions, predicting that other health-care unions around the nation would seek to match them. He noted that for the first time, part-time workers hired before Sept. 17, 1992, would be covered by the strong no-layoff language.
"Management told us for months that it needed to lay off thousands of our members, that the employment-security provisions in our old contract could not stand," Mr. Rivera said. "In fact, with this contract, we have won improved security guarantees, the biggest early retirement package in our history, as well as increases in wages and health coverage."
Under the new contract, the workers will no longer have to make co-payments or any other payment to their dental plan. They already do not have any out-of-pocket expenses for basic health coverage.
The agreement provides for the hospitals and nursing homes to contribute a total of $60 million a year to a retraining and job security fund, which will be used to retrain laid-off workers and pay them the equivalent of 80 percent of their wages for two years. That $60 million will come largely from money the hospitals save on pension contributions.
The job security fund, although at far smaller levels, was first set up in the contract negotiated in 1992, while the no-layoff provisions were first negotiated in the 1994 contract.
In an interview, Mr. Rivera said that in negotiations, he had originally pushed to extend the no-layoff clause to more workers while management had sought to reduce the coverage. He said he dropped his demand when management insisted that in exchange it be given the right to lay off experienced workers when hospitals merge.
Under the new early-retirement program, workers 62 years old with 20 years on the job will be entitled to a full pension, while under the current contract they need 25 years. As further incentive, workers 62 years old with 20 years on the job, or 65 with 5 years on the job, are being offered not just a full pension but also a $25,000 one-time payment and health insurance until they qualify for Medicare,
Workers as young as 55 would be offered $25,000 payments and varying combinations of health-care and pension coverage to accept early retirement. Negotiators estimated all these measures would cost $135 million to $150 million and would persuade 3,000 to 3,700 workers to retire early.
The union made no headway toward one of its chief goals, a promise from the hospitals not to fight its effort to unionize thousands of workers at the hospitals' satellite clinics throughout the metropolitan area.
Negotiators for both sides acknowledged that they felt considerable pressure to reach an agreement before the June 30 contract expiration. Hospital executives wanted to avoid the burden of running their institutions during a strike. Union officials feared that some hospitals might order large-scale layoffs of longtime workers once the present contract expired and left them without protection against layoffs.
Negotiations started in July, when Mr. Rivera urged management to reopen the current four-year contract almost a year before it expired. At that time, he proposed using pension plan money to pay for early retirements. His hope was that if thousands of workers took early retirement, no layoffs would be needed.
Those talks broke off in September, but many of the ideas that had been discussed were incorporated in the new agreement.
Formal negotiations were resumed on March 24, but they did not start in earnest until Memorial Day weekend, when they began holding daily bargaining sessions. They negotiated either at the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza at 48th Street and Broadway or, just across the street, at the offices of the hospitals' law firm, Proskauer Rose.
The new agreement caps an eventful and in many ways successful year for 1199 and for Mr. Rivera. In January, 1199 merged with the 1.1 million-member Service Employees International Union. At that time, it was also combined with a separate 30,000-member service employees' local, pushing 1199's membership to 150,000 and making it New York City's largest union.
And last year Mr. Rivera enlisted Vice President Al Gore in a successful effort to obtain $1.25 billion in Federal aid to help retrain New York hospital workers and help the state's hospitals adapt to the upheaval caused by managed care. Mr. Gore and other Federal officials have been attentive to some of Mr. Rivera's wishes because of the size of his union and its effectiveness in elections and Democratic primaries.

A ratification vote by the membership is scheduled over two weeks. (J. Emilio Flores/The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Small Programs Fall Victim to Budget Battle in City Hall

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
The room was muggy, but the window air-conditioner had been shut off so no one would miss a word. For five counselors who helped tenants navigate the city's housing courts, it was their turn to be shell-shocked. They sat nearly motionless as Larry Wood, their boss, told them they were being laid off because of a budget brawl at City Hall.
"Nonprofit organizations always live hand to mouth," Mr. Wood said apologetically. "But I didn't expect to be wiped out." 
 Mr. Wood is the chairman of the City-Wide Task Force on Housing Court, a private group established in 1981 that has an annual budget of $320,000. The counselors, who each make about $26,000 a year, had provided assistance at tables set up in housing courts in each borough since 1981. Now the tables are vacant and people who call the group's advice line get a recording saying that it cannot offer help "due to a loss of funds."
The City Council had agreed to give the group $263,000 -- about 82 percent of its budget. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has taken aim at $251 million in spending, deriding it as pork, and has vowed not to spend any of that money.
When the Mayor announced on Tuesday that he would not honor a budget that the City Council had adopted and then maintained over his attempts to veto it, he declared, "This is not going to really hurt many people, except the politicians who run the City Council."
By week's end, however, charitable groups throughout the city said they had been forced to scale back their plans and cut their staffs after deciding they had little chance of receiving the money promised by the City Council when the new budget year begins on July 1.
The dispute is over seventh-tenths of 1 percent of the $34 billion municipal budget. And caught up in the power struggle between the Council and the Mayor are Little League teams, health-care support services, advocacy organizations and other nonprofit groups that depend either largely or entirely on city money.
"Some of these groups are so small that what the Mayor calls 'pork' is going to endanger entire programs and entire organizations very quickly," said Fran Barrett, executive director of Community Resource Exchange, which helps nonprofit agencies. "People are fearful that the work they have been doing for years is about to disappear in a political tussle."
The problem for these groups is that although the Council voted overwhelmingly last week to override the Mayor's vetoes of spending he considered irresponsible, he has declared that he still will not spend the money. The Council plans to take the Mayor to court.
"We will utilize the law to prevent him from trying to carry out all three branches of government by himself," the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said.
In the meantime, a champion Little League team in the Bronx will not get a van to travel to games.
In Queens, members of the Rudy Hepatitis C Support Group (named not for the Mayor but for a man who succumbed to the disease) were proud of a new educational video they had obtained on the dangers of tattooing and body piercing. But the group's leaders say that now they will not have the cab fare they need to take the video around to schools, and they are too sick to take the subway.
And in Manhattan, the Roosevelt Island Disabled Association -- whose members have survived polio and strokes, gunshots and multiple sclerosis -- is cutting back its summer outings from three to one, since hiring a bus equipped with a wheelchair lift costs $400 for each trip. That means no trip to Coney Island or the New York Botanical Garden this year, the association says. The group had hoped to receive $3,500 from the city, roughly half its annual budget.
The Mayor's office said that dire predictions about the financial health of the nonprofit groups had proved unwarranted when they had been raised by Mr. Giuliani's critics in previous budget fights. "Many advocates and politicians cried wolf, yet today we have a safer, cleaner city than we've had in decades," said Deputy Mayor Randy M. Mastro. "We aim to continue that progress, yet at the same time insure that the city lives within its means."
Mr. Mastro added that the Mayor's proposed budget included record spending for libraries, day care and summer jobs for youth. "We're only talking about the Council adding on more money," Mr. Mastro said.
Charitable groups, however say they foresee calamity this year for two reasons. Many of them also lost money when Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed 1,000 items from the state budget in April. Among them was financing for the Legal Aid Society, which had been holding open several vacancies for lawyers until the fiscal year began, but now will not fill those slots. Patricia A. Bath, a spokeswoman for Legal Aid, said the group expected to lose at least $2 million because of the budget dispute.
Among those who would lose representation are elderly people whose benefits have been mistakenly cut off.
"You don't see these people standing outside your office or outside City Hall," Ms. Bath said. "They're in their apartments, doing without medicine or telephone service or food."
The second reason for dismay among nonprofit leaders is the uncertainty about financing, given the likely court fight. They explained that even under less volatile circumstances, money from the city for a fiscal year beginning in July often does not arrive until fall or early winter because of the time it takes for contracts to be prepared and approved by the Mayor's office. Many of the groups get loans to meet their payroll and other expenses in the meantime. But without an assurance that the city money will actually be forthcoming, lenders may be reluctant, leaders of the organizations say.
"Creditors will be concerned about whether we're going to get the contract, and whether it will be tied up in protracted litigation," said Rick Jones, the deputy director of Neighborhood Defender Service, a Harlem group that provides legal services to 2,500 families a year. If the budget dispute is not resolved, Mr. Jones said, the service will lose $2 million of its $2.5 million budget and may close its doors next month.
The mood was just as grim at the Women's Prison Association and Home Inc., a 155-year-old group that helps addicted convicts and their children. "We have two weeks to decide whether to close programs or lay off staff," said Ann L. Jacobs, the executive director. "We tightened our belt when there was a fiscal problem in the city. But now we're living like this in economically abundant times."
Still, there are groups that are taking a hopeful approach and mounting quiet lobbying campaigns. Denise K. Taylor, director of the Rhinelander Children's Center of the Children's Aid Society, spent a day writing a letter to the Mayor on behalf of a Saturday program for deaf and hard-of-hearing children who, she wrote, "would otherwise be isolated in their community on weekends."
The weeks ahead will be a time of grim choices, group leaders say. A dinner program for the elderly, held each weeknight at the cafeteria of Public School 134 on the Lower East Side, is budgeted to feed 150 people a day. But the program has become so popular that often more people than that show up to eat and to watch a video. Officials of Community Food Resource Center, which runs the program, had counted on city money to close the gap.
One regular, Susan F. Lee, said she had voted for Mr. Giuliani. "He has done a lot of good things," said Mrs. Lee, 73, a retired secretary. "Now we're disappointed, and we're scared."

HEADLINE: Stop Playing by China's Rules

BYLINE: By Robert Kagan and William Kristol; Robert Kagan is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. William Kristol is editor and publisher of the Weekly Standard.

 BODY:
In defending his China policy, President Clinton says America faces a stark choice: engage China as his Administration has done or isolate it. But that is a false choice.
No one, contrary to the President's recent assertion, is "seeking to isolate China." For example, the Administration's critics do not oppose any summit that advances America's overall strategic and moral interests. The problem with Mr. Clinton's policy is that it undermines those interests, because his brand of engagement is failing. 
 The Administration has argued, for instance, that giving satellites, supercomputers and other technology to China would encourage it to stop selling weapons of mass destruction and the missiles to deliver them. But in the last six months, China has been caught peddling nuclear-weapons-related material to Iran. And in recent years, China made missile and nuclear weapons technology available to Pakistan, inviting India's nuclear test.
The Clinton Administration has argued that once the United States stopped challenging China's human rights record and withdrew the threat of economic sanctions, China would ease repression at home. In fact, the Chinese Government has responded by exiling a couple of prominent dissidents and arresting many others -- in sum, by maintaining one of the world's most repressive regimes.
The Administration says its brand of engagement has fostered stability in Asia. Why, then, has China fired missiles off the coast of Taiwan, seized islands in the South China Sea and continued to increase its defense spending at an alarming rate?
Finally, to avoid offending Chinese sensibilities, the White House invents excuses for indefensible practices like forced abortion and religious repression. The Administration has always argued that its policy of engagement will make China more like us. In fact, it is making us more like them.
Last year, when it was reported that the Chinese Government tried to subvert American elections, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright declared there would be grave consequences if the story was substantiated. It was, but there have been no consequences. If any country other than China were involved, the summit would be postponed. But the President is keeping his appointment in Beijing. Indeed he pretends he has no choice but to be greeted at Tiananmen Square.
Mr. Clinton now describes our relationship with China as a "strategic partnership" and insists China responds best to incentives. But placating its Government at every turn is not the answer. The Chinese leadership must know that when it breaks its promises -- by aiding Pakistan's and Iran's nuclear weapons programs -- it will be punished with sanctions, including, for instance, cutting off trade with corporations known to be controlled by China's military. A year ago, in a memorandum to the State Department, Mr. Clinton's own Arms Control and Disarmament Agency pointed out: "The only time we have gotten movement from the Chinese on missile proliferation has been in the face of a penalty being imposed. Carrots have gotten us nothing."
The United States must make it clear in both word and deed that we will contain China's strategic ambitions. We should begin by reversing the decline in our military strength. Chinese leaders interpret America's shrinking defense budgets and our uncertain response to crises in the Persian Gulf and elsewhere as a sign of weakening resolve. Nor could it have escaped the notice of Beijing that when the President sent aircraft carriers to the gulf earlier this year, none were left in the East Asian theater.
Beijing evidently hopes to drive a wedge between the United States and its Asian allies. That is why the Chinese Government insisted that President Clinton not visit Japan, South Korea and Taiwan before or after the summit. But they are our true strategic partners in Asia and deserve the reassurance of a visit by an American President.
Mr. Clinton seems determined to cast his critics as backward-looking isolationists spoiling for a new cold war. In fact, the Clinton Administration's current policy invites Chinese adventurism abroad and repression at home. At the end of this bloody century, we all should have learned that appeasement, even when disguised as engagement, doesn't work.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Natasha Tibbott)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Securities Prices Are Helped by Increase in Dollar

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, supported by a rising dollar.
A meeting of the seven industrial nations over the weekend failed to produce any new measures to bolster Japan's ailing economy, thus strengthening the United States dollar yesterday against the yen. 
 A strong dollar makes investments like United States Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors, not only for the yield, but also for the potential of additional gains through currency translation.
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and manager of bond trading at Cowen & Company, said yesterday's trading session was mostly dollar driven, but with a little undertone of cautiousness. "I think the market was expecting more out of the G-7 meeting, and really there wasn't anything new or concrete to come out of it that would stimulate the Japanese economy and reform its ailing banking system," he said.
The 30-year bond rose 2/32, to 106 20/32. The bond's yield was unchanged at 5.66 percent.
Mr. Gamba believes the market will focus today on the two-year note auction. "The two-year notes will have little problem being absorbed by the market," he said. "The key here is what is happening overseas."
Analysts agree that the lack of economic reports this week will mean that bond market participants will focus on overseas events, the dollar and stock market activity.
Treasuries traded well yesterday because Asian stock markets had slumped and investors sought the relative safety of United States investments.
The Treasury will sell $23 billion in two-year and five-year notes this week, with the two-year issue to be sold today and the five-year note tomorrow. In when-issued trading, the two-year maturity was being offered late yesterday at a price to yield 5.47 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 5.46 percent.
Early talk in the market is that yields may need to increase on the two-year issue to attract investor interest. After this sale, the Treasury will offer five-year notes on a quarterly basis instead of monthly. Yesterday's auctions of the three-month bill came in at an average rate of 4.99 percent, down from 5.01 percent a week ago, while the rate for a six-month maturity was 5.12 percent, up from 5.065 percent. About $4.5 billion in corporate bonds are expected to be issued this week, but demand has eased somewhat because of the concern that the Asian economic turmoil could hurt the United States economy and corporate earnings.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury sale of new three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Bouafle Journal;
Age-Old Curse of Slavery Alive in the Ivory Coast

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: BOUAFLE, Ivory Coast

 BODY:
Ibrahim Diarra had no idea what city he was in when he straggled into the courtyard of the elderly man from his native Mali recently.
The man offered Mr. Diarra, 23, and three teen-age friends shelter after their escape from a nightmare. 
 Wet from the rain, exhausted and famished, all he knew was that he had just spent four months working on a plantation somewhere in Ivory Coast in a job that bore a strong resemblance to slavery and that on this morning, after his second attempt to get away, he was free.
Throughout his bondage, Mr. Diarra said, he was sent out at daybreak each morning, seven days a week, to work fields planted high with corn and cotton.
Under the stern gaze of an overseer, he and other workers there had to weed row after row of the crops planted in the dark, rich soil with their simple hoes and carry countless sacks of harvested crops the three miles back to the farmhouse. When they were thirsty they had to fetch water from a distant well.
The only break came in the evenings, when they were allowed to return to their camp for the only meal of the day -- invariably a thin corn porridge -- and then were locked inside their mud-walled pillbox shelter, where they were kept under guard until sunrise.
"I once told the boss I couldn't do this work anymore," Mr. Diarra said, "and I fled the next day. But they quickly caught me, stripped me naked, tied my hands and made me sit in the open under the sun all day. Some of the others who tried to escape were whipped in front of the rest of us until they bled badly."
Mr. Diarra and his three friends, also from Mali, constitute merely the tip of an iceberg of thousands of coerced migrant laborers, many of them children, in this overwhelmingly agricultural country. As escapees who found someone from their homeland instead of being snared in the web of overseers, bounty hunters and informers, they count among the luckiest ones.
Theirs is a tale as old as the ages in an Africa of abundant, hard-to-work land and sparse labor -- seemingly immutable realities that fed an indigenous slave trade long before the arrival of the first Europeans. But it is also a near-universal phenomenon and has been seen from the sugar estates of the Florida Everglades and the Dominican Republic to the cotton-bearing loam of the Mississippi Delta.
The ruses that are used to lure and retain the workers from desperately poor hinterlands of neighboring countries like Mali and Burkina Faso are just as tried and true.
Like thousands of other Malians, Mr. Diarra said he was recruited to do farm work in Ivory Coast by an unscrupulous countryman back home who promised him $250 for a year's work -- a fortune for many Malians -- and room and board on a plantation.
He was transported across the border by truck at night. He realized he had been duped when he reached the northern Ivorian town of Korhogo and overheard a negotiation between the transporter and a plantation owner in which he and his fellow travelers were effectively sold for the equivalent of about $30 each.
"People have always told me there was a lot of money to be made in Ivory Coast," Mr. Diarra said. "But as soon as we reached the plantation, we were locked up and placed under guard. We knew right away that it was a trap."
The Ivory Coast's independence movement gained momentum in the 1940's and 1950's as a reaction against the forced labor imposed by French colonialists bent on building a cash-crop economy based on cocoa and coffee here.
But today, the wealth of this country, West Africa's most prosperous, rests to a large extent on the backs of poorly paid immigrants whose labor has helped make the Ivory Coast an agricultural giant.
"I've found plantations here where the owners keep 45 children locked in a single room from dusk till dawn, with the only provision for a toilet being a hole in the wall," said Fassiriman Dembele, the Malian consul to Ivory Coast. His recent work traveling to towns like Bouafle in the central Ivorian countryside has brought public attention to the plight of migrant workers from his country for the first time. The embassy will help Mr. Diarra go home.
"We have two million Malians living in Ivory Coast," he said, "working in every sector of the economy, including tens of thousands of farm workers. The Government cannot afford to admit the extent of the problem, so they close their eyes. If all of these workers went home, they could no longer produce crops here."
An official of the Ivory Coast Ministry of Social Protection, Mama Fofana Kone, said her Government had learned of the plight of Malian migrant workers only from recent press reports and had begun an investigation. "With these kind of charges, we must verify the information ourselves," she said. "Until then we cannot make any declarations."
From the vantage point of Mr. Dembele, no better place to begin an inquiry exists than in his office, where a dozen or more ragged plantation escapees, most of them children, arrive almost every day seeking shelter or help in returning home.
"I made a bad mistake in coming here," said Souleymane Konate, a shy 12-year-old laborer with downcast eyes who had just reached Mr. Dembele's office at the Malian Embassy the other day. "But my parents couldn't clothe me anymore, and there was nowhere to go to school in our village. I had no choice but to look for work."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A youth from Mali standing in the village near Bouafle, Ivory Coast, where he has been forced to work as a slave on a corn plantation since he was tricked into going there by promises of work, housing and pay. (Robert Grossman for The New York Times)
 
Map of Ivory Coast showing location of Bouafle: Migrants from Mali work in towns like Bouafle, some as slaves.
