HEADLINE: Legislators and Whitman Agree on Budget

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 22

 BODY:
Republican legislative leaders and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman agreed on the broad outlines of a new $18.2 billion state budget today that would increase spending by more than $1 billion for public schools, state colleges, open space preservation and a handful of other programs.
The lawmakers largely followed the spending plan that Governor Whitman first outlined in February, but they did reject a few of her proposals. 
 These included their decision not to eliminate the sales tax on long-distance calls made within the state. They rejected proposed cuts in the prescription program for low-income elderly residents. And they stopped an effort by the Whitman administration to eliminate some state jobs and turn them over to private contractors, which Governor Whitman said would save $6 million.
The legislative leaders added almost $100 million in spending to the Governor's proposed budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1. The spending increases include $20 million for school construction costs, $10 million for municipalities to keep down property taxes, $10 million more to help maintain state parks and $8.5 million in additional aid for middle-income school districts.
"We are in agreement on 99 percent of this budget," said Pete McDonough, chief spokesman for Mrs. Whitman. "We will review the bill after it is introduced and the Governor will make her determinations about line-item vetoes after the bill is passed."
The budget is expected to be considered by the budget committees in the Senate and the Assembly on Thursday. It is expected to be voted on by both houses early next week. Mrs. Whitman is expected to sign the new budget into law before the new fiscal year begins.
State officials expect to end the current fiscal year on June 30 with a surplus of almost $1 billion and they estimate more than $700 million in new revenues in the next fiscal year. The state's economic boom has fueled budget largesse. The spending increase is more than 6 percent over this year's state budget and is the largest spending rise in the last four years.
Governor Whitman was unsuccessful in persuading lawmakers to raise the gasoline tax by 2 cents a gallon to help pay for the preservation of a million acres of farm land and other open space in the next decade.
But there is $50 million in the budget for the purchase of open land. And Mrs. Whitman and Republican legislative leaders have agreed on a plan to borrow $1.4 billion in the next 30 years to meet the Governor's goals for preserving open space. The proposal, which would go to the voters for approval in November, would cost taxpayers about $100 million a year.
Whitman administration officials and lawmakers said that the $50 million allocated in the new budget would be enough money for now because the program would not begin until January.
State Senator Robert E. Littell, a Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee, said that the unanticipated increase in tax revenues made the budget process this year more difficult at times. "The good news is that we have more money," Mr. Littell said. "The bad part is we have more money. The bad part is fending off all of the requests for new spending."
The new budget would set aside $661 million of the extra tax revenues for a so-called rainy day fund, $31 million more than Governor Whitman proposed earlier this year.
Assemblyman Richard H. Bagger, a Republican and chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee, said that he expected that revenue projections would exceed the Whitman administration's estimates in the coming months and that the rainy day fund would grow even more.
While Legislative leaders rejected Mrs. Whitman's proposed $24 million cut in the sales tax on long-distance telephone calls made within the state, Mr. Bagger said that lawmakers would consider offering other savings to taxpayers.
Mr. Bagger said that one legislative proposal under discussion would exempt more low-income residents from paying state income taxes. "I would rather see us direct a tax cut in a more targeted way," he said.
Despite the huge budget surplus and widespread opposition in the Legislature to raising the gasoline tax to help preserve farm land and other open space, the Whitman administration is continuing to push a 5-cent gasoline tax increase to help pay for transportation projects.
The administration was encouraged today that the gasoline tax increase would win legislative support after a bill was introduced with bipartisan support that would put the gasoline tax increase on the November ballot for voters to consider.
The increase would raise state taxes on gasoline to 19.5 cents a gallon from 14.5 cents a gallon, with the added revenue used for transportation projects.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Pressed On 'One China' Policy

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Tuesday, June 23

 BODY:
China's Foreign Minister today called on President Clinton to make a public statement during his state visit this week restating American opposition to any move by Taiwan toward independence.
In a news conference this morning the minister, Tang Jiaxuan, also called on the United States to halt sales of advanced weapons like fighter planes and defensive missiles to Taiwan. 
 "The United States should take concrete action to match the commitments it has made on Taiwan with deeds," he said, referring to the sale of advanced arms.
Mr. Tang's statements broke no new ground and reflected the overriding position of Taiwan, considered here as a renegade part of the Chinese motherland, in Chinese foreign policy. But they did disclose one of the key unresolved issues between the two countries for a summit meeting that is expected to stress positive images and gloss over differences.
While Washington supports a "one China" policy and opposes Taiwan's independence, Taiwan enjoys strong support in the Congress. It appears extremely unlikely that China will get the promise it seeks.
Nonetheless, Mr. Tang gave an upbeat assessment of the coming visit, which the Chinese Government hopes will improve China's image in America and foster closer economic and political ties.
"We expect the visit to be crowned with a complete success," Mr. Tang said. "It will propel China-United States relations into a new stage of growth."
The Chinese leaders are well aware, Mr. Tang said, of what he called the "discord and noises" in the United States coming from critics of the Administration's policy of engaging China. But he said: "I am convinced this does not represent the desire and conscience of the vast majority of the American people."
Mr. Tang also responded to the attacks on Mr. Clinton's willingness to be greeted in Tiananmen Square, where the military crushed student demonstrations in 1989. He said that the spot -- a plaza on the edge of the square in front of the Great Hall of the People -- was the routine site for greeting foreign heads of state and that if President Jiang were not to meet President Clinton there, it would be "a lack of courtesy."
The Foreign Minister also brushed aside calls by some democracy advocates in China for President Clinton to meet with their representatives. The so-called dissidents, Mr. Tang said, "usually are people who have violated the criminal law of China." He noted that President Clinton has already indicated he will not seek a meeting with any political dissidents during this visit.
On other issues to be discussed, a senior Chinese trade official said yesterday that China hoped to make progress toward joining the World Trade Organization.
But in contrast with earlier hopes that entry could be clinched by now, the official, Shi Guangsheng, Minister for Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, said there was no timetable. His reaction to American statements that China was far from satisfying requirements for opening its markets to outsiders was mild.
He said that "we will continue to hope for positive and substantive progress" toward agreement on entry into the trading body.
"China wants to join the W.T.O. because this is necessary for our own economic reform and opening up," Mr. Shi said.
The organization sets global trade rules. Its 132 member nations must reduce barriers to trade and investment, and in turn they are given better trading conditions in other member countries.
On Saturday in Beijing the chief American trade negotiator, Charlene Barshefsky, said it had become clear that Chinese leaders, preoccupied with domestic economic dangers, were not ready to make the major changes needed. Besides general tariff levels, American officials are especially concerned about barriers to agricultural imports and to foreign involvement in financial, accounting, tourism and other service industries.
China has portrayed entry into the trade body as a political as well as an economic goal, and has sometimes lambasted the West for imposing what China considers unfair requirements. But today Mr. Shi, consistent with a general effort by officials to minimize conflict, kept his complaints muted.

HEADLINE: Hospitals Uniting to Fight Drug-Resistant Bacteria

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
Jolted by the rapid spread of bacteria that resist antibiotics, New York City's business community and six top hospitals are forging a novel alliance to detect, identify and, if all goes well, reduce the bacteria's levels in the city's hospitals.
For the last decade, health experts nationwide have been cautiously worrying about the threat posed by the increasing immunity of the bacteria, which can cause potentially fatal diseases like tuberculosis and pneumonia and serious infections like strep or staph. 
 The rate of death from resistant bacteria is relatively low, most experts agree. But the new alliance recognizes a growing concern about not only the bacteria, but also about a potential side effect: that a public health issue has economic consequences as well. A major concern for the alliance is that patients fearing infection will shun New York's otherwise respected hospitals, harming an industry that is one of the city's economic mainstays.
At the center of the initiative is the notion -- widely assumed but scientifically unproven -- that New York City has more strains of drug-resistant bacteria than most other parts of the country, or at least that some strains appear in the city first.
"Clearly, if New York has a bigger problem than other places, it's going to affect the competitiveness of our hospitals," said Willa Appel, president of the Policy Center of the New York City Partnership, the city's leading business group, which is overseeing the project.
There are other cost concerns in a city where the health care industry is the largest private employer. A recent study by the Lewin Group, a Washington-based health care consultant, estimated that staph infections alone cost $435 million to treat in the New York area in 1995. In general, patients with infections must be hospitalized longer, erasing the savings associated with managed care and other cost-cutting measures.
Barry Kreiswirth, an infectious-disease expert who runs a laboratory in Manhattan that identifies bacteria and is involved in the project, said the issue of resistance to antibiotics also raises questions about many medical procedures that are profitable to hospitals, like triple-bypass surgery.
"Hospitals which make money on these procedures will start having major problems," he said, "and I don't know how the H.M.O.'s are going to deal with it."
The initiative focuses its efforts on hospitals, where the risk of infections is far greater than in the general population. Hospitals are by definition centers for sick people and, with so many antibiotics in use, the bacteria most likely to survive are those that have developed some resistance. More organisms are becoming partially or completely resistant to all antibiotics on the market, and few new antibiotics are being developed.
The New York City Partnership, which represents about 700 companies, has undertaken several initiatives in areas of the economy it believes are at risk. Late last year, it began studying antibiotic resistance.
Ms. Appel said the project would cost more than $1 million for the first two years, and she is seeking Federal and state grants to pay for it.
The initiative is at an early stage. The most concrete -- and unusual -- accomplishment is the hospitals' agreement to share information about infections that they are normally reluctant to discuss with each other. To address that concern, the information in the project would not be public, and in fact, the names of the hospitals would be available to only a few people involved.
"These guys are competitive," Dr. Kreiswirth said. "They really don't want to air their dirty laundry. The thing is, they all have dirty laundry."
The main goal of the project is to enable hospitals to detect and identify new bacterial strains before they spread, Ms. Appel said. To do that, the program would standardize the data bases of the hospitals, which would plug in information about their infections and in return be able to find out about infections at other hospitals.
The project also calls for the hospitals to create uniform methods of identifying various bacteria, including the accurate but expensive DNA "fingerprinting" technique used to separate similar strains. The project would also require hospitals to report the quantity and types of antibiotics they dispense, to determine whether greater use correlates with greater resistance.
Nationally, the rate at which people are developing infections in hospitals rose 36 percent from 1975 to 1995, according to a study released earlier this year. Of the 36 million hospital admissions in 1995, there were 1.8 million infections contracted in hospitals, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. Infections contributed to the deaths of 88,100 of those patients, and experts say infection was the direct cause of death in perhaps a quarter of the cases.
Roughly 70 percent of those 1.8 million infections were caused by bacteria with some resistance to one or more antibiotics. It is uncertain how many people die from bacteria that cannot be treated with antibiotics, but experts say the number is surely rising. There are no comparative statistics for New York City or New York State.
"There is beginning to compile enough evidence to say that resistance itself is contributing to mortality," said Dr. Robert Gaynes, chief of surveillance for the hospital infections program at the C.D.C. "I don't think I could have said that five years ago."
In New York, health experts are treading a fine line between measured concern and outright alarm. In the United States, the problem of drug-resistant tuberculosis that emerged in the early 1990's was centered in New York City, and several other strains of resistant bacteria were discovered in New York before they were detected in other parts of the country. An example is enterococci -- which can cause infections of wounds, blood or urinary tracts -- with resistance to vancomycin, the antibiotic considered the last line of defense. The strain was first detected in the United States simultaneously in New York and Boston in 1989 and has since spread nationwide.
Dr. Brian P. Currie, the medical epidemiologist at one of the hospitals participating in the project, Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, said enterococci resistant to vancomycin did not appear at his hospital until 1991. But by the end of 1994, 40 percent of all enterococci samples showed resistance to the drug.
Unlike the tuberculosis bacterium, enterococci are rarely found in the general population, a fact that underscores the need for the New York City Partnership project to reduce the level of infections in hospitals, Dr. Currie said.
"It's a hospital issue," he said.
Among the questions the project seeks to answer is whether New York indeed has more resistant bacteria than other regions do. Experts have speculated that the city's role as a magnet for business and worldwide immigration contributes to the problem, especially because many immigrants come from nations in which antibiotic use is much more widespread than in the United States.
Several other experts, including Dr. Currie, have also speculated that the sheer number of hospitals in New York plays a role. That may be particularly true in an era of mergers and affiliations in which patients and workers travel more frequently among institutions, the experts say.
"There is a tremendous concentration of hospitals, of antibiotic usage," Dr. Currie said. "Basically, what you are producing is almost ideal conditions for the spread of bacteria that have developed a multiple antibiotic resistance."
Aside from Montefiore, the collaborating hospitals are: Beth Israel Medical Center, New York and Presbyterian Hospital, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and Mount Sinai Medical Center, all in Manhattan, and Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. The Public Health Research Institute, a private organization in Manhattan, and Rockefeller University are also participating.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Modern Art Of Mastery On the Mound

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
GREG MADDUX is an artist," Joe Torre, the Yankee manager, has said. "Every time you swing at one of his pitches, it's a ball, and when you don't, it's a strike."
Indeed, Maddux, the Atlanta Braves right-hander, permits so little activity on the bases that each game he pitches could be titled "Still Life." 
 Not last night, however. The canvas got a little crowded for him at Yankee Stadium, in the first game of a series that has been billed as a possible preview of the World Series. Maddux allowed nine hits and three runs before departing after six innings with a 4-3 lead, and he learned from the showers that the Yankees had won, 6-4, with no decision for him.
It was less than one of his routine masterpieces -- even Picasso had the occasional bungle -- but when Maddux had to be dazzling, he was. In the sixth inning, with two runners on base and one out in a 3-3 game, he struck out Scott Brosius and forced Joe Girardi to bounce weakly to the mound.
Maddux then left the game, having been plagued by a stiff neck he had awakened with and which troubled him so much that he almost didn't start. "It was killing him," Braves Manager Bobby Cox said.
Maddux won the Cy Young award four straight years (1992-95) and is the leading pitcher in the National League again, with a 10-2 record -- he has won eight in a row -- and a 1.62 earned run average. And he has achieved his mastery so effortlessly that it's mystifying.
Mark Grace, the Chicago Cubs first baseman, observed that Maddux pitches "like he's in a rocking chair." Like Grandma Moses?
"I know absolutely nothing about art," Maddux said last weekend. "If there was an art handicap like there is a golf handicap, I would be a 50."
What, then, is the esthetic secret to his success, which is certain to land him in the Hall of Fame? Now in his 13th major league season, Maddux has nearly twice as many victories, 194, as losses, 110, and his strikeout-to-walk ratio is also remarkable; last year, he gave up just 20 walks while striking out 177 batters. Last night, he whiffed four and walked none.
There is nothing outwardly noteworthy about perhaps the best pitcher of our time. He has the demeanor of a bookkeeper. He is 32 years old, stands 6 feet tall, weighs 175 pounds. He wears glasses off the field, has a physique that would not draw attention at the beach, rarely shows emotion and frustrates batters to such a degree that they nearly weep.
Some pitchers throw the ball at nearly 100 miles an hour, some have wicked breaking balls. Maddux has neither. "I saw Sandy Koufax and I saw Nolan Ryan," he said, "and I knew I couldn't pitch like those guys. I wasn't going to overpower anybody."
His fastball is generally clocked in the mid- to upper 80's, and he uses breaking balls sparingly. "I found that velocity can be misleading," he said. "I rely on location of my fastball and on changeups. If you stand by a highway and watch cars go by, you can't really tell which one is going 80 miles an hour and which is going 90. And if you throw real hard every pitch, hitters will eventually time them."
Maddux learned from other masters of the mound. His classroom was the dugout. When he studied Mario Soto, he discerned that one could win with, basically, two pitches. "Soto was able to pitch effectively with just a fastball and a changeup," Maddux said. "Which is what I do -- though his fastball was better than mine. You locate your fastball, and you keep your changeup down. If that doesn't work, you'll be backing up third and home all day."
Unlike many in sports who analyze and parse and dissect and deconstruct the commonplace components of running, jumping and hurling, Maddux wants no part of it. "You do something well in sports, it gets magnified," he said. "I just throw a baseball for a living."
His consistency, his professionalism and his understanding of hitters and of his own abilities, however, belie such a casual approach.
"I try to keep it simple," he said. "At the same time, I try not to be too smart. The fewest amount of pitches you throw a hitter, the greater your chances of getting him out."
Then a crucial element of success for Maddux is that less is more. "In art," Henry James wrote, "economy is always beauty." Not in the eye of every beholder. For batters who must swing at pitches on their fists, or at their knees, or in the crevices of the strike zone where they are least likely to do damage, it is ugly. A tapper here, a pop fly there, a lunge for strike three. Ask Brosius or Girardi, among others. Modern art, one could almost hear a batter mutter. It stinks.

HEADLINE: Record Price Echoes Buying Frenzy of 80's;
Market Boom Propels Skyscraper From White Elephant to Trophy

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In the latest sign of just how hot the New York real estate market is, a 52-story skyscraper on Fifth Avenue is expected to be sold this month at a record price for office space in this country: $523 a square foot.
The deal for 712 Fifth Avenue and a number of other astronomical prices for office towers in Manhattan reflect the city's booming economy and tight office market, which have convinced buyers that they can charge ever-higher rents to make their investments pay off. 
 But the fierce bidding has some skeptics recalling the boom market of a decade ago, when buyers paid huge sums for Manhattan office towers in the hopes of big increases in rent. Rents do not always go up, the naysayers warn, and if the economy sours, the investors could be left yet again with empty buildings and empty pockets.
In fact, the story of 712 Fifth Avenue is itself a cautionary tale about big ambitions, bad timing and how quickly the real estate market can change. Despite the sale price of $285 million, the developer, A. Alfred Taubman, will not make a dime and by most accounts will have lost tens of millions of dollars on the building.
The reason? It was built during the last boom, in the 1980's, but came on the market just as the 90's recession hit. And the building, between 55th and 56th Streets across the avenue from Trump Tower, has languished as an exquisite white elephant ever since.
Rival bidders and brokers involved in the sale said 712 Fifth Avenue was being bought by the Paramount Group, the investment arm of the Otto family of Germany, who own Spiegel, the mail-order company. At that price, real estate experts say, Paramount would get a 5.5 percent return on its investment -- the kind of narrow margin that gives brokers and lenders cold sweats.
"It's deja vu all over again," said Douglas Durst, who is building Manhattan's first new office tower since 1992, at 4 Times Square. "Just like the 1980's, they're paying prices based on future rents. But these prices are beyond comprehension."
The deal would exceed the record price set by Kato Kagaku, a Japanese corn syrup manufacturer, in 1986, when it bought Tower 49, at 12 East 49th Street, for roughly $500 a square foot. Mr. Taubman's company, Taubman Centers Inc. in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., which owns and develops shopping malls, declined to comment, as did the Paramount Group.
Of course, no one is predicting the sudden collapse of the New York real-estate market. After stagnating for much of the 1990's, rents are rising and office space is tight in both midtown and downtown. If rents continue upward, dire warnings will seem like so much squawking from Chicken Little.
"If you track supply and demand, we see a clear path towards increasing rents," said Stephen B. Siegel, chief executive of Insignia/ESG, a real estate company. "For the next three to five years, it's going to be a strong landlord's marketplace. There's just not enough space to meet demand."
But increasingly, some real estate operators say, trophy buildings, and even some not-so-grand properties, are selling for prices that leave them scratching their heads. The feverish bidding raises the ceilings on prices for all properties. High prices mean smaller profits on rent. Betting on the future can be very risky, particularly for an industry notorious for its cycles of boom and bust, some old-line real estate executives say.
Last month, Conseco, an insurance company based in Carmel, Ind., and Donald J. Trump signed a deal to buy the 50-story General Motors Building in midtown for an awe-inspiring $800 million, or $500 per square foot. Rents cannot be quickly increased for many of the long-term, blue chip tenants. Nor, most real estate experts say, can the top part of the tower be converted to condominiums. But the new owners say there is money to be made on the undervalued retail space and the plaza in front of the building.
Certainly the bargains that seemed so plentiful a few years ago are all but gone. In February, Kent M. Swig, David A. Burris and the Corsair Group bought the 70-year-old Renaissance Revival building at 48 Wall Street for $37.5 million, or $122.55 per square foot. The price is more than 10 times the amount paid for a similar building in lower Manhattan in 1995, and real estate executives said the amount leaves the new investors with little margin for error.
"We'll see a lot of records broken in 1998 because of the dynamics of the market," said Scott Latham, a broker and managing director with CB Richard Ellis, a real estate brokerage. "The buyers spending other people's money will overpay." Mr. Latham added, "It's becoming less of an economic game and more about trophy hunting."
In recent weeks, a group of developers and investors pushed the bidding on the Woolworth Building, the handsome neo-Gothic tower near City Hall, to more than $165 million. Steven C. Witkoff, an investor, and Lehman Brothers had initially dropped out of the bidding at about $140 million, complaining of an overheated market. But last Friday, the partners reversed course, signing a pre-emptive deal for the building for about $155 million.
Despite the Woolworth Building's unfashionable location, investors like Mr. Witkoff argue that the skyscraper is an irreplaceable landmark and therefore a good bet -- unlike, say, the vacant downtown tower at 140 Broadway, for which Larry Silverstein and Morgan Stanley paid $191 million, or $160 per square foot. The Broadway building also needs $50 million in renovations.
Brokers say the reasons for the soaring prices vary. Some buyers will pay a premium for the prestige of a trophy building or because they believe that they can find profits where others cannot. Foreign buyers, particularly those from Germany, who seem to have replaced the Japanese investors of the 1980's, are willing to accept more meager returns. The rapid escalation of prices is also propelled by a gusher of money from Wall Street, speculative investment groups and investors.
"The Germans have been in the forefront of buying prime real estate overseas because they can't get the returns in Germany itself," said Aby Rosen, president of RFR Holdings, a subsidiary of RFR Frankfurt, a real estate company in Frankfurt.
More than a few developers, brokers and investors privately compare the current bidding battles to those of the 1980's, just before a recession sliced property values in half, crushed lenders with large real estate loans and left huge blocks of office space empty.
During the boom, developers poured $18 billion into projects that added 50 million square feet of office space and 106,500 luxury apartments in Manhattan. In 1986, a subsidiary of Mitsui & Company, the Japanese conglomerate, paid $612 million for the Exxon Building in midtown, then the highest price ever for a single office tower in New York City.
Mr. Taubman's skyscraper at 712 Fifth Avenue emerged during this period.
In 1983, two developers, David S. Solomon and G. Ware Travelstead, set about patching together 12 parcels between 55th and 56th Streets for a new building, possibly a luxurious apartment tower. But they tangled with Mr. Trump, who wanted no competition with his new brass and glass condominium across the street, Trump Tower. Mr. Trump joined preservationists, who sought to block the project and preserve the Rizzoli Building and the Coty Building, with its famous Lalique glass windows.
By the time a compromise was struck and construction of what is now an office tower began in 1987, the costs had soared by tens of millions of dollars. Mr. Taubman, who is also the chairman of Sotheby's, had emerged as a partner and eventually took over the project. The tower finally opened in 1990 during a recession, and the building's beautiful but relatively small floors sat empty. The sales brochure said the total costs for 712 Fifth were more than $400 million.
"The building made a statement, but the timing was horrible," said David L. Elovitz, chairman of the Elovitz Group, which was hired in 1989 to market 712 Fifth Avenue.
It was worse than that. By 1990, 28.5 million square feet of midtown office space -- more than the entire market in Seattle, Portland or Tampa -- yawned empty, according to Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate company. It took nearly a decade for the real estate market to recover.
Optimistic buyers dispute any resemblance now to the overheated 1980's, contending that midtown office vacancy rates are at 8.8 percent and falling, not rising, while the average rent is $38.79 per square foot, $5 more than it was a year ago. Interest rates are low. Demand is high, they say, but few office buildings are under construction.
But others point to potentially worrisome signs. The city's current prosperity depends heavily on the Wall Street boom -- which no one thinks can last forever -- while New York's unemployment rate remains above the national average. Also, for the first time in 10 years developers are building speculative office space in Jersey City and Stamford, Conn., and that is likely to have a dampening effect on New York rents.
"We don't have the massive overbuilding we had in the 1980's, when developers overbuilt in every category," said Steven R. Hash, a managing director with Lehman Brothers. "But I'm quick to admit that a lot of these deals don't make sense."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Prices Sink, Hong Kong Curbs Land Sales

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, June 22

 BODY:
Seeking to stop a frightening downward spiral in the property market, Hong Kong's government today announced the halting of its sale of land until next March. The action, which was made public after the stock market closed, was the starkest sign yet of how deeply the Asian crisis was hurting Hong Kong's normally resilient economy.
Property prices drive the broader stock market here, and the government is the biggest single landowner, selling about half of Hong Kong's new residential property at public auctions.
By halting land sales, officials are trying to stop the plunge in prices. And the breadth and duration of the move amount to government intervention on a huge scale in Hong Kong's most important business. 
 "The Asian crisis has brought a lot of suffering and pain to Hong Kong people," said Tung Chee-hwa, the territory's chief executive. "We believe we are in a critical phase and, therefore, we have to be pragmatic."
Mr. Tung announced a series of measures to restore consumer confidence and ease the deepening credit shortage. These include the lowering of import and export duties, a tax rebate and a freeze in government salaries.
Still, Mr. Tung acknowledged that no degree of stimulus would pull Hong Kong out of what is fast becoming its worst downturn since World War II. Property prices have plunged 40 percent in the last six months, unemployment is at a 15-year high, and output declined by 2 percent in the first quarter.
In a further setback for Hong Kong, the Standard & Poor's ratings agency warned today that it might lower the credit rating of the territory's short-term and long-term debt, which would increase government borrowing costs. Standard & Poor's said it had placed Hong Kong on a credit watch list for review because of a "growing likelihood of a protracted economic downturn that could challenge the ability of Kong Kong's government to maintain its prudent fiscal policies and traditional noninterventionist stance toward the economy."
Mr. Tung said the economy would shrink again in the second quarter -- the first official confirmation of recession. Unless the government acted to stabilize property prices, he said, the financial condition of Hong Kong's banks would deteriorate and a crisis of confidence would overwhelm local financial markets.
Influential business executives in the territory applauded the halting of public property sales.
Nonetheless, the government's aggressive intervention may frighten overseas investors, who value Hong Kong in part because the authorities try not to intrude in the markets. Late today, some analysts were already questioning whether Hong Kong would continue linking its currency to the United States dollar at a fixed exchange rate.
Stocks, which had rebounded the previous four sessions, fell sharply, with the benchmark Hang Seng index losing 4.5 percent. In morning trading Tuesday, the Hang Seng was up about 1 percent.
Making matters worse, the Japanese yen declined. Its fall had been broken by joint intervention in the currency markets last week from the United States and Japanese central banks to prop up the yen's value. But after Japan provided no persuasive details in its latest plan to invigorate the economy, the yen weakened again and Hong Kong's market followed.
The action taken here today on property sales is a sign that Hong Kong officials see little hope of a rebound in the yen any time soon.
"I'd be a rare animal if I said the situation in Japan were stable," said Sir Donald Tsang, the territory's Financial Secretary, who devised the new measures in the last two weeks.
Without any boost to the economy from outside, Sir Donald said Hong Kong felt compelled to take the extraordinary action of halting land sales. In the heyday of growth here, property auctions used to draw scores of developers, who bid up the price of land to levels some deemed absurd -- feeling sure that they could build towering apartment complexes and sell the units for millions.
Now, the auctions have become dismal affairs. As for the two million Hong Kong people who already own apartments, Sir Donald said that the 40 percent decline in property prices was "traumatic" and that the government needed to reassure them that their investments were not worthless.
By forgoing auctions for nearly a year, he estimated that the government would lose more than 30 billion Hong Kong dollars, or roughly $3.8 billion (United States) -- resulting in a rare budget deficit of 21.4 billion Hong Kong dollars, or nearly $2.8 billion.
Sir Donald and Mr. Tung reaffirmed Hong Kong's determination to continue linking the currency to the United States dollar. But analysts said today's action raised questions about how much economic hardship Hong Kong was willing to endure before it devalued its currency.
Normally, in an economy with a fixed exchange rate, the government would allow external market forces to depress the price of assets such as property. That is what Hong Kong did over the last six months. Unlike Asian countries that devalued their currencies, Hong Kong defended the dollar by increasing interest rates, even though that devastated the property market by making loans prohibitively expensive.
Now, it seems to be bowing to political pressure to ease the pain. The free fall in property prices hammered both powerful developers and individual homeowners. Hong Kong's newly elected legislators accused the territory's administration of insensitivity toward the plight of ordinary citizens, while the tycoons pressed top officials at private meetings.
Real estate executives said the decision would restore confidence. "It's the signal that the market has been waiting for," said Nicholas Brooke, chairman of Brooke Hillier Parker, a real estate brokerage firm here.
But other experts said the government was engaged in an increasingly desperate struggle to ease the consequences of a burst bubble economy. "Either land prices would have had to give or the peg would have had to go," said Jan Lee, chief economist here of the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank.

Russia to Sell India Two Nuclear Plants
Russia has agreed to sell two nuclear power stations to India, defying calls to punish India because of its nuclear testing. Russia concluded the deal on Sunday, which is worth at least $3 billion to Russia's cash-starved nuclear energy industry. A9 

Iraq Criticizes Arms Monitors
Iraq criticized a United Nations report that said it was still hiding details about its program to develop weapons of mass destruction. The Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, said in a letter to the Security Council that the report misrepresented Iraq's willingness to make a full disclosure and fulfill conditions for lifting the embargo on oil sales. A6
 
Oil Producers Feel Pressure
The recent drop in oil prices has resulted in the most serious fall in oil revenue in a decade and has prompted several oil-producing countries to borrow money and grow concerned about political consequences. A6

Israel has provided assurances that a proposed major expansion of the city limits of Jerusalem will not extend the city's authority into the West Bank, the State Department said. State Department officials remained critical of the proposal, but tempered earlier statements. A8

Prime Minister Javier Valle Riestra said that Peru should pardon and expel an American woman jailed for life on charges of terrorism because of mistakes in her trial, but it was unclear whether President Alberto K. Fujimori agreed. A11

South Korean military forces seized a suspected North Korean submarine after it became entangled in fishing nets in South Korean waters, immediately raising tensions between the countries. A10

China's Foreign Minister said that during his state visit President Clinton should publicly restate opposition to any move by Taiwan toward independence and that the United States should halt sales of advanced weapons to Taiwan. A10
 
Diplomatic Conflict in Belarus

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: NYC;
Celluloid City: Godfather Of Locations

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY is taking a pounding from the movie industry this season, what with an overgrown lizard squishing it, a tsunami engulfing it and an asteroid bopping it hard enough to make anyone wish he had a bunker of his own.
This, some are convinced, is Hollywood's way of saying it really loves us. Maybe there is something to that. Cinematically speaking, New York is hot. There were 213 feature films shot here last year, a record, and while the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting will not say how 1998 is shaping up, the city seems to be doing well enough. 
 If it weren't, the Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens would presumably not be planning to expand, and a couple of young entrepreneurs would not be trying to build a large movie studio in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. They are far enough along to have received City Hall's go-ahead, provided they also get the necessary private financing by year's end.
"The attraction for a lot of writers and directors is the city itself," said James P. Rutherford, a managing director at J. P. Morgan and the project's financial adviser. Now, once the New York exterior shots are taken care of, actors and crews usually trek back to Los Angeles for the indoor scenes. In theory, a Hollywood-style operation in the Navy Yard would keep them hanging around, and spending money, the whole time.
"We just want to make it easy for the people who want to be here," Mr. Rutherford said.
New York's appeal to moviemakers goes back a long way, a point that was reaffirmed the other day when the American Film Institute came up with its 100 best American films of all time.
The howls of protest over this list were immediate and, many would say, justified. How, they asked, did "Dances With Wolves" qualify (No. 75) but nothing by Ernst Lubitsch or Preston Sturges? The absence of any Audrey Hepburn movie other than the plodding "My Fair Lady" (No. 91) is reason alone to arouse suspicion; take it from someone who has been in love with her since he first saw "Breakfast at Tiffany's."
All the same, the Top 100 includes many indisputably great films, and nearly a quarter of them, 23, are set in this city, entirely or in part. All were not shot here. But even if filmed on sound stages, New York was their backdrop, including No. 1, "Citizen Kane," and No. 100, "Yankee Doodle Dandy."
No other place is remotely as popular, and the city does even better in the Top 50, where it figures in 15 films, or 30 percent. Among them are the first two "Godfather" movies (ranked Nos. 3 and 32), "All About Eve" (16) "Raging Bull" (24) "Annie Hall" (31) "Rear Window" (42) and "Taxi Driver" (47).
(Confession: Rigorous standards were bent slightly to include No. 50, "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid." On their way to Bolivia, Butch and Sundance stopped by Coney Island.)
"The fact that Manhattan's a small island, and so many people of diverse backgrounds share it, is one reason the city's such a great destination for film makers," said Bruce Goldstein, who has put together several programs of New York movies for the Film Forum in Greenwich Village.
MR. GOLDSTEIN traces New York movies from the 1920's and 30's, when neighborhoods like Orchard Street and Park Avenue were used to establish class differences, through the New York films noirs of the 40's and 50's, to the falling-apart city of the 70's: a nightmarish vision, he says, that "didn't stop even when things got better."
"The city's so visual," he said. "It always has been, and it still is. Every studio back lot had a New York street, not a Boston street or a San Francisco street."
He, for one, has little use for a "best" list that leaves out a searing New York film like "Sweet Smell of Success." But there are compensations. One could argue that the three top-rated films all make important nods to the city: "Citizen Kane" and "The Godfather" for sure, in first and third place, but also "Casablanca," ranked No. 2 and not included in the earlier count of 23 New York films.
You are perhaps shocked, shocked, to hear that the city figures in that Humphrey Bogart classic? It does.
When a German officer speculates about taking over New York, Bogart tells him, "There are certain sections of New York, major, that I wouldn't advise you to try to invade." With that Gotham spirit, World War II was won.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
J. F. LEHMAN TO BUY SPECIAL DEVICES FOR $296 MILLION

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Special Devices Inc., a maker of triggers for the inflation of automotive air bags, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a unit of J. F. Lehman & Company for $37 a share, or about $296 million. J. F. Lehman, based in New York, is a private equity fund that invests in the aerospace, engineering and manufacturing industries. Special Devices, based in Newhall, Calif., also makes products in tactical missiles and military crew escape systems. It employs more than 1,200 people in California, Arizona and Illinois and had revenue of $140.5 million in 1997.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Syracuse's Rating Falls

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE

 BODY:
Two national investor agencies have downgraded Syracuse's long-term bond rating, which could make the city more costly to run.
Moody's Investors Service dropped Syracuse's rating yesterday to its lowest point since 1938, citing the city's money shortages, declining revenues and heavy borrowing. 
 Moody's dropped the city's rating from A3 to Baa1. Syracuse had maintained an A-level rating for 60 years. Standard & Poor's dropped the city's rating from A to BBB.
The new ratings characterize the city as a medium-grade investment risk. Lowered ratings mean the city must pay higher interest rates for the money it borrows through bonds.
The City Director of Administration, Kenneth Mokrzycki, said yesterday that Syracuse was trying to reverse the trend of declining revenues, but until there was a major change, more short-term borrowing was likely.
Moody's said signs of the city's weakened finances were its need to borrow to shore up its cash flow and the possible need for $61 million more in short-term borrowing in the new fiscal year.
Standard & Poor's cited the heavy short-term borrowing as the main reason for its decision to downgrade the city's rating.
Mayor Roy Bernardi has proposed a one-year salary freeze and the elimination of 77 jobs to cope with the city's budget difficulties.

HEADLINE: JAZZ FESTIVAL REVIEW;
So Emotional, So Thoughtful

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS 

 BODY:
The singer Ruben Blades, who performed as part of the JVC Jazz Festival at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, has had one of the odder careers in music, moving from the position of office boy at Fania records in New York to Panamanian presidential candidate. Along the way he made some of New York salsa's most important records, as a singer with Willie Colon and, on his own, recordings that took on the Americas as their subject and delved into politics and culture with long narrative works that made pop music profoundly literate. Where most pop and dance music articulate little and suggest plenty, Mr. Blades articulated everything and suggested it as well.
He has clearly been struggling with what to do with himself, working as an actor in Hollywood, placing himself brilliantly as the elder Salvador Agron in Paul Simon's "Capeman." And he rarely sings anymore. That's too bad. Mr. Blades, when he was in the middle of his big push to fuse the English- and Spanish-speaking worlds in his music during the mid-1980's, seemed poised to become the only salsa singer -- and the term limits his ambition and abilities -- to reach the international audiences so easily reached by a handful of Brazilian singers. 
 But just as clearly, Mr. Blades hasn't forgotten his subject; on Sunday night, he joked that Spanish should be everybody's second language, because when the United States economy collapses, Americans can find work south of the border.
Though he was struggling with a cold, Mr. Blades, originally from Panama, infused his singing with great intelligence and emotionalism. He's one of those rare singers able to give intellectually and provide for a dance without alienating either constituency. He's the professor that dances, and throughout the concert he exuded deep confidence and cool without arrogance. The audience, nearly filling the hall, gave him a standing ovation on his entrance, knowing exactly what role he plays in the larger culture.
The concert began in earnest with the second song, "Buscando Guyaba" ("Looking for Guava"), a tune unlike much of his material in that it works metaphorically and is happy. The song, from one of the largest-selling salsa records, his own "Siembra" (Fania), moves at a sunny pace, and Mr. Blades repeated his improvisations from the album, adding new ones to it. The medium-tempo groove and Jimmy Bosch's roaring trombone solo made people feel good.
He dipped into later, more political work, including a song about El Salvador, "El Padre Antonio y el Monaguillo Andres," which he sang in a pop style. His material regularly changed rhythm. The harmonies, with their odd movements, underscored the words. By the time he had finished, with a review of his work covering nearly 30 years, Mr. Blades had positioned himself as a major cultural figure unlimited by idiom, language or nationality.
The concert had opened with a set by the percussionist Pancho Sanchez and his Latin jazz group. They played easygoing, smooth music that had a dreamy feel to it, almost out of focus. Then Mongo Santamaria showed up to play congas on one tune, and with his hard slap, lifted the music up. Mr. Sanchez picked up the shekere, and the music became taut and swinging. The audience loved it, giving Mr. Santamaria a standing ovation.

LENGTH: 1556 words

HEADLINE: THE COOKING SCHOOL REPORT;
France Or U.S.? Now It's A Hard Choice

BYLINE: By AMANDA HESSER 

 BODY:
IT used to be that if you wanted to become a chef, you were expected to go to cooking school in Paris. There you learned classic technique, the organization of the French kitchen and discipline under the critical eye of French instructors. Words like souffle, galantine and fricassee trickled into your vocabulary, a chef's knife became an extension of your hand.
And when you returned to the United States, you were practically guaranteed to land a job at a top restaurant.
But over the last decade, the culinary world has changed. Cuisines fused, and American kitchens were transformed from French food factories into dens of creativity. Restaurants began relying on local produce and a home-grown sensibility. And as they prospered, they created a new demand for chefs that a handful of schools abroad could not satisfy. Cooking schools have since sprouted all over this country -- there are now almost 800 -- and French cuisine is only part of the curriculum. 
 Today, when we go out to eat, the dishes we order more often reflect the values of schools like the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., or Johnson & Wales in Providence, R.I., than of any revered Paris institution. Consider the July issue of Food & Wine magazine, which hails the 10 new chefs it considers the best in the country: 7 were trained in the United States.
But nowhere is the break with the past clearer than in a comparison of the Culinary Institute, the most influential school in the United States, with its counterpart in France, Le Cordon Bleu in Paris.
Le Cordon Bleu has not wavered in its allegiance to French cooking -- choux pastry and beurre blanc are as much in its blood as ever, and its cuisine focus remains purely French.
The Culinary Institute teaches French technique, too, but it is more interested in introducing students to the world of cooking, the business of running a restaurant and even how to cope with it all, with classes like stress reduction and personal health.
The institute's campus is on a hill, high over the Hudson River in what was a Jesuit seminary before cooks wielding whisks descended upon it in 1972. Today, there is no mistaking you are at a cooking school. The names of the buildings read like advertisements for the food industry. The General Foods Nutrition Center houses one of the school's four restaurants, which are staffed by students and open to the public. The Conrad N. Hilton Library is filled with cookbooks and a sidewalk of the stars, lined with clay handprints and photos of chefs like Jeremiah Tower and Eric Ripert.
It also houses the Danny Kaye Theater (yes, the entertainer), which looks like a lecture hall, except that, instead of a podium, there is an up-to-the-minute demonstration kitchen, complete with overhead mirrors and television screens displaying close-ups of the stove and work area.
Starting at 7:30 A.M., the campus crawls with 2,100 students, knife cases in tote and toques bobbing. In 36 spacious teaching kitchens, the air is filled with the sounds of mixers whirring, knives tapping on cutting boards and the occasional roar of an instructor. Some students are fresh-faced, right out of high school, some are grayish, an unusual mix with an average starting age of 23. Yet there is a powerful feeling of solidarity: everyone is here to cook.
The 103-year-old Cordon Bleu looks a bit worn in comparison. It is squeezed into a narrow building in a quiet residential area of the Left Bank in Paris. The classrooms are less modern and smaller than the Culinary Institute's. But the atmosphere is more personal, with a student-to-instructor ratio of 10 to 1, compared with 17 to 1 at the Culinary Institute. There is no library and no restaurant, not even a school cafeteria.
But Le Cordon Bleu doesn't aspire to a campus environment. A temple is more like it, with students as worshipers who have made the pilgrimage to learn the secret of cooking and to take it back home.
"Let's face it," said Lindsay Gott, a student from San Francisco, "it's Paris, and the enthusiasm about food that's here, you feel it."
It is certainly something the Culinary Institute lacks. Tucked away in upstate New York, it suffers from the insularity of many campuses. Students have little exposure to restaurants. There is a wine club, an ice-carving club, even a cigar club, but few field trips to restaurants in New York City.
The institute applies a university philosophy to its curriculum, too. There are a 21-month program for an associate's degree and a 38-month program for a bachelor's degree. As cooking schools go, that is a lengthy commitment. (Le Cordon Bleu's program lasts nine months.) But students at the institute are earning a college degree -- an associate in occupational studies or a bachelor of professional studies -- approved by the State Board of Regents.
"Nowadays, just to be a great culinarian isn't enough," Tim Ryan, the school's senior vice president, said, "People need to have the business acumen, the business skills."
So bachelor's degree candidates must study cuisine and pastry, management, economics and psychology. "We do want to stress balance and healthier living, so people stay healthier, livelier and in touch with their creative forces," Mr. Ryan said.
Students also spend four weeks at the school's recently opened Greystone campus in St. Helena, Calif., visiting wineries, restaurants and farms.
The bachelor's program, a school spokesman said, is a response to the change in perception of chefs. In census polls of the 1970's, a chef was considered a domestic servant, not, as today, a professional.
In Paris, however, being a chef has a long tradition of respect. Le Cordon Bleu's three-semester program is designed for students to master one thing: French technique.
Students -- whose average age is 26 -- are first taught the fundamentals, from technique to palate education. The second semester focuses on French regional cooking, and the third refines skills and lets students unleash their creativity on classic dishes.
But they never learn how to run a restaurant. "We are only dealing with hands-on culinary training at the highest level," Andre J. Cointreau, president of the school, said. Many prefer this to learning how to fold napkins and calculate costs.
"I really care about cooking," said Frankie Carl, 45, a New Yorker in her final semester. "I don't care about the business side of it. I'd hire someone for that."
The Culinary Institute tries to keep up with the restaurant industry. In its baking kitchens are installed stone-deck ovens like those used in many bread bakeries, and the school has added instruction on slow-fermentation breads made with organic flours, a big departure from the hotel rolls taught at most cooking schools. (Le Cordon Bleu still uses a convection oven.) And in the St. Andrew's Cafe, the school's light-cuisine restaurant, students are taught to use a wood-fired pizza oven and rotisserie.
In the classrooms, though, students are merely introduced to emerging cuisines of the world. Students take an Asian cuisine course that lasts only seven days: three days for Chinese cooking, two days for Japanese, a day for Thai and one for Vietnamese.
At the Greystone campus, in the former Christian Brothers winery, the school offers continuing-education courses ranging from wedding cakes to food writing to "fire, spice and the global grill."
This is where Le Cordon Bleu suffers most in comparison. The French school sniffs at trends and ignores fads. Though it has added a wine course, cheese instruction and a few continuing-education courses, there have been no major shifts over recent years in the way it teaches classic technique. Patricia Gastaud Gallagher, the academic director, says the school is paying more attention to seasonal ingredients, but a class being taught in April was making lamb tart using tasteless winter tomatoes.
In some ways, Le Cordon Bleu seems frozen in time. A brochure showcases pulled-sugar works and fish en gelee. It is difficult to imagine such antiquities enticing anyone to become a chef.
Yet, the school has a waiting list and has opened a new outpost, in Australia, adding to those in London, Tokyo and Ottawa.
Le Cordon Bleu's greatest strengths are its site and its short program. Some students -- especially career-changers -- value how quickly one can earn a degree and the total immersion in the food culture of Paris.
The grand diplome in cuisine and pastry can be earned in 12 months, including a 3-month restaurant internship. And in that year, the student will come out with a thorough understanding of a cuisine. Not just any cuisine, but one whose techniques form the base of most Western cooking.
The Culinary Institute's approach -- introducing students to the world of cooking, rather than mastering it -- is both the school's edge and its fault. Students see what the culinary world has to offer, but it is merely a starting point, like any undergraduate program.
But if you are an aspiring chef that starting point will be a decisive influence on the shape of your career. You may no longer need to go to France to learn to cook, but if you want to serve foie gras dusted with five-spice powder in Los Angeles, New York and Tokyo, you may need to stay here to learn how to do it.
